DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Notice of Intention to Withdraw Notices of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 109a, I give notice that, at the giving of notices on the next day of sitting, I shall withdraw Business of the Senate, notices of motion Nos 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5, standing in my name for the next day of sitting for the disallowance of the Casino Control Ordinance 1988, as contained in Territory of Christmas Island Ordinance No. 4 of 1988, and certain Australian Capital Territory ordinances. I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances at its meeting this morning considered correspondence received from the Minister for the Arts and Territories, Hon. Clyde Holding, on several matters of concern to the Committee. The Minister responded to the issues raised by the Committee regarding the Territory of Christmas Island Casino Control Ordinance and provided advice and agreed to amendments to meet its concerns.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister also explained to the Committee's satisfaction the background to the Nurses Ordinance and undertook to amend the ordinance on other matters of concern to the Committee. The Minister also responded regarding the Noise Control Ordinance, providing an explanation and undertaking to amend the ordinance. The Minister also responded to the Committee's concerns regarding possible retrospectivity under the Rates and Land Tax (Amendment) Ordinance. The Committee accepted the Minister's explanation.

The Minister provided to the Committee copies of documentation relating to the Agents (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 2) and undertook to remove certain provisions from the Ordinance. The Committee thanks the Minister for his cooperation in these matters. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a brief description of the Committee's scrutiny and its correspondence, for the information of honourable senators and others.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
SUMMARY OF THE COMMITTEE'S SCRUTINY
CASINO CONTROL ORDINANCE 1988 BEING TERRITORY OF CHRISTMAS ISLAND ORDINANCE No. 4 OF 1988 AND MADE UNDER THE CHRISTMAS ISLAND ACT 1958
This Ordinance provides for the establishment of a casino on Christmas Island.

The Committee's concerns related to tabling, but not disallowance, of variations the original Agreement; review of decisions; qualifications of the Casino Controller and other persons; filling of vacancies on the Authority; powers of search (including personal search) by inspectors; disclosure of interests and delegation of powers and other matters.

The Minister explained that tabling of variations to the Agreement was to ensure disclosure, but did not consider commercial transactions should be subject to disallowance. The Minister clarified jurisdiction of the courts, and a reference to `the Court'.

The Minister undertook to amend the Ordinance to set minimum qualifications for the Casino Controller, Deputy and Inspectors, to make the filling of a vacancy on the Authority mandatory, to provide that searches be conducted only by persons with appropriate qualifications, and other matters.

The Committee noted the difficulties associated with implementing previous undertakings relating to the Australian Capital Territory Casino Control Ordinance 1988 and relevant to this Ordinance regarding review of decisions and the suitability test. The Committee accepts the Minister's explanation and undertaking to amend the Ordinance to require the Minister to grant approval if he or she is satisfied the applicants meet the relevant requirements.
The Committee thanks the Minister for his co-operation in these matters.
NOISE CONTROL ORDINANCE 1988 BEING AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY ORDINANCE No. 71 OF 1988 AND MADE UNDER THE SEAT OF GOVERNMENT (ADMINISTRATION) ACT 1910
This Ordinance provides for the control of noise in both residential and industrial settings.

The Committee's concerns related to the lack of mandatory requirements that instruments and procedures for measuring noise be included in a Noise Control Manual, the lack of certainty as to under which Ordinance identification cards for authorised persons were issued, and the lack of tabling in Parliament of Annual Reports.

The Minister agreed to mandatory inclusion of the instruments and procedures for measuring noise in the Manual and tabling of the Annual Report, and undertook to amend the Ordinance accordingly. The Minister explained the connection between the Air Pollution Ordinance 1984 and this Ordinance regarding the issue of identification cards to authorised persons. The Committee accepted the Minister's advice and undertakings.
The Committee thanks the Minister for his co-operation in these matters.
RATES AND LAND TAX (AMENDMENT) ORDINANCE 1988 BEING AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY ORDINANCE No. 63 OF 1988 AND MADE UNDER THE SEAT OF GOVERNMENT (ADMINISTRATION) ACT 1910
This Ordinance provides for triennial revaluations for rating and land tax purposes.
The Committee's concern related to possible retrospectivity in the imposition of either rates or land tax.

The Minister for the Arts and Territories, the Hon. Clyde Holding, M.P., explained the operation of the relevant sections. Rates may be retrospectively imposed where land was not valued or re-valued at the appropriate time, and while landowners may not know the value to be determined, the valuation would be in accord with the Ordinance with back-dated rates and land taxes being only for the period of ownership. There is a right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal where the valuation is disputed. The Committee accepts the Minister's advice and thanks him for his cooperation in this matter.
NURSES ORDINANCE 1988 BEING AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY ORDINANCE No. 61 OF 1988 AND MADE UNDER THE SEAT OF GOVERNMENT (ADMINISTRATION) ACT 1910
This Ordinance establishes a Nurses Board to supervise the administration, registration and enrolment of nurses.

The Committee's concerns related to the absence of the phrase ``without reasonable cause'' in particular provision, some omissions and apparent inconsistencies regarding review of decisions/applications for registration of categories of nurses/addresses for certificates and professional addresses in the Register.

The Minister for the Arts and Territories the Hon. Clyde Holding, M.P., agreed to amendment of the Ordinance to include the phrase ``without reasonable cause'', the address to which certificates are to be sent and other matters. The Committee accepted the Minister's explanations of the review provisions, the registration of existing infants nurses and non-inclusion of residential addresses in the Register.
The Committee thanks the Minister for his cooperation in these matters.
AGENTS (AMENDMENT) ORDINANCE (No. 2) 1988 BEING AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY ORDINANCE No. 47 OF 1988 AND MADE UNDER THE SEAT OF GOVERNMENT (ADMINISTRATION) ACT 1910
This Ordinance introduces a scheme for the licensing of travel agents.

The A.C.T. joins a Co-operative Scheme for the Uniform Regulation of Travel Agents with a Participation Agreement (the Agreement) and a Travel Compensation Trust Fund Deed (the Deed) to provide for the protection of people who deal with licensed travel agents.

The Committee's concerns related to the failure to provide copies of the Agreement and the Deed for perusal, whether the Agreement and the Deed form part of legislation, entry at any time by warrant, and tabling and disallowance of licence application forms.
The Minister for the Arts and Territories, the Hon. Clyde Holding, M.P., provided copies of the Agreement and the Deed.

The Committee accepted the Minister's advice not to include the Agreement and the Deed in the legislation, and noted the provision in the Agreement for a Ministerial Council to oversee the compensation scheme.
The Committee accepted the Minister's advice concerning the necessity for the warrant to authorise entry at any time.

The Committee was concerned that the licence application forms were not subject to tabling and disallowance. The Chairman informed the Minister that, in the Committee's view, and in line with precedents, forms were legislative in nature and should be prescribed by regulation; and sought re-consideration of the matter. The Minister undertook to remove certain paragraphs from the Ordinance in effect providing that applications need only to be in writing and signed by the applicant thereby obviating the need to prescribe licence application forms. The Committee accepts the Minister's undertaking and thanks him for his cooperation in these matters.

Dear Bob
I refer to my letter of 23 November concerning the Christmas Island Casino Control Ordinance, and I thank you for agreeing to defer the Senate's consideration of your motion of disallowance.

At item (k) of my letter I indicated it would not be appropriate to make decisions under sections 54, 59, 61 (4), 62 (4), 64 (4) or 65 (5) reviewable. For the record I am advised that the actual decision making powers to which the above sections relate are contained in sections 53, 59, 61 (1), 62 (1), 64 (1), and 65 (1).

I indicated that the Attorney-General's Department had raised some difficulties with the undertakings I had made previously to amend similar sections of the ACT Ordinance. If implemented those undertakings would result in the Minister being obliged to grant approvals unless he or she was satisfied that the applicant did not meet the required criteria.

The Attorney-General's Department has pointed out, correctly, I believe, that this would alter the suitability test from one of ``demonstrated to be suitable'' to ``not demonstrated to be unsuitable''. This would be a far lower, and clearly unsatisfactory test.

Applicants under the sections in question seek approvals to undertake significant functions with regard to the casino and should bear the onus of establishing their suitability. This is so because it is essential that the highest possible standards of integrity be maintained to avoid possible corruption or infiltration of the casino by organised crime.

However, I do agree that the Minister should not have a further discretion to refuse an approval once the relevant suitability criteria are satisfied, and accordingly, I propose to amend the Ordinance with regard to sections 53, 59, 61 (1), 62 (2), 64 (1) and 65 (1) to require the Minister to grant the approval if he or she is satisfied the relevant requirements are met. This would give effect to my previously expressed intention with regard to the ACT Ordinance, and make it easier for a refused applicant to apply for judicial review.
I trust that this proposal and those contained in my previous letter will resolve the concerns raised by the Committee.
Yours sincerely
Clyde Holding

Dear Bob
Thank you for your letter of 7 November 1988 concerning the Christmas Island Casino Control Ordinance 1988 (`C Ordinance').

Many of the points you raise were raised in the context of similar provisions in the ACT Casino Control Ordinance 1988. For most of these my response, below, is similar to my letter of 3 November on the ACT Ordinance. In some cases the Christmas Island situation requires different treatment.

Since my letter of 3 November, however, the Attorney-General's Department has raised with my Department difficulties in implementing some of the undertakings I made in the ACT case. Some of the points raised are relevant to the CI Ordinance also. The difficulties are described below. As they require more detailed examination by officers of the two Departments, I cannot give a final response on them now, either in the Christmas Island or the ACT context. I should be grateful therefore if you agreed to the postponement of the Senate's consideration of your motion of disallowance of the CI Ordinance, which I believe is due this week, until later in the sittings.
(a) `Agreement'

The `original Agreement' as defined in subsection 2 (1) of the CI Ordinance is an existing commercial agreement providing for the development of the Christmas Island resort and casino. It was therefore inappropriate to provide the same mechanisms as are provided in the ACT Ordinance relating to the ACT `Development Agreement'. The `original Agreement' was tabled in Parliament on 7 October 1987.

The `Agreement' as defined in subsection 2 (1) of the CI Ordinance refers to the `Original Agreement' as it might be after some future variation, and section 52 (as you have noted) provides that any variations would be tabled.

As set out in paragraph (d) of my response relating to the ACT Ordinance, the Government was concerned to ensure disclosure of as many aspects of these commercial transactions as possible and has therefore provided for tabling of variations of the Agreement.

However the reality is that the Government would be unable to conclude commercial transactions if they were subject to disallowance and for this reason the Government believes it is essential that these documents not be disallowable instruments.
(b) `the Court'

The appropriate jurisdiction for review of decision made under the CI Ordinance was the subject of careful consideration by both my Department and the Attorney-General's Department. It was concluded that given the geographic isolation of Christmas Island it would be expensive to confer jurisdiction on the AAT, which has no registry on the Island. It was agreed that the already existing Christmas Island Magistrate's Court could adequately exercise the review function.

With regard to section 27, while subsection 27 (1) confers jurisdiction on the Supreme Court, subsections 27 (2) and 27 (3) give the option of having the matter dealt with summarily in the Magistrate's Court if both prosecution and defence agree. If the parties choose the summary jurisdiction, the penalty applicable is lessened. See the definition of `the Court' in subsection 2 (1). I agree that use of `the Court' here is somewhat confusing and I will have subsections 27 (2) and (3) amended to clarify it.
(c) and (d) Qualifications of Casino Controller and Deputy, and Casino Surveillance Authority; Inspectors.
I will amend the Ordinance to set a minimum qualification for the Casino Controller, Deputy, and Inspectors.

With regard to qualifications for members of the Casino Surveillance Authority, the Committee will be aware of the geographic isolation of Christmas Island and the small size of the island community. These factors severely limit the choice of persons suitable and available for appointment to the Authority. The Government concluded it would be unrealistic to specify strict qualifications for Authority members in these circumstances.
I agree to amend the Ordinance to make the filling of a vacancy on the Authority mandatory, on the same conditions as will apply in the ACT.
I agree to amend paragraph 8 (2) (b) as requested, and to insert into section 9 a provision similar to subsection 104 (3) of the ACT Ordinance.

I have considered your comments concerning subsection 9 (7) and I agree that personal searches are a very serious matter. With regard to the appointment of inspectors of both sexes, in a community as small as Christmas Island there can be difficulty in appointing `sufficient inspectors of both sexes'. However subsection 9 (7) will be amended so that only persons with appropriate appointments will conduct searches. I had not envisaged that bystanders would be called on.
(e) Police entry
I will amend subsection 10 (1) to accord with subsection 106 (1) of the ACT Ordinance.
(f) Disclosure of interests and delegations of powers

The Government has not specified whether Authority members are to be `absentee' or `local', so that `absentee' members can be appointed whenever the smallness of the Christmas Island community makes this necessary. Nominees for appointment will be considered case by case and I expect that persons, `absentee' or `local', likely to have significant conflicts of interest would not be appointed.

With regard to section 44 delegations, it is usual for such a power to exist to ensure the functions can be efficiently performed. Whether the Authority members are `absentee' or `local', I would not expect this power of delegation to be exercised in such a way as to dilute the power of the Authority itself.
(g) Forgery and Forged Documents
The Committee is quite correct; subparagraph 46 (3) (b) (i) should read `remuneration or greater remuneration.'
(h) Lease of Project etc.

Subsection 63 (2) provides that in considering an application mentioned in subsection 63 (1) the Minister shall have regard to the matters specified in section 55. Subsection 55 (2) requires that the Minister should have regard to any recommendation made by the Authority. I believe this answers the Committee's concern.
(i) Cheques
I agree to amend the CI Ordinance along the lines agreed to in the ACT case.
(j) Restoration of Casino Employee's Service
I agree to insert a notification provision in subsection 105 (3).
(k) Appeals against Decisions
I do not believe it is appropriate to make decisions under sections 54, 59, 61 (4), 62 (4), 64 (4) or 65 (5) reviewable, as these decisions are essentially of a commercial and policy nature.

In paragraph (k) of my letter on the ACT Ordinance, I indicated that similar sections of the ACT Ordinance could be amended so that the Minister is required to grant the approval, etc. required unless the Minister is satisfied that the criteria specified for the approval are not met.

However, it has been pointed out that a decision under section 59, for example, of the CI Ordinance, to approve the assignment of the casino licence, must be made with regard to the criteria specified in subsection 55 (1). That subsection requires (in this case) that the Minister be `satisfied' of such things as the business reputation, sound character and business conduct, and freedom from unfavourable business associations of the proposed assignee. To provide that approval is to be given unless the Minister is satisfied that the criteria are not met, means that, in a case where the Minister was unable to conclude that he or she was satisfied that the applicant for approval did not meet the criterion of e.g. a reputation for (past) sound business conduct, but had been presented with evidence that equally ruled out a satisfaction that the assignee did meet the criterion, the Minister would be obliged to grant the approval.

I do not think this would be satisfactory. To prevent infiltration of the casino project by criminal interests, it is essential to insist that an applicant for approval to participate should bear the onus of establishing suitability. `Not unsuitable' is not a high enough standard to meet. As presently advised, therefore, I do not propose to extend my undertaking on the ACT Ordinance to these Christmas Island decisions. However, I have asked my officers to examine whether there is another way to accommodate your concerns, and I will be writing to you again on the matter.

An amendment along ACT lines is not appropriate for section 66 of the CI Ordinance, for different reasons. The power to terminate a contract under the section already depends on the Minister's considering that it is not in the public interest for the contract to remain in force, there having been either no response to the Minister's `show cause' notice, or a response which does not persuade the Minister to change his opinion.

No `decision' is made under paragraph 102 (2) (c). The paragraph simply refers to the Controller's decision to renew or refuse to renew a licence. This is made under subsection 99 (1), which extends to both the initial licence and renewals of the licence. Decisions under subsection 99 (1) are reviewable-see paragraph 112 (1) (n).
(l) Forms
I am prepared to give the same undertakings in relation to forms as I gave in relation to the ACT Ordinance.
Yours sincerely
Clyde Holding

Dear Minister,

At its meetings on 20 October 1988 and 3 November 1988 the Committee considered the Casino Control Ordinance 1988 contained in the Territory of Christmas Island Ordinance No. 4 of 1988. The Committee draws to your attention the following matters.
(a) ``Agreement''

The Ordinance merely contains definitions in s. 2 (1) of `'Agreement'' and ``the original Agreement'' and there are references in several sections to the ``agreement''. The A.C.T. Casino Control Ordinance, by contrast, sets out very fully provisions about the development and control agreements. In addition, there does not appear to be a provision for tabling the ``the original Agreement'' in Parliament, although s. 52 provides that a variation of ``the original Agreement'' is to be tabled. A further point is that although the variation is to be tabled Parliament does not seem to have power to do anything about it.
(b) The Court

Section 3 (1) defines ``the Court'' as the Magistrate's Court upon which are conferred rights that would normally be conferred on the mainland on the AAT. The Committee would be grateful for you advice on the reasons why this authority was conferred on the Magistrate's Court.

It is possible there may be a confusing provision in s. 27 (2) and (3) which also refer to ``the Court''. Section 27 (1) confers jurisdiction for an offence on the Supreme Court and, given that the heading to s. 27 refers to the Supreme Court, almost certainly Supreme Court is meant. The Committee considers it may be desirable to clarify this drafting point.
(c) Qualifications of Casino Controller and Deputy, and Casino Surveillance Authority.

Section 4 provides that the Minister may appoint a Casino Controller and a Deputy or Deputies. Similarly, s. 33 provides for the appointment of the Casino Surveillance Authority. Upon these persons devolves almost all the legal authority for ensuring that the casino is properly run. The Committee notes that while there is no direct counterpart to the Casino Controller in the A.C.T. Ordinance there is, of course, a Casino Surveillance Authority. The Committee further notes that in contrast to the very strict provisions in the A.C.T. Ordinance relating to the qualifications of authority members there are no qualifications at all provided for in the Christmas Island Ordinance. The Committee would appreciate your comments on this.

You will recall the comments made by the Committee in its letter of 3 November 1988 regarding the filling of vacancies in the A.C.T. Casino Surveillance Authority. You will also recall your undertaking to amend the A.C.T. Ordinance to make the appointment of another person mandatory, provided that the Minister may decide not to make that appointment if satisfied that it would be inappropriate to do so, having regard to the small length of the remainder of the appointment period. The Committee considers there should be a similar provision in the Christmas Island Ordinance, particularly as the Authority will only have 3 members instead of the 5 in the A.C.T.
(d) Inspectors

The question of the qualifications of Casino Controller noted above in (c) is compounded by s. 5 providing that the Casino Controller (and not the Minister as in s. 11 (1) of the A.C.T. Ordinance) appoint inspectors without any qualifying criteria to curb the discretion. The inspectors, in turn, have great responsibilities for ensuring the proper running of the Casino, including very substantial powers of search of premises and persons.

You will recall the comments made by the Committee in its letter of 3 November 1988 regarding the power of an inspector to give a direction orally. In response to these comments you undertook to amend the A.C.T. Ordinance to provide that an oral direction is only to be given where the inspector is satisfied that the circumstances amount to an emergency. The Committee believes there should be a similar amendment of s. 8 (2) (b).

In addition, the Committee is concerned that, although under s. 9 an inspector may only search with consent, the protection which is written into s. 104 (3) of the A.C.T. Ordinance that ``it shall be presumed that the person did not consent unless the contrary is established'' is missing from the Christmas Island Ordinance. The Committee believes this should be attended to.

Section 9 (7) requires searches by a person of the same sex, but if not available another person of the opposite sex can be asked. The Committee believes personal searches are very serious matters and asks whether it is envisaged that bystanders will be called in. The Committee would appreciate reasons why there are not sufficient properly appointed inspectors of both sexes.
(e) Police entry

Section 10 provides that a police officer may enter whereas s. 106 of the A.C.T. Ordinance restricts this to a sergeant or officer authorised by an officer of sergeant's rank or above. The Committee accepts that personnel may be scarce on Christmas Island but believes that the alternative of proper authorisation by a more senior officer could be used.
(f) Disclosure of interests and delegation of powers

Section 37 requires disclosure of interests, quite properly so in the opinion of the Committee. The Committee would, however, welcome your advice as to the operation in practice of this provision. In particular, the Committee would like to know whether the Authority members are to be ``absentee'' or ``local'' and, if local, whether such a small population would result in many ``direct or (especially) indirect pecuniary interest'' problems. The same difficulties arise with s. 44 delegations; if Authority members are ``absentees'' then this wide delegation power greatly dilutes the authority of the Authority.
(g) Forgery and Forged Documents.
The Committee asks whether the phrase ``to earn remuneration of greater remuneration'' is s. 46 (3) (b) (i) should be ``to earn remuneration or greater remuneration''.
(h) Lease of Project, or Casino and Casino Operation Agreement

Part VI deals with a lease of the project or Casino and the casino operation agreement or variations thereof and the suitability of persons. Under s. 63 (1) the Minister must have an investigation under s. 24 and the Committee asks whether the Authority should have a role in advising the Minister.
(i) Cheques

Section 83 (2) provides for the Minister to specify the period for presentation of cheques by notice in the Gazette. You will recall the Committee's concern with the similar provision in s. 80 (2) of the A.C.T. Ordinance and your undertaking to amend the Ordinance to provide for Parliamentary Control. The Committee considers that similar changes should be made to s. 83 (2).
(k) Appeals against decisions

Many decisions under the Ordinance may be appealed against but others may not. The non-appealable decisions are: s. 54 (refusal to grant a licence); s. 59 (assignment of the casino licence); s. 61 (4) (refusal to approve lease); s. 62 (4) (refusal to approve casino operation agreement); s. 64 (4) (refusal to approve variation); s. 65 (5) (refusal to approve prescribed contract or variation); s. 66 (termination of prescribed contract); and s. 102 (2) (c) (refusal of renewal of casino employee's licence). The Committee would welcome your advice on why these matters were not made subject to appeal. You will recall the Committee raised similar concerns with respect to appeal rights in the A.C.T. Ordinance.
(l) Forms

There are references in the Ordinance to forms which are to be approved but no mention is made of Parliamentary review. These are: s. 16 (1) (directions for exclusion from casino); s. 53 (2) (form of casino licence); s. 59 (2) (form for assignment of casino licence); s. 61 (2) (application for approval of project or casino); s. 62 (2) (application for approval of casino operation agreement); s. 65 (2) (application for approval of prescribed contract); s. 89 (1) (form of financial statement and accounts); s. 95 (1) (application for casino employee's licence); s. 99 (3) (form of casino employee's licence); s. 101 (1) (form of provisional employee's licence); s. 102 (2) (application for renewal of casino employee's licence); s. 103 (2) (application for renewal of casino employee's licence); and s. 107 (1) (b) (information on all casino employees). You will recall the Committee raised similar concerns in relation to the A.C.T. Ordinance and that you undertook to make all the forms subject to tabling and disallowance.
The Committee would welcome your advice and assistance in relation to the above matters.
Yours sincerely,

Dear Bob
I refer to your letter of 20 October 1988 concerning the Noise Control Ordinance 1988.

The Committee noted that, according to the Explanatory Statement, the Noise Control Manual is to contain information on the instruments and procedures used when measuring noise. However the Committee is concerned that subsection 17 (2) gives the Authority a discretion as to whether such matters are included in the Manual. I accept the Committee's view that it should be mandatory for instruments and procedures to be set out in the Manual and undertake to amend the Ordinance.
I also accept the Committee's view that Annual Reports should be required to be tabled in Parliament and undertake to amend section 49 of the Ordinance accordingly.

As to the Committee's query concerning the production of identification cards by the Authority or inspectors, I hope that the following information explains the operation of subsection 26 (2) of the Ordinance.

The Pollution Control Authority is a person appointed by the Minister under subsection 7 (1) of the Air Pollution Ordinance 1984. That person also has supervisory powers in relation to inspectors appointed under the Noise Control Ordinance. It is the Authority who appoints the inspectors and only the Authority can give directions to employers under the important Part III (Hearing Conservation) of the Ordinance.
Subsection 7 (4) of the Air Pollution Ordinance 1984 only deals with the identification card issued to the Authority and reads:
``The Minister shall issue to a person appointed under subsection (1) a certificate signed by the Minister to the effect that the person is the Pollution Control Authority''.

No inspectors are issued identification cards under subsection 7 (4) of the Air Pollution Ordinance. Dear Bob
I refer to your letter of 30 September 1988 about the Rates and Land Tax (Amendment) Ordinance 1988.
You have sought my advice as to whether new sections 15a and 22ea apply rates or land tax retrospectively.
New section 15a relates to land which has, for some reason or other, not been previously valued or revalued at the last general revaluation.
The section provides for the imposition of rates, or revised rates, for the period for which the land was unvalued or not re-valued.

The effect is that the owner of land can have rates retrospectively imposed on him or her. However, because this can only occur where the land is rateable and was not valued or re-valued at the appropriate time the land owner would always be aware that a valuation or revaluation would inevitably be carried out.

Accordingly, there is no retrospective change to a landowner's legal obligation to pay rates. Whilst the owner would not know the value that would eventually be determined he or she would know that a valuation would be determined in accordance with the Ordinance.

Care has been taken to ensure that a person is only charged such back-dated rates and land tax for the period during which he or she actually owned the land in question. There is also a right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in cases where the valuation is disputed.

Similar considerations apply to new section 22ea. It would only apply to land which had not been valued, or re-valued as required. Accordingly an owner should be aware that a revised assessment of land tax will be prepared. The appeal against a disputed unimproved value has the effect of allowing a review of the assessment of land tax.
I hope the above information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely

The Committee is concerned that in the equivalent provision relating to registered nurses, namely section 18 (5), the words ``without reasonable excuse'' do not appear. This phrase is an important protection of individual rights and the Committee believes that it should be inserted in section 18 (5) to ensure that registered nurses enjoy the same rights as enrolled nurses.

Dear Minister,

I refer to your letter of 8 November 1988 concerning aspects of the Agents (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 2) 1988, being A.C.T. Ordinance No. 47 of 1988 tabled in the Senate on 31 August 1988. The letter was considered by the Committee at its meeting on 24 November 1988.
The Committee is grateful for your helpful advice which meets its first two concerns.

The Committee believes, however, that the licence application forms in ss. 48 (1) (a) and 49 (1) (a) of the Principal Ordinance, as amended by ss. 26 (a) and 27 (a) should be prescribed under the regulations. The Committee notes your description of the forms as administrative, by which it is assumed you mean the forms are not legislative. Here, the Committee understands that under the amendments the use of the forms may be mandatory, and unless the forms are used the Board may not, and possibly legally cannot, consider or deal with an application. In these circumstances the Committee considers that the forms will be documents of considerable significance for the individual concerned.

The Committee also has difficulty with the forms being ``made available by the Board''. The Board in this case is the Agents Board of the Australian Capital Territory, a body characterised in your letter as independent. By this it is assumed you mean independent of Ministerial control. The Committee considers it undesirable that an independent body is to supply mandatory forms in connection with a compulsory scheme involving certain areas of personal and corporate livelihood. This is particularly so when the scheme provides what the Explanatory Statement calls ``strict penalties''.

Another important aspect is that of privacy. In the present case a Board with the characteristics described above require an individual or corporation, as a condition of practising a livelihood or carrying on a business, to furnish information by form. The Parliament is, apparently, neither to be made aware of such information nor to have power to do anything about it. The Committee is concerned that the type of information to be requested from individuals may be such that the Board does not wish it to be subject to disallowance.

The Committee notes the statement in your letter that it is ensured the forms will not be intrusive because of the independence of the Board (from the Minister? from the Secretary of the Department? from the Parliament?) and because it is composed of one public servant, one lawyer, two real estate agents, two travel agents and a consumer representative. The Committee believes, however, that prescription of the forms by regulation is appropriate and that the structure and composition of the Board are arguments in favour of, not against, Parliamentary tabling and disallowance.

The Committee notes there are ample recent precedents for forms to be prescribed in A.C.T. Regulations. The Credit Regulations, Regulations 1985 No. 5 for example, prescribe eleven forms covering sixteen pages, with additional provisions relating to the completion of the forms. These Regulations were amended twice in 1986 in respect of the forms (Regulations 1986 Nos. 17 and 19), once to include an additional form and once to substitute an existing form. The Co-operative Societies Regulations (Amendment), Regulations 1985 No. 8 amended its Form C. The Liquor Regulations Form 9 was amended in 1986 (Regulations 1986 No. 20), as were Public Health (Dairy) Regulations, Regulations 1986 No. 28, Forms 1, 2, 3 and 4. Form 7 of the Liquor Regulations was amended in 1987 (Regulations 1987 No. 8) and Forms A and B of the Meat Regulations in 1988 (Regulations 1988 No. 4).
All these new and amended forms were subject to tabling and disallowance.

In addition, there are parts of Schedules to A.C.T. Regulations which are in fact forms although not so called; see for example Schedule 1 to the Gaming Machine Regulations, Regulations 1987 No. 7, which refers to the mandatory use of ``the following form'' and the separate mandatory ``following form of declaration''. These are also subject to tabling and disallowance.

You will also recall your helpful offer to amend the Casino Control Ordinances of the A.C.T. (No. 72 of 1988) and Christmas Island (No. 4 of 1988) to provide for forms to be subject to tabling and disallowance by way of regulation, and the acceptance by the Committee so far of your offer for the A.C.T. Ordinance. Your statement is noted that your consent in the case of the A.C.T. Casino Control Ordinance is not to be taken as a general precedent that forms should be made as legislative instruments and that such a decision would depend on the circumstances of each case. The Committee believes, however, that in the present situation there is a stronger argument on personal rights and liberties and privacy grounds for the forms being prescribed than in most of the other many examples where this is done. Simply by way of example, I refer you to the Noise Control Regulations, Regulations 1988 No. 18, made on 1 November 1988.
The Committee would appreciate your early advice on this important matter.
Yours sincerely,

Dear Bob

I refer to your letter of 1 September 1988 to the former Minister the Hon. Gary Punch MP, concerning the Agents (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 2) 1988 (the Ordinance) in which you seek advice in relation to three matters.

Firstly the Committee points out that in its examination of the Ordinance it was not able to cite the documents involved. By this I take the Committee to be referring to the Participation Agreement and the Travel Compensation Fund Trust Deed. To assist the Committee I have attached a copy of the Trust Deed and the Participation Agreement.

The Committee sought advice as to whether the Trust Deed or the Participation Agreement forms part of the legislation of participating states. None of the States have incorporated the Agreement in their legislation as it is preparatory to the enactment of the legislation and dictates the form that the legislation is to take. Further, its inclusion may involve unnecessary and confusing duplication of provisions.

The States of New South Wales, South Australia and Western Australia have included the Deed in their Regulations. In Victoria the Minister has power to declare by notice in the Gazette a scheme to be an approved compensation scheme for the purposes of the Act.

To prescribe the Deed under the regulations or to include it in a schedule to the Ordinance would unnecessarily complicate the amendment procedure for the Deed. The Deed will be an evolving document and I am of the opinion that the amendment procedures to effect a change should be as flexible as possible to ensure that where there is a requirement to amend the Deed members of the community and registered travel agents will not be disadvantaged because of inherent delays in processing an amendment to the legislation. It is worth noting that the Participation Agreement established a Ministerial Council to oversight the compensation scheme and this will include the Trust Deed. Given the involvement of the Ministerial Council, the ACT Administration and the Agent's Board I am confident there will be ample supervision of the Trust Deed to protect the public while maintaining sufficient administrative flexibility to ensure the efficient operation of the scheme. The Deed is held at the office of the Registrar of Agents and will be available to the public.

Secondly the Committee expresses concern that paragraph 71l (3) (c) provides that a warrant may authorise entry at any time of the day or night, where it does not specify particular hours. As some unlicensed agents operate on a part-time basis and outside normal office hours it is important for the Ordinance to authorise entry at times appropriate to those unusual operations. In addition, the Attorney-General's Department advises that the paragraph is consistent with similar provisions, such as paragraph 235 (3) (b) of the Credit Ordinance 1985.

Thirdly the Committee seeks advice as to whether the licence application forms as provided for in paragraphs 26 (a) and 27 (a) are to be prescribed under the regulations. The forms are of an administrative nature and as such it is undesirable to prescribe them. It may be necessary from time to time to amend the application forms to reflect the requirements of the Agent's Board or those of the industry. I consider that the structure and independence of the Board will ensure that the forms used will not be intrusive and will only require essential information necessary for the Board's deliberations. Presently the Board consists of a representative from the ACT Administration, a Barrister and Solicitor, two real estate agents and a community consumer representative. Following the expansion of the Board by the Ordinance from five to seven members it is intended, on the participation in the scheme by the ACT, to appoint two travel agents to the Board.
I trust that the foregoing is of assistance to the Committee.
Yours sincerely

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Harradine moving that the General Business Notice of Motion No. 232 standing in the name of Senator Peter Baume, relating to World Aids Day, be called on forthwith and have precedence over all other business until determined.

Yesterday a notice of motion was placed before the Senate by Senator Peter Baume. Today is World AIDS Day. It is important that the Senate debate this motion. We should ensure that time is made available today for complete consideration and debate of this question. It would be treating this matter with ill-considered haste if the motion were to be called formal. To pass this motion as a mere formality in this chamber, without giving the chamber the opportunity to consider and debate the matter fully, would be doing it an injustice. There is a need to get this question right.

TALK.START.PARA: —That can't happen. I don't sustain that. You only had to call `not formal' to ensure that that did not occur.

—This is an important matter. It needs to be discussed and debated today. That is why I am moving my motion. It is necessary that this be done, not only because of the importance of the matter but also so that we, as members of this chamber, members of parliament, get this situation right. It would not be appropriate for the Senate to pass Senator Baume's motion unless the opportunity had been given to Senator Baume and other honourable senators to consider what policies will minimise the impact of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection and acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The other parts of the motion express sympathy to the families and friends of the more than 500 Australians who have died already from AIDS. It is important for this motion to be fully debated so that we can place on record the fact that there is a fundamental premise, which is that we should treat persons with the AIDS virus with unconditional care and consideration. We should not be judgmental, in the sense that no-one can judge the interior disposition of another. It is important that we have this opportunity of debating this issue so that we are able to identify the high risk activity and to ensure that future generations do not act in a way that would only spread this disease.

I believe it is important for this debate to take place. I do not consider that policies which treat homosexuality as another valid lifestyle, particularly if this is being taught in schools, are appropriate. Some people believe that and may say, if the motion is passed, `Well, the Senate has supported policies which minimise the impact of HIV infection'. I do not consider that to be the case at all. I do not consider that a policy which virtually says, `You can do what you like, when you like, how you like, with whom you like, provided you use a condom', is going to minimise the impact of HIV infection. I do not believe that the promotion of abortion of babies of HIV-infected women is a proper way to minimise the impact of HIV infection.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, I remind you that you have moved for the suspension of Standing Orders. You are beginning to debate the substantial matters in the notice of motion. I ask you to come back to the point-that is, that Standing Orders be suspended.

—Thank you, Mr President. I am attempting to indicate the importance that honourable senators should attach to this motion and the need to know precisely what the motion means. I am saying this quite seriously today, because, unless we know precisely what this motion means, it may be used as justification by the Government, or anybody else, to promote policies which would, in the long term, create a climate for the dramatic spread of AIDS in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are to discuss this motion, it ought to be discussed now and it ought to be given priority on this day. That is a major consideration, because 1,100 persons in Australia have been diagnosed as having AIDS, and nearly half of those people have died. So it is an important matter. It should not simply pass without comment. Time needs to be allowed, at this first stage of our proceedings today, for a full discussion to take place on this question. The final reason why I believe it ought to be discussed today is that this will be the only occasion that the Senate will have to discuss this question prior to the date on which responses to the Government's discussion paper close.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This proposal by Senator Harradine is entirely a straw man. He has put it up to knock it over. I presented the notice of motion yesterday, and it would have been my wish that it could have been called on as formal today in the Senate. But I have no desire to override the procedures or rights of other senators. I did not seek to have the motion declared formal because Senator Harradine had told me himself that he would not agree to such a procedure. TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Macklin and I remind honourable senators that we are debating a motion for the suspension of Standing Orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope to be very brief. Since this matter has been raised in the Senate this morning, I would not wish the remarks which have been made by Senator Peter Baume necessarily to be taken to express the total view of everyone on the Opposition side of the chamber in relation to his notice of motion. I would not myself have raised the matters that have been raised by Senator Harradine because it was my understanding that this notice of motion would not be declared formal and, therefore, the matter would not arise. But since Senator Harradine has raised it by his motion to suspend Standing Orders, may I simply say that, notwithstanding the obviously very close and careful consideration which has been given by the drafters of the motion to producing a motion which purports to be in totally unexceptionable language, had the matter come before the Senate at least paragraph (f) of the motion would have raised considerable doubts in my mind because of its ambiguity-I have to say deliberate ambiguity-as to what the policies in question are or might be which are referred to in that paragraph. I simply say that I am not going to support Senator Harradine's motion to suspend Standing Orders, but I would not wish by my silence to have my position on the motion itself misunderstood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two issues running here. The first is whether we should pass Senator Peter Baume's motion today. Had it come on I would have wholeheartedly voted for it and I believe that probably 80 per cent of this chamber would have given it support. The other issue is Government business. We had a debate on the Green Paper on acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) some time ago in this chamber. We are now facing a situation in which the Appropriation Bills need to be passed. It is not as though on this occasion in this session the Government did not have legislation for this chamber to consider. We have had legislation from day one. There have been no delays as there have been in the past. We have had an immense amount of legislation to consider. In the first two weeks of the session we had seven matters of public importance on the Constitution. For the first seven weeks of sitting less than 30 per cent of this chamber's time has been devoted to legislation. We have had numerous disallowance motions and other things. I have not taken a grumpy attitude to this. I have just said to myself, `Well, the Senate rolls along as it always rolls along'. However, it is appropriate that we pass the Appropriation Bills today and it is inappropriate to take up a large part of the debating time today for any reason--
—Have I ever been an offender in the other respects?

—Well you are committing a big offence today, Senator. Senator Harradine has been here since 1975 and he knows that once a debate such as this starts it could well go through until 8 o'clock or 9 o'clock tonight. We have seen that happen before. We have seen a three-minute report on the Parliament House Construction Authority blow out to two hours. One Wednesday we spent 47 minutes on notices of motion. This place becomes an anarchistic swamp in which time is totally wasted.

SPEECH.PARA: Our rejection of the motion to suspend Standing Orders today should not and cannot be taken as a lack of concern for AIDS victims. I was very tempted to move an amendment which supported the motion but added to it the words `at 10.30 p.m. this day', in order to test people's sincerity and see who wanted to stay here until 3 o'clock or 4 o'clock in the morning debating these issues. We must get the Appropriation Bills through today. It is not a scare tactic to say that next week a lot of people will not be paid. Already one group of public servants-those who take cash-will have their pay delayed, so we need to get those Bills through today. We probably have three or four hours debate left on the Appropriation Bills. I assure those few people who read Hansard that the rejection by the Government of the motion to suspend Standing Orders is not a lack of concern for the motion supported by Senator Peter Baume. I say on behalf of all Government senators that that motion would have received our enthusiastic support. I congratulate Senator Baume on his motion, but point out regretfully that we cannot sit here debating this matter this morning, given our other priorities.
Question resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill's genesis is a request from the South Australian Government that the National Crime Authority Act 1984 be amended to enable the appointment of additional members to the National Crime Authority for specific investigations. The South Australian Government has indicated that such an amendment would allow the appointment of an additional member to undertake a proposed South Australian reference to the National Crime Authority in relation to allegations of criminal activity and corruption in South Australia. Further, the South Australian Government has formally agreed to fund the establishment of a National Crime Authority office in that State.

The National Crime Authority is a highly skilled body working in the most complex areas of organised crime. It is a relatively small body which has demonstrated an ability to investigate across the broad spectrum of criminal activity.

The Authority was established, in part, as a viable alternative to the then growing proliferation of Royal Commission-type inquiries which were undertaking investigations into a variety of subjects, and in particular various aspects of organised criminal activity. The Authority's independence, coercive powers, knowledge and expertise in the fight against organised crime together with its focus on the gathering of admissible evidence make it the best alternative to deal with allegations of criminal activity and corruption of the kind being made in South Australia. The South Australian Government has already had the benefit of a Report from the National Crime Authority on certain South Australian investigations during 1986 and 1987 so that the Authority has a knowledge of the South Australian criminal environment.

The Inter-Governmental Committee has approved a South Australian reference pursuant to section 14 of the National Crime Authority Act. The Inter-Governmental Committee also considered this Bill and supports the Commonwealth introduction of this Bill.

It is against this background that this Bill amends the National Crime Authority Act to allow the Inter-Governmental Committee, which consists of the Commonwealth Minister and a Minister from each participating State, to create additional offices of member of the National Crime Authority in relation to a specific Commonwealth or State reference. These additional offices can only be created where a reference to the Authority has been made and the Inter-Governmental Committee, having regard to that reference and any related references, thinks that the appointment of an additional member of the Authority is necessary to enable the Authority to perform its functions. For example, where the Inter-Governmental Committee concludes that a reference requires that the member undertaking it have special skills or expertise or that the Chairman's and 2 members' resources are fully utilised, then it can create an additional office of member to conduct that reference. These amendments will provide the Inter-Governmental Committee with the power to increase the number of members of the Authority to enable the Authority to deal with additional matters warranting referral to the Authority without impeding the Authority's current activities.

The Bill provides that the additional member will be appointed to undertake a particular reference and any related references nominated by the relevant Commonwealth or State Minister. For example, where an additional member is appointed to undertake a South Australian reference and the criminals involved in South Australia also operate or have connections in Victoria, the Victorian Minister may state that a resultant Victorian reference is related to the South Australian reference. The additional member would then undertake both the South Australian reference and the related Victorian reference.

It will be the function of the Inter-Governmental Committee to unanimously recommend a person for appointment to an additional office of member and any advice to the Governor-General with respect to the appointment is required to be consistent with the recommendation under proposed new subsection 7 (8AB).

An underlying premise of the Bill is that the facility to appoint additional members will be used for dealing with additional Commonwealth or State references and will allow the number of members of the Authority to fluctuate in response to the number, nature and status of the references made to it.

The powers and functions of the additional member are limited to the original reference or any related references. The Bill provides that an additional member ceases to hold office upon the withdrawal of the original reference in relation to that member or the completion of the original reference or any related references. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.
