SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Select Committee on Legislation Procedures.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement concerning the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The Senate appointed the Committee on 25 August 1988 to inquire into and report upon a number of matters relating to the referral of Bills to committees and changes to Senate procedures to facilitate the referral of Bills and the expediting of Senate consideration of Bills. The Committee considered its task to be one of recommending specific and practical proposals to achieve the aims of more thorough examination of legislation and more efficient processing of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee notes in the report that there has been a general view among senators for some years that the referral of more Bills to committees would improve the legislative process and allow more effective examination of legislation. The Committee has made a number of specific recommendations, including a recommendation that more Bills than at present be referred to committees. Each recommendation is accompanied by a specific alteration to the procedures of the Senate to give effect to the recommendation. The Committee recommends that these changes to procedures be adopted by the Senate. The proposals of the Committee include a number of measures to expedite proceedings in the Senate and thereby save time which may be devoted to consideration of Bills by committees.

At its first meeting the Committee authorised its members to confer freely with other senators concerning proposals before the Committee. The members of the Committee, particularly the three party Whips, then engaged in a consultative process to receive ideas from senators and to test the reaction of senators to various proposals. The aim of this process was to ensure that the Committee made sound and practical recommendations which were likely to attract considerable support from senators.

The Committee considers that its proposals do not involve a radical change in how the Senate operates but only a shift of the allocation of time spent on legislation from the Senate itself to committees. The proposals have been carefully framed so as to appropriately preserve the rights of individual senators and of the majority of the Senate.

I have been asked to indicate that some members of the Committee reserve their final position in relation to some of the recommendations, and may not necessarily support specific recommendations when they are finally dealt with by the Senate. Those senators have supported the inclusion of these recommendations because they consider they are worthy of consideration by the Senate.

I wish to thank my fellow members of the Committee for their diligent work. On behalf of the Committee I also thank the Clerk of the Senate, Mr Harry Evans, and Mr Neil Bessell, of the Senate Committee Office, for their invaluable assistance.
Motion (by Senator Colston)-by leave-agreed to:

That consideration of the report be an order of the day for the first day of sitting in 1989, that the order of the day be listed on the Notice Paper as Business of the Senate and continue to be so listed until finally determined.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 30 November.
GROUP E
Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs
Proposed expenditure-$210,576,000-agreed to.
Department of Administrative Services
Proposed expenditure, $1,362,935,000

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid I might take a little time on this proposed expenditure. However, I take note of the very important point made before by the Minister for the Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) about the need to pass the Appropriation Bills today. There are certain outstanding matters concerning the Department of Administrative Services and others still to be considered which cannot properly pass without comment in this important committee stage of the debate. The first issue I want to raise under the Department of Administrative Services relates to the National Media Liaison Service (NMLS). We had discussions on that matter in Senate Estimates Committee E.
—On `animals'.

—As my colleague has just said, the accepted definition of NMLS is animals. From the Opposition's point of view I have to say that the animals are doing a good propaganda job on behalf of this Government. That is the point I want to take up because what we have seen in the operation of the National Media Liaison Service is nothing short of a deliberate misuse of public money for the purposes of a political party as distinct from the government of the day. That ought to be a matter of considerable concern to this Parliament and certainly to the taxpayers of Australia, because we are talking about an organisation with a budget exceeding $1m.

SPEECH.PARA: Many questions were asked about this matter in the Estimates Committee. I have received answers to some of the many questions Senator Michael Baume and I and others raised, but there are numerous questions to which I have not yet received replies in relation to NMLS. I am concerned that we will have to go through and pass the appropriations for this Department without appropriate replies having been received to all the questions that I have asked. I would like to know why this has occurred, whether it has been a deliberate action or an oversight. It is a matter of concern. I do not think we can get away with it by saying that Administrative Services wants to give all the answers in one hit. After all, we have got some of the answers already in relation to other aspects of administrative services so why do we not have answers relating to NMLS?

We heard in the Estimates Committee that this Labor Government is, in the Minister's eyes, blameless in its operation of NMLS or certainly no worse or different from predecessor governments, in particular the Fraser Government. We were told that the Fraser Government had a similar operation which operated under guidelines which were more politically colourful than the existing one. One might reasonably ask: What is the Opposition's concern? Why should Australian taxpayers be concerned about it?

There are several points that ought to be made that have not been appropriately and properly made about the operations of the NMLS and the way in which it has differed from the operations of previous liaison units under other governments, particularly the Fraser Government. There is no doubt that the NMLS under this Government has stepped up its political operations. This has been done at the deliberate direction of the Government. One has only to talk to the people in the press gallery in this building to know that the NMLS is a very powerful political propaganda unit. It is not a unit which is operating simply to disseminate the information of government. To pretend that it is acting in that way is to try to fool the Australian people.

The second point that I think needs to be brought out is that the figures that have been provided, including during the Senate Estimate Committee hearings, on the costs and the numbers involved in this propaganda unit are questionable because the NMLS is in addition to individual press secretaries for Ministers. We are still awaiting answers to relevant questions as to the number of additional staff involved in those activities. Why have those questions not been answered? Surely it would be simple to find the answers.

The next point that the Committee ought to be aware of is that the salaries for the NMLS are not included under a specific NMLS vote; the salaries are hidden in other parts of the accounts. I asked the Government; it was raised in the Estimates Committee. I do not believe we got anything like a satisfactory reply. I ask the Minister again: Why is there not a specific allocation that can be more clearly identified? In particular, by putting the salary of the Director of the NMLS under a different vote and giving him another hat, the Government is deliberately circumventing its own guidelines in terms of the operations of the unit. The Director of the NMLS spent most of his time-this was admitted during Estimates hearings-during the last election campaign at the Australian Labor Party's (ALP) campaign headquarters. As I said, the Government has admitted that. Surely nobody expects us to believe that in that capacity he was promoting Government policy; of course he was not. His activities at the ALP campaign headquarters during the last election were overtly partisan. They had nothing to do with the promotion of Government programs; they had everything to do with getting the ALP elected-with taxpayers' funds paying the salaries of those people. The NMLS has a staff of 21 spread around Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is 22 now.

—It has been increased to 22. It has a total budget in excess of $1m. To supervise that operation should take a very large chunk of the Director's time. To say, as one of the officials at the Senate Estimates committee said, that the Director is primarily the director of the ministerial media group is a laugh. The NMLS has a turnover greater than most small businesses in Australia. If the Director is taking his job seriously of course he would have to be directing a large chunk of his time towards those activities. So I say to the Committee that the operation of the NMLS, and in particular the way in which the Director's salary is accounted for, is simply a device to circumvent the Government's own guidelines. Until we receive further answers to the questions that have been put, the full extent of the Government's usage of taxpayers' funds for overtly political purposes vis-a-vis the NMLS cannot be known.

SPEECH.PARA: I reject completely the statements that have been made by the Government that it really has just been continuing what the Fraser Government put in place. No previous government has used a media liaison group, by whatever title, in the way in which the Hawke Government has. There is no doubt that it represents a deliberate misuse of public money. In effect, what we are seeing with the NMLS is a deliberate diversion of taxpayers' money into the coffers of the Labor Party's propaganda machine. I hope that at the next Senate Estimates hearings, for the Supplementary Estimates, we will be able to have a much more objective and frank disclosure of the activities of that Service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Time and time again this morning Senator Short has said that the National Media Liaison Service (NMLS) is involved in political activities, that this is bad and that it should not be involved in political activities, that this is bad and that it should not be involved in active politics. Maybe only once did he allude to any possible involvement in politics. So apparently if one comes in here and expresses a generality often enough, what one says will be accepted as the truth.
—I will provide it.

—Good, we will hear from Senator Baume in a moment. Let me go to the question of Mr Parks's role in the last election. As I have said, Mr Parks holds two positions. He is head of the ministerial press pool and head of NMLS. Quite clearly he worked as head of the ministerial press pool, as a normal ministerial staffer, during the last election.

SPEECH.PARA: Is Senator Short telling me that in the last election all of Mr Howard's staff went on holidays? Is he telling me that Mr Howard's staff did nothing political in the election period? If he is telling me that, I now start to understand what the problem is on the honourable senator's side. I now understand that Mr Howard probably had to fight the last election not only without the support of his colleagues but also, apparently, without the support of any of his staff. Of course ministerial staff--

TALK.START.PARA: —We are talking about the NMLS.

—The NMLS members of staff are employed under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act. I made very clear at the Estimates Committee that they work for the Government. As is the case with any other ministerial staffer, it is their job to work for the Government. Until a few months ago they were nominally on my staff. I would expect them to normally do their duty.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short has not referred today to the guidelines that I signed on, I think, 23 September 1987. He knows that these guidelines exist because I tabled them during the hearings of the Estimates Committee. Those guidelines direct staff not to engage in partisan political activity. If they do, they will be disciplined.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are waiting for it.
—You are deliberately circumventing those guidelines.

—I am waiting for Senator Baume to give his example. Senator Baume did not bring up any direct examples at the Estimates Committee hearings. If examples are brought up, we will examine them. I will not accept them on face value because I have learned not to accept things on face value from those opposite. Let me give the Committee an example of that. Senator Short said today that numerous questions have not been answered. I would like Senator Short to detail the questions that have not been answered. Six questions within my ministerial responsibility covering Immigration and Administrative Services are yet to be answered. Senator Short is awaiting three replies. The first is in respect of a question asked on page 114 of the Estimates Committee Hansard regarding the names, salaries and location of NMLS members since its creation. On page 117 Senator Short asked a question about salaries and administrative costs. Finally, on page 125, Senator Short asked a question on notice which does not relate to animals at all but concerns ministerial consultants. It is always possible that in our search of the Hansard we have overlooked what Senator Short regards as questions on notice. But one could hardly say that numerous questions have not been answered.
—Some arrived 10 minutes ago.
—We will have to sort that out. As I say, I understand that at the moment there are six outstanding questions.
—There should not be any outstanding questions when we come to examine these matters.

—Senator Short says that there should be no outstanding questions, but one of the questions asks us to compare five years of Labor Government with the Fraser years. So we are looking at a period of 13 years of comparative costs. This will probably involve getting records back from archives to be researched in order to give the honourable senator an answer. This will involve immense cost. Questions of this sort take some time to answer. But Senator Short cannot accuse me of allowing a lot of questions asked at Estimates Committees to be unanswered. I always get on the back of the department concerned. Where it is possible to provide answers, they are provided.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, we hear all of this nonsense from those opposite about there being a massive propaganda machine for the Australian Labor Party. The job of the NMLS is to collate, monitor and disseminate information in support of Government programs. As I said, the memo that I signed last year contained a specific direction not to get involved in partisan politics. Senator Short has not raised some of the other answers he received to his questions. For instance, he asked how many officers travelled to Melbourne in the August-September period. The inference is that they all go down on a free ticket to see the football grand final. How many of the animals staff went to New South Wales during the period of the New South Wales election? Senator Baume has not referred to that. The answer is none. Why does Senator Baume not refer to a lot of the answers where he was clean bowled?

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be, because the answers are crooked.

—That is Senator Baume's assertion. Let me clear up the distinction between what the Hawke Government has done and what the good old Fraser Government did. I am glad that at least the Opposition no longer suffers from political amnesia and is willing to acknowledge that Malcolm Fraser exists.
—We have never denied it. That is a phoney remark.
—A lot of Opposition members have ducked for cover when Fraser's name has been mentioned, as though he never existed, as though the whole era had disappeared out of their memories.
—Of course it existed, but it was honest then.

—Honest! Let us have a look at the media guide published by the Liberal Secretariat. It advises people to go to the Government Information Unit for assistance. How does a coalition member get his information, and who does he use? He uses the Government Information Unit-as a candidate, not as a member of parliament. Of course he does. Let us look at the memo of 1978 which talks about the liaison officers the then Government was appointing. The problem was that those in the States were `unusually susceptible to anti-Canberra stories', so it wanted to appoint liaison officers in the Government Information Unit. Their role-the memo says `his' role, but we have gone a long way in 10 years-was `to report regularly on significant State issues which have or could have relevance to the Government, to disseminate effectively government information in his State'. On it goes talking about his role `to liaise and communicate with Ministers'. The final point was `to maintain close contact with party officials in the States keeping them fully informed of developments on the Federal scene'.

SPEECH.PARA: There is very little difference between the Government Information Unit and the National Media Liaison Service. There has been very little difference in the criticism of both-when we were in opposition and now that the coalition is in opposition. I bet Senator Short and Senator Michael Baume anything they like that, if they win the next election or the one after, they will also have a unit working in Parliament House disseminating government policies. Of course they will. It will be part of a Minister's staff. It will not be part of the Public Service, in exactly the same way as the NMLS is not part of the Public Service. All we are hearing is bleating from the Opposition-all to do with excuse-making: `Why can we not win elections? It is all to do with the Government's propaganda machine, it is all to do with the crook electoral system. It is all to do with this or that, et cetera'. They are whinges of opposition. I have been through it all. I know what it is about. The reality is that the Opposition should look elsewhere for its failings, and not try to blame some sort of conspiracy theory. It is very sad when oppositions fall prey to paranoia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us pin this crooked `animals'-the National Media Liaison Service (NMLS)-propaganda machine and let us pin the crooked defences being made of it. It is incredible that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) can get up in this place and say with a straight face that there is very little difference between the propaganda machine of the present Government and the information service provided by the previous Government. It is not just the Opposition that is making these sorts of claims of propaganda. I refer the Minister to a feature in the Weekend Australian of last Saturday. In a large full page article Errol Simper says that the National Media Liaison Service:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . according to many journalists and the Federal Opposition, are engaged in an unadulterated propaganda exercise designed to keep Labor in power.
The article goes on to quote a Mr Juddery, long associated with the Canberra Times.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was that?
—Mr Bruce Juddery. Mr Juddery is quoted in the article as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: There would seem to be a big difference between what exists now and what existed under the Fraser government, and what the organisation was when it was started by the Whitlam government as the Australian Government Liaison Service in the early 79s. That service had a far greater claim to impartiality.
It, at least, put up some pretence of putting out a straightforward, relatively impartial record of what the Government was doing.
The article goes on to say:
There are those who have worked for the liaison service who say it did a scrupulous job of being impartial in 1983 under the former special minister for State, Mr Mick Young.
They say it was later, when it came under the direction of Mr Colin Parks -
with his famous two hats-
and the former minister for sport and tourism, Mr John Brown, that the service took on a sharper political focus.
Mr Parks is then quoted in the article as saying:
The service did become a lot more active after I took over.

I am putting to the Minister that it is not simply an Opposition plot to describe this service as such. Journalists are quoted in this article as saying exactly the same thing, and its director is effectively conceding a change, certainly in style and emphasis, after he took it over to make it more active-and clearly more politically active.

Let us consider the absolute nonsense this Minister was prepared to come out with today. I have a high regard for this Minister in normal circumstances. It is only in this situation-where he knows that he has an impossible case to defend, where he is defending the indefensible, defending a propaganda machine which he knows is acknowledged by journalists themselves to be a propaganda machine-that this Minister comes in and embarrasses himself by making the extraordinary remark that there is very little difference between the information services of the present Labor Government and the previous Liberal Government.

We have already heard comments by journalists, but let us consider the detail of the facts. In the Estimates Committee hearings this Minister had the effrontery to say that even in numerical terms there was very little difference between the two services. He came out with some incredibly phoney statistics. As a result, I asked him specifically for an honest comparison between the public relations and press officer activities of the Fraser Government and of his Government. Ten minutes ago I received the answer. I received it fortuitously before this debate began because I just happened to go back to my office to pick up some papers. This debate could well have gone on without my knowing the answer existed. Senator Short, who stayed in the chamber, did not receive these replies and made his contribution without the knowledge that they existed. I hope that that may well prompt Senator Short to have another go.

The information revealed in response to my question, the real comparison of how many staffers the Fraser Government had engaged in public relations and press office activities and how many staffers this Government has-including `animals' and their media service-leads us to take a staggeringly different view from the one this Minister was prepared to put across to the Estimates Committee and to this Parliament. The reality is that the Fraser Government's liaison service was in place of providing press secretaries for most Ministers. Very few Ministers in the Fraser Government had press secretaries-for one very good reason: Fraser had seen how under the Whitlam Government, with every Minister having a press secretary, those press secretaries spent most of their time promoting their Ministers instead of promoting the Government. It was chaotic. All one had to do was go down to the non-members bar every night and one would find press secretaries of different Ministers not only promoting their Ministers but trying to undermine other Ministers.

Fraser said he would have none of that when he was in government. He limited the number of Ministers having press secretaries to a very small number indeed. The Prime Minister had three; the Deputy Prime Minister had one; the Leader of the Government in the Senate had one; and there were two to cover all other Ministers. That was a total of seven press secretaries for the entire Ministry. That, of course, was a very different situation from the one which exists under this Government. We find that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has two; the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) has one; the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) has one; the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) has one; and the other Ministers have 10-a total of 15. But that is only part of the story. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table, provided to me in reply to my question, which I received this morning and which I have referred to the Minister.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-

Ministry 30

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. What this table shows is that instead of their being similar in number, the total number of press secretaries in February 1983, under the previous Government, was 16. Under this Government, it is 30-just about double. In this Minister's view, that means, `It's just about the same'. That is what he said; that there is no difference. A doubling is `no difference' to this Minister. How can we take him seriously when he comes into this place? It is incredible that a man of his integrity-and I respect his integrity-should come in with such an appalling brief and pretend that a doubling of the number of people in a propaganda machine does not constitute any real difference. It is absolutely incredible.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at this Government's other public relations people. The total under the Fraser Government, as I said, was 16: the Minister had seven; there were three in the Government Information Unit; and there were six Federal information directors. The total number was 16. Under this Government, instead of there being seven public relations people attached to Ministers, as I said, there are 15 attached to Ministers; there are nine `animals', and another six in the Ministerial Media Group are allocated to Ministers. In a sense, instead of 15 ministerial press secretaries, basically there are 21.

That is only part of the matter, because on top of that, there are 12 back-up `animals' staff-in this propaganda machine-lifting the number of press secretaries, or back-up staff, not to 30, but to 42. This is a propaganda machine of 42 people, costing multimillions of dollars. This Minister hides behind that fact, saying, `It's roughly the same number; it's roughly about the same as it was under the Fraser Government; there is no real difference'. On both scores, numerical and factual, about what it actually does, there is a monumental difference in style, nature and size, and this Minister cannot get away from it.
There is an attempt, at the end of this response, to pretend that the situation is not quite as bad as it looks. The response reads:

It is difficult to make a direct comparison between the number of press secretaries employed by Ministers of the Fraser Government as against the number of press secretaries employed by the present Government as a number of journalists and media staff were employed by Ministers of the Fraser Government in positions not described as press secretaries.

That is the most incredibly asinine remark that could be made. The question is: What were they actually doing? Is the Minister suggesting that people who were employed for other purposes were in fact wickedly and deceptively doing other jobs? I do not recall this alert and dynamic Minister, who was in opposition alert and dynamic, ever establishing, or even alleging, in opposition that that was the case. We have heard already from him that when he was in opposition he made the same kinds of attacks on the Fraser Government as we are now making on his Government. All I say to this Minister is that, if he were so alert, so dynamic, so aware of what was going on and so effective in opposition, why did he not make that sort of comment then? It is as inaccurate now as it was then.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you checked the Hansard?
—No, I have not.
—Of course, you have not.

—I have not because I did not have time. I did not have time because Senator Ray gave us this response 10 minutes before this debate started. The fact is that when I was in government I can recall no such debate, no such major issue, about these people acting secretly, in an improper role, being instructed to do things which were not under their Public Service requirements, or there being a hidden press corps. If the Minister can produce evidence of that, I would be interested to see it. But when I was in government-as an ex-journalist, that is exactly the kind of thing I would have been looking for-I have no recollection of that kind of attack being made. If the Minister has a better recollection, rather than making an empty charge, let him adjourn this debate and come back when he has done his homework. At least we will give him more time to do his homework than he gave us to do ours on this document, which he gave to us 10 minutes before this debate started.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many other issues I would like to raise. I hope that Senator Short will pursue some other matters. I want to give the examples which the Minister challenged me to give about the party political way in which this propaganda machine has acted, despite his instructions in the document he tabled, that representatives of NMLS will not work with local or State party branches and will not be involved in party programs or electoral campaigning. I will give the Minister examples. They are given in the back of the documents which the Minister has provided to us. I look forward to having an opportunity of debating this matter in a few minutes, after Senator Short gives a further contribution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (11.08)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two things I wish to say. The first is that Senator Baume says that there is a massive propaganda machine because one article in a newspaper asserts that. That is absolutely pathetic. He says, `I have absolute proof that the Government Information Unit was pure and that this successor to it is impure, because I have read a newspaper article'. What a revelation! One journalist is quoted as saying he thinks it has a sharper focus. That is not evidence and that is not proof.
—What about the other quotes?

—Let me get to the real point. I will cede the floor to Senator Baume. He has come into this chamber and virtually said that I misled the Estimates Committee because I said there was no difference at all between the Fraser Government and the Hawke Government. Senator Baume did not actually refer to the quote, did he? Does he want to look at the Hansard now so that we can have an argument about it? Let him read the Hansard.
—You just said it just now-very little difference. You said it 10 minutes ago.

—I was referring-and the honourable senator should know this if he has read the Hansard-to the staffing of the Government Information Unit and the National Media Liaison Service (NMLS). I believe I was not referring to general press allocations. There is no doubt that the Hawke Government has taken a different approach to the Fraser Government in that regard. It does allocate more ministerial press secretaries. If the honourable senator will find the quote in Hansard where I say there is no difference between the totality, I will retract. But if he cannot, he must retract. It is no use coming in here--
—I will give you the bit in the Estimates Committee when the Chairman asked you to stop going in that direction.
—Where is the honourable senator referring to?
—In the Estimates Committee.
—What page?
—I will tell you in a minute when I come to it.

—Again, all we have in this debate is the big assertion and a suggestion that somehow the old Government Information Unit was above question. Senator Michael Baume is on the public record as saying that we never raised the issue. He is going to get a phone call from Feathers McLaren shortly. The trouble is that if he gives the honourable senator all the questions he used to ask on this, it will probably suffocate him. He should go and ring ex-Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and ask her whether we have asked questions on the Government Information Unit and its role.
—That's not what I said.

—He went on to say that if we did, it was not effective because he, as a journalist, had not heard about it. This is the period of Mr Objective, Steve Martin, the journalist over here; Mr Objective is saying he would have written a big story exposing the Government. At that time he was the honourable member for Macarthur, was he not, and writing for another newspaper under another name?
—No, I wasn't the member for Macarthur. That's totally false again.
—I was asking the question. I was not stating a fact.
—That sort of rhetorical question is a dishonest debating trick.

—So the honourable member was not the member for Macarthur, so he would not have been doing a Deakin and secretly writing newspaper articles criticising his own party. I accept that. But if he is telling me, and if he is asking me to accept, that in 1983 or 1982 he would have written articles attacking the Liberal Party over its propaganda when he was again seeking preselection, he should not test our gullibility that far. I am still waiting for Senator Baume to tell me and to justify his statement in here. I do have one quote here where I said:

SPEECH.PARA: I hate to harp on comparisons, Senator, but the Government Information Unit in 1982 had 10 journalists and nine keyboard operators. It has not changed much.

If he looked to see who NMLS employs now and the number of keyboard operators, he would agree with me that it has not much changed. But he comes in here and says, without referencing back to Hansard, that a person such as me, who he has some high regard for, has now suddenly misled the chamber and has demeaned himself.

Let us go finally to the conspiracy theory about the arrival of these documents on his desk. Not in my heart of hearts, I have to make an admission, did I expect the estimates for the Department of Administrative Services to be on at 10 o'clock this morning. When we started the committee stage I had no idea that even the estimates for the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs would be considered this early. So there is no conspiracy theory.

TALK.START.PARA: —You pressed us to get them by today or you wouldn't be able to pay people.

—Of course, but joy of joys, Senator Baume, I had no idea this would be up before us so early. So he must not say that these papers were lobbed on his desk because we wanted to deprive him of an opportunity. I would have absolutely anticipated--
—You expected the Bills to be out of the way by now.
—Yes, but going to the conspiracy part, you said that we were trying to deprive you of these answers. If I had been engaged in some conspiracy, the honourable senators would never have got them.
—We wouldn't have got them, if you had your way on the timetable for the appropriations, until after the Bills had passed.

—Quite often answers are not given to questions until after Bills are passed. But if the honourable senator is suggesting that these answers have been held up for political reasons, I assure him that its not true. But some things take longer than others to research. If Senator Baume is doing a bit of research, I am going to have to rely on him to quote chapter and verse in future, not to give a generalised assertion of what his impression was of my views. Quite frankly, I cannot accept them unless he can source them. It is very unfair of him to come in here and set up straw men and knock them over and then say that I have been misleading the chamber with those answers. He has never had such honest answers on the National Media Liaison Service since he has been asking questions, because I have asserted that the National Media Liaison Service is there to support government, not the oppositions, that its members are not public servants but they do support government policy. That is their role on a ministerial staff, the same as any other ministerial staffers or Opposition staff holders. They are, however, precluded, and they should be precluded, from being actively involved in party campaigning in, say, by-elections, et cetera. I am not saying that it could never occur, that the enthusiasts would not say, `I have got to get out there and support Labor candidates'. But if it is drawn to the attention of the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr West, he will enforce that statement put down and signed by me as to their duties, and so he should.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Michael Baume said in his remarks, many of these answers, or answers to several of the outstanding questions, arrived on our desks about 10 minutes before this debate started. And, as was said in interjections across the chamber, had the appropriations been passed in the timescale that the Government was looking for, namely earlier this week at the latest, we would not have had these answers. I accept the statement of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) that there was not a conspiracy involved in this. I know the Minister acts in good faith, but that does not detract from the point that despite the amount of time involved in a lot of these matters-and I accept there is a lot of time involved-it is more than four weeks since the Estimates Committee hearings ended. That is a lengthy period. I do not resile at all from my earlier statement that it is wrong for this chamber to have to debate Appropriation Bills with outstanding questions not answered.

SPEECH.PARA: I make that as a general comment, not just of the Department of Administrative Services, as it happens with many departments. Indeed, last year I recall during the appropriations debate that we in fact refused to pass the appropriations for the Department of Defence because there had been questions outstanding for up to 12 months, I think, from the previous Estimates Committee hearing. We refused to let the appropriations pass until those questions were forthcoming. Surprise, surprise, those questions which had been outstanding for 12 months or more suddenly came forward in the space of, I think, 24 hours. So I am making a general point-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am still waiting for answers from Estimates Committee C asked in 1982 when you were in government.
—Put us back and we will give them to you.

—That is right, and the statute of limitations would not apply in those circumstances. I have not had a chance to look at the answers that have just been received as closely as I would have wished. One of the questions was from me and concerned consultants on the staff of Ministers. On the very brief look that I have had at the answers now provided, I must say that I am absolutely staggered at the amount of money being spent by this Government in putting consultants onto the staffs of Ministers. The answer that I have got says:

SPEECH.PARA: During the year 1 July 87 to 30 June 88, 60 consultants were employed by Ministers.

The annual costs of consultants on the staffs of Ministers has gone up since 1984-85, when the figure was $364,000. In the year just completed, 1987-88, that figure has gone to $1.9m, and this year the appropriation for 1988-89 is only $14,000 short of $2m for consultants. That is a staggering figure. It is a figure which I think I am correct in saying has never been fully identified in the Estimates figures and the appropriations figures. I think it has been included in an administrative item but I am not sure it has been itemised in the way it has now been. But whether it has or has not is not the question. The point I want to make is that that is another enormous addition to the resources of the Government in a way that is not made fully manifest to the Australian public. It is, in my view, another scandalous use of taxpayers money when one looks at some of the people who have been involved in those consultancies and the length of time they have been involved. It is obviously a scam way of getting around staffing levels in Ministers' offices. Some of those consultants have been employed as consultants for more than three years. Peter Steedman has been a consultant for 3 years and 2 months. David McKenzie, who I think was a former Labor member of the House of Representatives--

TALK.START.PARA: —Stop it there. No, that is a different McKenzie. I even remember the Prime Minister making the same mistake.

—I thank the Minister. However, my main point is the length of time that a David McKenzie has been a consultant. The consultancy started in January 1986. He had an 18 months consultancy which took him to July 1987. In January 1988 he was taken on for another year. Helen Mayer, the former member for Chisholm who was defeated at the last election, was employed by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly). She gave Helen Mayer a job for a period of 12 months initially, from September 1987, a couple of months after Mrs Mayer was defeated at the election. That has been extended for a couple of months. That consultancy is based in Melbourne and its purpose is to undertake two tasks. The first is to look into the disparities faced by service personnel and families caused through inter-State transfers. The second is to look into the educational difficulties facing children of Defence Force members. Why that study was undertaken by a person who may or may not have the relevant qualifications for such a study is beyond me. It has never been explained. It is obviously an opportunity to give jobs for the boys and girls of the Australian Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: If one flips through these pages quickly and looks at the names of the consultants shown in the answers to these questions, one finds that many of them are apparatchiks of the Labor machine who have been around for a long time. The Government is paying out taxpayers money in a way which is hidden. These people are not on staff. They are consultants. If the Government is going to be fair dinkum why does it not put them in an established position? It is part of the matter that Senator Michael Baume and myself have been talking about this morning in terms of the enormous resources that this Government has put into staff for purely political purposes as distinct from governmental purposes. That in my view is a scandalous misuse of public money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak just briefly on that matter. The general trend today is to use consultants so that one can vary staff around.
—For a three-year consultancy?
—Oh, yes; for three years or more. What Senator Short says is terrible here is being done in New South Wales by Nick Greiner. It is exactly the same. So is the Northern Territory.
—Another `exactly the same comment'. Boy, oh boy, you are strong on that `exactly the same', aren't you?
—Do you want me to list the Northern Territory Government's consultants?

—Senator Collins may assist in a moment and list all the consultants used by the Northern Territory Government. This is not a secret process. At least each year, maybe every six months, we table in this Parliament a list of all the consultants and their duties. That is a good process because it allows Senator Short and others to ask, `Are they justified?'. There is nothing secret about employing consultants. That is the normal practice. They are properly approved by Cabinet. Some Ministers find consultancies in specific areas very useful.

SPEECH.PARA: We could go back to the old Fraser days, of course, when the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet set up mini-departments to check on what the other departments were doing. Talk about a waste of resources! That was one of the most massive wastes of resources. But Malcolm did not trust anyone. So he used to have replicated in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet all the people overlooking the other departments. It was far more costly than consultants. Consultants are there for a specific reason, to work on specific projects. Senator Short complains that it might be jobs for the boys and defeated members of parliament. There is always a tendency for any government to look after its own in that regard. I do not want to go through all the Liberal appointments to ambassadorial posts, to appointments as Administrator of the Northern Territory, Christmas Island, with Mr Yates, et cetera.

But in one general defence of both governments I have to say this: quite often members of parliament, given their experience in these chambers, are very well suited to these jobs. I have often referred to this chamber and the other chamber, to the whole place, as the most extensive tertiary institution in the country where people are continually educated on a whole series of issues and administrative skills that serve them well when they go to government jobs. I have always been a supporter of ex-members of parliament becoming diplomats, becoming administrators and being put back into the system because of their great knowledge and experience. It is often seen as a reward. No doubt that is an element in both governments' thinking, in my view, that one looks after one's own when a person has been defeated, as long as it does not get to the point-Senator Short may allege it does; I deny it though-of rampant cronyism or giving people jobs just so they have jobs. People have to be criticised if it gets to that point.

I suppose the longer a government goes the more open it is to that sort of criticism. Consultancies are a thing of the current day. Again, harping back to the dreaded years of 1981-82, we used to ask a lot of questions about consultants and computers and why the cost for them was always going up. The sorts of answers I give now Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle gave then. Nothing changes. Maybe in six years time Senator Short will be giving me the same answers from this side.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just make a quick response to that because I do not want to be misunderstood. I am not objecting to the use in a consultancy role of certain people who may have skills because of having had a parliamentary background or whatever. I accept the point the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) made, that some of those people are very well suited to diplomatic posts and other such things. My great concern is twofold. The first issue relates to the extraordinary growth in the use of consultants by this Government. There has been more than a five-fold increase in spending on consultants on ministerial staffs in the last four years. That is an enormous increase in expenditure. The consultancy work that is done-I am sure Senator Robert Ray would agree with me on this-by a person who is attached to a Minister's staff is a vastly different thing from the Government having a consultant to undertake a specific project. They are like chalk and cheese. My first point therefore relates to the enormous increase in expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: My second point is that genuine consultancies on a ministerial staff-I do not deny they might arise from time to time-could not conceivably run for the length of time that many of these consultancies have. The employment of Mr Steedman for three years is not a consultancy; that is employing a person on a ministerial staff. Presumably because the Government does not have a position for him on the establishment, it calls it a consultancy. In my view that is a very improper way to run a ministerial consultancy service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter which is different from the matters that have been raised this morning. It concerns some statements which were made by Senator Sheil earlier this year. Not all of my comments are directed to Senator Sheil because some of the matters he mentioned could conceivably have some effect on my staff and the staff of other Queensland members of this Parliament. I have asked my staff about some of the matters that were raised and they do not seem to be having any problems.

SPEECH.PARA: I go back to 17 October when Senator Sheil asked a question of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) who is in the chamber at the moment. Amongst other things Senator Sheil spoke about a new computer system to streamline payments and salaries. He then went on to say that the system was failing and some employees were waiting many weeks to collect their travelling allowances. He said:

In other words, they are digging into their own pockets to work for the Government. One of my own staff is still awaiting travelling allowances dating back to July; another waited seven weeks for a pay cheque.

I checked with my own staff and they tell me that if they ask for their travelling allowances in advance these are always paid into their bank accounts on the day on which they are requested. They do say that if they happen to be away a day longer than they anticipated, and ask for extra travelling allowance for that day, that is not paid in advance, of course, and it takes some time to arrive. Has Senator Ray or the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) made any inquiries about this to see whether staff are digging into their own pockets for travelling allowances when they fail to make application in advance or make application after they complete their term of duty?
I wish to raise some other matters which are slightly connected. The following day in the Senate Senator Ray made a statement about Senator Sheil's staff and, amongst other things, he said:

Since 1 July 1988 Senator Sheil has notified the Department of two new staff. In respect of the first, the Department made the first salary payment within five days of being notified of her commencement. In respect of the second, the Department was formally advised on 10 August 1988 that some staff member had been employed since 13 April 1987-some 16 months later.

I was in the chamber when that was mentioned and I was sure that an error had been made and the date of 13 April 1987 was really meant to be 13 April 1988. Subsequently letters were tabled which indicated that my understanding was incorrect and the date was 13 April 1987. I wonder whether any investigations have been made about the fact that a person was working in Senator Sheil's office for 16 months without pay and then a request was made for that person to go on staff.

Finally, I wish to make the point that the following day-19 October-Senator Sheil made a personal explanation in which he claimed to have been misrepresented. At the end of his remarks the President said that they were hardly a personal explanation, but rather a statement. In that personal explanation or statement Senator Sheil said:

Senator Ray also informed the Senate that a staff member I employed earlier this year was paid within five days of commencing duty. Again, that is completely incorrect. The staff member did not receive her first pay packet until seven weeks after she started.

There seems to me to be some misunderstanding by Senator Sheil about when this person started and when the Department was contacted. Have investigations been made into the situation with travel allowances and the 16-month delay in notifying the Department of staff changes? Also did that staff member receive her pay packet seven weeks after she started or within five days of the Department being notified? Can Senator Ray throw any light on these matters?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that staff are encouraged to get the travel allowance in advance, so that it can be paid very quickly. Normally if it is not paid in advance or a claim is submitted for an extra day, there is approximately a 30-day delay. As I acknowledged at the time, a new system was introduced in Queensland so there could have been slightly longer delays but we believe that any of the technical hitches there have now been solved.

SPEECH.PARA: I think Senator Colston also made the point that someone had not been paid for seven weeks. That was because the Department had not been notified of her being on the staff. On notification of coming on staff that person was paid within five days. Whilst Senator Sheil has never clarified that issue, he quite clearly misquoted me in this chamber by saying that I was wrong when I said that only five days had passed. The parliamentary and ministerial services section of the Department of Administrative Services cannot pay people unless it knows they are on the payroll. It does not have osmosis or extra sensory perception or any other ability to divine that someone is working. It was only in the course of all that that other letters came to light, indicating that another staff member had apparently been appointed, as Senator Colston said, some time in April 1987. This was not known to the Department until that person wished to travel to Canberra some time in 1988. It was explained to that person that she could only be put on the staff when Senator Sheil sent a letter saying that she was on the staff. As it was, even that took another three months or so to arrive.

Senator Sheil explained that the reason why the person had not notified that she was on the staff from about 13 April was her own business. But in a letter to the Department the explanation given was that her appointment had not been notified because for the last 16 months the honourable senator had been too busy to notify the Department that she was working. We do not ever not take the word of a member of parliament but clearly the Department wrote to Senator Sheil quite a long time ago asking for some substantiation that the person worked from April 1987 right through. It would not surprise Senator Colston to hear that there has been no response. I know Senator Sheil is very busy but I would have thought that that matter being one of public controversy that he sparked off by his accusations, which then backfired on him, one would at least have expected him to respond to that letter. No such response is yet forthcoming, no back pay has been paid and the mystery remains.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -I would just like to follow that up a little. I have here a copy of the letter dated 11 July 1988, which was tabled in the Senate, in which an employee of Senator Sheil said, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: Attached find Pro forma agreement for a member of Electorate staff.
This letter is by way of explanation for the delay in submitting form.
I commenced working with the Senator on Monday 13 April 1987-commuting each day between my home in Brisbane and the office in Surfers Paradise.
At that time the Senator was away in Canberra and various parts of the Electorate and the forms were not completed.
As Senator Ray mentioned, the letter said:
The situation has now arisen that Senator Sheil requires me to travel to Canberra on various occasions and consequently the forms are essential for a number to be obtained.
I am not quite sure what that means. The letter continues:
Please advise if there is anything overlooked.

I think something was probably overlooked for about 16 months, but I do not think that is what the staff member meant. The Minister alluded to the fact that back payment was requested by Senator Sheil, not by the staff member; but I would like to know this: if the Department had not been notified for 16 months that this person was on the staff and was travelling daily between the suburb of Annerley in Brisbane and Surfers Paradise and returning, as was claimed in the letter, and if that person happened to have an accident on the way to work or on the way home from work, would that person be covered by workers compensation? It is not a question that I ask idly, because I often travel on that road between Brisbane and the Gold Coast. A lot of drivers on that road regard themselves as rally drivers rather than ordinary drivers and it is a road on which there are a fair number of accidents. I ask: Under those circumstances would that person be covered by workers compensation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot give the honourable senator a judgment on that and, given the pay rises that judges are about to get, I am not really inclined to do their work. All I can say is that that matter would certainly go to the courts. One of the reasons we encourage everyone to formalise staff arrangements is that staff members are properly covered. I cannot give the honourable senator a legal opinion on it. I am glad that someone so altruistic as not to accept pay for 16 months was not involved in an accident, because I think it would be very sad for the person concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Minister must have been a little confused about what I thought I had said fairly clearly, cleanly and directly when he responded with his image of injured innocence. I commend him for that presentation. I think he does that even better than being quick on his feet, which he is so good at as well. But this injured innocence does not lie too well with what I actually said. I did not deny that, when he was in opposition, there was debate on the previous Government's press services. He ,gave a fanciful response. I said that there were no complaints that I know of of journalists, in effect, masquerading as ordinary staff members in other Ministers' offices, because that is the implication of his response. I draw the attention of the Minister to this, because he has just gone off on the wrong tram. And I do not want to be inundated with calls from Feathers McLaren, thanks; although it was a very kind offer.

SPEECH.PARA: I am just telling the Minister the facts. I know that he will not be accustomed to dealing with them, but I am telling him the facts. The fact is that the answer I quoted said it is difficult to make a direct comparison between the number of press secretaries employed by Ministers of the Fraser Government and the number of press secretaries employed by Ministers in the present Government, as a number of journalists and media staff were employed by Ministers in the Fraser Government in positions not described as press secretaries. That was the issue that I regarded as phoney when I responded to this. I said that I did not recall complaints of that nature, that journalists were masquerading as ordinary staff members, being raised by the Minister when he was in opposition. If he can demonstrate that not to be so, good luck to him. But do not come up with some phoney straw man and burn it down, as he accused me of putting up a phoney straw man. Two can play that game, Minister. I will join him at it any time.
Let me turn now to what the Minister said at Estimates Committee E. The official having described what the cost of the National Media Liaison Service (NMLS) is, Senator Robert Ray went on to say:
That figure compares fairly favourably with the 1982-83 budget allocation for the Government Information Unit-its predecessor . . .
He then went on to describe what the costs would be in current terms. The Chairman said:
I cannot allow you to go on with that sort of information, Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read it. That is sarcastic, isn't it? He is not directing me not to go on.

—Except, I suppose, that it bore no relation to the question; I do not know. The point is that I then took the Minister to task in effect by saying, `Come on, it is not realistic or accurate to describe this as its predecessor, because of the enormously different functions involved'. I pursued the Minister over that. If he reads the Hansard he will see that I was saying, `Come on, there are different functions'. In other words, I was saying that the Minister was being misleading simply to describe it as its predecessor, simply give its costs and simply compare it. That was the whole thrust of the questioning. The Minister, being very quick on his feet, then recognised that that was the thrust of the question, and we can tell from his subsequent non-answers that he recognised the thrust of the question. I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Could I ask the Minister, in view of that interesting information, whether the duties are exactly comparable.
His non-answer was to provide a list of the current duties without indicating whether they were comparable whatsoever. His non-answers were to continue after I said:

The thrust of my question related to functions. As you would recognise, Minister, the functions of ministerial press secretaries and/or departmental press assistants given to Ministers would be similar to many of the functions which you have just attributed to the previous group but which are not carried out by this present Media Liaison Service.
The Minister's response was:
Some of the functions are different of course, not the least being to do political work . . .
I then asked:
In those circumstances, would you say that the $1.135m is only a fraction of the cost of the Government's media and press relations bill in respect of its ministerial and other promotional effort?
The Minister's non-answer was:
It relates to a specific purpose. There are other expenditures for other purposes.

The Minister was creating the totally false impression that its predecessor-the implication being the predecessor in respect of all its functions-was expending even more in current terms than the present one. If the Minister is prepared to put a different gloss on that, that is up to him. All I am saying is that that, combined with his comment today that there is very little difference between the coalition and Labor operations as if they are exactly comparable-and the Minister should have a look at today's Hansard-shows that the Minister is misleading the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want me to deal with that now?

—The Minister can do it in a minute, or he can do it whenever he likes; he is in control of the chamber. But I want to make a couple more points yet, because I have a lot of things to say. Under the guidelines the Minister gave to this propaganda machine, guideline (c) states:

SPEECH.PARA: State representatives are to provide local members of all parties with details of Government programs and assist their media presentation.

I stress the words `all parties'. Is that not a kind, generous and loving gesture from this Government? Except that when we look at what they actually do, we see that they provide information solely and exclusively on that level to Government members. Senator Short asked the Minister:
Has the NMLS actually produced any publications since it was created?
That was in 1983. The answer was:
The NMLS publishes Focal Point on a weekly basis. It is sent to Government MPs.
It is not sent to Opposition members, which is contrary to the statement in guideline (c) which says `of all parties'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where it says `relevant'.
—I do not see the word `relevant'. Guideline (c) states, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . are to provide local members of all parties with details of Government programs . . .
Maybe the Minister wants to rewrite his guidelines to insert a few words like that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought you quoted the word `relevant', that's all.

—In that case the Minister has misheard and misquoted for the second time today. It is sent to Government members of Parliament-why not all MPs, as I think Senator Harradine interjected?-for circulation?
—What are we missing out on?

—I presume we are missing out on information. But let us face it; it is nothing new for this Government not to provide full and open access to information. As we have seen, I cannot get information about who the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) invited to the opening of Parliament House. Information about who I invited is publicly available.
—I cannot get answers concerning the Estimates.

—And Senator Harradine cannot get information about the Estimates. But that is not all. The Record of Government is also published. Federal Insight and Rural Focus are published on an irregular basis. Apparently the Minister has not been taking his All Bran. The latest issue of Record of Government is dated 1986, the latest Federal Insight is dated 20 October 1988, and the latest Rural Focus was published in October 1988. All these publications are sent to Labor members of parliament from an organisation whose duty is to provide local members of all parties with details of government programs and assist their media presentation. So if the Minister wants an indication of the extent to which the guidelines appear to have been broken on party political lines, that seems to be a bit of evidence from the horse's mouth. To the questions we asked about whether NMLS staff had been to various places, whether they had participated in referendums or moved into various States at different times, the Minister said that all the questions had been answered and the answer was no. I have flagged these answers. I wanted to deal with them because I was intrigued at the wording differences between the answers and the actual questions. For example, I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Are any additional or temporary staff employed by the National Media Liaison Service at election time? Do voluntary or unpaid workers use the facilities of the National Media Liaison Service at election time; either voluntary or non-paid workers?
The answer is carefully different from the question. It says:
No extra staff were employed for the period of the 1987 election campaign.
That deals with the first question. The answer to the next question states:
The National Media Liaison Service does not have `voluntary staff'.

I did not ask whether it had voluntary staff; I asked whether any volunteers from the Labor Party came in to use the expensive equipment, the faxes, the telephones, the free lines to Townsville-heaven knows why it has these people in Townsville, but I will go into that in a minute-and all the electronic equipment of major use in an election campaign. I asked whether anyone came in to use it. I did not ask, `Do you have voluntary staff?'. It would be nice if I got a straightforward answer to what seemed to me to be a straightforward question. I also asked:
On how many occasions do staff members of the National Media Liaison Service, who are not based in New South Wales, visit New South Wales during the New South Wales election campaign?
The answer, again, slightly different from the question, reads:
No National Media Liaison Service staff member visited New South Wales at official expense during the New South Wales election campaign.

I do not know whether it is impossible to find out whether any National Media Liaison Service people actually worked there. The fact that they were not visiting at official expense does not necessarily mean that they were not there being paid for their normal jobs but doing their normal jobs in Sydney rather than in some other centre. Does the use of the words `at official expense' mean that no-one was working there? I will not suggest that staff members were sufficiently generous to give up their holidays to work although I suppose they would all recognise that if their party lost the election they would lose their jobs. As I recall, all the members of our media group lost their jobs when the Government changed.

As time is running on I will refer to some other matters. The `animals' I refer to are nine top journalists earning about as much as a member of parliament. The top salary, including the ministerial staff allowance, is $52,251. That is more than members of parliament get. So it is a pretty highly paid propaganda operation. It is a beauty. The propaganda machine is getting more than members of parliament and I presume it is because the Minister takes the view that it is more effective.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you know what a top grade journalist gets in the market-place now?
—As a journalist I was getting far more in real terms than I am earning here.
—Exactly. You have answered your own question.

—Exactly, but I am making the point that it is such a priority of this Government to get top propagandists that they are paid far more than members of parliament get to staff their operations. It intrigues me to look at the location of the NMLS. Why are there four `animals' in Queensland and only two in New South Wales? What is the point? Obviously it is that there is a greater political need for the NMLS up there because the Labor Party is so on the nose and has been on the nose in Queensland for so long. Apparently there is a feeling that they can be of some use. Clearly the Labor Party distributes `animals' on a basis of political need rather than the proper serving--
—It is the need for information.
—Well, how can we justify four--
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Now we are getting down to the nitpicking. I want to return to the central issue that Senator Michael Baume has tried to gloss over today. He said that I had said that there was very little difference between money expended on press generally in the Government-this is a summary-and what was spent on the press in the Fraser years. I invite him to go back to the Hansard to find where that was said at Estimates Committee E. He has glossed over it. He has not found it because it is not there. He attempted to quote the answer that we have provided showing the figures 16 and 30 and said that I had misled the Committee but my comments were directed very specifically-and Senator Baume knows this and should acknowledge it-to the staffing levels and cost of the Government Information Unit and the National Media Liaison Service (NMLS). This is very clear at the bottom of page 114 of Hansard. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: I hate to harp on comparisons, Senator, but the Government Information Unit in 1982 had 10 journalists and nine keyboard operators. It has not changed much.
Apparently I went on to say:
. . . keyboard operators go up as journalists go down.
That is basically what I was saying. I was not saying that this Government does not have more ministerial press officers than had the Fraser Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't say that the Fraser Government had fewer, did you?
—Does the honourable senator want me to say that now?
—Yes.

—I confess: we have a few more press officers than had the Fraser Government. I hereby tender my resignation to the Governor-General and invite those opposite to become the Government! Are they the sweet words Senator Michael Baume has been waiting for?
—It is a pity you didn't say it in the Estimates Committee when you had the burden of the pressure of the questioning.

—But the question was never directly asked. The honourable senator asked me to get information about how many officers were employed over a period. I did not have that information in my memory and I said I would get it. I cannot be expected to answer questions the honourable senator does not ask, yet Senator Baume alleged this morning in his first speech, to which I took the most serious exception, that I had in some way misled this chamber or the Committee. The real problem is that he did not ask the right questions. If the honourable senator had gone on to ask me, `What I want to know is how much money, in terms of salary and administrative expenses, total press effort in this Government is costing compared with the Fraser Government' and then put the amount at either 1983 dollars or 1988 dollars we would have had some reason to compare. Then he went on to distort my response by saying that my well-held view that there is not much difference between the two is again misleading the chamber. It is just a matter of opinion: he has his opinion; I have my opinion. The most substantive evidence he put forward to back up his evidence today was some newspaper article from last week.
—That you fed to them anyway.
—Oh no, that is a very harsh interjection. It is not becoming of Senator McMullan's normal, gracious demeanour in this chamber.
—To him it was a compliment.
—I see. I do not know who fed the story to the newspaper. There is nothing wrong with parliamentarians drawing attention to major issues in newspapers.
—It has happened.

—Of course it has happened that someone has fed a story to the newspaper, distorted the story to the newspaper and then claimed it in here as fact. It is just part of the political merry-go-round. I do not think that I have much more that is useful to say on the subject of the NMLS. However, I noted one question from Senator Short which sparked my interest. He referred to a newspaper article that suggested that maybe we should have a transfer of responsibility in this area away from the Department of Administrative Services to the portfolio of Senator Richardson-the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Given that I would rather not have to waste two hours here on this when I have meetings planned, I certainly will suggest that Senator Richardson take over this area. As I handed Defence to him in this chamber, I might hand this to him. That suggestion has some merit so that we can have some senatorial supervision over this area. I am really indebted to Senator Short for that suggestion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond very briefly to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray). He asked why I did not ask the right question. The question I asked was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . how many press secretaries were employed by Ministers of that Fraser Government, as against the number of press secretaries employed by this Government?

I asked what was their total cost in salary and administrative expenses. That is exactly the question he just accused me of not asking. I did not get an answer to it, of course. The Minister's reply states:
Salary and administrative costs for press secretaries cannot readily be extracted from the total costs of staff employed by all Ministers, office holders, senators and members.

So I asked the right question; the Minister just did not answer it. So it is a bit quaint to say that I did not ask the right question. The excuse was that the information cannot readily be extracted. Earlier today the Minister said that it would involve immense cost. When one asks the right question and one does not get an answer, it is additional hypocrisy for the Minister to say that one did not ask the right question; we have had plenty of that today. I ask the Minister, in that case: what was the cost of providing the partial answer that I received today relating to the numbers? I would not think it would be very much. I do not think the time taken would be very long. Perhaps he could explain why we got it 10 minutes before the debate began. The question was asked on 19 October. It took from 19 October until the beginning of December for the Department to give us the information that there were 16 ministerial press secretaries or the equivalent back in 1983 compared with 30 now. Of course, as I said earlier, that 30 left off the 16 back-up staff. That really lifts the current number to 46. I do not know what the back-up staff would have been in 1983.

I return to the question of why there are more National Media Liaison Service (NMLS) staff-`animals'-in Queensland. Why are there four `animals' in Queensland and two in New South Wales, two in Victoria, et cetera? There are five in Canberra. I can understand that. After all, the lion tamers are in Canberra so that is where one would assume the `animals' would be. I ask the Minister: What is the motive for having, in population terms, a massive concentration of `animals' per head of population in Queensland as against any other State? What criteria determine where the `animals' should be caged? I would be interested to hear his response. During Senate Estimates hearings I also asked the Minister whether `animals' would be available, as it says in his answer, to provide local members of all parties with details and assist their media presentation; whether that assistance would be available to members of the coalition in opposition.

Senator Ray is so sensitive now it is essential to quote his exact words. I got the impression from him that that would be such a low priority on the list of `animals' ' priorities that one would be wasting one's time to ask for that assistance. Maybe the Minister will say that that is an unfair assessment of what he had to say. But basically he was saying that one would be wasting one's time to ask `animals' to do what his memorandum requires them to do. The Minister says to the chamber, `Give us examples of this dreadful political bias'. The fact is that his own answers indicate it quite clearly. As he stresses, these people are not public servants; they are working for the Government. They are working for the Government in power and they are working in a political way, as journalists themselves have said in the article referred to. They say, when asked, that it is true that they act in a particularly political propagandising manner, a manner in which they did not work back in 1983 under Mr Young. There has been a clear change in emphasis and style, a doubling in total media assistance staff from the number under Fraser, a change in the actual nature and operation of the NMLS since Mr John Brown became responsible for it and employed Mr Parks.

TALK.START.PARA: —And got caught.

—Yes. The facts are simple: this Government has created a propaganda machine. It sought to hide the cost of it originally in the documents. One had to ask questions to find out what the costs were. It has as its director a person who is directly employed not by the Department of Administrative Services, where these people reside-they are not on the normal strength-and hidden in the allocations for the Department of Administrative Services; it is run by someone who is employed by the Government's own media operation. In my mind the wearing of the two hats by the director clearly establishes the political propagandising nature of the organisation.
