This is a curious way to operate this body and it is even more curious that this organisation hides behind the pretence of a memorandum signed by this Minister saying that it is to provide local members of all parties with details and that it will not be involved in party programs when the evidence clearly shows that it is and has been, and even more will be, under this Minister, judging from the responses we have received in the debate today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of points to make. The National Media Liaison Service (NMLS) is not under my control. Senator Baume said `under this Minister'. I do have a few things on the immigration plate to deal with on occasions! He asked why so many staff are employed in Queensland. There is a dramatic, massive staffing of four compared with two elsewhere! This demonstrates our commitment to far north Queensland, which most people regard as a separate State anyway. It may be to do with the productivity of the Queensland Government. It has a more massive disinformation campaign to do with Federal programs than anyone else.
—If you want to talk about propaganda units, talk about that one; there are 52 journalists.

—No-one in this chamber wants to discuss Queensland. We are tired of Queensland. We are tired of a situation in which one can take a bag full of money-$250,000 we heard earlier this week-and be issued with a $53m contract. We have become immune to all that sort of thing. Even Senator Baume could understand that trying to get government information out of Queensland would have been a difficult thing from a Federal level, given the type of operation Bjelke-Petersen had in Queensland. I imagine that is it. I must say that it never occurred to me to inquire.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Baume complains that one aspect of the memorandum has not been adhered to. Certainly I will take the time today to draw that again to the attention of the director. I will remind him of item (c) in the memorandum and tell him to make sure that all local members are given this information.

However, the real furphy lies in Senator Baume's remarks about assisting local members in promoting government policy. I really do not think that any honourable senators opposite or any Opposition members in the House of Representatives are going to call upon the National Media Liaison Service to help them promote government policy. Basically those opposite are not, or would rarely be, big supporters of government policy. That is a furphy, and I think Senator Baume realises that it is.

I take Senator Baume's first point in relation to item (c) of the memorandum. I take his word that he has not been given the information. As I say, I will draw it to the attention of the director. I did not sign the memorandum as a joke. The direction was meant to be carried out. I still maintain that in relation to party campaigning it has been carried out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to draw the attention of the Committee to the actual cost of the referendums this year. I do so because, if people took the Estimates Committee E Hansard at face value, they would get a considerable understatement of the actual cost of the referendums. During the Estimates Committee hearings, when the Australian Electoral Commission officers were being examined, Senator Durack asked for the cost of the referendums. The Electoral Commissioner said that the cost would be a whisker over $37m. That figure, I presume, is accurate so far as the Electoral Commission is concerned, but it needs to be pointed out that the actual cost of the referendums was considerably greater than $37m. That does not include the $3m that was spent on the Government's advertising campaign. Two of the four advertisements in that campaign were found to be illegal and the Government had to change those illegal advertisements to make them conform with the provisions of the Electoral Act. That was quite an extraordinary thing to have happened.

SPEECH.PARA: It was extraordinary that in the Estimates Committee hearings we were told that the Electoral Commission, which has responsibility for the administration of the Electoral Act and therefore matters pertaining to the legality of advertising for elections and referendums, had not even been consulted in the preparation of the Government's advertising campaign. It was only as a result of the Commission's own initiative that legal opinion was sought by the Commission which led to two of the four advertisements being ruled illegal. It was an absolutely classic case of the left hand of the Government not knowing what the right hand was doing. So there is a $3m addition to the $37m that was mentioned by Dr Hughes in the Estimates hearing.

An additional $6m has to be added for the cost of the conduct of the Constitutional Commission, a body which this Government set up three years ago to try to give the Government a mandate to rewrite the Constitution in a way which would fit the Australian Labor Party's long term agenda for this country. When we add that figure, we have a minimum cost for the referendums of $46m.

This $46m was absolutely wasted, for two reasons. Firstly, the referendums were never really likely to get up. One would have to say that in retrospect. History has now shown that unless both major parties support proposals for constitutional change those proposals will not get up, and it is an absolute waste of money on the Government's part to attempt to get them up. The second reason it was an absolute waste of money is that there was no earthly reason for running the referendums separately from a general election. Had they been run in conjunction with the next Federal election their cost would have been minimal compared with the extraordinarily extravagant waste that was incurred this year. I believe that the referendums were yet another example of the extraordinary sense of priorities of this Government. When it comes to allocating taxpayers' funds, the priorities of this Government seem to be absolutely out of line with the values and needs of the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to deal with the estimates for Parliament House Construction Authority. During Estimates Committee E hearings I asked whether there were many outstanding problems to be resolved in terms of equipment and so on that was not working in the new Parliament House. Apparently, as a result of a misunderstanding of my question, the response was that there were not many outstanding problems to be resolved. I then went through a list of them. There was an enormous number of items regarding which there were problems, particularly in the food area. Is it possible to get a correct answer, instead of the incorrect answer I got in the Estimates Committee hearing, relating to the hot-presses which were supposed to keep food warm in the dining room?
—Close to your heart, Senator.

—Yes. There have been continual complaints about the coldness of food served in the dining room. To what extent is this related to the fact that the hot-presses, especially designed as a one-off operation, did not work? The answer given in the Estimates Committee hearing was:

SPEECH.PARA: The problems are basically derived from the fact that they were one-off items; they were not proprietary items. We resolved the problems, we thought, and had them to everyone's satisfaction. Unfortunately, the user decided to change his operation so that they would not be used at all. I understand that was due to some industrial pressure from his own staff. Our response to that has since been to say, `Even though you do not want to use them in your operational sequences, we will get them fixed up to the full extent of the contract'. That would include having the doors rectified.

Having pursued this matter, my understanding is that the items were condemned because of heat problems and particularly the risk of fire. I would be grateful if we were advised of the real situation. I have also been given a clear impression by officers of the Joint House Department that the Parliament will be required to suffer considerable cost burdens resulting from major renovations and changes to equipment and areas in Parliament House that are not satisfactory. I would be grateful to get some kind of indication of what the additional costs are that the Parliament is likely to face as a result of the Joint House Department finding that there are matters which have not been adequately resolved by the Construction Authority, and whether the Construction Authority has been discussing these problems with the Joint House Department representatives or any other relevant persons.

In particular, I ask: What was the problem which involved the digging up and destroying of large slabs of black marble in the main corridor to the Senate a couple of weeks ago? It was evident, after this black marble had been dug up, that electricity junction boxes were covered in water. I have seen now that sections of that black marble floor have been replaced with a totally different colour of black marble. When renovations, repairs or corrections of this nature take place-obviously, it is inevitable that repairs will have to be done-is it going to involve the destruction of very expensive items, like black marble, and their replacement with items that do not appear to be of the same colour or nature?

I also draw to the Committee's attention the fact that the indentation of the floor, particularly of the Great Hall, by the heels of women's shoes is going to require, as we found in Senate Estimates Committee hearings, a major sanding operation over the Christmas period. I am afraid I cannot recall how much this will cost, but I wondered whether it would be necessary to take the same action in all the other wooden corridors in Parliament House and who would meet the cost of that major sanding and resurfacing, or refacing, that is to go on. Is such work a result of unexpected wear? In other words, is it the responsibility of the Joint House Department to correct that extraordinary wear, or was it entirely expected within the contract of the supplier?

Is the Parliament House Construction Authority happy that that flooring is adequate and meets the requirements of the Construction Authority, and it is what the Construction Authority would have regarded as totally acceptable? Having sanded and resurfaced the Great Hall after less than a year of activity-five months of sittings of the Parliament-what will be the result of the resurfacing? Will it then last for a long time? Can it be done better, or will this job be required to be done every six months or so, presumably at enormous expense to the Parliament?

TALK.START.PARA: —None of the officials here know anything about the food warmers or heating devices. I will try to get an answer to that question. I would have thought that by this stage that would be a matter for the Joint House Department rather than for the Parliament House Construction Authority (PHCA). Regarding the lifting of the marble slabs, my advice is that that would have been a contract defect and the expense would have been incurred by the contractor rather than taxpayers. As for the pockmarking of the wooden floors around Parliament House, there are no plans, to my knowledge, to do anything about that-in the Great Hall or anywhere else. There are no plans for any sanding, as far as I know, and that has been confirmed by the officials who are present. The pockmarking of the Great Hall, in particular, is being looked at by the Joint House Department and the PHCA.

—I thank the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) for his response, but I understand that in the Senate Estimates committee hearings an answer was given that the damage to the floor of the Great Hall would be dealt with by sanding and resurfacing over the Christmas break and that it was going to cost a substantial amount of money. I cannot put my hand on the page of the Estimates committee transcript on which that statement appears. My recollection certainly was that it had been decided that it was necessary to do that. I would be grateful if we could find out who is going to pay for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sanding was one of the options which was being considered, as I understand it. The advice has just been confirmed that no decision has been made as to whether it will be sanded or whether anything else will be done.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet
Proposed expenditure-$86,006,000

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we move to the vote for the Attorney-General's Department and in view of the fact that material in relation to Estimates Committee A and, in particular, in relation to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, came to me only after the debate had concluded, I seek leave to briefly refer back to that Department.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you will not abuse the leave and go on for half an hour.

—No, it should not take longer than five minutes. The matter which concerns me is this: on 7 October I sought details of figures and costs relating to Mr Hayden's undertakings in that month-what was a thoroughly unnecessary and unjustifiable overseas junket which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at the time laughingly chose to describe as a `familiarisation tour'; that being, of course, by someone who had already chalked up no fewer than 41 trips in a period of just over five years.

SPEECH.PARA: I asked for the information on 7 October. During three meetings of the Estimates Committee I was not provided with that information, other than to be given on 13 October some information to the effect that it was not possible to provide a detailed breakdown of the costs of the trip until Mr Hayden returned to Australia. Mr Hayden himself had proposed the countries to be visited and the dates, his staff had made detailed arrangements, and the Department had not been involved in the arrangements of his itinerary.

Since that time, I have been patiently awaiting receipt of that additional information. Yesterday evening, at 7.20 p.m.-bearing in mind that the Senate was scheduled to adjourn at 7.30 p.m.-material was provided to me by way of an addendum to answers which purported to give a detailed budget breakdown of the Governor-General-designate's overseas trip. That indicated that air fares had been of the order of $23,000; accommodation and meals amounted to $23,805; and transport and other incidental expenses amounted to $13,249-a total of $60,397. I was further told that it was possible, but not expected, that further accounts may come to hand.

The note also confirms that it was almost entirely a private venture and that the only official visits or portions of the trip that could be classified as official commitments were a call by Mr Hayden on the Governor of Hong Kong; a luncheon function in New York in honour of the President of Fiji; and a cup of tea at Buckingham Palace. One would assume that each of those matters were paid for. Nonetheless, the cost of accommodation and meals for Mr and Mrs Hayden and a departmental officer average out a approximately $1,600 per day. Transport and other expenses amount to almost $1,000 per day. My inquiries indicated that the `other' includes a $63 a day incidental allowance which is normally provided to Ministers and which was generously provided in this instance to Mr Hayden. Presumably, it was provided tax-free and went straight into his pocket. These figures indicate that Mr Hayden has certainly gone for broke. I can understand why there is a very great degree of sensitivity. But what concerns me above all is that I think the facts as they are indicate a very serious conspiracy, which involved Mr Hayden, to withhold information from this chamber and the public in the hope that it would go unnoticed.

I can understand the exquisite sensitivity and embarrassment of the public revelation that a humble working class boy from the backblocks of Queensland managed to rack up $1,600 a day for accommodation and meals, together with $1,000 a day for car hire and incidentals, but the fact is that that information was sought last Wednesday on the basis that this debate would take place last Friday. At 5 p.m. last Friday the Department indicated that it was in possession of the information, that it had already been discussed with Mr Hayden but that it wanted to check one further matter. There was no further communication until last evening. I put this to honourable senators: it is quite clear that the Department withheld that information until it was aware that the debate on Estimates Committee A had concluded and that the information was then conveyed via the Government Whip's office, which is not the normal course of events. It should have been provided in the mail to the Secretary of that Estimates Committee. Nonetheless, it was provided at a time when it must have been clear to all concerned that there was a very good prospect that most senators would not be interested in the matter as they would be preoccupied with Christmas parties and the like and the Senate was due to rise shortly. In fact, the material was provided to me at 7.20 p.m.

I am advised that Mr Hayden was consulted again yesterday morning. It is quite clear that Mr Hayden is no political tyro. He had enough nous to call off the trip, but he also had 20-plus years in the Parliament and more than five years as Leader of the Opposition, and he would have been acutely aware of the timing and sensitivity of this material. It is clear to me that Mr Hayden was actively involved in the attempt to withhold this information from the Parliament. I regard that as a disgrace and I urge this chamber to require the Government to provide a full explanation of how this situation came about, why the information was not provided in the normal course of events, and why it took six weeks to come up with these figures, which must have been known to the Department, or could have been obtained by the Department.

Again, the timing was exquisite. The first answer which said that it would not be possible to provide a detailed breakdown of the costs until Mr Hayden returned from Australia was given to me the day before Mr Hayden returned. Again, quite clearly, there has been an attempt at every stage to avoid providing this information, in the hope that at the last minute it would go unnoticed. It certainly has not. I believe it is a disgrace. The Government must come clean on this cover-up and explain precisely who it was that took the decision to withhold this information. Unless that is done, there will continue to be a very real question mark over Mr Hayden's fitness for office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Estimates Committee A was dealt with in this chamber after lunch yesterday and at that time there were no questions from the Opposition--
—We did not have the documents.

—I understand that. The honourable senator should let me finish. I said that at that time there were no questions from the Opposition. The information was subsequently provided. If I might volunteer an opinion, it might not need to have been provided. However, it was. It is upon this information that Senator Alston has raised his latest series of questions.
—There was an undertaking to provide the answer.

—Yes; I understand that. Sometimes, even yesterday for example, I, as the Minister in this chamber, undertook to get answers for people in respect of certain matters arising before the Estimates Committee.
—Was it your decision to withhold this until last night?
—Oh, come off it. This is pathetic.
—Well, whose decision was it?

—This issue has all the characteristics of an Opposition attack in this place. First of all, Senator Alston did not even get his facts right when he went off about this matter last night. Last night he was claiming that the costs of the visit had suddenly rocketed from about $23,000 to $60,000. His claim was not even on the basis of an intelligent reading of the Hansard.
—I said the inform- ation--

—That is what the honourable senator said last night, and it was not on the basis of an intelligent reading of the Hansard. He is characterised in everything he does by the sort of style which possesses this Opposition. Those opposite fly off the handle about silly things without even getting their facts right. This is the alternative government in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators opposite can make all the noise they like, but that is the fact of the matter. Senator Alston started by getting his facts wrong.
—Are you saying he did not spend the money?
—Perhaps Senator Baume ought to look at the matter. He is an expert on getting the facts wrong. That is why he is on the back bench.
—Is that why you're saying he did not spend the money?

—No, I am not saying anything like that. I am saying that Senator Alston did not get his facts right. He started on the false assumption that the costs had rocketed from about $23,000 to $60,000. He overlooks the fact that in the Senate Estimates Committee hearing of 31 October-I invite Opposition senators to read the Hansard-an official of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet (PM and C) gave a preliminary indication of costs which amounted to over $58,000. I ask Senator Alston whether that is right or wrong. He is pretty good on the noise when I am trying to talk. I am asking him whether it is right or wrong that the amount estimated at that time for Mr Hayden's trip was $58,000.
—A very general indication, no detailed breakdown at all.

—The honourable senator can say what he likes. He will not give an answer as to whether the figure is right or wrong. The figure given to Senator Alston yesterday is little different from that $58,000 figure; it is $60,397. Senator Alston wants to allege some cover-up by officers of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet in respect of this issue. If he knew anything about it he would know that these figures are compiled in overseas posts and are sent back over time and that is what was said in the Estimates Committee.
—Are you denying they are extravagant? They are paid over there, irrespective of how extravagant they are.
—Now he is claiming the question of extravagance by further interjection.
—Are you denying they are extravagant?
—Mr Hayden was entitled to go overseas on the basis of ministerial guidelines.
—Because he did not have any trips previously?

—I do not want to deal with that sort of interjection. Mr Hayden was entitled to go overseas as Governor-General designate on the basis of guidelines applying to ministerial trips, and all items which fall within the guidelines will be paid by the Government. If there is any item which falls outside the guidelines, it will not be paid by the Government; Mr Hayden will pay it. That is the procedure which has--
—Has he repaid anything?
—No, but he will. If there is any item outside the guidelines, Mr Hayden will repay it.
—You will have to change the guidelines.
—No, there is no question of changing the guidelines.
—He has given back part of the allowance, has not he?
—You have for Keating.

—Mr President, I appreciate the Opposition's concern in carrying on this flurry of interjections. Having started down this course, as I said earlier, on a completely wrong set of assumptions about the facts, which are clearly in the Hansard in relation to the Estimates Committee--
—Why was the information provided to me via the Government Whip's office at 20 past seven last night?

—I can tell the honourable senator why. The officer concerned had the information here in his bag, when Senate Estimates Committee A was being dealt with. He had it right here in his bag, but there was not a question from members of the Opposition. They were all out of the chamber, bludging somewhere, I suppose. The fact of the matter is that there was no issue raised by the Opposition. The next group of Estimates came on and the officers from PM and C went out, which is the normal thing to do. The information was then provided to Senator Alston, who thought, `I have got a free kick out of all this stuff. The figure was $23,000 originally and now it is $58,000 or $60,000 or whatever'.
—You are digging a very deep hole.
—Senator Short, who is an expert on digging deep holes for himself, is now accusing me of that.
—When was the decision taken to provide this information?

—I can provide Senator Alston with that information. Of course, it was taken at an appropriate time so the information would be here when the Estimates Committee was being debated. Senator Alston has raised a number of other matters--
—On 13 October it was quite clear they were going to provide additional information, wasn't it?

—I did. Senator Alston has raised a number of other matters, including the rationale for visits by Governors-General designate; that is, to provide a complete break from previous professional life. It was not expected that Mr Hayden's diary would be full of official engagements on these visits.
—It certainly was not.

—If Senator Alston digs out the engagements diary for two Governors-General who were appointed by the Opposition when it was in government he will find that exactly the same pattern was followed then. All the expenditures that fall within the guidelines will be met by the Government. Any expenditures which do not fall within those guidelines will be met by Mr Hayden.
—Do you chalk up $1,000 a day in cars when you are away?
—I do not know, Senator. I do not know what they charge for cars in New York.
—Order! I do not believe the Minister need answer that question.
—Of course I do not. Senator Alston, on the basis of this little charade, will always be on private visits. He will never be on a government one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise an important matter in the Senate today. Like my colleagues, I have been concerned for sometime about the question of Aboriginal projects in various parts of the north and north-western areas of New South Wales. I point out that I am not simply getting on a band wagon as a late convert. It is now over 12 months since I first raised the issue of funding for several Aboriginal schemes in New South Wales. I have raised the matter at Estimates committee meetings. In fact, I did so as early as a few years ago. I have given information to colleagues to enable them also to pursue these questions and I have put questions on notice to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand). I do not believe that I or the people of New South Wales have received satisfactory answers to any of the concerns that have been raised.

SPEECH.PARA: In the short time that I have available I do not propose to mention Toomelah because it has already been referred to in other debates in this place and has received widespread publicity. Some of the projects that worry me and many of my constituents, both black and white, include the Oasis Hotel at Walgett, the Nardoola farm project at Moree and the Tamworth district farm at Trelawney. Let me say at the outset that we are at a very sensitive stage in Australian race relations. We have a government which is fanning an immigration brawl out of a sheer desire to create feelings of bigotry and bias in an attempt to make the Opposition look bad-in my opinion, it is making itself look bad-without any consideration of the damage it is doing to Australia and Australians as a whole. As a result, one realises what little hope there is in trying to discuss such issues rationally with the appropriate Ministers.

The same situation applies to Aborigines. Today, one has to be very careful if the subject of Aborigines is brought up in conversation to avoid being labelled as a `boong-basher' or a `black lover'. We have reached such a paranoid state that Australia is quickly being divided into two camps and any rational discussion of such things as funding for Aboriginal projects is fraught with risks of accusations and exaggeration.

As I have said, I have been very disturbed for some time at what is clearly not a normal business practice in the funding and running of such farms as Nardoola and Trelawney. For those who do not know, these two properties are located in the north-western areas of the State that I represent. They are funded by grants from the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) and, by their very location and the nature of funding, they are scrutinised carefully by both black and white people in the community.

Nardoola was bought by the ADC for the Aboriginal community at a cost of nearly $600,000. What has happened there has created understandable anger and resentment. Over a period of four years we have witnessed that farm deteriorate from a viable rural enterprise to a wasted opportunity. Houses were burnt, materials were either sold or stolen and the place is generally run down, abused and neglected. Little if anything positive came out of it. By 1986 the value of that farm dropped from $600,000 to $261,000. Public money poured in to this undertaking at a time when farmers in the district were going out backwards because they could not get financial relief, schools in the district were fighting for every penny they could for equipment and hospitals were desperately short of staff and resources. But, in any case, there was no excuse under any circumstances for such a blatant misuse of public money-the taxpayers' money.

The ADC, for its part, justified this apparent failure by claiming the farm was never assessed for its commercial viability but, rather-and I quote from departmental advice-was regarded `as a social resource'. The fact that a viable operation was made in just four years a worthless, filthy mess appears not to worry the Department of Aboriginal Affairs at all. It is obvious why local feeling still runs high over the issue and the same resentment and anger would apply equally to a white man's project that was similarly abused.

The Oasis Hotel at Walgett is another example of lack of judgment, wasted public funding and local resident anger at such frivolous abuse of the public purse. The Oasis Hotel and the selection of appropriate people to run it also raise questions. A decision to hand the hotel over to the Barwon Aboriginal community, along with funds for operational purposes, was made earlier this year. There was concern at the time-and this concern continues-that the head of this group was not the most appropriate person to be running a hotel. There are allegations that the head of the Barwon community is facing a number of serious criminal charges, including assault. While this is common knowledge in the district, the Government, or at least the ADC, appears not to know or be concerned. I understand that that person is now not on that body.

People in the Walgett area also want to know why a high-speed sports boat was purchased for flood relief functions during the recent Walgett floods. I would have thought that, if such a boat were purchased, a speed boat would not be the most appropriate craft. I very much doubt that it would be the type of boat recommended for such a job. Where is the boat now, who is using it and for what purpose is it being used? Who paid for the boat and where did the money come from? Are taxpayers' funds being used in the best possible way?

I might point out that I am not the only person asking these questions. The Tamworth local Aboriginal Lands Council is also highly critical of the ADC. Its head, Mr Ivan Johnson, says that the ADC has ignored his group and poured money into unviable projects such as Nardoola and the Oasis Hotel when Aborigines in the area are homeless. He says:

We speak out for all Aborigines of Tamworth when we say you can't put all the homeless Aborigines into the hotel at Walgett or Nardoola or another broken down enterprise which was bought to help Aboriginal communities. Health, employment and housing are our main aims.
I wish this Government would correct the situation and put the money where it should be put-that is, into those areas.

When local Aborigines complain that the ADC does not listen to them and does nothing for them, one begins to realise the extent of the rot that has set in. If this is happening in one town in one State, what must be happening time and again throughout Australia? It is not just a case of a few dollars being unwisely spent; it is a massive misappropriation of funds. The most naive interpretation of the ADC's lack of judgment is clumsy ineptitude. There could be far more sinister reasons behind it.

The result in the meantime is two properties in northern New South Wales that have been allowed to become rural slums and a closed hotel into which hundreds of thousands of dollars have been poured for little result. The Government's investigations must put a stop to this sort of rorting of the system. This sort of thing does the Aboriginal community little good and a great deal of adverse publicity and bad feelings are generated. The situation cannot be allowed to continue. I am at a loss to understand how a Minister, who supposedly has had total responsibility for all that has gone on, has been able to keep his job. It is obvious the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, either did not know what was going on, and so should be sacked for incompetence, or he did know, but for whatever reasons did nothing about it, and so should be sacked for lack of action and unsound political judgment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take a few minutes afforded by this matter of public interest debate to mention some of the problems which I believe are still facing the car industry today. I think it is timely to make these remarks, given in the tabling yesterday in the Senate of the annual report of the Automotive Industry Authority. The Authority was established by the Government in October 1984 to oversee the implementation of the sectoral plan for the industry, now more commonly referred to as the Button car plan.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a concern, which I have expressed in this chamber when each previous report of the Authority has been tabled. The Authority publishes a document each year called Report on the state of the car industry which contains much useful information and statistics. However, the report of the Authority itself is fairly scant in its consideration of the state of the industry. It merely lists the balance sheet of the Authority, the membership and other short items.

This gives me the impression that the report is tabled each year only because of a statutory requirement. It does not even give a general picture of the industry. Nowhere does the report list the objectives of the Button car plan, nor does it report on the progress or implementation of the plan-both important elements which could be in the larger `state of the car industry' document and which, in my mind, are essential for any person who is really interested in the very existence of the Authority.

This very complex industry has been subject over the years to a degree of criticism, much of it well-founded but some of it is quite ignorant. The Prices Surveillance Authority recently undertook a reference into the price of replacement parts for motor cars. Some interesting remarks were made in its fourth government inquiry into car parts costs in the last 10 years. For instance, the average motor car is driven about 15,000 kilometres each year. Also, seven million cars are registered in Australia and this number grows by 3 per cent each year. Interestingly-and this reflects on the decline in the average man's standard of living over the past few years-the proportion of cars more than 10 years old has risen from 14 per cent to 30 per cent. We are becoming something like New Zealand. The spare parts market in this country is said to be worth about $2,600m per annum, added to which is another $2,000m for parts used in crash repairs.

It is also astounding to see the other statistics about the dramatic increase in the costs of motor vehicles. In 1984, the year in which the Button plan began, the price of a locally made six-cylinder family car was equivalent to 30.6 weeks of work for the average Australian, based on average weekly male earnings. In 1988 it took 41.4 weeks work to buy the cheapest Ford Falcon or Holden Commodore. It is true to say that a major reason for the increase in the cost of cars is the depreciation of the Australian currency, but there are other factors which play a role as well. If depreciation was the only factor, why would the price of television receivers, video cassette recorders and compact disc players be falling by as much as 10 per cent a year before inflation?

Many European and Japanese cars face a 42.5 per cent tariff and a 30 per cent sales tax which, in turn, makes them cripplingly expensive. For example, a Mercedes Benz 390E is priced at $70,000 in Australia but sells for $23,000 in West Germany-slightly more than the price here of a new base model Ford Falcon car. Similarly, the Mazda RX7 turbo sells in Australia for almost $53,650 while in Japan it costs $28,000.

The Button car plan is drawing to the end of its lifespan. Many people in the industry and I are concerned that despite what I believe to be a genuine attempt by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) to improve car manufacturing in Australia, the prices of Australian-made cars, imported cars and spare parts continue to rise at a much higher rate than earnings.

I believe that it is now time to look at some of the mechanisms available to us. For example, we could try to reduce the rate of the price hikes and to improve competition by reducing the level of the tariff and by making some quota adjustments. In fact, the industry remains fragile and, because of its size, can have a major effect on the general Australian economy. I hope that the concerns that I have drawn attention to are taken note of by the Authority and by the Minister who is responsible for this plan.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES AND NORTHERN TERRITORY GRANTS (RURAL ADJUSTMENT) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 November, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —During the time that is usually set aside for lunch today, the Senate will be debating quite significant legislation to which there will be no amendments and on which divisions will not be called. The Opposition parties and the Australian Democrats will be supporting the legislation so that it can, in effect, be pushed through. But the fact that these significant Bills are all being debated and pushed through during this lunchtime is a criticism of the Government's agenda. Frankly, the States and Northern Territory Grants (Rural Adjustment) Bill 1988 is an excellent example of significant legislation. The fact that the Government is allowing this legislation to go through without any major debate is an indication of its attitude towards these matters. As I have indicated, the Opposition does not oppose this legislation. However, because of the Government's ineptitude in arranging its business, we are forced to debate briefly this and other legislation that affects farmers.

SPEECH.PARA: In recent years, 2 to 3 per cent of farmers have left the land every year and today there are only 170,000 left in Australia. The productivity of those Australian farmers is between two and three times greater than in Australian industry generally. Yet, in 1985 the income of farmers in Australia as a whole was only one-third of average weekly earnings. This Government has placed heavy emphasis on restructuring of industry with little regard to the fact that manufacturing industries by comparison continue to be heavily protected. The Government has generated industry plans, such as the passenger motor vehicle plan, the textile, clothing and footwear plan and the steel plan, which include the acceptance of redundancy payments for those forced out of the industry. The aim of rural adjustment, which was introduced by the Menzies Government, is to accommodate and assist the adjustment process and alleviate the trauma of farmers not only leaving their occupation but also having to leave their homesteads.

The decision to restrict the Commonwealth's role to the setting of the broad guidelines and giving the States greater flexibility, management and financial responsibility under the guidelines, should stop the notorious buck-passing which has been so much a part of the Commonwealth-State relations and the objectives of the scheme are now much more clearly defined in this new legislation.

This Bill should facilitate structural change and assist, rather than impede, market forces. I hope that it will help the long term viability of those remaining in farming and lessen the trauma for those leaving the industry. Under the Bill, people will be able to receive household assistance for up to two years and those who choose to do so, subject of course to a means test, and who within six months realise that the sensible thing to do is to leave the farm, can receive assistance of up to $28,000. This means that such a person could leave the farm with a $28,000 grant plus up to $28,000 of his own original assets. This is not a lot of money, but at least it is some help to a farmer in dire straits; it is of some assistance in helping him to overcome the trauma of not only losing his occupation but also, as I have indicated, losing his home.

The Bill also ensures that those States that administer the scheme proficiently will benefit from the scheme, whilst the State which makes unwise decisions will have less money to assist those it is intended to benefit. That is, of course, a great incentive to better management by the States. Overall, as I have said, the Bill should stop the buck-passing and ensure smoother restructuring within the industry. I hope it will serve the farming community well. The Opposition supports the Bill.
