DEBATE.TITLE: TRITICALE LEVY BILL 1988TRITICALE LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1988RURAL INDUSTRIES RESEARCH AMENDMENT BILL 1988WHEAT MARKETING AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 November, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating cognately a package of rural industry related Bills-namely, the Triticale Levy Collection Bill 1988, the Triticale Levy Bill 1988, the Rural Industries Research Amendment Bill 1988 and the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1988. Of course, the major Bill is the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1988. This Bill implements those aspects of the McColl Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport relating to the development of a more cost effective grain distribution system by changing the terms of operation of the Australian Wheat Board. The Royal Commission made three sets of specific recommendations-one concerning storage and handling, one concerning land transport and one concerning ports and shipping. This legislation alters the requirements in respect of the Australian Wheat Board by removing the sole receiver requirement for the Board in dealing with wheat storage in each of the States-that is, it removes the State bulk handling monopoly for the storage of wheat relating to the Wheat Board in each State. Secondly, it requires the Wheat Board to maximise net returns to growers and, thirdly, it requires the Board to disaggregate costs. The Bill has the strong support of the Grains Council of Australia, the Australian Wheat Board and the Federal coalition.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation should not be confused with other wheat legislation that the Minister at the table, the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), tried to cast some aspersions on yesterday in answer to a dorothy dix question in this place. This Government is trying to deregulate the domestic wheat market by allowing the big boys to come in and grind some of the farmers into the ground and by using the first and the weakest seller as a basis for the floor price for wheat in Australia. That is different legislation altogether so I will not confuse anyone by referring to it at length. But the Opposition does support the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill, which is before us at the moment.

I would like to address myself to the triticale levy Bills. The triticale industry is a developing grain producing industry. Of course, those who were lucky enough to see the head of triticale that I produced in this chamber a few days ago now know a lot more about this grain than they did before. Triticale was developed by crossing wheat and rye and it is the hybrid of the genus name for the wheat triticum and rye secale. It can also be grown in a harsher or more marginal area than that used for wheat. Therefore, it is a little different from some of the other crops.

There have been a series of problems in producing a successful commercial crop of triticale and for the last 40 years scientists have spent endless hours trying to perfect the breeding of a satisfactory hybrid. Research has continued with little help from the Government until now. Of course, the Government has been responsible for the cancellation of many of the research activities related to farming that were carried out by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). But this Bill, which the Government is putting up, is going to help the triticale growers.

To date, there has been only a voluntary levy arrangement, and this is a credit to the growers. In line with the voluntary levy for research into chemical residues in our beef, our farming community has again shown that, unlike the Government, it is prepared to take responsibility for its own affairs. The farming community always takes responsibility for its own affairs and that is why it does not want to see a lot of changes to the wheat industry, which I should not even be talking about in this debate.

The legislative levy being discussed today is included in the special rural research funding arrangements and involves the Government matching the growers' contribution to research on a dollar for dollar basis. I understand that the legislative levy will raise some $160,000 from the growers and the same amount from the Government this year. The triticale industry will now deservedly receive funding under the legislation, similar to that covering the grain, legumes, cotton and sugar industries.

I support the comments that the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Murray, Mr Bruce Lloyd, made in the other place that rural people and industries which participate fully and readily, deserve this type of assistance. This Government stands condemned for its efforts to emasculate the farming industries. Although it deserves brickbats for what it is doing for the rest of the industry, it deserves a bit of praise in this instance because the legislation is a step in the right direction.

It must be said though that although the triticale industry is a relatively small industry, it does have the capacity to contribute significantly to the Australian domestic market. With further research and the establishment of a stable hybrid, it could also become quite valuable as an export product. We should not forget that the rural industry is worth $22 billion to this country and that its exports are worth $15 billion. In fact, it is not a case of riding on the sheep's back-the whole of this country rides on the back of primary products. The efficiency and the competitiveness of our primary industries are vital to Australia's future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I thank Senator Panizza for that comment. The voice of the rural industries in this place is sometimes not heard. It is nice to hear from the honourable senator who always does his bit for Western Australia despite the fact that the Government is not always happy to do something for our export industries. Because of what has happened in the area of scientific research in our country during the last few years, and particularly during 1988, we must be aware that there are, and will continue to be, serious consequences for the rural industries. I have already mentioned the cuts that have been made in respect of the CSIRO.

SPEECH.PARA: The Rural Industries Research Amendment Bill 1988, which is also being addressed today, amends the principal Act by seeking to include Commonwealth seeding funding for the triticale industry under current funding arrangements for Australian rural research. I have read some of the speeches that were made in the other place. I note the honourable member for Wannon, Mr Hawker, made some quite strong comments about what the Hawke Government has done to the rural people of Australia since it came to power. There has been a $37m cut in the superphosphate bounty subsidy; a $50m cut in road funding, a $109m cut in a depreciation allowance; and a $124m increase in levies and charges for the farming communities. There has been a 4.5 per cent increase in fuel excise and a $5.4m cut in assistance for isolated children. This is a real kick in the teeth for all the people who live outside the major metropolitan areas of this great country of ours. Approximately $1 billion has been removed from the primary sector since the Labor Government came to power. Primary industry needs support and encouragement; it needs to be encouraged further so that investment and production will increase.

As I said earlier, primary industry is definitely being affected by CSIRO cuts. That premier research organisation is finding it increasingly difficult to keep up with the rest of the world in the field of research. In fact, the problems created by the CSIRO cuts have been raised often in this place. Only in August of this year the Government cut another $8.7m off the CSIRO. Research must continue; if it does so with Government assistance. I congratulate the triticale growers on their initiative and their support for attempts to legislate in respect of research funding for this product.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to direct most of my remarks in this cognate debate to the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1988, the provisions of which represent the first stage of the Government's planned deregulation of the domestic wheat market. As Senator Brownhill has said, this legislation is a result of the recommendations of the McColl Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport which was presented to the Government earlier this year along with the Industry Assistance Commission report into wheat marketing. The royal commission, of course, found the existing system of grain distribution to be `highly regulated and dominated by a small number of bulk handling, rail, port and marketing authorities' with `inadequate incentives for efficiency'. It found that most grain was channelled along a restricted number of predetermined paths, the cost of moving grain therefore being higher than it would otherwise be, and that prices rarely reflected the actual cost of providing the related service.

SPEECH.PARA: The commission saw a number of ways of bringing about a more efficient and cost-effective method of grain distribution to meet Australia's future needs. It recommended that marketing authorities should undertake to minimise their costs to growers and reflect in returns to each grower the actual charges incurred by that grower for storage, handling and transport services; that competition in storage and handling services be introduced by removing the restriction to only one licensed receiver in each State; and that port services and sea transport charges be disaggregated. The royal commission also recommended that greater competition be encouraged between land transport and rail services through the removal of restrictions precluding the use of road transport and by the `commercialisation' of rail freight services in addition to port authorities, in order to bring about greater competition in the provision of those port services.

This legislation is supported by the Opposition parties, the Australian Wheat Board, the Grains Council of Australia and the farming community. The Australian Democrats do not oppose it. The Bill has adopted those recommendations over which the Commonwealth has jurisdiction. It provides for the Australian Wheat Board to enter into contracts for services relating to the distribution of grain with whomever it chooses, rather than being required to nominate a sole authorised receiver of grain in each State, as is presently the case. This will provide the Australian Wheat Board with the flexibility to employ those agencies which can provide, in its view, the most efficient service at the least cost to growers.

In addition, the Board is required, firstly, to provide growers those disaggregated charges which were recommended for the handling, storage and transport of their grain so that they can make choices as to the grain path which attracts the least cost. Secondly, it is required to minimise its distribution costs and to reflect in its returns to each grower the actual charges.

While the provisions contained in this legislation will go some of the way towards creating the conditions to bring about greater returns to growers, most of the royal commission's recommendations cover transport, ports and shipping, which fall within the ambit of State responsibility where 80 per cent of the estimated national savings of $10 a tonne will have to be achieved. The royal commission saw this as happening through the lifting of restrictions on road transport, through the removal of State rail monopolies and by addressing the problems of restrictive work practices and industrial disputes that occur, mainly on the waterfront but also in the rail systems, to ensure that the enormous costs flowing back from such practices are reduced.

Those recommendations of the royal commission have met with mixed reaction from the States. Both the New South Wales Government and the New South Wales Grain Handling Authority support the recommendations. Bulk handling authorities in other States, particularly in South Australia and Western Australia, after initial reservations have, I think, come to accept that they are actually well placed to continue as major providers of bulk storage and handling services. In most States, with the exception of South Australia, which is, of course, serviced by Australian National, there is understandable concern among rail authorities about the prospect of the removal of their monopoly over the transport of grain, and the Australian Railways Union in particular has voted its strong opposition to transport deregulation.

The Grains Council of Australia and the Australian Road Transport Federation have made various suggestions about transport reforms. The issue of damage of roads as a result of an increase in traffic has been raised. The royal commission, when addressing this matter, recommended that an efficient road user charging system be introduced whereby the costs of road damage are paid for by those road users that create the costs. Local councils have expressed concern with regard to road funding.

In his second reading speech, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) envisaged a reallocation between road and rail to make sure that each part of the task is handled by whichever body is best suited to carry it out. It is a fact that the legislation before us does not of itself deregulate grain transport and the political actions which will be necessary to do that will be taken at other levels. Of course, the States and local authorities will have to act and make their voices heard. I put on the record that the Australian Democrats take quite seriously the concerns expressed by local government in this area, especially when we look at the recommendations of the Grains Council, the Australian Road Transport Federation and others.

We also have questions about the user-pays charging system which was referred to by the royal commission and which is referred to from time to time by the deregulators in this area. If such a system involves fuel excise, local councils will say that they want a higher proportion of the money collected under this user pays system to go into road funding. Legislation which will come before the Senate in the next two weeks actually provides for a 10 per cent reduction in the current charge of 5.59c a litre. This Government is not taking that into account. The Democrats support local governments' views in this matter. The Grains Council, which proposed an increased larger transport capacity, is obviously not taking those issues into account as much as it ought to be.

The royal commission has been vague. As far as the Democrats are concerned, State railways are the very best way that we can address the problem of road damage and road use. But, of course, they must be efficient. Unfortunately, railway lines are being ripped up all over the country. This has been a bipartisan exercise. As a Victorian, I have watched Liberal governments preside over the ripping up of branch rail systems. This practice, which has been continued under Labor governments, casts doubt on the claims by the royal commission and the Government of savings which they say will make up for losses that will be incurred if deregulation of the domestic market takes place as the Government is proposing.

One of the reasons the Australian Democrats will not be supporting that deregulation is that the costs will far outweigh the benefits in our view. It will be interesting to see whether Senator Brownhill's sentiments and those of the National Party of Australia are carried through in coalition policy which, no doubt, will not be revealed to us until the Western Australian election.

I would like to link my comments on the triticale Bills with some comments I want to make on the Rural Industries Research Amendment Bill that is also part of this package. Senator Brownhill told us some interesting and relevant facts about the development of triticale. This promising product has been developed over several decades as a result of research in the rural area and we all regret that research is being cut back by this Government. This research was paid for out of the public purse. When the Australian Democrats alone attempted to stand up against the introduction of plant variety rights in this place, we said and warned at that time that public sector research funding in this area would be reduced, and it has. I think triticale is proof positive that we have, in the past, been able to undertake research and development and develop new products in the rural area. Triticale is of course, a hybrid, so there was never any need for plant patenting. I simply put on record that our warnings about reductions in research funding are becoming a reality. We also share the views of all of those in the community who regret the reduction in research funding and, in particular, in rural research funding, which is taking place in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating a package of Bills which includes the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1988. Of course, as Senator Brownhill has already pointed out, the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill should not be confused with the wheat marketing system which may change next year. The name of the Bill is certainly a misnomer. In fact, it has nothing to do whatsoever with wheat marketing. Nonetheless, it is important.

SPEECH.PARA: I object to the Bill being debated in this way in this chamber at this hour of the day. This Bill is the most significant thing that has happened in the handling of grain since 1947. However, legislation concerning an industry which handles Australia's second biggest agricultural product, worth $3 billion this year, is being rushed through in the lunch hour, with each speaker being given a minimal time in which to speak. I think it is a disgrace that the people who are responsible for Government business should allow this to happen. Although we spent an hour this morning discussing Mr Hayden's trip, we are now shoving through at lunch time the most important Bill for 41 years on the handling of grain.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should not have wasted an hour this morning.
—I do not know how much time was taken this morning. As I say, the biggest change since 1947 has been shoved through in this way.

SPEECH.PARA: In effect, this Bill seeks to do away with the need to appoint a sole receiver in each State. For all its shortcomings, the Bill is the result of the McColl Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport. That inquiry dealt with nothing else but wheat handling, storage and transport. A lot of people around this country and in this Parliament would have liked it to have looked at marketing. However, the Government is trying to use the recommendations of the royal commission as an excuse to deregulate the domestic market. As far as I am concerned, a lot of water will flow under the bridge before this proposition sees the light of day.

Along with my Opposition colleagues, I support the Bill. I believe that no person in this place is more qualified than I am in this area, having regard to my hands-on experience in grain handling and storage in the last 30-odd years. I go back to the 1950s when I started my long discourse with Cooperative Bulk Handling Ltd (CBH) of Western Australia. That contact has continued ever since.

To date, each State has had a sole receiver. Western Australia leads Australia in the bulk handling of grain, commencing in 1926 with the formation of Cooperative Bulk Handling, a cooperative solely made up of growers. South Australia later copied Western Australia and its system is probably as good as ours in Western Australia. Queensland also has a cooperative and Victoria and New South Wales have government instrumentalities. Incidentally, both of these systems leave a lot to be desired.

The cooperative idea is a good one. This is what got CBH off the ground in the first place. Of course, being a cooperative, CBH has virtually unlimited money raising powers. A good example of this was the funding by CBH of the Kwinana terminal in the mid-1970s out of the second advance of the previous season. This arrogant attitude by CBH meant that some of the money that was used came from growers who had already sold their farms at the end of the previous season and would never use those facilities again.

It is now time to do away with the sole receiver. The main reasons are: firstly, the total breakdown in New South Wales and the partial breakdown in Victoria, to which Senator Powell alluded some time ago; and, secondly, the need for competition in other States. My experience has shown that cooperatives, although a good way to start a new system, do not reach full efficiency. This is because certain work practices creep in and directors are inward thinking. Using strict receival hours of seven to 12 and one to six during week days and seven to 12 on Saturdays in busy times and eight to 12 and one to six in less busy times, may have been okay when the crop was harvested at a much slower pace in about two to three months. But the crop now comes off in a third of that time and, of course, a bottleneck results. The board of management of CBH in Western Australia has been insensitive to a call for change and it is time that it received a bit of medicine by way of competition. I have been working on this matter since 1982 and this chain of events was probably responsible for my decision to stand for election to this place.

CBH has been insensitive to change in respect of rail freight. For example, this year in my town a private buyer of feed wheat set up under permit a 5,000-tonne facility which can receive 24 hours a day, seven days a week. The silo can be filled in one week. Of course, other practices remain, such as staffing levels which are far too high in the off-season. Competition will get rid of a lot of those sorts of things. Also a new warehousing wheat system that was introduced this year will cut out a lot of inefficiencies that have crept into the system. These inefficiencies include multiple handling of grain when no incentive exists to deliver to bins on the main line rather than on branch lines.

The Bill also seeks the deregulation, with the help of the States, of the transport of grain. Of course, the States have to pass complementary legislation to do that. As I was saying, I have been working on transport deregulation for the last five years. Westrail has always used a grain freight as a tax to balance its books. Farmers who do not use their own transport are, by regulation, required to use rail if they are more than 100 kilometres from the ports in Western Australia. In other words, long haulage is geographically regulated to rail. When we finally got the Western Australian Government to deregulate in some trial areas, the price at some sidings dropped overnight from $25 per tonne to $14 per tonne, but there is a long way to go.

I could go on all day, Mr Acting Deputy President, but my time is limited. Other measures, such as the new standards of vehicle loading along with the introduction of B-doubles-a configuration of trailers that allows a maximum pay load with minimum tare weight-will help in this area. As has already been pointed out, more road funding will be needed if competition is to be improved. Government should be looking towards funding local roads. We all know what this Government has done in the area of road funding in the last four years.

I will just briefly mention the Triticale Levy Bill 1988. For the information of this Senate, triticale has been around since the time of the Egyptians and the Romans. So it has not been developed in the last five, 10 or 20 years, as has been suggested here today. The Triticale Levy Collection Bill 1988 will raise some $165,000 for research which will be matched by the Government.

Triticale has a place in the export trade. The amount of this grain grown by farmers has gradually increased over the last five years. I think mention has been made that the value of the crop is $15m to $20m. This worthwhile grain is grown mainly for the feed, although it can be used in the manufacture of certain sorts of breads. I consider that it has a future. This grain, which has a protein content of up to 18 per cent in certain cases, can be grown on poorer soils and as an alternative crop. In closing, I again express my disgust that this important package of Bills is being debated in this fashion and at this time of the day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have taken note of the contributions of several senators in this debate. I thank them all for participating. The Government has noted their views and I have nothing further to add.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 November, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Amendment Bill 1988, but again draws the attention of the Senate to the fact that the Government has not brought this legislation forward in its agenda in sufficient time to allow a proper and adequate debate on what is a very important issue.

SPEECH.PARA: In Australia we have declining oil reserves combined with a massive fall in the return on investment because of the dramatic fall in oil prices. The Government's policies provide no decent incentives to further exploration. It is clear that the Government does not want a full-scale debate on the issues involved because that would reveal its lack of foresight and the fact that its policies are not generating renewed exploration. The placing of this Bill in the Government's agenda demonstrates the tiredness and ineptitude of this Government and its Ministers and how much out of touch they are with the people of this nation.

The Opposition is desperately concerned about the predictions of the fall in oil production in Australia over the next decade and the consequences for this nation of the need to import oil to replace the oil which we will not be producing by the year 2000. This Government's policies are not doing anything about solving that problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Lewis has said, the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Amendment Bill 1988 is fairly uncontentious. But the same cannot be said of the crude oil industry's draconian tax regime. Like Senator Lewis, I would have preferred a much longer debate on this very serious question. The crude oil industry is the most heavily taxed industry in Australia. It pays about 69c in the dollar in taxation. In addition to the normal corporate rate of tax of 49 per cent, there is a whole arsenal of secondary taxes, including a government royalty of 10 to 12.5 per cent of wellhead value on established onshore and offshore areas and an excise on crude oil and certain offshore liquid petroleum gas production.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's latest exercise in creative taxation has produced the resource rental tax for offshore greenfield areas and cash bonus bidding on so-called highly prospective acreages in Australia. To cap this all off, there is the 20c a litre excise paid by the motorist-the Australian consumer. The so-called windfall tax gains from rising oil prices in the late 1970s, which triggered the introduction of secondary taxes, have well and truly disappeared, but the taxes remain. During the oil shocks of the 1970s the price, for example, of Saudi Arabian light crude was in excess of $US30 a barrel. A couple of weeks ago crude oil was languishing at about $US10 a barrel and it is presently about $US14.

The Australian industry has been hit particularly hard this year. Not only has it suffered the worldwide slump in oil prices, it has been crucified by an appreciating Australian dollar. The net result has been a 34 per cent drop in the price of Australian crude oil in 1988. Yet, despite this price collapse, the Government continues to use the oil industry as a milch cow.

People on the other side of the chamber, and particularly the Australian Democrats, often make the point that when Opposition senators speak on this subject they are simply acting as lobbyists for the oil companies. Nothing could be further from the truth. When we complain about these gross secondary levels of taxation, we are acting as lobbyists for Australia. What we are confronting is probably the most serious problem this nation will confront from about 1992 onwards-and that is, a looming oil crisis.

In these high-taxing times of the Hawke Government, soaring taxation has been a fact of life. I suppose there is nothing unusual about that-everyone has copped it. But what makes taxation of the oil industry especially worrying is the fact that we are running out of oil and these punitive secondary taxes on the crude oil industry are just more nails in the coffin of Australia's energy self-sufficiency. In 1985 Australia was about 100 per cent self-sufficient in oil, but existing reserves are now expected to supply only 25 per cent of the demand by the year 2000. What does this mean? It means that if by the year 2000 we are to be 50 per cent self-sufficient, we will need to discover in excess of a billion barrels of oil before the end of the century.

The Australian crude oil industry has calculated that $26 billion, more than $2 billion a year, will have to be spent on oil exploration and 1,400 wildcat wells will have to be drilled if we are to achieve just 50 per cent of oil sufficiency. However, a combination of the drastic fall in the price of oil and those secondary taxes has meant that exploration of this magnitude is simply not happening. It just cannot happen. The Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), who is at the table, recently described the outlook for the petroleum exploration industry in 1989 as good, especially in the Timor Sea. I do not disagree with that. But I think we are seeing coming to fruition the plans that were put into place some time ago. One just does not bring an offshore drilling rig in with a month's notice.

I note, from the Minister's Energy 2000-type presentation, that he admits the fact that we are going to be short of oil. He thinks that what is happening in the Timor Sea and an expansion of the sale of our coal to the Northern Hemisphere countries will enable us to cope with this shortage. He might have to have a second think when the Northern Hemisphere countries start to do something about their concerns about the greenhouse effect from the burning of hydrocarbons. I agree that there is little the Government can do about fluctuating commodity prices. But there is plenty it can do about the industry's taxation burden. The Australian oil industry's tax regime needs an urgent rethink by the Government. Senator Cook in a press release of 24 November, said:
Clearly, I will be keeping a close eye on exploration trends to ensure that we have the best policies in place.
He then went on to say:
At present we do.

We question that statement very seriously because there is no doubt that the present taxation policies are a great disincentive to new exploration in our effort to find more oil. Of course, the position is exacerbated by our current account deficit. According to this morning's press, we currently have a net foreign debt of $93 billion a year. The October figures indicate that that debt is increasing at the rate of $1,685 billion a month, which is in fact $65m a day-

Mr Acting Deputy President, I am sure you will agree that this figure can be more easily understood; the other figures are too big to contemplate. There is no doubt that there is a critical lack of oil. The highest taxing Government in Australia's history must stop killing off our major export and import replacement industries with secondary and excessive taxation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have noted the comments of Senator Lewis and Senator Parer. I thank them for those comments, most of which were not directed to the Bill as such. However, they both indicated that they supported the legislation which I suspect we will dispose of shortly.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Parer raised some matters which perhaps I can very briefly comment on, given that I am the Minister responsible in this Government for energy policy. I might say that, as a Minister, one sometimes feels somewhat frustrated about not having opportunities to more adequately canvass with the Opposition the detail of energy policy in Australia. There is a need for constructive debate because, although we expect to be in government certainly until the end of the century and maybe beyond, eventually it may be possible that the Opposition will take over the treasury bench. If that occurs, it is important that the energy policy be a consistent one for the nation.

I just want to comment very briefly that it is true that oil producers in Australia are taxed more heavily than are other industries. For a start, they pay company taxation. However, the ordinary citizens of this country, who in fact own the resource-in this case, oil-under the land or under the sea, are entitled to an income from the exploitation of what is a rare and depleting resource. They are entitled to an income for leasing off the development, and the ability to make a profit out of that development, to producers. That is to say, there is an element of what the economists would call `public good' in the taxation that is imposed on top of normal company taxation so that the community can benefit from the exploitation of a rare and as I have said, depleting resource. That is the first point I make.

The second point I make concerns our ability to remain self-sufficient in oil. We are now about 90 per cent self-sufficient. By the end of this century, depending on what we find, we will be between 30 and 50 per cent self-sufficient. That has implications certainly for our ability to sustain our normal standard of living without needing large imports of oil or, importantly, without using alternative transport fuels obtained from the conversion of natural gas, the liquefaction of coal, the development of ethanol and so on. I might say that all of those three possibilities are real and ought not be dismissed.

Three things govern the development of oil in Australia. The first is the price per barrel-that is, the incentive for commercial operators to develop their finds and make a profit. That price, as we know, has gone downwards rapidly and is still very low. Although the price has gone up a few notches following the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries meeting in Vienna, which was completed this week, it is still extraordinarily low. While the price is low, the incentive for commercial operators to try to develop reserves is also low.

Prospectivity is the second reason why people get into oil development. What is the prospectivity of Australia? The prospectivity of Australia is still reasonably good. Many areas of Australia have not been adequately prospected. Indeed the Timor Sea beckons as a region in this country where prospectivity is high. There are seven off-shore rigs operating in the Timor Sea on oil exploration as we speak. When we conclude, as we will next year, the terms of agreement between the Indonesian Government and the Australian Government on developing the Timor Gap-the disputed territory between Australia and Indonesia-the prospectivity will increase.

The third area is cost. It is under the question of cost that the taxation debate arises and I have referred to that. If one were economically rational and wanted to make a sensible choice in terms of energy policy, the best thing to do would be to leave our oil in the ground and buy from overseas when the international price of crude oil is very low, as it is now. That would be the most rational thing to do. Then, when the price rises, we would be able to be self-sufficient in terms of the oil we have here now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sounds like Rex Connor.

—I am just putting a rational argument. I am not taking into account the wider concerns about keeping fuel moving. There are other concerns about the question of the impact on the balance of payments, which is an important consideration; the loss of revenue to the Government; and our ability to meet expenditures for our social justice programs, education, defence, social welfare and all the other areas we are fitted with and take responsibility for. So I just make those points which I know are not relevant to the Bill. I must say that the bait held out by Senator Parer was overpowering for me. I am grateful to him in that he gave me the opportunity to make those points.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 picks up a range of unrelated issues in the portfolio of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin). It covers repeal of canned fruits legislation, amendments to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act, the Export Control Act, the Fishing Industry Research and Development Act, the Meat Inspection Act, the Minerals (Submerged Lands) Act, the Plant Variety Rights Act, the Wool Marketing Act, the Dairy Produce Act, the Rural Industries Research Act and even the Pig Industry Act.

SPEECH.PARA: While the use of omnibus Bills is appropriate for dealing with minor items, the inclusion in this Bill of legislation which terminates the stabilising marketing arrangements which have been in existence for many years for the fruit canning industry is clearly inappropriate and obviously a device by the Government to obviate adequate debate on this very important measure.

My colleague in the other place the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) detailed at length why the use of an omnibus Bill was inappropriate to deal with these issues and, in the time available for this debate, it would be impossible even briefly to cover the ground. The Opposition does not oppose the legislation but, again, draws the attention of farmers, fishermen, orchardists and canners to the cavalier approach adopted by this Government to their problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
