QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNIVERSITY OF NEW SOUTH WALES: EDUCATIONAL TELEVISION LICENCE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer the Minister to a decision of the Department of Transport and Communications to refuse to renew an educational television licence held by the University of New South Wales for 23 years. Is not this decision inconsistent with both the Government's policy on broadcasting to provide more diverse television services and the stated aim of its education and training policy? How does the Government justify holding the noose around the necks of universities by having the Minister for Employment, Education and Training demanding that they become more outward-looking while another Minister's department is preventing such initiatives occurring in policy areas such as communications? Will universities be granted access to broadcasting licences according to their educational functions, or will they have to compete with other potential public broadcasters for licences? Finally, how long will groups wishing to be involved in public broadcasting have to wait before the Government ends its vacillation on its public television policy?
—I am afraid I have no knowledge of the matter to which Senator Lewis refers, nor any brief on it. I will seek an early reply.

—Has the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade seen reports of proposed measures in South Africa which would require groups or individuals in South Africa to disclose foreign funding to the Government? What would be the Australian Government's attitude to such measures?

—I have seen press reports that a committee of the South African Parliament has published the text of a disclosure of foreign funding Bill which would allow the South African Government to require organisations or individuals to reveal the source, the amount and the purpose of foreign funding. The report states that a special registrar, reporting to the Justice Minister, would check how foreign funds were being used. Under the special assistance program for South Africans and Namibians, known as SAPSAN, Australia is providing significant development assistance to South Africans who are disadvantaged by apartheid. This amounts to some $7.5m over five years beginning in 1986. The program in South Africa is directed in particular at providing scholarships for tertiary study, teacher upgrading and other educational assistance, as well as trade union training and urban and rural community development. Similar aid is provided by other Western governments, including the British, the Federal Republic of Germany and other European Community countries, the United States of America and Canada. The Government would be most concerned if state controls were now to be used in South Africa to inhibit the flow of Australian aid to disadvantaged South Africans. We have already made our concern known to the South African Government. We will continue to monitor the progress of the current legislation and to register our ongoing interest and concern.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and it relates to the Government's failure to honour a commitment given to the over 2,600 members of the Australian Federal Police when it established the Australian Federal Police (AFP) charter of objectives in 1985. That charter stated in part that the Australian Federal Police would be the Commonwealth's primary law enforcement agency and that efficient recruitment, training and personnel management systems would be developed to ensure the attainment of those objectives. Is the Minister aware that for the period from 1979 to the present day over 53 per cent of invalidity retirements from the Australian Federal Police involved anxiety and depression as the major cause, compared with the Commonwealth Public Service average of 29 per cent? Is the Minister also aware that the invalidity rate for Australian Federal Police members up to the age of 35 is six times higher than the Public Service average? Does the Minister acknowledge that these figures highlight the extremely low morale and frustration being experienced by members of the Federal Police over this Government's lack of compassion for the stresses which they are being placed under in their daily jobs? Further, can the Minister explain why the Government has failed to implement the findings of the working party investigation into deficiencies in the Australian Federal Police superannuation arrangements, which investigation was instigated by this Government in December 1985 and completed in August 1987? For the benefit of the Minister, I point out that that report came down overwhelmingly in favour of a separate superannuation scheme to meet the specialised needs of the Australian Federal Police.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would not be surprising, in the field of policing, given the particularly dangerous operations in which police might be involved, that a certain level of stress, beyond that which is the norm in the Public Service as a whole, does occur. It seems to me to be just a matter of commonsense that the peculiar pressures to which the police are subjected, not only in the operational sense but, as is well documented, in the way in which members of the community can regard the police, could lead to the sorts of figures to which Senator Calvert points. But I most emphatically deny that this Government has not been conscious of the need to evolve within the Australian Federal Police a set of objectives and a management structure which will enable its members to get the greatest possible satisfaction out of the tasks which they are asked to undertake on behalf of the community. Indeed, it is to that end that many of the functions which the Federal Police formerly held have been stripped away from them so that members can see themselves, outside of the community policing role in the Australian Capital Territory, as forming an investigative agency nationwide, with the resources, training and personnel to give it a real edge as the pre-eminent law enforcement agency in the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.PARA: I am surprised that Senator Calvert-perhaps because he has been reading the law and justice policy of the Opposition-is not aware of the fact that we have tried to limit the functions of the Australian Federal Police in the national sense to those detective and investigative duties which are so important for the successful combating of organised crime, drug trafficking and major fraud against the Commonwealth. Indeed, it is interesting that the law and justice policy document put out by the Opposition only a couple of weeks ago speaks of the Australian Federal Police being responsible for-this is no doubt Senator Hill and Mr Brown's work-security and protection functions at Parliament House, international airports, some diplomatic and consular missions and specified Commonwealth properties. That is completely wrong. It is true that the Australian Federal Police still retain a role at international airports and at some few specified Commonwealth properties.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is whether they should be responsible for that.

—Senator Hill has made a terrible error. He has said that the Australian Federal Police are involved in the guarding of Parliament House, for example, which they are certainly not, and are involved in guarding consular and diplomatic missions, which they are certainly not. So the Opposition has put out a law and justice policy document which bears no relation to the facts as to the tasks undertaken by the Australian Federal Police. I have talked to many members of the Australian Federal Police, in particular over the winter recess, leading up to the annual conference of the Australian Federal Police Association and the dinner I attended at the Manly Police Staff College. My experience is that the Australian Federal Police Association and its members perceive the move of the Federal Police in the direction of becoming the pre-eminent law enforcement agency, by reason of concentrating on investigation and detective work, as the way to go in order to give them greater job satisfaction, which I believe will lead to the sort of good morale which is so important in any force.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. In case the Minister cannot remember my question, I asked about the failure of the Government to instigate recommendations on the superannuation scheme for the Australian Federal Police. How does the Minister justify the current position where members of the AFP who feel the necessity to retire five years early, at age 55, attract superannuation benefits which are similar to other Commonwealth employees retiring 10 years early-that is, 36 per cent of salaries for 30 years' service? AFP members are discriminated against in their superannuation scheme. Can the Minister answer these queries?

—As is well known, the whole question of superannuation benefits available to Commonwealth employees is being comprehensively reviewed under the aegis of my friend and colleague the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh. I believe that that review will properly take account of the special factors relating to the Australian Federal Police. About this time last year-in the week or so before Christmas-Senator Walsh agreed to a proposal I put up to enable a special cessation payment to be given to members of the Australian Federal Police which takes account of the fact that they do have to retire earlier than general public servants, who are able to make their superannuation contributions up to the age of 65. As a result of negotiations between Senator Walsh and myself, this special cessation scheme was brought into operation for the AFP just before Christmas last year. But that does not deal with the overall, wider question of superannuation. That is being looked at and I believe that there will be a favourable outcome.

—Is the Minister for Finance aware of the revelations at the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct in Queensland on Tuesday, 29 November 1988 which indicate that government contracts worth millions of dollars were let to a French construction company, Citra, after the said company had made donations of $250,000 to the Queensland branch of the National Party of Australia? A number of these government contracts could involve Federal funds, for such projects as the upgrading of the Bruce Highway, which was worth $3,045,000 in November 1983; the Western arterial road project, worth $2,376,000 in December 1983; and the Gateway arterial road, worth $2,600,000 in September 1984. Can the Minister investigate in order to ascertain whether Federal funds allocated for public works in Queensland are let on the basis of a proper tendering system and not on the basis of bribery and corruption? If the Minister finds that Federal funds for public works in Queensland are being let on the basis of bribery and corruption, what action will the Federal Government take to stop Queensland National Party's Corruption Incorporated misusing Australian Government funds?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the allegations. Apart from the specific ones to which Senator Schacht referred, I have in front of me a copy of today's Courier-Mail which reports the former National Party trustee, Sir Edward Lyons, telling the inquiry on Tuesday that in 1983 he asked a Citra representative to donate funds to the National Party. The article said:

ANSWER.PARA: Sir Edward said the company subsequently gave the Nationals $250,000 in cash, before the October 1983 State election.
In the next month, Citra had received two State Government contracts. One was a $3 million Bruce Highway upgrading and the other was the $2.5 million Bundaberg Hospital job.

The $2.5m contract in question was let after the Bjelke-Petersen Cabinet had overruled the decision of the Bundaberg Hospital Board to award the contract to the lowest tender. As I said, that was overruled by the Bjelke-Petersen Government and the contract was awarded to Citra.

There is a prima facie case to support the proposition that these contracts were determined not by commercial merit but by political bribes. Almost certainly the Bruce Highway construction, which was mentioned by Senator Schacht, involved some Commonwealth funds. However, I do not think that there is anything we can do after the event to ensure that Commonwealth taxpayers' funds are not misused by the Queensland National Party machine. I have long been concerned about the one area of Commonwealth Government expenditure for which I have direct ministerial responsibility-that is, the national disaster relief arrangements. There has been clear misuse of those funds in the past by the Queensland State Government.

The question also obviously embraces funding under the roads program and the hospitals program. I do not think we can do anything to get back the money that has already been spent, but I will certainly speak to the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Willis, and the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, to see whether they have any views on how we can tighten up on maladministration, which clearly has occurred in Queensland over the national disaster relief arrangements. There is also a prima facie case that there has been maladministration in these other areas.

Finally, I wish to put on the record that the highway contract and the Bundaberg hospital contract have the same sort of reek about them as the awarding of a contract to an Italian company to build the middle section of the gas pipeline from Dampier to Perth in 1981 or 1982. There was a prima facie case of that contract having been awarded on corrupt grounds by the O'Connor Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to an executive order signed on 18 November by President Reagan, part 21 of which authorises the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) to `recapture' plutonium and enriched uranium from civilian nuclear power plants for use in nuclear weapons. I further note that the main military reactors run by the United States to produce nuclear weapons fuel have been closed down due to grave health and safety risks and that future supplies of weapons-grade plutonium and uranium from those sources are not assured. Does the executive order remove any distinction between the civilian and military uses of nuclear energy in the United States? Would the recapture of Australian-origin nuclear material from civilian plants by the NRC violate the 1981 bilateral safeguards agreement between the United States and Australia? Does the order mean that all Australian uranium exported to the United States now has a dual military-civilian purpose, in violation of the safeguards agreement? Will the Government cancel future uranium shipments to the United States and arrange the return of all Australian-origin nuclear material in the United States in accordance with article 11 of the agreement. Finally, given the crisis in the United States nuclear weapons industry, is the seizure of civilian nuclear materials for the United States nuclear weapons program imminent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The executive order to which Senator Sanders refers updates earlier executive orders to similar effect dating back to 1954 which call upon United States departments and agencies to develop contingency plans to ensure continuity of government in the event of a national security emergency in the United States. The plans are administrative arrangements, not policy decisions, and could not be put into effect without appropriate enabling legislation from Congress.

ANSWER.PARA: Against that background the answers to Senator Sanders's specific questions are as follows: First, no, the executive order does not remove the distinction between civilian and military uses of nuclear energy in the United States. In answer to the second question relating to the recapture of Australian-origin nuclear material from civilian plants, I point out that all Australian-obligated nuclear material in the United States is subject to the United States-Australia nuclear safeguards agreement under which the United States has accepted binding treaty level obligations to use this material for exclusively peaceful purposes. The Australian Government has every confidence that the United States will continue to honour these obligations. The answer to the third question is no, the order does not mean that all Australian uranium exported to the United States has a dual military-civilian purpose. The conditions set down in the bilateral nuclear safeguards agreement clearly restrict use to peaceful, non-explosive purposes. Fourthly, the Government sees no need to cancel future uranium shipments to the United States nor to arrange the return of Australian-obligated nuclear material from the United States. Finally, the Government is aware that the future shape of the nuclear weapons industry in the United States is currently under consideration by the United States Administration but this does not mean the seizure of civilian nuclear materials for the United States weapons program is either imminent or likely.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. How can the Minister guarantee that the legislation which would be necessary would take into account Australian safeguard provisions?

—It is a treaty obligation of which the United States in the past has always been respectful. Unless the honourable senator's confidence in his country is totally lacking I think both of us would assume that the willingness to observe treaty obligations would continue in the future.

—I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to the recent elections in Pakistan for the position of Prime Minister as well as for local parliamentary representatives. I also refer to the fact that this is the first democratic election held in Pakistan in over a decade. My question to the Minister is: Does he welcome these democratic elections? Will he assure the new, democratically elected Government in Pakistan of Australia's support?

—The Australian Government very warmly welcomed the holding of democratic elections in Pakistan and the opportunity they provided for all Pakistanis to participate in the running of their country. We congratulate Ms Benazir Bhutto on her success in gaining the largest number of seats in those elections. We now understand that, after an obviously somewhat protracted process, the Acting President of Pakistan is likely to call on Ms Bhutto later today to form a government. Australia looks forward very much to working with Ms Bhutto's democratically elected government and to a continuation of the friendly and cooperative relations enjoyed by our two countries.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY COMMISSION: STAFF EXPENDITURES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. During the recent hearings of Estimates Committee A, evidence was given that a deputy director of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission had spent $22,299.69-an amount higher than all employees' average weekly earnings-on first-class air fares and travel allowance for travel to his office in Sydney from his home in Canberra. The Committee was also told that this expenditure was only for the period from 8 January to 18 October this year and that the reason it was incurred was that the officer concerned apparently did not want to move to Sydney. Can the Minister tell me whether the deputy director is still commuting between Canberra and Sydney? If so, will the Government do anything to stop this blatant abuse? Can the Minister tell me whether the Government has sought an explanation from the Commission for this obvious misuse of taxpayers' money? What action will the Government be taking to discipline the officer or officers who allowed this to occur?

—That question is properly addressed to me. I am certainly familiar with the background to the matter, because Senator Bishop raised it on a number of occasions during the Estimates Committee hearing. I think there was also a story about this matter in the Australian Financial Review on 17 November. As a result, a review of the arrangements was made, the arrangements notified to the Senate Committee. That review has resulted in action being taken to rectify the situation. The Canberra based Senior Executive Service level 3 position has been abolished to coincide with the transfer of the Commission's last remaining Canberra-based branch, the Commonwealth jurisdiction branch, to the recently established Comcare organisation. As a matter of interest, I understand that the officer concerned is not keen to move to Sydney and that he has been informed that he is in excess of the requirements of the Commission in Canberra.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services been drawn to today's issue of the Sydney Morning Herald, which reports claims at the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct that Mr Don Lane, a former Queensland Cabinet Minister, had seen the postal vote of a Queensland Supreme Court judge? What chance would there be of a Queensland Cabinet Minister identifying the postal vote of Justice Douglas at a Commonwealth election? Can the Minister assure the Senate--
—Do you understand the question?

—Yes, and I understand what it means, too, for the Opposition. Can the Minister assure the Senate of the complete integrity and secrecy of postal voting under the provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act as administered by the Australian Electoral Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Actually, I think that question was meant for Senator Arthur Gietzelt, but he is not here at the moment. I did read those reports in this morning's newspaper, with a fair degree of surprise. The general thrust of the newspaper article suggested that the key candidate, the hot favourite, to take over the position of Chief Justice in Queensland was nobbled on the spurious reason that Mr Don Lane contacted Sir Ted Lyons, who in turn contacted Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen and said that Don Lane had seen the Justice's postal vote at the previous State election and that he had committed the greatest crime in Queensland-even greater than child molesting-and had voted Labor! On that basis--
—It is a pretty serious offence.

—The carpetbagger interjects that this is a serious offence. I think Senator Stone has admitted that he voted Labor on one occasion. This just shows the inconsistent standards of the Premier of Queensland-that he would knock off a Chief Justice because he once voted Labor but would bring Senator Stone here at Senator Collard's expense.

ANSWER.PARA: Getting back to the main thrust of the question, I believe that this could not happen at a Federal election. I am not versed enough in terms of the Queensland electoral laws and procedures to know whether it would be possible to determine who voted where by postal vote. But at a Federal level postal votes are returned and, when they are opened, the votes are placed upside down and are counted in multiples; and it would be very unusual-in fact, I think almost impossible-to source the vote back to a particular individual. I have previously had to compare the Queensland Government with the Government of Louisiana in the 1930s, but I must say, having heard that particular allegation, that Huey Long was a dead-set amateur.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is also directed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, seeks a different assurance from the one sought by Senator Burns. What guarantees has the Minister received from Vietnam that the playwright Ta Duy Binh, who has been refused refugee status by the Government, will not be punished on his return to his own country? What form will the guarantees take and who has given them? Who in the bureaucracy or in the Government accepts responsibility in the event that this young man is ill treated when he returns to Vietnam? Does the Minister accept responsibility? Can he give an assurance about his safety? Will the Minister give a further assurance beyond his reported sympathetic consideration that Mr Binh will be able to migrate to Australia if he applies in the normal way when he returns home?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Binh arrived in Australia, I think, to attend a cultural function. It is quite clear from the interview with Mr Binh that, before he left Vietnam, he had always intended to apply for refugee status in Australia. He applied for refugee status. It was considered by the Determination of Refugee Status Committee, which unanimously rejected his refugee claims, including, I might add, in the technical sense also supported by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. Having been refused at that level, it is now up to Mr Binh, under his legal obligations, to return to Vietnam.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, this case differs from any other refugee cases in as much as it has had a lot of publicity. This gives us a long term problem in dealing with any of those cases. If someone is not a refugee by definition but, by attacking his homeland country in the media, he automatically becomes a refugee, that has long term implications for visitor programs to this country and our immigration policy. Everybody realises that Australia is a large immigration country. Every realises that, sadly, many people miss out in their applications to come here. If it is seen that, by using refugee status, people can emigrate to Australia and miss the normal immigration criteria, we would be facing a serious situation.

I will come to some of the honourable senator's specific points in a moment. We can deal with this matter in a number of ways. We can say that we will allow no more visitors from this country, and I am certain that that could also be the reaction at the other end. We treat these refugee cases on an individual basis and not on a class basis. We do not have a class of refugees, such as Tamils, Vietnamese, or Lebanese. This is often confused.

Obviously, having refused Mr Binh's application for refugee status, we have had some concerns as to whether he would be persecuted. Having looked at his previous history in Vietnam, where he was not subject to any persecution-and that is quite clear from the evidence-discussions have taken place between Mr Simmington from my Department and officials from the Vietnamese Embassy. Those discussions are continuing on a couple of points. The dialogue is continuing. The indication from the Vietnamese Government is fairly clearly that the gentleman concerned will not be subject to any abuse or maltreatment.

Probably the one remaining factor that is not clear in my mind yet from the discussions held between officials is whether the Vietnamese Government would put an artificial barrier in the way of Mr Binh's application to come to Australia. The relationships between the Government of Vietnam and Australia on immigration matters are continually improving. We now have an agreement for an orderly departure system, an immigration system, to Australia which is a big breakthrough. It means that many families in Vietnam that want to come to Australia no longer have to make the arduous march to camps or travel on boats, et cetera. We are establishing an orderly migration program for the reunification of relatives. This is not an easy case, but I believe that if it were handled incorrectly we would endanger that orderly departure program, and many more people would be potential sufferers.

The honourable senator asked me what guarantees I could give. No Minister can give an absolute guarantee. I cannot give an absolute guarantee that if I deport someone back to New York tomorrow that he will survive for the rest of his life without being knifed, mugged or something else. I cannot give absolute guarantees. One is required to use the best judgment available. When determining refugee cases I do not determine them directly; we have an interdepartmental committee, as I think the previous Government did, which very carefully measures the case of any refugee. I point out that the process in Australia takes three months, and sometimes it is quicker. The process in other countries, through the courts, takes longer. For instance, in Canada it takes seven years. The interesting thing is that the success rate in Australia is identical to that of Canada-15 per cent. That at least reassures me that the procedures are not particularly off-key.

As I said, this was not an easy case on which to make a judgment. I understand that there is still one point to be clarified in the negotiations. Having given those assurances, I think the Government of Vietnam would be very conscious of its image in this country and of the development of the relations between the two and would not wish to breach them. Senator Chaney asked me whether I would take personal responsibility. Every time a refugee goes home, every time someone is deported, I have to take that responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for his reply. I note that he made the point in his reply that it is a matter of achieving the best judgment one can make in these admittedly very difficult matters. I also note that the Minister said that the Government had received assurances. I do not think the Minister in his reply dealt with the form of these assurances. I would like him to give the Senate more detail on the nature of the assurances given and the reason for his judgment that the assurances are satisfactory, bearing in mind the reports that an examination of earlier cases involving students from Vietnam has led officials to change their initial view that a return was a matter that could be countenanced. I ask the Minister: What form of assurance or guarantee has he received from the Vietnamese Government, and why does that satisfy him that the position is secure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated to Senator Chaney, the discussions are not complete. There have been two rounds of discussions on this matter, and assurances have been given to our officials by the Vietnamese Embassy on behalf of the Vietnamese Government. Another issue being discussed at the moment is whether an Australian civilian can accompany Mr Binh back to Vietnam for the three or four months we assume he will be there. That also is under discussion. It would not be an Australian official because, I think, the Vietnamese Government would object. Again, I hope in the next couple of days to get a report about how those negotiations are going.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Defence aware that opinion polls conducted by the international market research company Frank Small and Associates over the last 12 months have shown a strong swing in public opinion against visits by nuclear-armed warships, with the most recent poll showing only 22 per cent support for the visits? In light of this information and the recent protests throughout the country against the visits, are there any plans for further naval salutes or other events which could involve nuclear-armed or powered warships? If so, where and when are they planned? Or will the Government move to reduce the number of visits in deference to the wishes of the Australian people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —We have no plans for any more naval salutes at this stage. We might have in 100 years time for the tricentenary. Normal visits by ships are usually arranged at two weeks notice and, to my knowledge, none have been planned. When they are planned, the Australian Government will welcome the ships of our allies to this country. As for the opinion poll, it should be very comforting to Senator Dunn. It probably means she will get 78 per cent of the vote at the next State election rather than 1.3 per cent. I would have thought that would be fairly good news. This Government does not operate, and neither, I think, does any other national government, on the basis of opinion polls. Opinion polls vary according to the questions asked.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not mean to belittle this particular company. It is not one I have come across before. Senator Dunn has not adduced any evidence as to how wide the poll was or what questions were asked. If I produce a poll tomorrow showing that the majority of Australians support the American alliance, does that mean Senator Dunn will support motions in this chamber supporting that alliance? Of course she will not. There is only one place where these things are tested; they are tested at the ballot box. On the last opportunity people had to speak in her State, at least 90 per cent voted for parties supporting the American alliance and the visits of these ships. The best she could say is that 10 per cent supported her view, a view shared by her colleague Senator McLean. I am not accusing him of having identical views, by the way; I am speaking about the view of opposing visits of ships-nuclear-armed, nuclear-powered, or whatever they may be. I am not particularly impressed by those opinion polls. Nevertheless, they may give Senator Dunn some comfort in terms of the next election. But I would not mortgage a house on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Justice aware that the Law Council of Australia has strongly criticised the proposed retrospective War Crimes Amendment Bill which the Government seems anxious to force through the Senate this session? Does the Minister agree with the Law Council of Australia that the Bill will not ensure that all accused people will receive a fair trial, because the alleged crimes took place in other countries over 40 years ago and witnesses will be difficult to locate or may be dead, and corroborative documents may no longer be available? Are fair trials possible after more than 40 years? In the light of these criticisms, will the Government reconsider the whole Bill or at the very least give the courts the power to stay proceedings to avoid injustice being done to defendants?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Both Senator Hamer in his question and the Law Council of Australia have badly misconceived the whole basis of the trials that will take place. There is no need for this Parliament to vest in the common law courts and the judges who will conduct these criminal trials a special power in relation to preventing an abuse of the process of the courts by an inability of the defence to present its case adequately. The honourable senator is quite wrong to speak in terms of trying to force the foreshadowed legislation through the Senate. It has been on the Senate Notice Paper for 12 months, and I am sure it will be dealt with by the end of this session. I believe that an adequate opportunity for debate will be given to it by the Leader of the Government in the Senate. As the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs concluded, if the ordinary rules relating to the trials of accused persons in Australia are adhered to we obviously have a much better situation than would be the case under the old legislation which spoke of courts martial.

ANSWER.PARA: The whole tenor, the whole purpose, of this legislation is to get these matters before an ordinary court where the ordinary rules relating to the standard of proof beyond reasonable doubt, the admissibility and weight of evidence, et cetera, can be dealt with as they would by any other court in this country. I believe that in the same way as judges are well able, because of their inherent Commonwealth powers, to ensure that the trials before them are conducted fairly, they will do precisely the same in this instance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Finance aware of remarks made by Senator Michael Baume in last Thursday's adjournment debate regarding alleged deficiencies in the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust (SFIT) annual report? If so, can the Minister comment on the accuracy of Senator Baume's remarks?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Baume's remarks about the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust annual report are about as reliable as a Patrick Partners prospectus and have about as much relationship to reality or truth as a Patrick Partners prospectus used to have. I will not go through all of the things he said, but he described the report as `the most dishonest and deliberately misleading report from a government agency to come before this Parliament in my 13 years in the place'. He went on to talk about dishonesty and so on. He claimed:

ANSWER.PARA: The report does not reveal that the Trust suffered an incredible turnaround in equity earnings of more than half a billion dollars in the year to 30 June 1988 . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right, the report part. You have to look at the statistics in the back.
—I suggest that instead of writing dodgy prospectuses Senator Baume should get the report out and look at page 21. He will find this:

ANSWER.PARA: In the financial year ended 30 June 1988 SFIT's equity portfolio incurred a negative return of 11.7 per cent.

Did Senator Baume actually read it? Did he open the covers, or just go off half-cocked the way he usually does? The income of the fund, he alleged, had somehow been `doctored'-that is his term-by switching from Australian Valuation Office valuers to commercial valuers and he said that without the boost to income resulting from the higher commercial valuations SFIT's income would have dropped from $918m to $576m. Note 12 of the financial statements refers to some property-not all property-having been valued by commercial valuers. The income statement, however, shows that the difference generated by the change of valuers for certain properties was treated as an abnormal item and not reflected in the return of 13.4 per cent. Senator Baume should go back to writing Patrick Partners prospectuses rather than misinterpreting annual reports from statutory authorities. He used terms such as `crooked', `wasteful', `deceptive' and `dishonest'. Where are all the humbugs on the Opposition benches who complain about the alleged misuse of Parliament to defame people outside the Parliament? Where were they when Senator Baume was talking about crooked, deceptive, dishonest practices in SFIT? Where was Senator Chaney? Was he jumping up to raise a point of order? Not on your life.

Senator Baume also alleged that management costs had jumped by 60 per cent. He ignored the fact that there was an identified $3m one-off cost for computer equipment. He chose, just as if he was still writing a Patrick Partners prospectus, to ignore the one-off capital items and say that administrative costs had jumped by 60 per cent. In conjunction with the lack of detail he alleged in the report, in conjunction with the comprehensive financial statement, the report details SFIT's approach to portfolio management, including sectoral diversification and the question of trade-offs between risk and return. The performance for the year, including for each sector, the five-year comparative performance and, most importantly, the relationship to the relevant indices, including sectoral weightings within the share portfolio, can be found on page 20. Just as SFIT did not list all its fixed interest holdings, it has not listed all the shareholdings but this information can be provided if required. The information contained in the annual report is presented on a sector and overall portfolio basis rather than the individual stock or assets basis.

The attack on SFIT with Senator Baume's defamations and misrepresentations of all the people associated with the SFIT board of management, including Mr Dewar, who I thought was regarded as a member of the Melbourne establishment, were accurately reported by the Melbourne Herald in the text but alongside a photograph of Senator Peter Baume. I suggest that Senator Peter Baume should sue the Herald for libel.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice in his own right and also in his capacity as Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer to the current inquiry by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal into whether Mr Alan Bond is a fit and proper person to hold a various range of television and radio licences, which inquiry is confined to three issues, none of which touch on the propriety of Mr Bond's behaviour in the takeover of the Bell Group. Is it a fact that the decision of the National Companies and Securities Commission to make a tentative finding indicating that there had been collusion between Bond and the Western Australian State Government Insurance Commission but not to pursue the matter to finality came about because of this Government's deliberate withholding of funds to the NCSC and because of the disgraceful reliance by the Western Australian Government on the shield of Crown impunity? Why has the Government not taken action in the package of companies legislation to remove this unwarranted protection from Commonwealth and State agencies engaged in commercial activities? In view of the very serious unresolved questions relating to Mr Bond's role in the matter, will the Government urgently request the Tribunal to examine the matter in the course of its current inquiry?

—It should be evident to any senator that four or five out of those half dozen questions bear no relationship to my portfolio responsibilities. The only one that I think did was the question of whether the NCSC was so starved of funds that it was unable to undertake a proper investigation into the relationship between Bond and the State Government Insurance Office in Western Australia. The answer is, of course, no. The National Companies and Securities Commission is well able to undertake the necessary investigations into these matters, as I mentioned to Senator Messner in answer to a question I think only on Monday.
—That is not what they believed, was it?

—Senator Hill could not have been listening to my answer to Senator Messner on Monday. Mr Bosch told me at Tullamarine Airport that in relation to the investigation being undertaken at the moment under section 36 the Commission had adequate resources to get it under way in a speedy and timely way.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources. Given the Minister's announcement on Tuesday that the Government intends to sacrifice the 100-metre high eucalypts of Tasmania to the woodchippers, I ask the Minister whether he intends to prolong the woodchippers' ball in his own State of Western Australia. Has the Minister read newspaper reports dated 24 and 26 November in the West Australian and the Albany Advertiser about the current financial state of TPS Group Ltd, the parent company of McLean Consolidated Pty Ltd, which is applying for an export woodchip licence to export woodchips from Albany, Western Australia? Is the Minister familiar with TPS Group Ltd's severe financial difficulties which, according to the group's auditors, `raised doubts that the group could continue as a going concern'? If so, can the Minister advise the Senate of the suitability of this company's wholly owned subsidiary to operate responsibly in Western Australia's diminishing native forests, given the possibility that its parent company may be forced to cease trading? Finally, can the Minister give an assurance that the financial troubles of McLean's parent company, the TPS Group, along with public disillusionment with government involvement in financially shaky institutions such as Rothwells, will be a consideration in the Minister's decision whether or not to grant an export woodchip licence to McLean Consolidated Pty Ltd?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I should say in answering this question from Senator Vallentine that she should have an opportunity to withdraw the introductory paragraph to her question because it is factually wrong. I know that Senator Vallentine likes to argue from the point of view of what is the case. What she has asserted is so factually wrong, so untrue, as to render her ridiculous. What this Government has done is preserve a quarter of a million hectares of the very tallest trees in Australia in the Southern Forests and the Lemonthyme-trees that have been described as the tallest flowering plants in the world. It has done so in a way in which they will be protected by World Heritage. The area that Senator Vallentine seems to think might contain trees is obviously, from her introductory paragraph, the hole in the doughnut area, which contains small spherical scrub. She is just so factually wrong in the introduction to the question that she is ridiculous and should have the opportunity to withdraw the allegation.

ANSWER.PARA: I turn to the question of the McLean licence application and the TPS Group. I have not actually read the reports, but if it is true that the TPS Group and McLeans are suffering financial difficulty-Senator Vallentine asserts that, and I have no question with the accuracy of the assertion she has made although I do not personally have knowledge of the situation-that is a great pity. I do not profess to know all about TPS's operations, but I do know this: it is trying to develop an investment package to expand private plantations of Australian hardwoods in an area near Albany in Western Australia; that is, it is trying to develop a forest resource which will meet the needs of woodchippers from private plantations, thus in the longer term obviating the need for woodchippers to have access to a native forest resource. I would have thought that all of us in the chamber, including the Independents, would applaud any business enterprise that was trying to expand the forest resource base by planting on hitherto undeveloped land in order to meet the needs of industry.

Australia exports about $400m of forest products a year but imports $1.9 billion of forest products a year. So we cut forests in other countries to the value of $1.9 billion. Some of those countries protect their environment as we do, but many of them do not. I would like to see industries like TPS encouraged rather than denigrated so that we can protect the environment not just in Australia but globally. I think that is an important consideration in terms of forest industry development for Australia.

Senator Vallentine asked me whether I would take these facts into account when considering the McLean application for the issuance of a woodchip licence. I have now received final documentation from the Western Australian Government commenting on the McLean application, and the applications by Whittakers Ltd and WA Chip and Pulp Co. Pty Ltd for woodchip export licences. I will be dealing with those applications in the next few weeks. I hope to expedite the matter. In regard to making a decision, the McLean application is based almost exclusively on exporting woodchips derived from sawmill residue; that is, in the process of milling and dealing with timber a residue pile is created and it is woodchips out of that pile, as I understand it, that McLean wishes to export. If it does not export woodchips out of that pile, the pile is burnt; it is destroyed. That ought to be considered when referring to the application by McLean for a licence.

I have not yet made a determination on, nor have I applied my mind to, the issue of McLean in particular. But a fortnight ago in Perth I spent all of one morning with eight environment and conservation groups from the south-west of Western Australia, going through with them in considerable detail all the implications of a woodchip export licence. For the record, there was no obligation on me to do this, but I believe that, in dealing with the issuance of licences concerning a matter as sensitive as this, there ought to be open disclosure by the Government and a genuine attempt to deal with the objections that are put forward by bona fide groups. I took a whole morning out to do that. If Senator Vallentine wants to check with those groups she will find that a proper, full and adequate consultation took place. When I come to make a decision about the issuance of the licence to McLean I will take all relevant factors into account. Some of those factors may be related to the question asked of me today and some of those factors may be related to the objections, but they will also be related to the information provided to me by the Western Australian Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Prime Minister confirm that the Prime Minister yesterday, in the course of a radio interview, used the famous `f' word in the following context? I quote him, deleting the word:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . may I take this opportunity of wishing you all a merry Christmas and a happy and a good reporting 1989. Thanks very much.
Thereupon followed an interjected question. The Prime Minister answered:
Oh get . . .

Does the Government consider the use of this language by national leaders to be acceptable when there is a risk of broadcast on public radio, or does the Government expect the media to protect the Prime Minister from his indiscretions by deleting them? Can the Minister say whether this signifies the general moral decay of the Government, or merely of the Prime Minister?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen that report.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Is it a fact that Western Mining Corporation built a uranium pilot plant some eight kilometres north of Kalgoorlie in Western Australia in 1978? Is this plant still in operation? If not, when did it cease operations? How many shipments of uranium ore, by road and rail, have been shipped to this plant? What is the total tonnage of uranium ore that has been transported to Western Australia to the present time? Who was responsible for approval being given to the interstate transport of radioactive material? Was the Western Australian Government notified of such shipments? Was any yellowcake produced at the plant? If so, where is it now; if not, what was produced and where is it now?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will have to get some details on the specific questions of fact Senator Jenkins has asked me about. However, I recall that a pilot plant was built by Western Mining near Kalgoorlie. I cannot vouch for the year it was built but I think that the honourable senator is about right; it was in the late 1970s. The purpose of the pilot plant was to prove up the technology to treat uranium ore to the level of yellowcake in anticipation that the Yeelirrie uranium prospect that Western Mining held north of Kalgoorlie would go ahead. We know that the Yeelirrie uranium prospect has not gone ahead. I do not know whether the plant has ceased production, but I anticipate that it has, as it ran through the pilot operation a certain amount of tonnage which it announced in advance it would do to perfect the technology, and it exported out of Western Australia, as I recall, some samples to possible clients for a future production run if the Yeelirrie mine went ahead. I am a bit hazy about this, but my recollection is that it exported that to a West German company. I will get the honourable senator specific details on those precise points later.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator asked as well whether it was approved by the Western Australian Government, or was the Western Australian Government notified about the shipments. I do not have any direct information on whether the Western Australian Government was notified about them. The State Government of the day was the Charles Court Government, and the Federal Government of the day was the Malcolm Fraser Government. I have not checked the records to see whether either of those governments knew, and I am not in a position now to say whether they did. I suppose obviously the Federal Government must have approved the issue of a licence to export yellowcake samples. As the State governments control internal transport, the Western Australian Government must have approved the arrangements for transport to the port for dispatch by shipping. As I said, I will supplement this answer with the particular detail when I am able to check with my Department what that detail is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Finance seen a press statement issued this afternoon by the shadow Minister for Finance, John Hewson, in which he implied that he regards it as important to distract attention from the cost of Opposition promises? Will the Government follow Dr Hewson's advice and announce a mini-Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answers are yes and no. I do have a copy of the press release, and an extraordinary press release it is. One of the noteworthy things about it-although this is not a surprise-is that it has not clarified, in any way whatsoever, whether the Opposition is committed to any of the extensive list of expenditure promises, implicit and explicit, which the Treasurer and I released today. The statements it has made are vague and sloppy-implicit and explicit-and the reason the Treasurer and I held that press conference was to draw the attention of the public to them.
—How much are your July tax cuts going to cost?

—Senator Chaney will find out in about April. We do not have $2 billion worth of expenditure increases hanging around; nor do we have any promises to abolish $3 billion worth of revenue without doing anything about tax rates or tax thresholds. The Opposition has made $3 billion worth of explicit promises to get rid of revenue, without saying a word about tax rates or tax thresholds.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that, early this afternoon, Mr Oakes and a number of other journalists sought some clarification from Mr Howard about what the Opposition is really committed to and what it is not committed to, and he got no enlightenment either. The really remarkable point-no, this is not surprising, but it is pretty cheeky-is that Dr Hewson is challenging the Treasurer to a debate. We all know that Dr Hewson believes he should be the shadow Treasurer; we all know he believes he should be the Treasurer, if not Prime Minister; but the plain fact is that he is not the shadow Treasurer.

I do recognise, mere meritricious player though he is, that he does have better intellectual equipment to be shadow Treasurer than the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, who in fact is the shadow Treasurer. If Dr Hewson wants a debate on this question, I will be very happy to have it with him. Ever since Senator Stone was sacked, I have felt rather deprived not to have the odd joust with the shadow Finance spokesman. I warn Dr Hewson that, if he takes up my challenge to have a debate, I will be hammering him on these points, among others: is the Opposition committed to spending another $500m a year on road construction; or will it continue the present Government's policy of maintaining it in real terms; or will it adopt Senator Stone's policy--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. I think the Minister, having issued a challenge to a debate, is now proceeding to commence the debate. I ask you to call him to order and to tell him to stop debating the question or sit down.
—Order! The Minister is tending to stray rather widely from the question that was asked of him about a mini-Budget.

—Certainly, Mr President. I will also be asking Dr Hewson: is the Opposition genuinely committed to abolishing the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax, and to bringing back the tax rort for goldminers, at a cost of $2 billion-plus? What about the Alice Springs railway, which is of interest to Senator Collins? Will the Opposition say, `Not one dollar of Commonwealth taxpayers' money will be spent on any railway in the Northern Territory', and so on? I welcome a debate with Dr Hewson and I warn him that I will be driving him into the ground on every one of those issues.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 November, Senator Watson asked me a question in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. I am now in a position to give an answer to Senator Watson. Thioridazine tablets, of which Melleril is a brand name, are available under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme in four strengths-10 milligrams, 25 milligrams, 50 milligrams and 100 milligrams. The three weaker strengths had their listed maximum quantity doubled on 1 August due to a Government policy decision. However, the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) did consider the proposal before implementation. While it agreed that there should be no safety implications with the lower three strengths, it did advise that the 100 milligrams strength should not be included; hence, the 100 milligrams strength remains at that strength.

ANSWER.PARA: Due to concerns which have since been expressed, at its most recent meeting the PBAC reviewed the situation and has recommended that the listing of tranquillisers, including thioridazine, should revert to their prior to 1 August availability. This recommendation will be implemented in the next available reprint of the schedule on 1 April-maybe that is an appropriate date-1989.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation, on the grounds that I have been misrepresented by a Minister during Question time.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) accused me of having libelled the members of the Board of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust by making false claims about the dishonest nature of that annual report. He said that my comments were wrong; that I was false; and that he had produced what he claimed to be evidence to refute what I had said. And he imputed, it seemed to me, motives to my criticism of the Fund.

SPEECH.PARA: The facts are totally to the contrary. In each instance, on every issue that the Minister raised, he was totally wrong. The facts, as I stated them, are absolutely correct. He totally misrepresented me by claiming falsely that I was being untrue in saying that the report sought to hide the facts. I said:

It is only by a close, detailed examination of the accounts printed at the back of the annual report that the extent of the disastrous year for the Trust is revealed, because the printed report does not do so.

The Minister, in then seeking to claim that I was misleading this chamber, quoted from the detailed printed accounts at the back of the report. That is exactly the point that I had sought to make. He also claimed that my comment about administrative expenses having risen was somehow dishonest, because I had failed to mention the acquisition of some computer equipment. Note 10 in the accounts, which deals with administrative expenses, does not mention such computer purchases and, in any event, in normal circumstances they would be a capital item and not an administrative expense. The thrust and the detail of the Minister's attack on me and on my personal integrity during his response were totally false.

TALK.START.PARA: —He just said you got it wrong.

—He did not just say I got it wrong, and the Minister knows that perfectly well. He imputed motives to me and likened what I was saying and my attack to a dishonest prospectus. For the Minister at the table, the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), to give his blessing to such behaviour is a comment on him, more than on the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: This repeated attempt to use Question Time to slander members of the Opposition, in this case, me, by totally incorrect and misleading statements-and deliberately so, and that is imputing a motive-is, I believe, intolerable in this place. It has continued for far too long. I regret that I did not have the document with me in order that, as he said each misleading fact, I could have repudiated it. I do not have in my mind the whole list of issues. A succession of falsehoods came from this Minister. I believe that he should be asked to apologise and withdraw.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Public Service Act, I present the annual report of the Joint House Department for the year ended 1987-88.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
Mr President, are copies of the report available?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure, Senator. I will check. There is a proof copy, I am told.

—With respect, Mr President, I think it is totally unsatisfactory that, when we are discussing the tabling of this report in this chamber, there is nothing better than a proof copy available. I would have thought, particularly as we are debating the report of the Joint House Department, that that Department would have been capable, competent and efficient enough in its organisation of this building to produce a report in a finished form before it is tabled in this Parliament. Having, therefore, not had a chance to read it--
—It has never stopped you before.

—I am one of the few that it does stop. I do nothing more than draw the chamber's attention to the proposal of the Remuneration Tribunal. Enough has been said about it already, but I note-I am not conscious of the Government's response-that the present rate of annual salary of the Parliamentary Librarian is slightly in excess of $10,000 above that of the Principal Parliamentary Reporter and the Secretary to the Joint House Department, who are on the same salary. If I remember correctly, they are level 2 officers and the Parliamentary Librarian is a level 4 officer. Under the Tribunal's proposal, the Secretary to the Joint House shall receive a responsibility loading of $10,112 per annum, which would take his salary almost precisely to that of the Parliamentary Librarian. This means, for reasons beyond my capacity to interpret, that the Principal Parliamentary Reporter will be left languishing in the structure of the three departmental heads, some two grades below that of the Parliamentary Librarian and Secretary to the Joint House Department.

SPEECH.PARA: In my view the responsibilities of the Secretary to the Joint House Department are no greater than those of the Principal Parliamentary Reporter. I would have thought that their grades ought to be identical and that their salaries ought to reflect that. Because I do not have a copy of the report, I am unable to make further observations about that, except to say that I have no reason to believe that the Secretary to the Joint House Department has assumed new responsibilities that attract a promotion by two grades and a salary at that level. I hope that the Government, which daily seeks to impose its will upon the functioning of this Parliament, will look with some care at the levels of the three departmental heads. It seems to me unreasonable that the level of Principal Parliamentary Reporter should be lagging considerably behind those of the Parliamentary Librarian and, most of all, the Secretary to the Joint House Department. Of course, my comments in no way reflect upon their personal competence or capacity. Naturally, I am referring to the positions themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add a few words in discussing the annual report of the Joint House Department. I thank the Secretary to the Joint House Department for making it available to me a few minutes ago so that at least I could have a brief look at it. I join my colleague in saying that it is unfortunate that reports of this significance are not available to us to enable us to debate them properly. One of the concerns I have about the Joint House Department relates to the enormous expense this Department is going to face as a result of the unsatisfactory completion of work by the Parliament House Construction Authority and the unsatisfactory condition of many of the major items in this place. I raised this morning in the Estimates debate relating to the Parliament House Construction Authority the question of the pitting of the floors in Parliament House. We were then told that no decision had yet been made about what should be done about the incredible pitting of the floors.
—Ban high-heel shoes.
—As the honourable senator says, ban high-heeled shoes.
—Is that what you are going to suggest, is it?

—What I am going to suggest, if the honourable senator is at all interested, is that when contracts are let for such things, one would assume-apparently incorrectly-that the materials would be able to stand such pressure. Someone should have thought about the fact that women wear high-heel shoes. Maybe where Senator Schacht comes from they do not. Maybe he lives in a dream world. I have often thought he does. This is more evidence.
—They don't wear shoes.
—Perhaps where he operates they do not wear shoes. That could be so.
—They don't wear ties.

—They certainly do not wear ties; the honourable senator is quite right. I am concerned that the Joint House Department is going to face a massive volume of unexpected expenditure as a result of failures that it has inherited from the Parliament House Construction Authority. I refer not only to the Great Hall and the corridors, but also to the equipment in the dining rooms and elsewhere, about which I understand a report is being prepared for the Presiding Officers by the people in charge. I understand that that will involve considerable expenditure which, of course, will involve additional estimates, which we will have to deal with in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: I am particularly concerned about the floor and the response we got this morning. This morning we were told that there has been no decision about resanding, resurfacing and refacing the floors, which is in conflict with the evidence we were given on 20 October 1988 at Estimates Committee E, where Mr Fowler said:

The floor in the Great Hall, for example, is planned-and has been for some time-to have a sanding and be resealed over the Christmas recess. That is something that has been planned for at least a year, perhaps 18 months. So there is planned maintenance that you would expect on the flooring.
I asked about the level of pitting on the floor. One of the officers said:

Speaking personally, I am not surprised by it, but I think, as we have pointed out before, it is more evident in a building of this nature. That is because, firstly, of its special character where people are actually looking for these sorts of things and also because of the extent of the parquetry. We can only repeat that the best design practices were used and the best construction practices as well, and the result is what would normally be expected in all buildings, but I think we are just noticing it more in this building.

That seems to me to be a grossly unsatisfactory answer. I wonder whether Joint House has any plans about this. Obviously, the plan that we were advised of, to sand and resurface the floors over the Christmas break, has now gone by the board. What is Joint House going to do about the matter? Who is going to pay the bill?

TALK.START.PARA: —The taxpayers.
—The taxpayers will pay it, as Senator Puplick quite rightly says. But what about the people who actually laid that floor? Did they really expect nothing more?

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter I want to raise is one that was raised by my cousin, Senator Peter Baume. It relates to the role of Joint House in managing the art work collection. According to a letter I have here of 13 September 1988:
. . . the Joint House Department will be primarily responsible for curatorial functions in the building.
We are told that among these functions will be:
Identifying which works could be used for nominated Parliamentarians' suites and general circulation spaces.

We have heard from my cousin Senator Peter Baume how the Executive knocked off, as I understand it, an average of 27 paintings or works of art each, leaving an average of two for those at the bottom of the list, for lesser mortals. This is the very same Executive that had decided to cut the acquisition program--

TALK.START.PARA: —It's no use getting near the trough unless you get your snout in it.
—The very same Executive decided to cut the acquisitions program.
—If it comes to lesser mortals, I agree. I just make the point.
—A man of your stature-I mean political as well as personal-is not in a position to respond like that.
—You are a back bench windbag; that is all you are.
—As a senator who has nothing to offer in this situation other than personal abuse, I do not think he does himself any benefit at all by behaving in that childish and small-minded way.
—You get less salary for the same reason.

—The diversion by the Leader of the Government in the Senate is to cover his embarrassment over his rapacity in this matter. He has had his own snout in the art trough to the extent that his suite is full of--
—You are guessing. You have no idea; you don't know.

—If Senator Button is an average Minister-I admit that he does look as if he is below average-he would have 27 art works. If he is below average-I would expect that to be the case-he may have less. In any event, as my cousin Senator Peter Baume has established, the average Minister has something like 27 works of art in his suite. If the Minister is prepared to offer a view about how many he has got, having presumably participated in the Cabinet decision that reduced the amount of expenditure, I would be interested. I ask the Minister how many he would have had had he not shown the restraint that enabled him to have 27 art works on average in his room. Did the Minister show any personal restraint at all? Did he impose it on himself, having made the decision to limit the art work collection, or did he get in for all he could?
—It is Opposition sour grapes. That is all it is. You are going to be there for a long time. Get used to it.

—I ask that as a simple question. He is prepared to intervene in this way. The Minister should face up and come clean. He was silly enough to lead with his chin, so he should now come clean and tell us how many art works he knocked back because of his participation in a decision to reduce the amount of money that could be spent on acquiring them. If the Minister is shown to have clean hands, we might listen to him with a little more respect than he presently deserves.

SPEECH.PARA: The interesting matter is that there has been a lot of duckshoving about who is to blame for allowing the Executive to get their snouts in the art trough. I was interested to read a letter from the Clerk of the Senate outlining that the arrangements under which this was done were simply unsatisfactory. If the Joint House Department is in charge of identifying which works could be used for nominated parliamentarians suites, may I ask the Joint House Department to go around and reallocate them. The Department has the power. Let us have them reallocated.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, not some of the ones in ministerial suites.

—I acknowledge that most of Senator Aulich's ministerial colleagues have such appalling taste that probably very few of us would want some of the art works that they have chosen. But maybe they got some advisers to tell them what would be appropriate for their suites. I accept the honourable senator's interjection. It is most appropriate. Nonetheless, it is worth noting that the memorandum from the Clerk of the Senate dealing with this question demonstrates how totally misleading the Parliament House Construction Authority was in explaining to the Senate Estimates Committee how this allocation happened to take place. I will quote, if I may, from Mr Harry Evans's letter to Senator Childs. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: At page 5 of the Authority's answers, it is stated that I advised that the Authority control led the distribution of artworks to Ministers, office holders and Members and Senators, and that the Authority considers this advice to be misleading. I do not consider that my answer was misleading.
It is true, that, as the Authority indicates on the same page of the answers, the Presiding Officers have determined a scheme for the distribution of the remaining-
that word `remaining' is underlined-

artworks based on a seniority list of all Senators and Members, but this scheme was provided to the Authority only after the Authority had already distributed art-works to Ministers. The distribution of artworks to backbench Senators and Members in accordance with the scheme has not yet commenced. The fact remains that it is the Authority which has control of the distribution of artworks. Indeed, the statement by the Authority that ``the distribution of artworks from the rotational collection therefore has been and is still being done strictly in accordance with the priority listing done by the Presiding Officers''. . . is quite misleading, because, as I have indicated, artworks were distributed by the Authority to Ministers before the Presiding Officers determined the scheme for distribution.

Now that we have the facts let us start again. The Joint House Department has the authority to look after this collection. I believe this Senate should require Joint House to undertake this task immediately. It should give the members of this place a fair go and demonstrate to Ministers that they do not have the right to ride roughshod over this place. Nor have they or the Construction Authority the right to mislead this chamber as they did in terms of this letter from the Clerk about the manner in which this rip-off took place. I hope that at an appropriate time an appropriate motion may be moved to that effect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must rise for a few minutes in response to Senator Michael Baume's broad brush speech. I certainly will not respond to his concern about the art works. In fact I could lend him a Leunig cartoon that I have in my office, neatly framed, which is all about two boys kicking a football. I thought that that would be very symbolic of this place today.

SPEECH.PARA: I have risen in this debate in order that we can get back to first principles in relation to the way this place is run, and the way we go about designing, constructing and running major buildings in the Government's construction program. Senator Michael Baume has been most unfair and less than valuable in the comments he has made about the Joint House Department. It ought to come back to us in this place. All of us should remember that the very important early work done in designing and constructing this building, and approval of that work, was the responsibility of the Joint Standing Committee on the New and Permanent Parliament House which was formed in 1978. We had our representatives on that Committee. Our representatives on that Committee are largely responsible for what we have here today. The Joint House Department has been given the responsibility for making it work. It was not there making the decisions about the design of this place back in 1978.

I am prejudiced in that sense because I probably would never have built this place if it had been in my area of responsibility. The New South Wales Parliament had the right approach to a new or updated and more relevant Parliament House. At the same time, I am not going to come into this chamber and listen to people like Senator Michael Baume nitpicking on the outskirts about the problems that we have in the running of this place and blaming the Joint House Department.

We have to get back to first principles and use those first principles in an advisory manner and wisely when we get on to other construction programs that we as parliamentarians may be involved with. On average 10 per cent of the expenditure for any major construction project goes into the design and briefing stage; that is, the client spends time with the architect and the other people responsible for the ultimate design and the client clearly enunciates his or her brief. If that brief needs to be changed as a result of discussion during the briefing stage, it should be changed then because if mistakes are built into the design in those very early stages, many of those mistakes will never be overcome, even by the most efficient organisation that is ultimately given the opportunity or the responsibility to run a place such as this.

If honourable senators are concerned about distances, parquet floors, the fact that the drivers have no mess room to wait in and have to wait in their cars as they did at the old Parliament House, and the fact that recreation areas in this building are isolated and hardly used by senators at all-and I am concerned about those problems-it is wrong and immoral to blame the Joint House Department because it was we, as parliamentarians, who in 1978 elected our representatives to sit on the Joint Standing Committee on the New and Permanent Parliament House in order to right that design. If we were not satisfied with the prototype design put to use by architects of the day, then it was clearly our responsibility to say so and use the powers of enforcement, advice and decision-making that were given to our Committee. For Senator Michael Baume to come in here and in an unctuous way bag, on the outskirts, a department which has a responsibility to make this place run, and try to patch up the problems, is totally wrong. This is not the first time that Senator Baume has done this in relation to government construction projects.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not bag Joint House at all. You must have been listening to another debate.
—I have listened to Senator Baume on any number of occasions. This is not the first time that he has raised this issue.
—Of course it is not, but I was not bagging Joint House. Get your facts right.

—Senator Baume has had his opportunity to debate this issue. I am talking now. The situation is that the Joint House Committee is part of a whole process that is necessary to run this place. There is legislation coming before the Senate to make this place run more efficiently-there will be fewer departments and a rearrangement of responsibilities. This is an attempt to make a brand new, enlarged parliament work in the way that it should work. I hope that when that legislation comes before us we will look at it as if we were managers or clients. The sort of nitpicking that has gone on about the running of this place by the Joint House Department falls by the wayside because the responsibility comes back to us. We elect our representatives and we have the opportunity to rearrange the structures for the operation of this Parliament. The challenge is up to us. To stand back and nitpick is a waste of time. I believe that at this stage someone should put that on the record.
