DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the United States of America from 5 to 21 January 1988. In tabling the report of this delegation I want to draw the attention of the Senate to several matters. This delegation represented the real value which can be derived from parliamentary delegations making official visits overseas. This value is reflected not only in having a particular message heard in the areas of the United States visited, but also in the knowledge and experience gained by individual members of the delegation.

INTERJECT.PARA: This delegation had three major objectives: to reiterate the difficulties Australia faces in the trade area; to raise the awareness of Australia's technological capacity and of trade and investment opportunities in Australia; and to explore the thinking of senior United States officials, business leaders and experts in the public and private sector on a number of important issues to Australia's future, including economic development, regional concerns and strategic matters. The successful achievement of these goals, as illustrated in the delegation's report, was brought about by the harmony within the delegation and the united voice the delegation presented on many vital issues. Many political and business leaders remarked on this feature of meetings with the delegation especially when it was realised that all three major parties were represented.

The delegation had a full round of meetings and briefings with senior Reagan Administration officials and congressional leaders in Washington. The delegation also visited San Francisco, Houston, Baton Rouge, New Orleans, Atlanta and New York. The delegation found this to be a very valuable way to approach a country as large as the United States, not only because it demonstrated the great diversity of the country but also because local business and political leaders went out of their way to assist a delegation from a country which does not very often send official visitors to regions outside the Los Angeles, New York, Washington triangle. Congressional representatives were also able to spend a good deal more time with the delegation in their local areas than would have been the case in Washington.

I commend the report to the Senate and briefly mention the delegation's major recommendations: First, Australia through its representatives in Washington must not relent in repeating its trade message to congressional and administration leaders. Secondly, consideration should be given to engaging a specialist lobby firm to work on Australia's behalf in addition to the valuable work already being done by our permanent officials in Washington. Thirdly, in recognition of the dramatic economic growth in the southern region of the United States, centred on Atlanta and Georgia, a review of Australia's trade and consular representation in the southern region of the United States should be carried out with a view to achieving a greater official Australian representation in the area. The establishment of a consulate-general or an Austrade office in Atlanta should be explored as a means to achieve this. Fourthly, Australian delegations and visitors from both the public and private sectors should visit more places outside the Los Angeles, New York, Washington tri- angle. The interest in Australia especially in investment and trade opportunities is great in these areas and this potential should be explored wherever possible.

Finally, I pay a particular tribute to all members of the delegation and especially to the deputy leader, Senator Chris Puplick. The delegation operated as a well tuned team and this made my responsibilities as leader so much easier to carry out. The visit to the United States demonstrated to me and to many others the real value which can accrue to this Parliament and to Australia when official parliamentary delegations travel overseas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement and paper.

I will start my very brief remarks on behalf of the other members of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the United States of America by recording our thanks to you, Mr President. You acted as the leader of the parliamentary delegation and we all enjoyed not only the relaxed manner in which you led the delegation, but also the considerable hospitality that you extended on a number of occasions throughout our trip in the United States. I am told by your colleagues in the Australian Labor Party that you are a practised traveller on delegations and it is quite obvious that the skills you have acquired over many years of participating in and leading parliamentary delegations made the delegation's work a great deal easier. In recent times I have read that some parliamentary delegations have not travelled quite as happily as our delegation did. I believe the fact that ours did travel happily in very large measure bestows great credit on you, Mr President.

I should indicate that the other members of the delegation were Mr Brumby, Senator Childs, Mr Blunt, Mr Rocher and Senator Maguire. On their behalf I extend our thanks to you, Mr President, as delegation leader, also to Mr Walsh, your senior private secretary, who was with us briefly, and Mr Diamond, the secretary of the delegation, who certainly performed a very admirable role in support of our work and was of great assistance to all delegation members.

Mr President, I want only to draw attention to the fact, by way of emphasising the points which you made in your speech and the recommendations which are contained in the delegation's report, that it is very important in the United States that representatives from the differing parties speak with one voice to the United States, particularly about its trade protection policies. Although this is a slow and difficult process, I believe that there is an enormous value in the repetition by parliamentarians from Australia to their congressional counterparts of the very considerable concerns that Australia has about the trade policies of the United States.

We had the opportunity to talk to the Secretary of Agriculture and to others about a variety of matters, including the sugar industry, the wheat industry, the export enhancement program and a number of other irritants in Australia's bilateral relations with the United States. Indeed, I think we put into perspective the argument in Australia about the use of the American bases in this country as potential levers for bringing about change in United States agricultural policy.

The second recommendation is that the Government give consideration to the appointment of a specialist lobbyist firm to work in Washington on behalf of Australia. This is a recommendation which I support very strongly. Mr President, you will recall that in the course of discussions in Washington we met with a friend of mine by the name of Simon Pinniger, an Australian who works in the United States as a lobbyist in the agricultural sector. It is unfortunate that he works mainly for our competitors. He works for a number of countries in Africa and a number of countries in the Middle East, both buyers and sellers of agricultural products in the United States. They know that, despite the efforts of their embassies and legations in Washington, diplomats and people posted in Washington tend to come and go on a fairly short term basis, whereas lobbyists who are permanently based there are able to build up relationships with senior congressional figures which they cultivate over 10, 15 or 20 years and more. Under the seniority system in the United States Congress, people become chairmen of important committees or subcommittees largely as a result of their length of service rather than anything else. Many of the people who head the most important congressional committees, as far as Australian trade is concerned, are people who have been in the Congress for many years and have a great deal of seniority. It is only those lobbyists who have developed a working relationship with them over a prolonged period who are able to have any degree of influence, which is very hard for people who are based in Washington for perhaps two or three years to cultivate in their relatively short stay.

A year or so before this delegation I had the opportunity of travelling in the United States with a delegation which included some members of Parliament, including Senator Schacht, who is in the chamber at the moment. He will recall that, in discussions we had in the United States, this point about the need to cultivate relationships over a prolonged period with senior people in Congress was made to us in the course of our stay. I believe that the recommendation of this delegation that consideration be given to engaging specialist lobbyist firms in the United States is important. It will not just be in the agricultural area. I cite, for example, the developments that will take place in the Australian aerospace industry. It will be necessary to have people in the United States who will be able to deal with appropriate congressional committees as far as that is concerned.

The third recommendation is that an Australian presence be established in Georgia. That was certainly impressed upon us by representatives in that part of the United States. We had the pleasure of meeting Governor Harris, the Governor of Georgia, and Mayor Andrew Young, the Mayor of Atlanta, both of whom made the point that Australia is a major investor in the economy in Georgia and that the development of Australian commerce in southern States, from Georgia right the way through to southern California and New Mexico and Texas, is of some importance. Mr President, it was certainly true that people in Houston and Atlanta were very pleased to have the opportunity to talk to members of Australia's parliamentary delegation because, as you rightly said, there is a tendency for delegations to confine themselves to visiting Los Angeles, San Francisco occasionally, New York and Washington and they believe that, under those circumstances, they actually have some appreciation of what happens in the United States.

I think the time that we spent in those southern States was important. The discussions we had in the port of New Orleans with the port authorities and the world trade authorities similarly gave us a new perspective on some trade and transportation issues which are of importance. I certainly endorse the comments made in the delegation's report about a greater Australian presence in States such as Georgia.

I think it is also of some interest to note that we travelled through the state of Louisiana. When Senator Robert Ray mentioned Louisiana earlier today it drew to my recollection that wonderful series of stories about politicians in that part of the world. I had the pleasure of taking photographs of Senator Maguire standing in the State House at Baton Rouge with his finger in the bullet hole where the bullet eventually lodged after Governor Huey Long was disposed of. A comment was made, which perhaps Senator Ray had in mind, about the American politician who said that, when he died, he wanted to be buried in southern Louisiana so that he could remain active in politics. The whole ambience of politics in the southern part of the United States is considerably different from that in the eastern States or on the west coast and it is important for us to appreciate that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you meet Governor Mecham again?

—I respond very briefly to the comment Senator Schacht makes. For those who do not know, the delegation of which Senator Schacht and I were members met Governor Evan Mecham, Governor of the State of Arizona, the first Governor actually to be impeached and removed from office in 60 years. We were in Arizona the week after Governor Mecham was formally inaugurated. The recall petition was already circulating and had a large number of signatures on it within his first week in office. He was subsequently brought before an inquiry conducted by the Arizona State Assembly, somewhat akin to the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct. Governor Mecham was a used car salesman and some of his electoral practices were found to be sufficiently fraudulent actually to remove him from office. We can probably claim to be a very unique group of Australian parliamentarians to have met this person who will figure in the history books for perhaps somewhat less than the most starring reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: The final recommendation is that delegations move away from simply visiting the national capitals in places such as the United States. Mr President, as you rightly pointed out, the United States has been described as a country in which there are nine separate nations. An understanding of those nations and their regional differences within the United States is extremely important. I believe that the parliamentary delegation which you led had a considerable capacity to get a better understanding of a number of those issues.

This report contains the texts of a number of speeches delivered by Mr President in the United States. Those speeches to chambers of commerce and to meetings with the Society for International Affairs in New York are certainly worth reading because I think they are very important contributions on the way in which the Australian Parliament can put the view of the Australian people in a quite united fashion to groups as important as chambers of commerce and international societies.

There are two final points that I wish to make. Members of the delegation were also encouraged and given the opportunity to undertake separate visits in the course of the delegation. For example, at the end of the delegation Senator Maguire visited Kansas City and I think was quite impressed by the fact that he was the first parliamentarian to make a visit, as part of an official delegation, to Kansas City and to Missouri. The importance which was attached to his visit by representatives was very much appreciated.

I had the opportunity in the course of the delegation to visit a number of centres in the United States involved in the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) crisis. It is perhaps relevant on World AIDS Day that I mention that. The most striking thing, I think, was when, on the first day we were in the United States, I visited a hospice in the City of San Francisco, and I met the people running that hospice, both the religious organisation and the medical staff. I also met eight or nine of the patients who were there. It was striking because they were all people younger than I and they were in that hospice in order to die. It struck me at the time that it was quite clear that by the time I had returned to Australia at the end of the visit, some three of four weeks later, all those people would be dead. They went to the hospice purely for the purpose of dying. The hospice takes only those people who are in the last two or three weeks of their life. When one meets a group of people who are, as I said, all younger than oneself and one knows that, by the time one is safely back home in one's own bed and own country, all of them will be dead, it starts to make a further considerable impact on one's understanding of the AIDS problem.

I also visited a number of hospitals and the Department of Health in San Francisco. The delegation as a whole spent some time at the Center for Disease Control in Atlanta, talking with the researchers and people doing the primary work. I spent some time in Washington with the Congressional Committee which is in charge of the AIDS program and AIDS funding in the United States. I visited the institution in New York, called the Gay Men's Health Crisis Centre, which performs the same sort of role and function as the Albion Street clinic in Sydney. I visited the shanti project in San Francisco and a number of others. I have appended at the back of the report a very brief statement about the separate visit I made in terms of looking at those AIDS facilities and have made a number of comments about the management of the disease in Australia and in the United States in a comparative sense. Perhaps it is appropriate, as I said, on World AIDS Day to draw attention to that and to my belief that, if we get the right decisions made in Australia, there is no inevitability that we will go down the same road of tragedy as the United States has in its public health response to the AIDS crisis.

I apologise to colleagues for taking this amount of time to discuss this report. Nevertheless, it is an important report. I think the reports of parliamentary delegations should be formally noted in the Parliament. The way in which this delegation was led is, I believe, also a tribute to Mr President and to the officers of the Senate Department and his own staff who facilitated the arrangements for the delegation. Rather than seek leave to continue my remarks, I simply advise honourable senators that I believe this report is one which repays some study and thought. I hope the Government will find itself in a position to act upon the recommendations in due course.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Publications, I present the ninth special report entitled Review of the Auditor-General's efficiency audit report on the AGPS, together with the transcript of evidence and minutes of the proceedings. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This examination of the Australian Government Publishing Service (AGPS) efficiency audit report is the ninth special report of the Committee. Whilst it is not a detailed review of the AGPS, it affords the Committee the opportunity to report to the Parliament on progress at the AGPS since the Committee's 1978 report on that organisation. In inquiries such as the one that the Publications Committee has just undertaken, committees always run the risk of running off at a tangent and picking up very unusual and interesting bits of information which are not necessarily the target of the report or the brief of the Committee. However, our Committee did stick to its brief, and I commend the report to the Senate.

I would, however, mention two very interesting aspects which came out of the report but which were not necessarily the detail of the charge laid on the Committee in the examination it was directed to undertake on behalf of the Parliament. One interesting observation was that when we advertised for submissions-and we advertised widely in all national and State newspapers on 18 and 19 December last year-we also sought written submissions from all government and parliamentary departments, 39 major statutory authorities who were exempt from using the AGPS printing and publishing facilities, and nine non-Commonwealth exempt bodies, together with all unions whose members were employed at the AGPS. We sought to get as widespread an interest in the inquiry as possible. It is interesting to note on this point that the only submissions we received were those from departments and statutory authorities to which we wrote ourselves; so the accusation could be made that the advertising we undertook, at a cost to the Commonwealth and the taxpayer of Australia, was actually non-productive.

The second matter I want to mention briefly which came to light during the public hearings of the Committee was the propensity among government departments and other bodies to develop sophisticated in-house tabletop printing facilities. That in itself was not an issue that this Committee was charged with reporting on. But one interesting observation I have to make in regard to this is that when inquiries were made to these bodies who were using quite sophisticated equipment, with fairly substantial budgets in some cases, absolutely none of them employed an apprentice in the printing trade. There seems to be a view developing within departments that they do not need to train people. It is something that the Government has to be concerned about; the industry itself has to be concerned about it. Of course, the unions which have members in the industry have great interest in this sector of the industry, and should take note of and watch this development carefully in the future. In the interests of time, I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard the remainder of my remarks.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Under the Standing orders of both Houses, one of the roles of the Joint Committee on Publications is to inquire into the printing, publication and distribution of parliamentary and government publications. Since its commencement in 1970, the Joint Committee has presented eight `special' inquiry reports to the Parliament. This report is about improving:
the Government Printing Office;
the Australian Government Publishing Service; and
the Commonwealth printing and publishing system as a whole.

After careful consideration of all the evidence before it, the Committee believes that there should be some relaxation of the current system requiring Commonwealth departments and non-exempt bodies to be tied clients of the AGPS.
In particular, the Committee recommends:
that Departments and non-exempt bodies not be tied to the AGPS for non-core `general printing' and `publications' work up to a value of $20,000;
that they should continue to be required to seek and consider price quotations from the AGPS for all work;
that all AGPS core work-that is parliamentary work and urgent and confidential Government tasks-be charged for on a full cost recovery basis; and
that AGPS charge for non-core work at competitive commercially equivalent rates.

The Committee's report recognises that current Government administrative initiatives have been directed at devolving management responsibilities to departments and allowing managers more freedom to judge where, and how, to place resources to achieve optimum returns.
Departments should be able to exercise such freedom when undertaking their printing and publishing programs.

In line with current moves to place the AGPS on a more commercial footing, the Committee believes it is vital for the AGPS to be treated as a self-contained management unit employing appropriate management accounting systems.

All activities of the AGPS should be accounted for and charged out to appropriate departments and other bodies. The AGPS should have its own internal audit unit. It should promptly complete development of its computer based management systems and external financial statements. It should also regularly report to the Parliament on its operations, performance and outlook.
The Committee is aware that significant reforms have occurred at the AGPS during the last few years. While these may be applauded, many were overdue.
If the AGPS is to continue to be viable in the long term, it must continue to accept the need for reform and regular review of its operations.

The AGPS should not be a static organisation. It must be pro-active. It must be responsive and adaptive to needs and varying levels of demand. It should expand or contract its operations within the terms of the Commonwealth Charter of Printing and Publishing Responsibilities.
I now turn to the relationship of the AGPS with the Parliament. As honourable senators may recall, the origin of the AGPS stems from the work of this Committee and its predecessors.

The Committee believes that the priority status and special position of the Parliament should continue to be recognised by the AGPS. It should also be fully reflected in the Commonwealth Charter of Printing and Publishing Responsibilities.
As the AGPS implements a policy of full cost recovery for parliamentary work it may be necessary to increase appropriations for parliamentary printing and publishing as-
cost recovery rates will recoup all costs incurred with parliamentary work plus costs not recovered from non-core work charged out at commercial rates, and
AGPS should no longer receive any deficit funding.

To minimise the impact of this increase in parliamentary printing and publishing costs, the Committee has recommended that parliamentary computing systems and in-house printing capabilities be developed to meet the needs of users in this building for:
Votes and Proceedings of the House of Representatives,
Journals of the Senate, and
the Notice Papers of each House.

The Committee recommends that, for these parliamentary publications, the AGPS continue to meet the needs of users outside this building by using the camera-ready copy supplied by the Chamber departments.

The Committee believes that major savings and efficiency improvements will also be gained if computer systems for the electronic transfer of Hansard to the Government Printing Office are developed as quickly as possible.

The AGPS has had the equipment to receive and process electronic data since 1984. Although considerable action has already taken place on this issue, it will be necessary to fully introduce systems for the electronic transfer of Hansard as soon as possible if costs are to be contained and reduced. This is particularly the case as the AGPS moves towards full cost recovery.

To maintain the links between the Parliament and the AGPS, the Committee has decided to meet regularly with the Government Printer and senior officers of the AGPS during each of the Budget and autumn sittings. The Committee will report to the Parliament on the outcome of these meetings, where appropriate.

I would like to thank the members of the committee for their co-operation during this inquiry and their on-going diligence to the work of the committee. The expanded parliamentary committee system creates many additional commitments and the time and effort that members were able to provide is appreciated.

In conclusion, I would like to thank the Committee's Secretary, Peter Mason, for his support and the long hours he has put into the reference, especially as his committee work-load is in addition to his duties in the House of Representatives Bills and Papers Office.
I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the ninth special report of the Joint Committee on Publications entitled Review of the Auditor-General's efficiency audit report on the AGPS. I received this report only in the last couple of hours, so I have not had time to look at it in detail. However, I took particular note of a recommendation on page (xiv) which states:

SPEECH.PARA: That:

(i) the Joint Committee on Publications regularly meet with the Government Printer and senior officers of the AGPS during each of the Budget and autumn periods of sittings of the Parliament to discuss matters of mutual interest and concern . . .

To that recommendation I say a loud amen. I say that because, since I have been a member of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training and as that Committee has moved around Australia in its inquiries on active citizenship, I have become more and more aware of the lack of understanding and knowledge of the Australian public of the parliamentary process. That lack of knowledge of the proceedings and of the legislation covered by Bills, statutory rules, explanatory memorandums, ordinances and regulations puts our democracy at risk. If that information is not easily available to the public our democracy is also placed at risk.

In 1985 various publishers were permitted to obtain a licence to publish those materials-Commonwealth Acts, statutory rules, Bills, explanatory memoranda and regulations and ordinances-and make them available to the public: to people interested in the parliamentary process, law students, academics and general members of the public who wish to inform themselves about what goes on here and about the governing of our country. It was with great concern that I read a letter which I received yesterday and which I believe was addressed to all senators and members of the House of Representatives on a matter which should concern all of us and which requires an explanation. The letter was sent under the name of three major law publishers. They indicate that a review is being undertaken by the Australian Government Publishing Service (AGPS) with the intention of removing the blanket licence that has been available on application to publishers to produce those documents to which I referred earlier. There are some documents-quasi-legislation such as Australian Taxation Office rulings-which are outside the blanket licence. The publisher expressed concern that the licence which has been in place since 1985 is apparently being reviewed by the AGPS.

In the letter the publishers say that on 18 July 1988 law publishers wrote to the Minister for Administrative Services, the Hon. Stewart West, asking to be consulted about the review. They say that on 27 August the AGPS replied asking for a huge amount of information in less than a month but supplying no details of the review's terms of reference or its composition. On 7 September the Minister replied without giving any details and the law publishers again asked for basic information. On 21 November the Minister replied supplying the names of the officials conducting the review and confirming that there were no terms of reference and also informing the law publishers that submissions closed on 28 November. The law publishers claim that the letter was received by them on Thursday, 24 November, therefore allowing only one full working day to provide submissions. The publishers collecting the information originally asked for a meeting with the review committee. Their claim is that the Minister's office refused the request.

I view with concern this allegation-I am saying only that it is an allegation-that the law publishers have made on the manner in which this review has been conducted. If it has been conducted by the AGPS, I view with concern the haste, the lack of information and any attempts that are being made to reduce the free availability of information. I also would view with concern any attempt to reduce competition that AGPS may have to face by the law publishers if they are able to produce this material at a more reason- able cost. I call on the Minister responsible to give the Senate an explanation as to the goals of this review and an assurance that publishers will still be able to publish material such as Bills, Commonwealth Acts, statutory rules, explanatory memoranda and ordinances and regulations.

I have already expressed, in the Estimates committee hearings, my concern at the pricing and publishing policy of the AGPS. Its method of cross-subsidisation means that some papers which are vital for the public to have access to are priced prohibitively for individuals. The library conference held recently in Canberra indicated that the costs are almost prohibitive even for libraries to stock these materials. It is vital that these sorts of papers are available to the public. As I said, given the concerns that have been raised in the inquiry of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training into active citizenship, it is vital that there be no hindrance to or blocking of the availability to the public of information of this nature. I see this as a very serious issue. I ask that the Government address the allegations and claims that have been made, and I expect that the Senate will be duly informed.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the thirteenth report of the Standing Committee on Publications.

SPEECH.PARA: Report-by leave-adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Aulich, Chairman of Estimates Committee E, I table further information received by Estimates Committee E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following reports from the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts: report 292-the Public Accounts Committee and sittings of the Senate; report 293-Activities 1987-88; report 294-Five Efficiency Audits. As Vice-Chairman of the Committee, I seek leave to move a motion and make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

These reports give an indication of the range of the work of the Committee and some of the difficulties it faces in achieving its targets. With the exception of some outstanding matters mentioned in the report the Committee is satisfied that departments and agencies have responded positively to the Auditor-General's findings.

Report 293 is the annual report of the Public Accounts Committee and will give honourable senators an indication of the wide range of subjects covered by the Committee. DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO THE PHILIPPINES AND THE REPUBLIC OF KOREA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the Philippines and the Republic of Korea from 5 to 23 October 1988. I seek leave to make a short statement in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the delegation planned this overseas trip it intended to visit Japan. Regrettably, because of the illness of the Emperor Hirohito of Japan that part of the trip was postponed. However, this enabled the delegation to spend more time in the Philippines and South Korea, which was of great benefit to the members of the delegation.

SPEECH.PARA: The delegation spent approximately nine days in each place. I would like to touch on my observations. In the Philippines we covered almost the whole country, from Manila to Subic Bay, to Cebu, to Davao to Mindanao and to northern Samar, where there was a major Australian aid project in the form of the construction of a road. The project commenced in 1978, was delayed in 1983 and then recommenced and we saw it in the process of being completed. I appreciate the fact that no-one likes instant experts. We do not like them in this country and I am sure that no-one in any other country likes them but I think that some observations would not be amiss. It was certainly my view, and I think it was the view of the whole delegation, that the Philippines finds itself in a most difficult position after 20 years of decline under Marcos. There seems to be an unrealistic expectation in the country that Mrs Aquino, the new President, could fix in two years what was destroyed in 20 years under the previous leader.

From our point of view, the major problems that confront the country are poverty and insurgency. People leave the provinces for places like Manila and then squat on government property. Those who have seen the recent television program on the Philippines will know of the place called Smoky Mountain where some 10,000 people live in congested and unhygenic conditions.

The other major problem in the country is insurgency, although the situation seems to have changed in recent times for the better. It is difficult for those of us who live in a country like Australia, where we do not have guerilla attacks and 15 people a day being killed on the streets, to appreciate the difficulties that occur in countries like the Philippines. I suppose that it is easy for people who have strong human rights views to decry what happens in a country like the Philippines, without recognising the country's problems. It was explained to us in, I think, Davau by the people behind the so-called Alsa Massa-which is really Neighbourhood Watch with a difference-that they had 15 killings a day until they introduced certain anti-insurgency measures. The killings had been reduced to one a day. We in this country have difficulty coming to grips with such problems.

The next phase of the trip was our visit to the Republic of Korea. I had the benefit of having been to Korea a number of times. My first visit to Korea was in 1974. There was one hotel there and a 9 o'clock curfew. I have been back a few times since then. Prior to this trip my last visit was in 1984. There is no doubt that the Republic of Korea is one of the economic miracles of the world. In just over a decade Korea has achieved the status of being the third largest steel producer in the world and the third largest producer of microchips. We visited the new steelworks at Kwangyang Bay, which was built with the country's own technology, and which produces the same amount of steel as does Australia, with something like 5,000 employees. Korea has the latest state of the art technology.

Another thing that is obvious to anyone who follows the movements of the Republic of Korea is that its net foreign debt of about $30 billion is reducing at the rate of $US1 billion a month. So Korea is going in the opposite direction to us in that regard.

The trip was most intensive. There was little time for rest. The great benefit from these trips is what we learn from them. It has been my opinion for some time now that we can learn from the growth we have seen initially in Japan, followed by Taiwan, now Korea and, I believe, subsequently Thailand and lift the standard of living of our own country to those levels. It is interesting to reflect that it was not so many years ago that those countries were copying from the Western countries. We are now looking at them to find out how they have got it right, and we are copying from them.

I know that one or two of my colleagues want to speak to this report, so I will wind up. I pay tribute to the leader of the delegation, Dr Klugman. We had an interesting combination of people on the delegation. We had three members of the Senate and three members of the House of Representatives. We had Dr Klugman, Mr McArthur and Mr Millar from the House of Representatives Senator Beahan, Senator Burns and me, from the Senate. We had three Labor members, two Liberal members and one National Party member. Within the Labor group we had representatives from each of the three major factions. Notwithstanding that, and in the view of recent remarks by members of other delegations about the conduct of their delegations, the delegation acted in a unified fashion throughout the trip, there was harmony throughout the trip and we always ate at the same table. As deputy leader of the delegation, I pay tribute to Dr Klugman and to the other members of the delegation. On behalf of the delegation I thank Mrs Lyn Simons, the Sergeant-at-Arms in the House of Representatives, who accompanied the delegation and did such a fine job.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I indicate my appreciation of the capacity and the preparedness of the two ambassadors in South Korea and the Philippines to provide us with a lot of information, which demonstrated their expertise. All members of the embassy staffs were efficient people. One thing became clear very quickly. They had the capacity to make a connection with the people in different parts of society in those countries and to understand what they felt and what they were saying. It is one thing to have a connection with a government and nothing else; it is another thing to understand what different sections of the community think.

SPEECH.PARA: I was most impressed by the way in which our aid projects were being carried out, particularly the project we saw in Samar and the way that the money which is being spent there by the Australian Government to assist the Filipino people is being properly applied. One application was through the use of non-government organisations, which involved the people in developing projects in certain areas so that they had an association with the projects. It was not a question of people throwing money at them and their sitting down and waiting for more to come. It was quite poignant to hear them put to the delegation the plea that we should not leave the area but should continue to give its people assistance. That is not possible, however, and the Government would be well advised to give help to people in other areas. In the Philippines there has been a distinct lack of results in terms of economic advancement and the reallocation of land to peasants.

During the revolution one read about the unity between Laurel, the Vice-President, and Aquino, the President, and the united action to remove Marcos. The great pity is that that unity has gone; people are now starting to look at their personal position, and there is division. As a result, the people in the Philippines suffer.

It is quite unnerving to talk to some of the police in the Philippines, with the six-shooters at the hip and magazines of ammunition around their belts, even though they are surrounded by hundred of other people with submachine guns. It is sad when a trade union organisation like the KMU, which represents sugar workers, can have its vice-president shot publicly, and no progress is made in finding the culprit. It was indicated to us-this appears in the report-that the Communist Party's New People's Army is suspected. I would be very sceptical about that being the case. I believe we should continue to assist the Filipino people. The report describes our efforts in that regard.

As far as Korea is concerned, there is no doubt-I agree with Senator Parer-that it has made tremendous strides in terms of economic progress and providing better living standards for the people. One thing it sadly lacks is democracy. It is also good to see that in that regard it is moving forward. Certain demands are being made by the people. There is a minority government. Those people who were once in prison are now leading political parties and are able to put their point of view.

I wish to mention the discussion that is taking place about the reunification of North and South Korea. It seems to me that that is not a possibility. The first thing that is needed-and it would be needed before any second step could be taken-is some freedom of movement across the demilitarised zone. That does not seem possible, but until it is I believe that any talk of reunification is empty talk.

In closing, I thank the Australian people for the opportunity of representing them overseas. All visits like this, during which exchanges of points of view can be readily carried out, are to the advantage of this country as well as those which we visit.

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO SINGAPORE, MALAYSIA AND PAPUA NEW GUINEA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Singapore, Malaysia and Papua New Guinea from 27 July to 16 August 1988. I seek leave to make a short statement in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In light of the recent controversy concerning reports of other delegations, to which Senator Parer referred, I feel it important to say that this was a very harmonious, constructive and positive delegation, and I endorse the remarks made by the President in presenting his report earlier.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the success of this delegation, as well as thanking others, to whom I will refer later, I think specific mention should be made of its leadership. I refer, in particular, to the honourable member for Hughes, Mr Robert Tickner, and also to the deputy leader of the delegation, the honourable member for Bass, Mr Warwick Smith. They both played an excellent role. They worked well together and they made it much easier for the other members of the delegation.

There has been some controversy about the question of accompanying spouses. Two members of the delegation were accompanied by spouses. That in no way militated against the successful conduct of the business of the delegation. In fact, they enhanced our capacity to communicate with our hosts and saved us from some difficult circumstances in social situations.

The visit was very positive for individual members of parliament. Not only that, it gave us the opportunity to raise in a semi-official way issues on behalf of Australia that are very important. I hope and believe it increased the standard of understanding and perception of Australia in those countries. In particular, in tabling the report-which essentially speaks for itself and I do not wish to reiterate what it says-I must say that we had to deal with some very sensitive human rights matters. That is why I appreciated the harmonious, bipartisan attitude of the delegation. The issues were politically sensitive in the countries in which we found ourselves, particularly in Singapore and Malaysia, and in Australia. It was therefore very important that the matter be handled with discretion, and that was the case.

I take this opportunity to express my concern about the human rights situation in Singapore and Malaysia, as is referred to in the report, and to add a personal note about my concern, which I have raised in Malaysia, in Australia before we left, and again now, about the detention of Opposition members of parliament, representatives of the Democratic Action Party of Malaysia. I refer in particular to a parliamentary colleague and a person whom I met in Australia many years ago, even before I was National Secretary of the Australian Labor Party, when I was Secretary in Western Australia. Mr P. Patto, the Organising Secretary of the Democratic Action Party, is interned. I refer also to the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Lim Kit Siang, who is under detention for a second time. While I appreciate the circumstances in Malaysia, I think it is inappropriate that these people should remain in detention.

The important point about the delegation's visit to both countries was that it maintained its sense of perspective while raising forthrightly the sensitive human rights issues. It was also able to conduct positive dialogue with representatives from the public and private sectors, parliamentarians and others, in both countries, about important economic and trade relations and about things we can learn in science and technology. It made some very important contacts for subsequent enhancement of relations between our countries. I have been gratified in the brief period since we have returned to have had an exchange visit from the Director of the Science Park in Singapore who, during a visit to Canberra, came to see me and continued discussions which we had commenced during the visit to Singapore. I hope in that way I was able to help him in the visit and contribute to the evolution of policy in his country, as he was able to help us.

The issue that Senator Burns referred to with regard to the Philippines-Australian aid-remains a very important part of our relationship with Papua New Guinea. We also saw the broader nature of the mutual interests of our countries. I want to reinforce the recommendation of the delegation that Papua New Guinea, as such a close and important neighbour culturally, strategically and economically, should take a higher profile in the activities of the Parliament, in its relationship with other countries. We make a number of very worthwhile visits to many countries. It is all too rare that parliamentarians visit this country which is our nearest neighbour. I think we all found our understanding, as parliamentarians interested in the affairs of that country, was all too minimal and it is important that that understanding be enhanced.

I want to thank the hosts in the various countries, and the Australian High Commission staff. I endorse the remarks made by Senator Burns. High Commission staffs in these countries gave us outstanding assistance. They are outstanding representatives of our country. I thank my fellow delegates and Allan Kelly, the secretary to the delegation. I thank the Parliament and the people of Australia for the opportunity of representing them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I reiterate and support the remarks of Senator McMullan about the report of this delegation to Singapore, Malaysia and Papua New Guinea. It was the first occasion that I have represented Australia as a member of a parliamentary delegation, and I was very proud to do so. I did not know what to expect, but as was said by Senator McMullan and, I think, Senator Parer and Senator Burns, delegations are certainly not junkets. They are an opportunity for Australian parliamentarians to meet politicians from other countries. I, too, say that I was more than a little concerned about the human rights issues in Malaysia and Singapore. I particularly remember that when we were in Malaysia at a meeting with the Bar Council I was astonished to find the members all wearing pins on their lapels with the words `Justice for Judges'. I do not think many places in the world would have judges wearing badges such as that.

SPEECH.PARA: Some very positive aspects came to light as a result of the visit from our parliamentary delegation. Before I go any further I would also thank Allan Kelly for the wonderful way in which he looked after us, even though I did take a little time over a haircut one day which caused some concern to our leader. But we were a very harmonious group. It gave me the opportunity not only to understand the ways of politicians in other countries, but also to learn a little about politicians in our own country, and I was very gratified for that. The staff of the high commissions everywhere we visited, as Senator McMullan has said, were most helpful and their comprehensive briefings were more than adequate for the tasks that faced us.

I would like to highlight a few of what I thought were the positive aspects of the trip. I was very impressed by the professional approach to industry and commerce shown by the Malaysian Industrial Development Authority. I have passed on some of its ideas to my State Government in the hope that it may take note of them. While I am on that subject, as a delegation we noted that in Sabah-in fact, in all of Malaysia-there existed quite a good market for students to come to Australia to study. I am pleased to say that both Warwick Smith, MP, and I approached our State Government on returning to Tasmania-I am not taking credit for all of this-and that a small delegation, or working group of educationalists, has gone to Malaysia this week to follow up some of the contacts that we made and some earlier contacts made by the Tasmanian Government.

Another matter that came to light while we were in Sabah was an incident regarding the export of some feral goats from northern Australia to Kota Kinabalu. I was most upset to see the condition of those goats. Some 80 out of 400 died. I am a member of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare, and I am sure that my colleagues on that Committee would also be very disappointed at the way in which these animals were treated and the condition they arrived at in Malaysia. I have followed that matter up and I am pleased to say that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy has assured me that the chance of that happening again is most unlikely. I hope that is correct.

I suppose the highlight of our tour was the time we spent in Papua New Guinea. I must say that for me, on my first trip outside the country, it was somewhat of a culture shock. Anybody travelling to Papua New Guinea who has an opportunity to visit the Goroka show will see thousands of years of history in one particular area at one particular time. I would like to compliment publicly the work of our small detachment of engineers in Mendi in the Southern Highlands Province. They have not only helped the local people in all sorts of ways, but also they are providing a very positive Australian presence in an area that is still very much in the Stone Age in some ways. I was very pleased to have heard the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) recently, in this place, saying that Australia is hoping to place another unit of engineers in Papua New Guinea. It is a very positive way of Australia keeping its presence felt in this neighbouring country of ours which, believe it or not, is only five kilometres away from Australia. I reiterate what Senator McMullan said: the fact is that Papua New Guinea is so close to Australia, yet we were the first parliamentary delegation to visit that country in five years. That is something we should remember because, whilst our Foreign Ministers and officials from the Foreign Affairs departments may drop in to each other's country quite often, I think the contact between politicians at a more grass roots level is very important.

I was very impressed by the aid we are giving to the Papua New Guinea Police Force. I suppose the much publicised problem in Papua New Guinea at the moment is law and order and having to cope with the `rascals'. Some of the recommendations in our report, particularly about assisting the Papua New Guinea Government with unemployment schemes and the like, are a positive way in which our delegation may help solve that situation.

Another matter that I had some personal interest in was the perceived problem of hydatids. This matter was raised with us in Mendi in the Southern Highlands. The Papua New Guinea Government, in its wisdom, is trying to encourage the use of sheep rather than pigs in the native villages-and I think it is a great idea. It seems that the local authorities are concerned that the habits of the people, along with the dogs and everything else that goes with them, could bring about the onset of hydatids. Being a Tasmanian, I know the problems hydatids can cause, because Tasmania did have the highest incidence of hydatids in the world, apart from Yugoslavia. After 24 years we now have the cleanest situation concerning hydatids in the world. The health authorities in the Southern Highlands were aware of this. Since I have returned, I have contacted our local agricultural department and have sent some material to the Papua New Guinea authorities. I am pleased to say that Senator Cook has taken the matter up, and I hope an Australian International Development Assistance Bureau project will help Papua New Guinea resolve this problem down the track.

If the Government takes notice of our recommendation to continue the aid to the villagers in controlling rust in coffee, that will have a very significant effect on the local industry in Papua New Guinea, because the village system as the villagers know it in the Highlands relies wholly and solely on coffee, and anything that damaged that industry would be a major disaster in that area.

As other honourable senators have said, these delegations do drag on and we work very hard. But I will always remember the final function we had on the last evening in Kieta in the North Solomons Province, where the huge Bougainville copper mine is located and we were very impressed by that. We were given a farewell function by the Province and I will always remember the floor show, which was accompanied by a bamboo band. If honourable senators want to know what a bamboo band is, their instruments consist of different lengths of bamboo taped together with various lengths of insulating tape and are pounded on one end with a rubber thong. I assure honourable senators that it is a rather unusual noise, and just for Senator McMullan, I will remind him what it sounds like. It sounds like this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I think that is not in order, but you have done it now, so it is all right.

—by leave-Senator McMullan made a quite proper remark about the benefit of unity in such delegations and also referred to the lack of unity in another Australian parliamentary delegation. If Senator McMullan was referring to this year's Australian parliamentary delegation to Ethiopia, Tanzania, Mozambique and Zimbabwe, of which I was a member--

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I believe that, given the business of the Senate which has to be transacted in the next fortnight or so, it would be most helpful if you, Mr Deputy President, made sure that honourable senators were kept relevant to the report under consideration. I understood that Senator Baume sought leave to talk to the report under consideration and not to some other delegation.
—Senator Baume asked to make a statement on the report, and so far he is being relevant. Senator Michael Baume, you have leave to make a statement on the report.

—Thank you. I want only one minute. I was not seeking to embarrass the honourable senator, the Government or anyone, but I thank him for his interruption. If Senator McMullan was referring to that delegation, of which I was a member, I must say here that, with one or two minor exceptions, no host nation would have been aware of any conflicts or personal differences that may have existed between members of the delegation. Recent sensational press reports from Australia will no doubt come as a surprise to our hosts. I regret that these personal differences and related issues were made public by someone who clearly did not have the best interests of this nation at heart.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should answer an earlier question by Senator Durack, who has very kindly indicated that he is on a flight to Western Australia, I believe. Senator Durack asked me how many interrogations-that was the term that he used-had been undertaken by the Special Investigations Unit. Without adopting perhaps all of the overtones inherent in that word, let me say that a number of interviews have been undertaken but I am unable to give Senator Durack the exact number.

—I wish to ask a question in line with Senator Durack's question. With regard to the employment of the Commonwealth police in these inquiries-according to evidence that has been produced, they have been announcing themselves as Commonwealth police and asking questions-in what part of the charter of the Commonwealth police are these activities undertaken? There is no crime involved, at least no current crime-there may be a future crime. What exactly are the police doing questioning people when there is no alleged offence?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Greenwood and the Special Investigations Unit have sought to second officers from the Australian Federal Police-I think three-and some New South Wales police have been attached to the Special Investigations Unit at Mr Greenwood's request because of the obvious skills which they have in conducting investigations. The sorts of inquiries they are carrying out are an extension, if you like, of the sorts of inquiries that Mr Menzies undertook. As acknowledged by all sides in this Parliament, when the report of the Menzies Review of Alleged Entry of Criminals into Australia was tabled he required this further series of steps in order to further particularise the matters which he brought to the attention of the Executive and then to the Parliament by way of report.

SPEECH.PARA: The sorts of investigations being undertaken could be undertaken, I suppose, by various persons and under various auspices. In Canada it was the Deschenes Royal Commission. I know that in England similar sorts of inquiries are being undertaken by a former distinguished Director of Public Pros- ecutions. In this nation the inquiry is being undertaken by the Special Investigations Unit and police officers are attached to help in the further investigation of matters which Mr Menzies alerted us to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice has not answered my question. I can accept, though I do not approve of it, that the Special Investigations Unit can carry out investigations on available material suggesting there may be war criminals in Australia. It is not the same thing as Commonwealth police officers-they are the ones we are particularly concerned with in this Parliament-announcing themselves quite properly as Commonwealth police officers and questioning people when there is no alleged offence. I ask the Minister-I am sure that he would agree there is no alleged offence; there may be one in the future but there is not one at the moment-by what right and under what part of their charter are police officers questioning people when there is no alleged offence?

—The Australian Federal Police are being attached to the Special Investigations Unit in order to help it carry out its investigations. It is an Executive function to fully examine these matters as is necessary. The Federal Police are aiding the Executive in properly discharging its duty to fully and comprehensively conduct an investigation which is carried out expertly but fairly. They have a particular skill and have been attached to the unit for that reason. It is simply a question of the Australian Federal Police aiding the Executive in this particular matter.

—I want to be quite clear on what the Minister is saying. The Minister is saying, as I understand him, that the Australian Federal Police, paid for ultimately by an appropriation by the Federal Parliament, have a right to question Australian citizen residents when there is no alleged offence involved. Is that what the Minister is saying?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am saying that at this stage in the inquiries being undertaken by Mr Greenwood and the Special Investigations Unit it is appropriate that we have the assistance of skilled persons. Those persons who have been seconded from the Australian Federal Police are such skilled persons. They are undertaking interviews which are designed to help Mr Greenwood in resolving, I suppose, some preliminary questions. But it is simply a use of their particular abilities and skills in this stage of the work of the unit which, as Senator Hamer points out, precedes the passage of the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: As all honourable senators will know and as Mr Reith, for example, in the House of Representatives acknowledged in relation to the Menzies report, there was a requirement that that report be followed up with investigations. The Special Investigations Unit is constituted by persons of various skills, including archival experts and historians of great eminence, some seconded and some on contract, from Australia and around the world. Amongst members of the team that has been assembled to discharge this very onerous duty, and one on which the whole of Australia is, of course, concentrating its attention in order to ensure that it is conducted fairly, are these Federal Police officers with their special skills.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although it was a lengthy answer, I take it that the Minister's answer to my last question was yes.

I think that is a shocking indictment of the way the Government has tried--
—What a lot of nonsense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

It is of such importance that I hope he would at least take it on notice today and come back into this place with a more specific answer at a later date. Because of time restraints and for other reasons I will not pursue that matter further at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Very briefly, I want to make mention of a couple of other aspects relating to the work of the Special Investigations Unit (SIU) and the investigations that it is undertaking. I was very surprised indeed that the SIU was not able to tell us how long it would take to complete its investigations. At the Estimates Committee hearings in April it gave an estimation, from memory, of a year or so. At the last Estimates Committee hearings it was not able to give us any indication of time. I believe that that is a very serious matter. Again, for the reasons we went into in the earlier part of the discussion today, it is imperative that the investigations of the SIU be carried out with the utmost care. It is now known, although the Minister is not prepared to tell us how many people are involved, that investigations and interrogations of people are taking place in this country. Written responses from the SIU since the Estimates Committee hearings have also told us that witnesses are being interviewed in the Soviet Union, including the Baltic states and in countries such as Yugoslavia and Hungary. Therefore, I believe that this whole area is a powder keg. If the Government does not handle it more sensitively and frankly than it has been doing to date, it will cause very great concerns and problems in this country.

There have been various irregularities in relation to the travel of officers of the SIU. To date the costs have been quite phenomenal. The fact that the SIU is unable, at this stage, to put a date on the conclusion of its investigations presumably means that the cost is open-ended at this time. We do not know how many people are involved. The Menzies inquiry less than two years ago came up with a figure of 70 suggested names. We were told in the Estimates Committee that the number of names exceeds 500-I think it is 525-although the file has been closed on 110 of those. But that still leaves more than 400 names that were admitted at the Estimates Committee hearing. I understand from remarks that have been made since that time that there could be even more than that.

We were provided with what I believe is extraordinary information at the Estimates Committee hearing in terms of the sources of these names. As I understand it, 164 names were provided to Australia by the Soviet Union without any supporting material; I think that is what was indicated at the Estimates Committee. Quite frankly, that is a scandalous situation that the Government must explain in greater detail than it has done to date. I know that I speak for a large number of people both within this Parliament and outside the Parliament when I say to the Minister that there is an enormous amount of concern in the community about how this matter is being handled. The very fact that it has come up at all is a separate issue. But, in my view, the way the Government is handling it at the moment is designed-I presume not deliberately but it will have this effect-to make what is a very difficult and sensitive issue that much more difficult.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short said that various irregularities had occurred in the expenditure of the Special Investigations Unit. I cannot recall any such irregularities being pointed out at the Estimates Committee or in the Committee's report to this chamber. If he believes that such irregularities have occurred I would wish to be informed so that the responsible Minister, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), can take proper action. But I think it is an unfortunate assertion to make, in the absence of any evidence that I am aware of, that irregularities have occurred in relation to the expenditure of the Special Investigations Unit.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the list received from the Soviet Union, unfortunately, the Special Investigations Unit is not in a position to predetermine what it will receive from various sources. It was presented with a list of 164 names which, as I understand it, did not have any supporting material apart from an indication of the presence of persons in Australia. Obviously the Director, who was in receipt of that list, has formally requested the Soviet Union for details of the allegations. That has not been forthcoming so far and I believe that the status of the list would be well judged by that very fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that the Minister has commented on that list of 164 people I ask: What does the Government propose to do with those 164 names? How will the Special Investigations Unit (SIU) process the matter? As I understand it, those names have been in the hands of the SIU for more than 12 months but no evidence or backup material has been forthcoming from the Soviet authorities. What is the Government going to do? Will it leave the 164 names that have been supplied for more than 12 months by the Soviet Union without any substantiating evidence or material at all just hanging loose? That is not the way to run a country.

—Mr Greenwood has already shown a capacity to close files where there is either insufficient evidence or, for some reason, he considers that the allegation is not made out or could not be sufficiently made out. He has already indicated an ability and a capacity to do that. I believe that some 125 files have been closed. If the 164 names that have been forwarded from the Soviet Union fall into the category of `no evidence to back up allegations is forthcoming', quite clearly Mr Greenwood would also close those files. I am quite sure that the normal processes which he uses-and, as I have said, has already used, to the effect that many allegations have been discounted and files closed-would be able to be used in this instance.
—Have any of those 164 people been questioned by the Special Investigations Unit yet?

—In accordance with my previous indication to the chamber in answer to Senator Durack, quite clearly I am in no position to inform the chamber as to whether any of those 164 people have been interviewed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I wish to raise under the Attorney-General's Department is subprogram 4.4, the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) Magistrates Court. The documents which were supplied to Estimates Committee E set out in list form the functions of the court, which include, the criminal jurisdiction under which it tries offences punishable summarily, and holding preliminary inquiries into whether or not indictable offences should be heard before a jury. It may try a defendant on indictable offences other than the most serious offences. There is a civil jurisdiction with a monetary limit presently of $12,000 for claims for death and damages, family law matters, maintenance, workers compensation, second-hand dealers licences, collectors licences, auctioneers licences, mental health applications, criminal injuries compensation claims, domestic violence applications, small claims, the children's court, and the coroner's court. That is an extremely important list of activities.
—I think I know where we are going.

—We will get there. That is an important list of functions which are carried out by the court. I remind the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) that as from January next year, I think, the civil jurisdiction will increase to $50,000 which will mean a considerable increase in the amount of work involved. Presently there are five magistrates and I think the equivalent of two special magistrates working on a full time basis.

SPEECH.PARA: There are significant delays in getting cases heard before the Magistrates Court at present. I wish to refer to some of the times involved. Urgent matters in the criminal jurisdiction, I am told, take three to four months. If a person is in custody it may take four months; if not, it will take eight to nine months. Traffic offences take eight months, civil cases take five to six months, small claims take two to three months, family matters take two to three months, and the children's court-wait for it-takes two months if a matter is urgent and if it is not urgent it takes about three months. Workers compensation takes up to eight months. One can imagine the disruption to the life of a family waiting that long. Domestic violence, if it is urgent, takes a week. If it is not urgent it takes three to four weeks. I would have thought that any domestic violence matter was in the urgent category. Inquests take five to six weeks. Of course an inquest occurs only when there is extreme trauma and upset for a family. I certainly have had people contact me about the distress of having to wait for long for the outcome of an inquest.

In view of these delays and the work of the court, there ought to be an increase in funds to enable the court to carry out its functions properly. Not only is there not an increase but there is a decrease on the funds available last year. I wish to refer to the figures. The administrative expenses of the ACT Magistrates Court in 1987-88 were $628,000, yet this year the estimated expenses are put at $249,000, which is a reduction of $379,000. In amongst all the details of the Estimates is what is described as a one-off payment for the Forensic Medical Centre totalling $440,000. It was admitted at the Estimates Committee hearing that this was an erroneous figure and that, in fact, it was more like $267,000, which is a difference of $173,000. I ask the Minister: Where is the $173,000 and why has it not been restored?

The question remains as to whether the $267,000 is truly a one-off figure. It comprises $80,000 for each of 1985-86 and 1986-87-that is, a total of $160,000-in respect of forensic fees paid to the Health Commission of the ACT by the court. Apparently that was a negotiated figure which the two government agencies agreed was a reasonable cost at that time. The remainder, $107,000, which is the cost of toxicology tests for the year 1987-88, was arrived at on a fee for service basis. It was not just negotiated as had been the case in the two previous years. In other words, for 1987-88 the cost of forensic work for the Magistrates Court was $107,000, and there will be continuing forensic costs for this year. In fact, they are likely to be the same, if not higher, than they were last year. These costs will not disappear; it is not, as was stated at the time of the Estimates Committee hearing, a one-off expense. The court will require an allocation for this year's forensic fees, but it seems to me from reading the figures that none has been made. I hope the Minister will be able to explain it. I was surprised at comments made by the Department at the Estimates Committee hearing. One officer said:
Figures on workload are somewhat ambiguous. They suggest . . . a falling off in the criminal and civil work of the Court in the last 10 years . . .

Quite frankly, Minister, I would be very surprised if this were so. Of course no evidence was given to substantiate that comment. In terms of the court's ability to do the work which it is required to do I wish to refer to a problem the Office of ACT Administration has had in collecting parking fines. Honourable senators might think that that is not a particularly significant matter-it certainly is not the most important work the Magistrates Court is responsible for-but there is over $1m outstanding in parking fines because the court has not been able to cope with the volume of work. The Government has not changed the structure of parking fines so that they can be dealt with in some other way, and parking fine collection is still a matter to be dealt with by the Magistrates Court. That is the way the system runs at present. We can make out a very good case for changing it, but until that occurs that is what happens.

There has been an exchange of letters between the Attorney-General's Department and the ACT Administration has forgone $117,000 of its Budget allocation to allow the Attorney-General's Department to pay for additional services of the court to recover these moneys. There is something seriously wrong with our system when to get justice through the Magistrates Court we have to pay for it in that fashion. While the Government is running the court system it is obliged to provide the facilities to see that the work that should be done by the court in fact can be done-otherwise, change the system. The Government, for reasons best known to itself, has retained the running of the Magistrates Court, at least until 1990. The Magistrates Court will not be passing to the ACT government next year when other functions pass to it. I would say that the Government is obliged to provide this community with a magistrates court which functions properly and is able to do what it is required to do.

I am told that the Attorney-General's Department blames the Department of Finance for this problem. The Department of Finance may set the amount of money that is available, but it is the Attorney-General's Department and the Government which set the priorities for the way in which the money is spent. Clearly the ACT Magistrates Court, either in the mind of the Government or in the mind of the Attorney-General's Department, has a very low priority. I say to the Minister as an elected member of this community, that that is unacceptable. I also understand that the Budget shortfall on present indications will be significant. About 70 per cent of what has been allocated this year has already been spent. What happens when 100 per cent has been spent in a very short time? There is no doubt that the staff and magistrates of the court are clearly, reasonably and understandably demoralised by the way they have been treated by their own Department.

Talking of being demoralised, I want to refer to the matter that the Minister was probably alluding to when I started, that of the remuneration of magistrates. It is an absolute disgrace that magistrates' salaries are not being increased and are just under $66,000 at a time when we are looking at a proposed increase to the salary of the President of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to $180,000; ACT Supreme Court judges to $180,000; and Family Court judges to $162,000.

They are the figures that have been deemed fair and reasonable for those positions. I have already pointed out to the chamber that magistrates do a considerable amount of work that is done similarly by judges in the Family Court. The difference in salary? Under $66,000 for one and $162,000 for the other. I do not know how the Minister can sit there and contemplate paying magistrates at that rate when comparing them with the others in the judicial system. The magistrates are still being treated as poor relations.

There have been changes in the last 30 years. A long time ago the magistrates courts were called the courts of petty sessions. Such courts had little judicial responsibility and were presided over by people who were not legally qualified. That is not the case now and has not been the case for a very long time. The magistrates court is a court of significant judicial responsibility and magistrates ought to be paid accordingly. They are people who have been practising in the legal profession for many years and they ought to be remunerated in accordance with the work they are doing. Do not tell me that they are being paid what the Remuneration Tribunal thinks they are worth because, if that is the case, I would say that it is time the Government had a look at who is sitting on the Tribunal because it clearly does not understand the work of the magistrates court and the very important role that it plays in our community. The Tribunal ought to have its attention drawn to the list of functions carried out by the court that I read out earlier from the Government's own papers in relation to this section of the portfolio.

The remuneration of the magistrates is a disgrace and ought to be looked at. We will not get good people running magistrates courts if we do not pay them a little better. I have already indicated that a Family Court judge is worth $162,000. A magistrate must be worth something near that, not what he is being paid at present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had some conversations with the Chief Magistrate of the Australian Capital Territory, Mr Ron Cahill, I think only on Tuesday morning, and I understand very well the constraints under which the magistracy in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) feels it is operating.
