I believe that it is very significant that the exercise being undertaken to review the resources for the ACT Magistrates Court is progressing extremely well. The Chief Magistrate reported this to me and, as Senator Reid knows, he is chairman of the steering committee to which the working committee reports and makes its various suggestions. It will be incumbent on government to take very seriously the matters which arise out of that review which is being undertaken.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the resources available, Senator Reid will know that, as was indicated at the Estimates Committee, a misleading impression was given because of the presentation of the explanatory notes and the expenditure amounts in terms of not indicating clearly that the Supreme Court estimates included an amount which really would be devoted to administration of the magistrates courts. As I understand it, the various allocations between those two items will be adjusted in a way which makes it clearer as the year goes on that those moneys will be available, as they properly ought to be, to the Magistrates Court.

Senator Reid mentioned so much. The ACT Administration provided $117,000 for the provision of a magistrate and his supporting staff to deal with parking fines. Indeed, from the point of view of the ACT Administration, that will prove to be a very worthwhile investment: it will get much more than the $117,000 it spends on the support of the Magistrates Court in that respect. But I agree with Senator Reid that parking matters are a most inappropriate, time consuming and wasteful use of the Magistrates Court. The Government is moving to bring about a new system in relation to those who refuse to pay fines levied in respect of certain offences such as parking. I agree that the sooner that alternative scheme can be brought into operation the better. It ought to have been looked at a lot earlier. I hope that the alternative scheme will free the magistrates to concentrate on the sort of work which Senator Reid outlined as more properly characteristic of carrying out a judicial function which is satisfying for a person with the sort of training that magistrates have.

Magistrates have a wide range of matters to deal with. Many and various jurisdictions have been added in a sort of ad hoc manner over the years and I believe that magistrates' work has undergone a qualitative change. Nevertheless, I have to point out that the Remuneration Tribunal has examined the matter and has not seen fit to increase magistrates' salaries beyond the 3 per cent increase. Indeed, the salary for an ACT magistrate of $65,653 compares reasonably well with the lower end of the scale across Australia. Magistrates in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia have similar salaries: Western Australia is exceptional with a level of $75,000. The first three States I mentioned pay salaries in the region of $70,000 to $72,000 a year. In Tasmania the level is $64,345 and in the Northern Territory, $65,000. It will be seen that the salary set by the Remuneration Tribunal-not by the Government-for ACT magistrates of $65,653 is consistent with the lower end of the scale. I can assure Senator Reid that Mr Cahill in his representations to me made it clear that in order to continue to attract good persons to the bench, which naturally is his desire, he would wish to see an increase in that level of remuneration. I am simply pointing out that the level is not out of kilter with that available to magistrates in other jurisdictions.

Senator Reid pointed out the time that it can take to have a matter dealt with. I do not have any scale or graph in front of me outlining delays. They are always a cause of concern to the people involved in whatever jurisdiction they occur. Any undue delay is troubling and sometimes traumatic. In relation to domestic violence, I do not think the figure Senator Reid gave is right. I understand from Mr Cahill's conversation with me that an interim order can be obtained from a court within a couple of hours. Such orders deal with a great majority of domestic violence cases, which is a very large and growing jurisdiction for the courts in the Australian Capital Territory. In short, I believe that the Government, as indicated by setting up of the review into the resources available to the ACT magistracy and with other matters being undertaken such as the new regime to deal with parking fines, has a willingness to ensure that the ACT magistracy is adequately able to perform its very important task in this community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without going over it all again, there are one or two comments I would like to make in reply. I am aware of the review and what is going and and I hope that will come to something and that computerisation and things of that nature will be introduced. That too has been somewhat delayed. I am pleased to hear that the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has talked to the Chief Magistrate about these matters. My discussions have been principally with members of the legal profession who deal in the area. The Minister may talk to them at some stage as well.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of salaries, I recognise the figures that the Minister gave. As he said, the Australian Capital Territory rate tends to be at the lower end of the scale of magistrates' pay but the Minister must remember that there is no District Court in the Australian Capital Territory; the Magistrates Court is the only stage between not being in court at all and being in the Supreme Court. That is a significant difference. I believe that, if we have a Tribunal that just does not understand the place of the Magistrates Court here, some adjustment to the make-up of the Tribunal is necessary. It is obvious that the Tribunal has no understanding of the fact that magistrates do work that is so similar to the work of the Family Court judges when a Family Court judge has a salary of $162,000 and the salary of a magistrate is under $66,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few brief comments about the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC). Both the written evidence and the oral evidence supplied to Estimates Committee E confirmed the dreadful situation that the Government has now foisted upon the NCSC, which is the nation's corporate watchdog. There has been a massive increase in corporate crime in recent years. We were told at the hearing that the major areas of concern are insider trading, market manipulation, the warehousing of shares and directors' fiduciary duties. Yet, despite the massive increase in corporate crime, which is recognised generally, the Government will not provide the NCSC with the necessary resources to police these areas.

SPEECH.PARA: In real terms the NCSC is going backwards in its resources. It is being progressively starved, in a period which has included the largest stock market crash in our history. But despite the crash and, therefore, the increased role of the NCSC, the Government has determined a reduction in the approved staffing level for the NCSC, which has been cut back from 82 to 79. This year funding for the NCSC has fallen by 4 per cent in real terms. At the Estimates hearing the Executive Director of the Commission, Mr Schoer, gave evidence that the financial and other constraints imposed on the NCSC by the Government have meant:

Since the crash, there have been many more problems in the corporate sector and more risks are being taken by some of the entrepreneurs, which has meant that the Commission has had to be engaged in much more investigation.
He said:
There is a large number of inquiries we would have wished to make but could not.

As well, despite the fact that the Government's proposal to replace the NCSC with an Australian Securities Commission-I will get to that in a moment-has yet to pass the Parliament and, indeed, may never do so, in this year's Budget appropriations $1m is allocated for pre-establishment costs for the ASC. I ask the Minister; What is going to happen to those funds if they are not expended? If they are going to be expended this year, given the delays that have occurred, precisely on what matters are they going to be expended? It is interesting to note that Mr Schoer told us in the Estimates Committee hearing that the Commission had `fairly minimal involvement with the Attorney-General's corporate securities legislative package', and that it was not involved in discussions relating to the drafting of the legislation. I find it extraordinary that the body with the greatest expertise in the whole area of corporate law so far as the operation of the securities and financial markets is concerned was not involved at all in the drafting of a whole new panoply of securities law and legislation. Obviously, there is a conflict between the NCSC and the Attorney-General's Department in various respects. That was quite evident from an answer provided to us stating that according to the NCSC the proposed new corporate legislative package would not have allowed the NCSC, for example, to have played the role it did in investigating the bid by Bond for the Bell Group. That is the view of the NCSC. It appears not to be the view of the Attorney-General's Department.

It concerns me greatly that the NCSC is being starved of funds to carry out its legitimate and mandatory watchdog responsibilities over the Australian securities and financial markets at a time when there has never been a greater need for that, and at a time when the Commission is being given-rightly so-an investigative role in regard to Rothwells Ltd, Ariadne and some other important examples. It is difficult to escape the conclusion that the reason why the resources are not being adequately provided to the NCSC is that the Government wishes deliberately to stretch the NCSC to the limit and beyond so that it can then have more justification and support for its proposals to introduce the enormously centralist, socialist and bureaucratically engineered ASC to replace the NCSC and to redraw the corporate law picture.

TALK.START.PARA: —It could also be a cover-up for what is going on in some of the States, too.

—Yes; as my colleague Senator Messner says, it could well be intended to draw a blind or a cover-up over what is going on in the other States, particularly in Western Australia where the recent activities of the Western Australian Government have been described, very appropriately, as WA Inc. The Western Australian Government has become involved with the private sector and with big business, putting at risk hundreds of millions of dollars of taxpayers' funds. This Government is refusing to make the necessary investigations into the matter. To some degree the NCSC has now been asked to play a role regarding the Rothwells debacle. If the Government were fair dinkum about it, it would have a much broader inquiry. It would have a royal commission into the whole matter. If it is not going to do that, it should certainly provide the NCSC with the resources to do a proper job on the Rothwells investigation without so drawing its resources into that area that it is unable to carry out its important undertakings in other areas.

SPEECH.PARA: If that is not the reason why the Government is refusing to provide adequate funding to the NCSC, and why it is cutting it back significantly in real terms,-it is not just this year; it has happened progressively over the last two or three years-I hope that the Minister will inform the Committee what the legitimate reason is. Particularly at this time, it is an extraordinary example of a misallocation government priorities if the Government is going to deny funds in areas such as this whilst at the same time continuing to give enormous grants in the form of hand-outs to its mates all around the place across the board of government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I never thought that Senator Short would sound like President Gorbachev of the Soviet Union. For him to start railing against the proposed Australian Securities Commission (ASC) as being a centralised, bureaucratic, socialist monster-a Stalinist model, no doubt-shows that rhetoric has got the better of him. The fact is that funds for the operation of the National Companies and Securities Commission have not been affected in order to make the ASC proposal look better; nor is it the case that a cover-up has been attempted in order to starve the NCSC of sufficient resources adequately to undertake its investigation of the matters surrounding the collapse of Rothwells Ltd. As I have pointed out in this chamber before, I had the very good fortune to bump into Mr Bosch at Tullamarine Airport on Monday morning. I specifically asked him whether he had sufficient resources to undertake the inquiry into Rothwells. He said yes. He said that it could be got off the ground in a speedy and timely way.

SPEECH.PARA: No doubt, the Ministerial Council, which is meeting tomorrow, and for which the Attorneys have come from all over Australia to Canberra, will be able to further consider the matter in light of the various reports that will be available to it from the National Companies and Securities Commission and from the auditors, in relation to Rothwells. I believe that will enable them to determine whether the section 36 investigation, with all the power available to the NCSC under section 37, is indeed adequate. The fact is that the NCSC could have approached a relevant State Minister or the Commonwealth Minister in order to suggest that an investigation be undertaken under some other section of the legislation. It has not done so. I believe that that indicates that it believes at the moment that the sorts of hearings it will undertake speedily-or at least get off the ground speedily-will help to unravel this matter.

It is for neither of those reasons that there has been any reduction in resources. Speaking of the Ministerial Council brings one back to the central point that the NCSC is funded by governments, not by the Federal Government alone. It is the responsibility of all participating governments from around Australia, the various jurisdictions, to provide the funds to make the NCSC operate efficiently and well.

It would be remarkable if there were collusion-which is what the honourable senator must be suggesting-between all the members of the NCSC, representing all of the governments of different political complexions around Australia, to starve the NCSC of funds. That has only to be stated to indicate how highly improbable it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that mean that the Federal Government would be prepared to increase its funding of the NCSC?

—The funds available to the NCSC fall into the category of consideration by the Federal Government which requires that the various elements of the Attorney-General's portfolio be stringently looked at. They have been looked at. The same kinds of efficiencies that are required across the portfolio are required of the NCSC. From my experience of Estimates committees, both as a senator posing questions and as a Minister, what is of most concern about the NCSC, and the Trade Practices Commission to a lesser extent, is not so much the number of persons who are available to it under average staffing levels, which is, after all, a fairly artificial concept, but the quality of the people and the means to hold on to them in a marketplace, particularly in Melbourne--
—That is to do with resources, too.

—It is to do with salary levels, Senator, which is of great concern, particularly to the Attorney-General's portfolio, because of the difficulty of retaining people when they can be attracted by such enormously high salaries in the private sector. It is almost impossible to imagine the Commonwealth coming up with a comparable package.

SPEECH.PARA: That is not the only issue. Many people no doubt use-in a reasonable sense of the word-the NCSC as a ground within which they receive a certain level of experience before going to the private sector. It is that problem which is constantly raised before Estimates committees and which is a cause of concern and of constant discussion within the Government. Indeed, to some extent, the same general matter explains the Remuneration Tribunal's decision in relation to judicial salaries. If one is to attract people of first-rate quality to our benches, one needs to compete with the money that is available to top Queen's Counsels.

TALK.START.PARA: —Doesn't the same argument apply with respect to members of parliament?

—I do not know exactly with whom we are compared and the extent of the pool from which we are drawn. It is not such a narrow, well-paid pool from which we are drawn, Senator, unless one is perhaps a shareholder of note-I am not saying anything adverse-or a very successful person who has obtained a level of resources which goes beyond those available to the ordinary wage and salary earner.
—There is something to be said for the proposition that we would do it for nothing. Then we would sort out who is serious.
—I am prepared to do it for half as much, Senator.
—Half as much as I get, or half as much as you get?
—I think we are straying a little from the Estimates.
—It is the same as the essential elements.
—Order! There will be no conversations across the chamber.

—If I were asked to do the job for half of Senator Crichton-Browne's salary, I would certainly do it, but I would not want to set a precedent, and I do not believe I would be. Senator Short also asked about the $1m that has been appropriated in relation to the establishment costs of the ASC. That money will only be formally appropriated when the legislation is passed. Any expenditure undertaken to that point will be balanced by taking money from that former appropriation on the passage of legislation. If the worst scenario develops and the legislation is not passed by the Parliament, it would be a case of seeking the money from Additional Estimates. Clearly, there is some preliminary work which must be undertaken by any responsible government in the anticipation that once the Parliament passes the legislation, the Parliament intends that the various administrative and other machinery operates as soon as possible. It is in relation to that anticipation of the Parliament's will, and in order to facilitate the Parliament's will when the legislation is passed, that the expenditure is undertaken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak on a matter that pertains to the functions of the Attorney-General as they relate to the operation of the Australian Constitution. In today's Adelaide Advertiser there is an article headlined, `Haines sacrifices all for Hindmarsh'. It is to do with the proposal that Senator Haines leave the Senate and run for the Federal division of Hindmarsh. The import of the story is that Senator Haines will make a gigantic sacrifice, a throw of the dice on a winner-take-all basis: she will either win in Hindmarsh or she will be out of politics altogether. I will quote three or four paragraphs from this article, because it relates to the functions of filling a Senate vacancy under the Constitution of Australia. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Janine Haines is set to take a giant step into the political unknown.
The first woman leader of an Australian political party plans to give up her safe Senate seat in a bid to make the Australian Democrats a more credible national political force.
In a double dissolution of Federal Parliament, only a dramatic change to South Australia's voting patterns would see Senator Haines lose the seat she has held since 1978.
If the federal election expected about the end of next year involves a half-Senate poll (as widely predicted), she would not even need to face the people.
Senator Haines has decided to sacrifice that security to resign from Parliament and run for the western suburban Adelaide seat of Hindmarsh-where the Democrats managed only 8 per cent vote in 1987.

The point I wish to make, which this story does not conclude, and which Senator Haines has not stated, is that if a half Senate election is held next year, Senator Haines will be making no sacrifice at all. If she runs for Hindmarsh and, as expected, loses comprehensively the seat to the sitting Labor member, she can be reappointed for the rest of her unexpired term. She has a great opportunity, that does not come to many people in politics, of being able to win both sides of the bet. If she wins Hindmarsh, she will be in the lower House but, if, as expected, she loses, she will not lose anything, because under the constitutional change of 1977, her Party, the Australian Democrats has the right to nominate the replacement to fill the vacancy. Who are they going to nominate? There is no doubt that when Senator Haines loses in Hindmarsh they will nominate her to fill the rest of her unexpired term. So there is no sacrifice by Senator Haines. What we would like to see in South Australia, before we get similar headlines to those in the Adelaide Advertiser about this heroic sacrifice, is a statement from Senator Haines that if she does run in Hindmarsh and lose, as we all expect--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. I do not really want to interrupt my learned friend's rhetoric on this matter, but I do think it would be helpful if the relevance to the Estimates was indicated in this particular intervention, so that we can get on with what is the very difficult task of getting these Budget matters through by 10.30 tonight.
—I ask Senator Schacht to take note of the Minister's comments.

—Very briefly, I do notice that in the appropriation for the Attorney-General's Department we are spending $146m on administration. One of those costs will be the administration of the functions of filling a casual vacancy created in this chamber. That will be of some cost to the administration of the Parliament and the Department through the calling of a joint sitting of the Parliament. So it will entail some administrative cost. I must admit that not much of the $142m will be spent, but it will mean some cost.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary, all we are asking Senator Haines to do, if she is fair dinkum, is to state that if she runs for Hindmarsh and is not successful she will not reapply to come back to this chamber for the rest of her unexpired term, so that we do not have to put up with these sorts of stories that she and the Democrats are promoting about her heroic sacrifice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In talking briefly to the same subject-and for the same reasons; it concerns any possible administrative costs-I am pleased that Senator Schacht is so mindful of saving those pennies that he talks about. I think it shows that he has not paid very much attention to his own electorate, or bothered to listen to the radio, to watch the television or even to read the newspapers. If he had, he would have seen quite clearly that Senator Haines has stated emphatically, on every occasion that she has been interviewed about this, that if she runs-of course that is still a matter for herself and the party-and does not win the seat, she will not seek to fill her own vacancy. She has stated that clearly and categorically, and Senator Schacht knows that. If he had known that before, I would not have thought he would have needed to come in here and partake in that odd grandstanding exercise.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Department of Aboriginal Affairs
Proposed expenditure, $395,668,000

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite the comments that some of the Labor senators opposite have made-they seem to think this is going to take ages-I can assure them that if we are given good and prompt answers we will attempt to deal with this matter as expeditiously as we possibly can. However, that is not to deny the serious issues that have arisen in the administration of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the very issues that have attracted probably paramount press coverage in the last six or eight weeks. The fact that so much concentration by both the House of Representatives and this chamber has had to be made in the determination to clear up and to clean up a stack of issues relating to the administration of Aboriginal affairs is I think indicative of the extreme concern felt about this portfolio.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will see in the Estimates Committee E report a reservation expressed by Senator Durack, Senator Short and me. In discussing the maladministration of the Department by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, we came down in that reservation comment with the point:
. . . we consider the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to have been derelict in the exercise of his Ministerial responsibilities.

Nothing could be surer than that statement, as has been borne out by the fact, as I said in my speech during the second reading stage the other day, that 400 questions were put on notice and some 200 to 300 questions were subsequently asked by Senator Short and me during the hearing. Of course the matter has also been under very important consideration in the House of Representatives, because the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has instituted four Public Service inquiries into this portfolio since the consideration of the Estimates started on 21 October-four Public Service inquiries in addition to the three parliamentary inquiries that are already under way. That is a damning indictment of what has gone on. As I said, the House of Representatives has also given, through questions and through debate, considerable attention to this issue.

I would like to draw the attention of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) to the statements of my colleague, Mr Roger Shipton, the honourable member for Higgins in Victoria, who has repeatedly raised issues also with regard to this portfolio. In particular, today in the House of Representatives we saw one of the most shameful parliamentary performances ever. I remind the chamber that earlier this week the Government accepted for debate a censure motion on the Prime Minister relating to Mr Kornhauser. But what happened today when a censure motion was proposed involving the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand? It was gagged, it was stopped, it was thwarted at every move. Honourable senators probably heard the bells ringing a number of times when between 3 p.m. and 4 p.m. members in the House of Representatives were repeatedly gagged. Why did that matter arise? It arose because of the question that Mr Shipton originally put forward on 8 November, seeking additional information with regard to the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation (NAIHO). On that particular occasion Mr Shipton asked the Minister whether his predecessor, the present Minister for the Arts and Territories stopped:

funding to the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation because of malpractices and financial abuse? Has the Minister recommenced funding to that organisation; and if so, on what grounds? Was his predecessor wrong in stopping such funding? in any event, will the Minister have NAIHO investigated by the Auditor-General and the inquiries that the Government has established?
Mr Hand responded:

Yes, there was an internal inquiry conducted into matters concerning the funding arrangements for NAIHO by my predecessor; and funding did cease. Since that period, there has been a restructuring of the body known as NAIHO. Thirdly, I have met with representatives of that body and have discussed funding arrangements for the future. I am yet to make a decision.

That statement by the Minister flies in the face of the minutes of a meeting of senior officers of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs held on 5 September in which, when referring to NAIHO, it is stated:
At a meeting with the Minister on Thursday 1 September, the Minister directed that NAIHO received $180,000 this year in funding. This is to be confirmed in writing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. I want to know what is the basis for the authentication of whatever sort of document the honourable senator is purporting to quote from.
—I am quoting from a copy of minutes that have been given to me. However, I will foreshadow to the Minister that because on that basis I consider this matter to be so important--

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. As I understand it, the honourable senator is authenticating that particular document. He has not sought leave to incorporate or table it, as I understand it.
—I have not at this stage. However, I take this to be a true and correct record. I would foreshadow at this stage that I propose to move an amendment, and that amendment will read:

SPEECH.PARA: That, having considered the Report of Estimates Committee E in relation to the administration of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the Committee recommends that the Senate agree to the following resolution:
That there be laid on the table of the Senate on or before 5 December 1988:

(1) A copy of the report of auditors Arthur Andersen and Co., referred to by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in the course of his reply to a question without notice by the member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) in the House of Representatives on 8 November 1988;
(2) A copy of the record of proceedings of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs senior officers' meeting held on 5 September 1988; and

(3) A copy of any note for file made by Mr McDonald, as senior officer of Department of Aboriginal Affairs, recording his meeting with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs on 1 September, during which the issue of funding for NAIHO was discussed.

That is the amendment that I will move. This is a most important issue because what arises out of it is the very point that Senator Durack, Senator Short and I made in our reservation report to Estimates Committee E; that is, that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has been derelict in the exercise of his ministerial responsibilities. If it is borne out that those minutes are in exactly the terms that I have before me, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs lied to the Parliament today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Chairman, there is an allegation that Mr Hand lied to the other place.
—I said `if' it is borne out.
—Nevertheless, the very clear inference is made because the honourable senator said that he had authenticated those documents as a true and accurate record of the proceedings.
—I did not say that.
—The honourable senator did. When I asked the honourable senator he said that he had authenticated them as a true and accurate record.
—That is not what I said. It is not in Hansard.
—So the honourable senator's `if' is a very weak conditional statement preceeding his allegation that Mr Hand lied. I ask you, Mr Chairman, to require the honourable senator to withdraw that.

—Speaking to the point of order: I referred earlier to a copy of the minutes I had. That was the basis on which I quoted earlier. In referring to Mr Hand today I said if the matter that will be raised in the amendment that I have proposed requiring that a copy be laid on the table of the Senate is brought out then-I certainly made that point with that qualification-Mr Hand has certainly lied to the Parliament.
—There are certain comments to be made in regard to papers to be tabled. I do not think there is a point of order.

—This goes very much to the core of everything that we have been saying, that all is not well with the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. It certainly is not so. I want to talk about the points I made with regard to the four inquiries that the Government has had to institute and that the Prime Minister has had to put in place. It is unfortunate that we have not been given any terms of reference for those inquiries. They are very general. We certainly know that the Auditor General has been brought in. We know that the Public Service Commissioner has been brought in. We know that the Department of Finance has been asked to report on the accounting and administrative procedures. We know that Mr Menzies has been appointed to pick up the other matters and the legal issues that subsequently arise. I am sure that that is an acknowledgment by the Prime Minister that all of the issues that were raised in Senate Estimates Committee E were very serious.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also of major concern that we were dissatisfied totally with the quality of the performance indicators that were provided by the Department. Yet the Department has such an onerous responsibility in serving Aboriginal people throughout Australia. The fact that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission between them administer funds of $468m is indicative of the extent of their responsibilities and the problems that they have to fact up to. Yet these four inquiries that the Government has instituted do not provide any mechanisms for public participation, for people in the community to be able to make an input. There is no protection of witnesses or for the way in which they can come forward. In the representations that have been made to me in the last month or so that has been the major concern expressed by many of the constituents who have come forward and provided additional information.

I have passed the information to the Auditor-General. Where constituents have requested that their identity remain anonymous I have respected that. I have passed their assertions to the Auditor-General and asked him to investigate and report on them. Yet there is no mechanism by which I can be assured that the Auditor-General's report is going to be tabled in this Parliament. It, very obviously, will have to be tendered to the Prime Minister or to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. What joy does that give us? It certainly does not give us any.

If we look at the way in which the Department has been administered, particularly since the Federal election last year when Mr Hand assumed the portfolio responsibility, we have nothing but cause for concern. The way in which Mr Hand walked in and dismissed eight credible Aboriginal leaders in Australia from the Board of the Aboriginal Development Commission in May was absolutely disgraceful. The new appointees, who were appointed almost immediately afterwards, did not file their required pecuniary interest forms until some date in November, which was five to six months after their initial appointment and only after continual probing by Senator Short and myself in the Estimates committee. Charles Perkins did not lodge his pecuniary interest form until after he was sacked. How damned serious can we get when issues like this keep arising?

The Administrative and Clerical Officers Association certainly raised many issues with Minister Hand in a very important letter very early in the Minister's administration. Yet the Minister and Charles Perkins chose to file that letter. It did not get passed down through the Department for corrective action below the level of the Secretary. It did not reach the other officers of the Department who could have worked on it. The Minister may have been mulling it over since November or December of last year but he did not ask or put in train any effective new principles or administrative procedures within his department.

It can only be said that the entire administration and the manner in which the Department was administered by Mr Perkins and the Minister were disgraceful. If the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) will permit me, may I also refer to a copy of the minutes by the senior officers of 5 September. Let me highlight another issue which brings out the point of poor administration or perhaps some funny business at the crossroads by Charles Perkins. Under a separate issue entirely from the one that I raised earlier, the document refers to the Secretary, Mr Perkins. It reads:

The Secretary asked for inquiries to be made about the feasibility of holding a combined State Directors Regional Managers meeting in Adelaide two days prior to the Australian Grand Prix in Adelaide. Mr Miller, who indicated that the meeting was not practical because of accommodation shortages, was asked to follow up the proposal.

I ask the Minister: Can he investigate what happened around the time of the Adelaide Grand Prix? Did the officers of the Department-without, of course, Charles Perkins because he was sacked in the interim-get their fares paid to go to meetings prior to the Grand Prix? Did they then meet on the Monday and Tuesday? Of course, the Grand Prix was held on Saturday, 12 November, and Sunday, 13 November. Did the officers then attend meetings with the Minister on the Monday and Tuesday prior to there being, in the couple of days after that, the next meeting of the Australian Aboriginal Affairs Council? The fact that the Secretary, Mr Perkins-as I said, I am quoting from these minutes-asked about inquiries to be made about the feasibility of holding a meeting in Adelaide two days prior is so similar to so many of the other issues that were raised by Mr Perkins. If one goes through the transcript of Senate Estimates Committee E and sees the 40-odd occasions on which we put questions to Mr Perkins and he could not recall or had amnesia-often for things that happened a week earlier-one sees that it certainly did not blend well for a happy, effective or proper administration of that portfolio. The fact that the Minister obviously did not have his hand on his Secretary-pardon the pun-also points to many areas of slack administration.

In recent days the Prime Minister has announced that the Government will have a total rethink about the proposal for the formation of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). I quote from a press report of 9 November. The Canberra Times reported the Prime Minister as `thinking of some possible changes in approach on this matter' by Mr Hand. The report continued:
Mr Hawke said he thought the concept of the commission was sound, but Mr Hand was considering `alternatives or refinements'.
Further on it said:
The minister would not go back to Aboriginal communities with yet another start-up date, but would look at options such as administrative changes which did not need legislation.

I welcome any change by the Prime Minister, because this whole area of ATSIC needs to be totally reviewed. It is not a matter of just crashing through into something new to achieve aims. This Senate has very properly put in place the Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs to look into the whole ambit of that administration. From the Hansard reports of that Committee's hearings, which I have read, and submissions that people have made to that Committee, it is very obvious that overwhelming evidence is building up that Aboriginal people throughout Australia are not happy with the principles of Mr Hand's proposals for ATSIC. Obviously there are many inherent flaws.

When the Australian Democrats agreed to the initial deferment of the legislation they put out a press release listing seven areas which would require amendment. As I am aware-and I am sure Senator Collins from the Northern Territory is too-the traditional Aboriginal communities throughout northern Australia are far from happy with the proposals that are being put forward. The fact that there has to be a total rethink in this area points up the fact that we cannot go marching into some new, big, bandaided area. If we do, in four or five years time we will have another massive blow-out of a bureaucracy that will not meet the requirements of the Australian taxpayer or the Aboriginal community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tambling has made his usual criticism of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, claiming that he has been derelict in the exercise of his ministerial responsibilities in relation to what is admitted on all hands to be an extremely difficult portfolio. Indeed, Mr Hand has taken up this portfolio, as requested by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), with a great deal of insight and enthusiasm and at all stages has attempted to exercise proper responsibility for the orientation of services provided both by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission, which is an autonomous statutory body, in order that they may provide a range of services which will help the development of Aboriginal Australians within the Australian society. Given the various allegations and assertions of maladministration which in only one or two cases have been shown to be the case--
—Oh! One or two?
—Some 400 to 500 questions were asked during the Senate Estimates Committee E hearing but very few actually met with positive gold as far as Senator Tambling was concerned.
—Why the four Government inquiries?
—There were a few and therefore the various inquiries have been instituted in a way which I believe will enable concerns about maladministration to be properly addressed.
—Why were they necessary?

—Because there are real concerns; I agree with that. I am merely saying that it is wrong to give the impression that, because 400 questions were put on notice and another 300 were asked in Estimates Committee E, there are 700 matters wrong in the administration of Aboriginal affairs throughout Australia by the Federal Government. That is the sort of impression that that sort of assertion conveys. Nevertheless, there were some matters of concern and hence those inquiries have been established. Since the announcement of those inquiries, it has been generally agreed that they will provide a comprehensive and adequate framework for these matters of concern to be properly examined. This is particularly so when one takes into account the role to be played by Mr Andrew Menzies in coming to his independent assessment of whether the two or three inquiries being undertaken, for example, by the Auditor-General, the Department of Finance and the Public Service Commissioner, have been able to cover all the ground of concern.

SPEECH.PARA: Various allegations have been made. Senator Tambling referred to a letter from the national secretary of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association, Ms Ann Forward. In the Estimates Committee, as I recall, the various elements of that letter were gone through sentence by sentence and refutation was offered sentence by sentence by the officers who were being questioned. The sorts of allegations that were made in that letter were sufficiently answered by members of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs who attended that Committee hearing. Nevertheless, that letter continues to get a run as though it had never been the subject of refutation and explanation at the Estimates Committee.

Senator Tambling has gone in for his usual smear campaign-and that is a very unfortunate tendency-in relation to the holding of the meeting of certain officers from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and State Directors during the weekend of the Adelaide Grand Prix. For example, I have here today advising me on Estimates two officers from that Department who have indicated to me that the Australian Aboriginal Affairs Council (AAAC), which I assume is the Ministerial Council, was due to meet on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday of the week after the Grand Prix. Given the removal of the Secretary to the Department, obviously there would have been consternation and a need for consultation between the various elements of the portfolio from around Australia and also officers would have needed to consult in order to advise the Minister about the forthcoming Ministerial Council meeting. So it was determined that State directors and members of Central Office should meet in Adelaide on the Monday and Tuesday preceeding the AAAC. That is not an uncommon occurrence with Ministerial Councils. In fact, officials do usually meet a day or so before the Council meeting, wherever it is held, in order to check on the agenda with their counterparts and provide a full assessment of the really important matters on the agenda which may have been determined some weeks or even months before.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why had the briefing meeting not been arranged weeks earlier or even months earlier?
—I have just said that the removal of the Secretary to the Department meant that there was a special urgency--
—The Secretary had not been removed at that stage; you have your timing out by two months.

—I am also indicating that a meeting of the Minister with various advisers would have occurred anyway before the Ministerial Council meeting, as is commonly the case. The two officers who are here today have indicated to me that they claimed travelling allowance from Sunday night onwards to cover their visit to Adelaide. Therefore, of course if they attended the Grand Prix-and I have not had a chance to ask them about it-they would have done so at their own expense and out of their own interest. They certainly would not have done so at any cost to the taxpayer. It is unfortunate that Senator Tambling should give the impression--
—The impression comes from Mr Perkins' request in the minutes for the meeting to be held on the two days before the Grand Prix.
—That just goes to show that Senator Tambling cannot rely on everything that forms an impression in his mind from some notes of a meeting which he alleges occurred on a particular date.
—You are only talking about the two.

—Well, they are the only ones I have been able to consult. All I am saying is that I would find it unfortunate, and I think Senator Tambling would too, if those who attended that series of meetings of officials preceding the Ministerial Council were under a cloud that for them the major event of that week was attending the Grand Prix and at the expense of the Australian taxpayer. I have not had time to consider Senator Tambling's proposed amendment, but I imagine I will have time to do so during the dinner break.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I merely stress to the Minister the point that I made in quoting from the copy of the minutes available to me. I was making a firm criticism of Mr Perkins, who initiated the request that that senior officers meeting be held in the two days prior to the Grand Prix. It was that point that I was seeking to stress, to point out the unguided missile type of administration that Mr Perkins obviously led in the Department. I am not saying that other officers complied or would have claimed. That is probably a matter for next year's Senate Estimates committees to determine-who claimed travelling allowance and the amounts.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise two other issues with regard to this portfolio. One is the matter that we raised, both in the majority report of Estimates Committee E and in the reservation, with regard to the funding of Tranby College. In the reservation we questioned the propriety of allocating some $500,000 for conferences to be organised by the college around Australia with regard to an Aboriginal treaty. Subsequent answers that came in following the Estimates Committee hearings were conflicting. First, we received an answer which said that, legally, the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) was not in a position to make that funding available. Subsequently-I think it was yesterday-I received a rethink answer on that issue saying that the ADC had since gone out and sought the opinion of a Queen's Counsel, who obviously has now found a way in which it could be argued that that $500,000 could be made available legally.

The main point of my argument is that, again, this is six months after the event. The decision on that was taken back in June. That advice should have been on the table before the board of commissioners-whether it was a QC's opinion which said, `Yes, here is the loophole' or the original Attorney-General's Department advice which was, `No, you cannot do it'. I imagine that, if the original Attorney-General's Department advice had been on the table at the commissioners' meeting, the commissioners would have backed off and not even bothered to have sought a QC's opinion. It is disgraceful. That half a million dollars to achieve other objectives was very questionable, as I said at the time of the Estimates Committee and in my speech at the second reading stage, given the circumstances of the people involved.

I would like to address the relationship between; Mr Kevin Cooke, the Administrator of Tranby college, who is also the convener of the National Coalition of Aboriginal Organisations; Pat Dodson, the Chairman of the ADC Coordinating Committee supervising the half a million dollars of expenditure and who is also a leader of the National Coalition of Aboriginal Organisations; and Mr Kevin Tory of the Trade Union Committee on Aboriginal Rights, who has identified himself as one of the three people organising consultations on an Aboriginal treaty. How in the heck can Mr Kevin Tory claim to have any authority in this regard? He is not a commissioner or a staff member of the ADC, as far as I am aware. He is not a public servant within the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, as far as I am aware. He is from the Trade Union Committee on Aboriginal Rights. I find it strangely coincidental that that organisation has the same mailing address as the National Coalition of Aboriginal Organisations, with which Mr Riley from the office of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) has a very close link, and with which Mr Dodson from Alice Springs, who is certainly one of the new commissioners of the ADC, and Mr O'Shane, one of the activists from Queensland who is also a commissioner of the ADC, have links.

The way in which this half a million dollars has been funnelled and channelled from the Government deserves very quick and particular comment. I believe that earlier this week Mr Hawke attended a conference of Aboriginal people at which the treaty was again under consideration. He was questioned about it. An Australian Associated Press (AAP) report states:
We spoke to Prime Minister Hawke two weeks ago and asked him if the commitment was still strong. He said it was . . . we told him that it wasn't going to happen as quickly as he thought.
A further AAP report states:

Aborigines could take up to five years to decide whether they want to sign a treaty with the Australian Government . . . Kevin Tory, one of three Aboriginal men organising nationwide meetings of indigenous people to discuss the proposal, said the process of achieving any sort of consensus concerning a treaty was necessarily slow.

My question is: is the $1.9m set aside in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs for public awareness campaigns going to go on and on for five years? This half a million dollars is being channelled through funny front organisations which have links with community groups, and whose participants certainly have a conflict of interest, and, as we mentioned in Estimates Committee E, a college which has tenuous links with Cuba and Nicaragua. Is this the way this Government is going to organise its consultations on treaties around Australia? It is a very serious issue to be addressed by this Government. The Prime Minister said at Burunga in the Northern Territory in June that he was going to institute a special group of seven Aboriginal elders who would be responsible for the treaty negotiations that the Government wanted. That has not happened. There has been no contact with the traditional cultural leaders, other than Galarrwuy Yunupingu of the Northern Land Council, who is a mate of Mr Hand. The traditional Aboriginal people have been left out in the cold. This funny crowd of people in Sydney, from Tranby College, with its peculiar links to the National Coalition of Aboriginal Organisations, which is made up basically of urban radical Aboriginals, is the body doing the Government's bidding.

Similarly, I comment on the land council movement in the Northern Territory where breakaway movements are arising because of the ineptitude of Minister Hand and the way in which he has handled the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) proposal and is insulting the traditional Aboriginals of northern Australia. I am aware, and I am sure Senator Bob Collins is also, that some five or six other groups in the Northern Territory are currently saying, `We want out of the Northern Land Council and the Central Land Council because the Minister's, Mr Hand's, mates are in there running the show. They are fiddling around with the way it is all being done'. We need to be mindful of the fact that the administrative funds available to the Northern Land Council and the Central Land Council are in excess of $11m per annum. It makes them a very powerful propaganda machine doing the Government's bidding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —To answer a real Estimates question, the $1.9m set aside within the Department of Aboriginal Affairs for public awareness campaigns is not to do with the treaty. It is a completely different matter. In relation to the National Coalition of Aboriginal Organisations, I have mentioned before in this chamber that the Coalition is a very loose body which does not have a continuous list of members. It holds meetings from time to time and those who wish to attend may do so.
—Is it accountable to Aboriginals?

—It is accountable in that those who attend its meetings are very involved in Aboriginal affairs and various Aboriginal organisations and are answerable to their own organisations in relation to their participation in any matter undertaken by the Coalition.
—How representative are they?
—Anyone who is an Aboriginal can attend.
—Are you going to pay their air fares?

—No, I am not. With respect to land councils, requests to establish new councils will be considered in accordance with the provisions of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. That is clear. I think the further matters on which Senator Tambling has elaborated, particularly those relating to Tranby College, which he has somehow linked with Cuba and Nicaragua, should wait until after the dinner break.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner some matters were raised concerning Tranby College. I am advised that all Aboriginal Development Commission-Tranby files have been sealed in preparation for the Auditor-General's investigation. As a consequence, officers have not been able to get details concerning office holders of Tranby College from their files, as was requested. Kevin Tory is employed, we believe, by the Trade Union Campaign Against Racism but the ADC officers present do not know whether he is a director of Tranby, for the reasons that I have given. However, he is closely associated with Tranby. Kevin Cook has been closely associated with Tranby for several years but officers present do not know whether he is a director.

SPEECH.PARA: It is widely known that people associated with Tranby have contact with a wide diversity of people and organisations. As was established at the Estimates Committee, I think Tranby was founded by a Christian pastor and has been in existence since 1957. It is a registered charity and has a reputation for being generally well run. At present, officers do not have information concerning the names of directors.

I was also asked about links with Nicaragua and Cuba which were put forward in a way which I suppose was intended to colour Tranby as being some radical organisation. As I understand it, some students associated with Tranby have applied, not to the ADC or to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, but to the Department of Employment, Education and Training, for some assistance in their work experience program. Some students have nominated Cuba or Nicaragua, as officials understand it, for participation in the funding available from that portfolio. But officials in this portfolio are unable to say whether that application has been successful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) for that information. I want to say something about the task that Tranby College has been given to work on the promotion of the treaty proposal. In doing so, I support very strongly the remarks made by Senator Tambling earlier. If one looks at the answers that have been given to questions asked at the Senate Estimates Committee hearings-in particular, a question asked by Senator Collins requesting details about the nature of Tranby College-it is clear that one would have considerable doubts as to the reasons why the college would be the recipient of $420,000 of the $500,000 allocated for the promotion of the treaty proposal. The answer that was received in the last couple of weeks in response to the question that was left on notice by Senator Collins states, amongst other things:

SPEECH.PARA: The Co-operative for Aborigines Ltd (CAL) known as Tranby College is a registered charity organisation.
We knew that. It continues:
CAL was formerly called ABM Christian Community Co-operative Ltd but on 7 September-
I assume that means 7 September 1988-
the NSW Co-operative Act registered a change of name from ABMCCL to the Co-operative for Aborigines Ltd.
That is a bit of technical background. The point I want to make refers to the next part of the answer which was provided, which states:

Tranby College is basically involved in the area of preparatory tertiary education for Aboriginals. For example it conducts courses in Bookkeeping, Business Studies etc. In addition it is involved in training for Aboriginal organisations and Land Councils.
It has also a consulting unit called the Aboriginal Development Unit which provides consultancy on training and local studies such as the recent social study on Toomelah.

I ask the Minister: In light of the answer that has been provided and the description that has been given of the role of Tranby College, how does he see that college and the work it does-basically it is involved in the area of preparatory tertiary education for Aborigines-justifying the grant of almost half a million dollars to give it the prime role in the promotion of and discussions on the treaty proposal? It is not obvious to me that there is any relationship between the background of Tranby College and the role it performs that would equip it to do that. I think that is a very important question that I would certainly want answered.

I also want to pick up and develop the point that was made earlier by Senator Tambling. He advised the Senate of the change in advice that we had received as to whether, legally, Tranby College was a body with which the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC), which granted these funds, could have dealings. The information that was provided-I presume by the ADC rather than the Department of Aboriginal Affairs; it does not really matter which one-to the Estimates Committee was received by me on 23 November. Senator Tambling's question was:
In legal terms under the ADC Act, is Tranby College a body with which the ADC could have dealings?
I receive this response on 23 November:
In legal terms, no. The College does not meet the Aboriginal objects clause required under section 4 of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act 1980.

If that was the advice that was provided to this chamber on 23 November I want to know how it was possible for the ADC to make a grant of $420,000 to Tranby College for the purpose of promoting the treaty if the legal position, as seen by the ADC on 23 November, was that it was not legal to do so. Was any legal advice taken at the time the decision was made to make the grant to Tranby College? What legal advice did the ADC have at that stage? Why was the legal advice that it received on 23 November, that the college could not have had dealings with the ADC, overturned when on 30 November we were advised that the answer to Senator Tambling's question, which was received on 30 November, said, `The answer provided on 22 November stating ``no'' was incorrect.'? I quote again from the answer provided on 30 November. It reads:
Legal opinion recently provided by a Queen's Counsel is that the College is an `Aboriginal body' as defined in the ADC Act 1980.
The answer went on to say:
. . . the ADC regional office considered Tranby College was an Aboriginal Body and released grant funds. Following receipt of Question E 336-
that was the one on notice from Senator Tambling that came forward in the Estimates Committee hearing-

the legal opinion of the ADC's Principal Legal Officer was sought. His written opinion was that Tranby College was not an Aboriginal Body for the purposes of the Act. The response of 22 November was based on that opinion.

At the request of the Deputy Chairman a Queen's Counsel was briefed to provide his legal opinion as the interpretation of Section 4 of the Act was a crucial aspect in determining the Commission's funding program. Written opinion dated 25 November was that Tranby College is an Aboriginal Body as defined by Section 4 of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act 1980.
The Commission apologises for its earlier incorrect answer.

That was the end of the answer provided. That raises far more questions that it answers. For example, who was the Queen's Counsel? When was the Queen's Council's advice requested and when was it received? It says that it was `recently provided'. What legal opinion existed at the time that the ADC made its decision to grant the $420,000 to Tranby College? Has the Attorney-General's Department expressed a view on the Queen's Counsel's opinion? What does the Attorney-General's Department think? What do the Government's own legal advisers think about this QC's opinion? Why is this QC's opinion so sacrosanct? Whether the QC's opinion is right or wrong, the great unanswered question is: on what legal basis did the ADC grant that $420,000 to Tranby College in July or August? It may have been May; I am not sure. It was about six months ago. On what legal opinion was the ADC decision based? I repeat: on what criteria did the ADC make the decision to grant that money for the promotion for the treaty proposals to Tranby College, when on the basis of the information supplied to this chamber as to the role of Tranby College there appears to be no logical reason at all as to why it would be a worthy recipient of those funds, a recipient that would be able to utilise those funds to meet the objectives of the original grant? There are some quite major questions involved and I hope the Minister will be able to provide some answers before we approve the appropriations for this Department. I want to return to the motion that was foreshadowed by Senator Tambling before dinner. Unfortunately he is unable to be here tonight. On his behalf I move:

That, having considered the report of Estimates Committee E in relation to the administration of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the Committee recommends that the Senate agree to the following resolution:
That there be laid on the table of the Senate on or before 5 December 1988:

(a) A copy of the report of auditors Arthur Andersen and Co., referred to by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in the course of this reply to a question without notice by the member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) in the other place on 8 November 1988
(b) A copy of the record of proceedings of the Department Aboriginal Affairs senior officers' meeting held on 5 September 1988

(c) A copy of any note for file made by Mr McDonald, as senior officer of DAA, recording his meeting with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs on 1 September, during which the issue of funding for NAIHO was discussed.

I draw attention to a couple of other points. The first is in response to a written answer provided by the Department to a question on notice that I raised with it in the course of the Estimates hearings. It related to grants being made available to trade unions and community organisations over the last five financial years by the Department or its statutory authorities, and what was the situation in so far as outstanding reports were concerned? Without quoting the whole thing I note that in 1986-87 a total of 34 grant recipients had outstanding reports, and that in 1987-88 there was a total of 251 grant recipients with outstanding reports, the majority of which are quarterly reports for the period 31 April 1988 to 30 June 1988. When will those reports be available? It is now five months since the end of that financial year, and to have 251 grant recipients not having put in a financial report is, in my view, an absolute disgrace as far as the accountability of Government money is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has to be made clear that Tranby College is not simply concerned with the undertaking of preliminary tertiary studies; as shown by its involvement in Toomelah it is involved in a much wider range of concerns. In taking students under its wing from all parts of Australia it has developed a national reputation amongst Aboriginal bodies and persons such that it is well qualified in the eyes of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) as a body that would have the confidence of those to whom it provided the occasion for meetings and to consider the question of the treaty.
—What, to the tune of half a million dollars?

—That is irrelevant in the sense that the amount of money is going to be large in order to conduct these meetings right around Australia and to provide for consultation by a wide range of Aboriginal persons and institutions and bodies. Senator Short's question is whether Tranby College was a suitable body to undertake this role. I was trying to indicate that not only is it involved in preparatory tertiary education but it is involved in much wider concerns, as shown by its well-known role in relation to Toomelah. Because over 20 years it has obtained support from Aboriginal students from right around Australia, it has such a reputation that it is well placed to undertake the sorts of consultations that are required.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the legal opinions, the simple point is that the original decision by the Aboriginal Development Commission to select Tranby College as being a suitable body was vindicated by the opinion by the Queen's Counsel, Michael Adams from Sydney, who provided his opinion, I believe, on the date on which it was received by the Department; that is, 25 November. I understand it was dated 25 November and received by the Department on the same day, which is last Friday.

TALK.START.PARA: —The QC's opinion?

—As it says in the third paragraph of the answer. Written opinion dated 25 November was that Tranby College is an Aboriginal body defined in section 4 of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act 1980. That opinion was given last Friday and I understand that the Department received it on last Friday.
—Yes, but when was it requested?
—I do not have an answer to that immediately.
—That is the critical question.
—It was not the critical question. You asked a question about when it was received. I have told you when it was received.
—When it was received is much less important than when it was requested.
—The answer given is that--
—When was it requested? You have your advisers there.
—Order! Senator Short, you can rise again to ask that question.

—Yes. Originally the ADC regional office considered Tranby College was an Aboriginal body and released grant funds. Following receipt of question E336 the legal opinion of the ADC's principal legal officer was sought-not, as Senator Short said before dinner, the Attorney-General's opinion. His written opinion was that Tranby College was not an Aboriginal body for the purposes of the Act. The response of 22 November 1988 was based on that opinion. At the request of the Deputy Chairman, a Queen's Counsel was briefed to provide his legal opinion as the interpretation of section 4 of the Act was a crucial aspect in determining the Commission's funding program.

SPEECH.PARA: I am advised that the principal legal officer thought that what was required before the Commission could make money available to an Aboriginal body was that it have in its mandate that it be concerned with economic and social advancement. All that is actually required under law is that it be concerned with the advancement of Aboriginal persons. That has been accepted by the principal legal officer as being a correct interpretation of the legal requirements now that he has had a chance to read the opinion by Michael Adams, QC. It is fairly self-evident. The officer was reading too much into the requirement that there be economic and social advancement clauses written into the mandate of the body receiving money.

I am now advised that the request was made on 22 November. One can see how important it was for the Aboriginal Development Commission to receive top flight advice because, as I have indicated, the requirement in the objectives clause of Aboriginal bodies as to the type of advancement that should be specified in those objectives is obviously very crucial. The opinion was requested on 22 November and provided and received three days later. I think that is fairly straight forward. I think Senator Short asked a question about grants to trade union bodies or made a general comment about the number of reports which were outstanding.

TALK.START.PARA: —Trade unions and community organisations.
—Was the question about unacquitted grants in general? It was about grants to the trade union bodies-is that correct?
—That is right. Trade unions and community organisations.
—I think Senator Crichton-Browne asked me a question at Question Time a few days ago about unacquitted grants and whether I could provide a list of them.
—My question relates to the lack of receipt of reports by bodies to which grants have been made.
—I am advised that they are one and the same thing: that an acquittal of the grant requires a report as to the way in which the money was expended.
—And authorisation that spending has been in an appropriate fashion, and certification accordingly.

—Yes, that is right. In regard to 1987-88 grants, they are not required to be acquitted in final form until 31 December this calendar year. I have a note that follow-up action was instituted long before Senate Estimates Committee hearings.
—Give me a date.
—I am informed that these acquittals are required by 31 December 1988, by the end of this calendar year, for the preceding financial year, 1987-88.
—Did you say follow-up action was taken prior to the Estimates Committee?
—So I am told.
—How prior?
—I am told that follow-up action for 1986-87 was instituted long before Senate Estimates committee hearings.
—It would not have been just a couple of months, would it?
—I am informed, as must be obvious, that the whole process of checking the acquittal of grants is an ongoing process. In relation to the 1987-88 grants the deadline is 31 December this year.

—While we are on this point-this is not a rhetorical question-did Mr Perkins write to each of the directors of each state department in August of this year expressing concern about the unacquitted grants in each of the States and ask that some sort of action be taken at that stage?
—State directors were written to in strong terms in about August this year. It was indicated that there was a necessity for them to take firm action in this regard.

—I do not wish to reflect on the Minister or the advice he has given, but that seems to contradict the proposition he has just put to me; that is, that it is an ongoing process and that in some considerable period prior to the Estimates Committee hearings follow-up action was being taken. My judgment from what the Minister has told me is that there was no ongoing process, there was no vigorous acquittal process in place, and Mr Perkins, prompted by circumstances outside the Department, sought to have those acquittals extinguished and wrote accordingly in August-which is not an ongoing process, nor a considerable time prior to the Estimates Committee hearings.

—We have referred to only one piece of correspondence that has gone out. It is an ongoing process. That letter was written because of the grave concern of the Department that there be communicated to the State directors a sense of greater urgency in the need for the proper acquittal of grants going back to 1986-87 and perhaps even beyond. It is in relation to that necessity that the letter was written. It does not mean that that was the first time that the matter was made known to the State directors as a matter of concern to the Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment which has been moved by Senator Short on behalf of Senator Tambling and to make two remarks in relation to it. Firstly, I would like to dissociate the Australian Democrats from the smear campaign which I believe was implicit in the remarks Senator Tambling made in speaking to the motion. It was quite unnecessary to range as widely as he did. In seeking this information, which is a perfectly legitimate thing for the Opposition to do, he should have confined himself to those matters and not have ranged as widely as he did, attempting to bring a large number of Aboriginal people and Aboriginal organisations into disrepute.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, he was reflecting upon what had happened in the lower House today, where a request was made for this information and the Government evidently used its numbers to close ranks and prevent that information from being made public. I draw attention to the fact that both the Government and the Opposition have supported an electoral system for the Australian Capital Territory which will have the effect of ensconcing one of the major parties and will put in place permanently--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I take a point of order. I can tolerate having my train of thought interrupted by a speech from a member of a party that never turns up at Estimates committee hearings, but I find it intolerable to hear debated the virtues of the electoral system in the Australian Capital Territory.
—I suggest that you confine your remarks, Senator Coulter.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, on the point of order: Senator Tambling drew attention to the fact that the Opposition was quite incapable of extracting this information, which is the subject of the motion before us, from the Government because the Government had the numbers and closed ranks. I make the point that the Government and the Opposition have ensconced that same system in the Australian Capital Territory permanently. That is a great pity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the statement by the Australian Democrats that they will support the motion that I have moved on behalf of Senator Tambling. I totally reject Senator Coulter's comment that Senator Tambling was waging a smear campaign. Senator Tambling was not waging a smear campaign in any way at all. We are discussing the accountability of the hundreds of dollars of public funds that are spent on Aboriginal communities year after year. In the last five years $3.3 billion has been spent, and that is only by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. It excludes all the other money spent on these worthwhile issues by other departments. So we are talking about vast sums of taxpayers' money.

SPEECH.PARA: What Senator Tambling was saying, what I am saying, and what the Opposition is saying in the whole of this debate is the absolute opposite of a smear campaign. We are saying that the situation that has been disclosed as a result of the hearings of Senate Estimates Committee E, what is going on at the moment in the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs and in other areas is a sad and tragic example of how a government, perhaps with good intentions, can go wrong in trying to solve problems by throwing taxpayers' money at those problems without having firstly worked out its priorities as to where the money should go and secondly, having thrown the money, being absolutely recalcitrant regarding its accountability. That is what this is all about. At the end of the day the losers are certainly the taxpayers, but the real losers are the members of the Aboriginal communities for whom the funds should have been provided because they were necessary and are needed but who have not received them because they have been wasted, squandered and maladministered. That is what this is all about.

With respect to Senator Coulter, for him to accuse Senator Tambling of waging a smear campaign demonstrates a strong lack of understanding of what we are talking about in this whole debate. Having said that, I welcome Senator Coulter's comments in support of our motion.

I thank Senator Tate for his response in relation to the QC's advice. He has said that that request was made on 22 November. It is an exquisite irony, perhaps, at best that that happens to be the very date on which the answer was provided to Senate Estimates Committee E that the making of the grant had been illegal in the sense that the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) was not legally able to make the grant to Tranby College. That is a remarkable coincidence, at best. Apart from that, it misses the fundamental point; that is, what legal advice was available to the Aboriginal Development Commission when it took its decision months ago to make the grant to Tranby College. It did not have the QC's opinion. Does that mean that it had the opinion of the ADC's principal legal officer, which advice was that it was illegal, or did it have no advice at all? They are the questions that have to be asked. They are the questions to which the Minister is not providing a response. They are the questions that, in the public interest, demand a response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already given an answer but Senator Short seems not to be willing to listen. I have made it very clear that a legal opinion was not provided on this occasion to the Aboriginal Development Commission. It made the assumption, which has since been vindicated by the QC's opinion, that it was quite proper for it to go ahead and provide the money to Tranby College. It was only when, no doubt, frightened-overawed perhaps would be a better word-by some four hundred or five hundred questions on notice that were put down by various Senators for the Estimates Committee, that the principal legal officer, in a situation probably of some pressure, made the wrong assumption, which was that the objectives of the Aboriginal organisation required that there be a note about economic and social advancement. It was on that basis that the answer was provided to the honourable senator.

SPEECH.PARA: That has such implications for the question of the proper funding of a whole range of organisations that, quite clearly, the decision was properly taken to seek the opinion of a top QC. It was provided, and the result is that the original decision of the Aboriginal Development Commission can be seen to be perfectly in accordance with the proper legal requirements. So the assumption of the Commission at that meeting has, as I say, been vindicated.
