TALK.START.PARA: —The real situation is that the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) now has two opinions. It has one opinion from its own principal legal officer. The comments the Minister has just made on him, on his legal opinion and, therefore, on his expertise, I find absolutely extraordinary. The opinion of the ADC's principal legal officer says that it was not a legal transaction. The Commission has an opinion from someone else who happens to be a QC. I have no doubt that he is a good QC. I do not know Michael Adams. The Commission has a contrary opinion from him. What do the Government's own advisers say? What is the view of the Attorney-General's Department? What is the view of the Solicitor-General? What is the view of the Attorney-General? Have those conflicting opinions been put to him or to the Department?

—There is no need for that to be undertaken. The fact is that a principal legal officer, however able, is probably, by his own admission, not in the same class as Michael Adams, QC. As I understand it, and am advised, the principal legal officer concurs in the opinion of counsel and sees that he was in error in his original assumption that certain objectives had to be present in the objectives clause of the organisations.

—I find that answer extraordinary. The simple fact is that the poor principal legal officer has probably been browbeaten by the fact that a Queen's Counsel's opinion has been wheeled up. Whilst I in no way want to criticise the views of Queen's Counsels-they are very eminent people-I would have thought that, at the very least, Senator Tate, of all people, and the Attorney-General, Mr Bowen, would have learned, from having their fingers, hands and feet burnt in the referendum campaign because they relied on Queen's Counsels' advice, and having found that advice totally erroneous, they should not simply say that the advice was correct because it came from a Queen's Counsel. That is not the way for a government to do business, and it is unusual to do so.

—I think the best thing for me to do, to stop this continual argument about the worth of one opinion over another, would be to provide that legal opinion at some stage to the Senate. I do not think I can do so tonight, but my Department can no doubt get hold of it and provide it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that. It is a sensible thing to do. I also ask that the Minister get-because certainly I would want, we on this side of the Parliament would want, and, I would have thought, every member of the Parliament would want-a view from the Attorney-General's Department, from the Solicitor-General or from the Attorney-General, as to whether they concur with that advice.

SPEECH.PARA: I come back to the original point which has not been answered, that is, what legal advice, if any, did the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) have when it made its grant to Tranby College several months ago? Why was Tranby College selected, given the answer recently received by the Senate Estimates Committee about the nature and functions of Tranby College? No doubt the Minister is aware-if he is not, I think he ought to be-that there is very great concern in the Aboriginal communities around Australia that that grant to Tranby is a grant to the National Coalition of Aboriginal Organisations (NCAO), as the administrator of Tranby is also the convener of the Coalition. That was stated prior to the dinner break. Mr Pat Dodson, who is to chair the ADC Coordinating Committee on the Treaty consultations, is also a leader of the NCAO and there is a commonality of postal addresses. I do not believe that these matters have been addressed tonight. I think they are fundamental questions. The Government will do a very grave disservice to this Parliament if it does not provide response to those points and questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have answered that question at least four times. How many times do I have to go into the reasons why Tranby was selected and the course of the legal opinions in relation to it? I cannot add anything further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister to give me some explanation in respect of the unacquitted grants. Let me say for the record that I am not satisfied that the answer that the officers gave the Minister on the first occasion was a reflection of the truth. There is no ongoing program for the acquittal of grants. There has been a bungling mess and an absolute shambles in terms of unacquitted grants. The question I asked Senator Tate, as the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs on 25 November, was: how many unacquitted grants does the Department have presently outstanding nationally? That has nothing to do with 31 December, 1 January, or April Fools day. It is a close-off date which allows for a statistical answer. For reasons about which I can only speculate, and which the Department knows about, there has been a stalling of the answer. My guess is-and it is not an uninformed guess-that there has been a flurry in the Department in recent times to acquit the grants which have not so far been acquitted.

SPEECH.PARA: I put it to the Minister that at present there are about 2,000 unacquitted grants. I put to the Minister that there are associations and incorporated Aboriginal community bodies which are still attracting grants when they have unacquitted grants outstanding. I will wait for the Department to give the Minister further and better advice before I pursue my endeavours.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot give an answer this week as to the number of unacquitted grants. As I understand it, 37 field officers are being consulted. The material is being collated and an answer is expected next week. I have been told by officers that I will be able to give an answer to the honourable senator after Question Time before the Senate adjourns. I will endeavour to achieve that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister which I think is supplementary to that asked by Senator Crichton-Browne. The advice provided in relation to my question which we were debating earlier in relation to unacquitted grants was that, of the 1986-87 grants, a total of 34 grants have outstanding reports. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: These details are currently being prepared and will be presented at a later date.

I think that sentence supports very strongly the point that Senator Crichton-Browne is making. Were any of those 34 1986-87 grantees which have still not been reported recipients of grants in 1987-88?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am unable to provide an answer tonight, but obviously I can get the information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the greatest respect, let me say that the Department is either not providing the Minister with information or it is totally incompetent. I find it remarkable that a Government department, which was asked on 25 November what the status of unacquitted grants was, states on 1 December 1988 that it does not know. I assume that the number of unacquitted grants is not catalogued. Because I asked a question, I assume that the Department has some curiosity about the matter. Here we are, some five, six or seven days later, and the Department is in turmoil, trying to spew out figures which ought to be at hand. In some cases millions of dollars in single organisations are involved. The Minister is telling me that the Department cannot tell him whether these grants have been acquitted. It is a very simple, basic question, demanding and begging of a very simple and obvious answer.

SPEECH.PARA: I asked, for instance: Is it likely that, in the case of Western Australia as at September of this year, there were 769 unacquitted grants? Try that as a figure out of the air. Is the information available or is it not? Does the Minister have ongoing numbers or does he not? Is it unrealistic to imagine that the Department is capable of providing to itself and to its Minister, and to its Minister representing the Department in this chamber, the number at any given time? For instance, would it know, by looking at the Balgo Hills Aboriginal Community Incorporated profit and loss appropriation account as at 30 June 1987, whether the 1984-85 community development employment projects scheme grants of $483,684 is outstanding? Is it on the public record? The departmental officers have only got to do what I did and inquire through the Freedom of Information Act and pay out of their hard earned savings-which seems to amuse the departmental officers-and they will find the facts. But when I wrote to the Department and asked it for a refund of my money for getting information in the public interest, an officer wrote back and said he had carefully considered the grounds cited in support of my request; however, he considered that there were insufficient public interest grounds to remit the fees and charges levied. Is it fair that the Department can tell me that there are insufficient public interest grounds for refunding my money when I asked, in the public interest, whether grants were acquitted or unacquitted?

Weeks ago in this chamber I asked for an answer. Senator Richardson said, `Senator Crichton-Browne, I will give you an answer in a couple of days'. The very next day someone from Gerry Hand's office was on the phone sounding, I might say, very agitated. It just so happened that I had a prior commitment so I could not take his call, but I was available for the best part of the rest of the day. I have not heard from him since. I assume his moment of crisis passed. But I still do not know the answer and I still have not heard from Senator Richardson. In respect of the simple question to the Department about the number of unacquitted grants there is stunning silence. I find it remarkable that millions of dollars are outstanding and the Department cannot give me the answer. Surely the Department could have plucked out a couple of answers.

I asked seven simple questions. I asked: Are the Departmental officers sufficiently skilled to deal with the matter? I have been waiting seven days for an answer and I still have not got one. The Department does not know at this moment whether it has departmental officers sufficiently skilled to deal with the matter. I asked another simple question: What is the Government doing about these unacquitted grants? I would have thought that was a simple question. It could have said: We are doing something, or we are doing nothing, or we are taking valium, or we are having an Aspro and lying down, or we are working diligently in solving the problem. I have got no answer. I asked: Why has that occurred? I got no answer. The Department does not know why it has unacquitted grants going back for many years. It does not know why it is pumping taxpayers' funds into these organisations when they have already got unacquitted grants.

I asked another simple question-it ought to be like a drivers manual: Is the Department enforcing financial rules and guidelines for the administration of these grants? I cannot get an answer. Seven days later the Department does not know whether it is enforcing its financial rules and guidelines for the administration of these grants. What can this Department of Aboriginal Affairs tell us? If the officers do not know who the departmental head is I can understand their being confused, but I would have thought they would at least have known the normal procedures. I asked another simple question: Are grants still being made to organisations that presently have unacquitted grants? Is that difficult? Is that so complicated and confusing that the Department, which has a budget of billions of dollars and a thousand employees, cannot answer it? What is so devastating or penetrating and confusing that the Department cannot answer those simple and fundamental questions?

I do not imagine the Minister is very proud of that Department. It cannot answer simple questions. It cannot tell me whether my assessment of the Department having 2,200 unacquitted grants outstanding, as a ballpark figure, is right or wrong. I really do not know what the Department does know. Before I press on with the other matters, which will take me into the dark mire of confusion, perhaps the Minister could explain to me why any one of those seven questions has not been answered after seven days.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be obvious that I cannot provide an answer as to the numbers. I have given an undertaking, as advised by the officers, that to satisfy Senator Crichton-Browne's question that material will be available before we get up. In other words, I will provide it to the chamber after Question Time some time in the next fortnight. As to the range of questions which Senator Crichton-Browne posed, I think quite properly I obviously took them, and the departmental officers have taken them, to be a composite question. He would not want a partial answer which would perhaps just make a qualitative assessment of `Yes we have officers who are skilled enough to provide the supervision and the backup required to conduct the acquittal of grants' and so on and so forth. We want to provide a full and composite answer to the seven-part question, and that will be provided.

—I say to Senator Tate, with the greatest respect, that I will be quite happy if the Department will give one question its very best shot. Let us pick question 5 out of the bag. Are the departmental officers sufficiently skilled to deal with the matter? If they answer no, can I be told why they are not skilled; if they answer yes, can I be told why they are skilled, and if they are skilled can the Minister tell me why he cannot give me the answer to any of the other questions?

—I believe the Department-evident may I say, from my experience during the Estimates Committee-has very skilled personnel available to administer the various programs. But it does not follow from that that it is able to collate and bring together all of the information that the honourable senator requires in a matter of five or six days. It will take some time, but I do not take that to be a reflection on the skill of the officers concerned. It is simply an indication of the scope of the material which has to be gathered.

—Before I slip away from that question, I ask the Department for an assurance that it has not suddenly begun to acquit grants since the events began to emerge which caused the resignation of the previous head of the Department, or just prior to that. Will the Department give me an indication whether its endeavours have been reinvigorated as a result of my questions?

—I can only repeat that the question of the acquittal of grants is one that arises with every year's grants. It is an ongoing program, to use the jargon. It is not the case that this has suddenly become a matter of terrible urgency with some sort of artificiality attached to it. What has given a focus and impetus to it is Senator Crichton-Browne's question, to which we are attempting to answer.

—What the Minister is saying is that the acquittal of grants is an ongoing matter. Therefore I would assume that if I plotted the number of grants acquitted each month there would be some uniformity of the graph and I would not expect to find a distortion. For instance, I would not expect to find that in the months of October, November or December an abnormal number of grants acquitted.

—I do not think that that follows at all. Indeed, on the advice given to me a while ago, which I relayed to the chamber, that grants given by a financial year do not have to be acquitted until the end of the calendar year, one would expect in the latter part of the calendar year-namely, October, November and December-much of that acquittal would take place. I would expect the graph to go up in those latter months.

—Perhaps I asked the question badly. My question was really intended to convey this impression: could I expect to find a number of acquittals in October, November, December and perhaps January of this year and next year to be, for all intents and purposes, similar to that of the previous year in those months?

—I do not know the answer to that. It may be that there are a varying number of grants and therefore the number of acquittals will obviously vary. It depends on many factors, not just crude aggregate numbers. I would nevertheless say that I would expect, as the end of the calendar year approaches, that we would get a lot more acquittals being recorded.

—May I bring the Minister back to the bald question again. Will he give me an undertaking and an assurance that the acquittal of grants at present and going back to October of this year is within the framework of the normality of the Department, or have the acquittals been simulated from directions from the Minister or as a result of events that have occurred in either chamber? I think that request is simple enough. Could I expect to find that there is nothing unique about the present period?

—I am advised that the concern about the number of unacquitted grants was manifested late last year. So this in fact has not been a matter of special and unique-I think that was the term the honourable senator used-attention only over the last couple of months because of the furore surrounding the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. Nevertheless, it stands to reason that, human nature being what it is, knowing the scrutiny that the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio is under, I would expect State directors to respond very readily to the hounding, almost, that they are receiving in order to provide the acquittals. I cannot deny, obviously, that in the general atmosphere that has been created over the last couple of months there would be an added incentive to acquit these grants as speedily as possible and to meet the end of the calendar year deadline.

—May I ask Senator Tate to reflect upon and give me his view of the integrity of the argument that is put in respect of my application for a refund of the cost under the Freedom of Information Act. The Department told me that it was inappropriate for a senator to be refunded because it was not sufficiently in the public interest.

—I do not know the details of this matter at all. I would imagine that if Senator Crichton-Browne is not satisfied with the decision that has been made by the Department he can go through the processes of appealing against that decision. It is not my role to try to second guess the departmental officers who made that particular decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will leave that for another time. May I ask the Minister's view of the level of competence in terms of management and skill of the Department. The Minister should remember point 5 of my series of questions about what I understand to be a review of the departmental processes, particularly with respect to funding of major projects in the financial year 1987-88, including activities in the current financial year and a report that I understand was written by Mr Dunlevy and Mr Lyne of the Minister's Department. The findings were in respect of project control which goes to the very heart of the Department's capacity to protect the integrity and the careful spending of taxpayers' money. The findings of the project control were:

SPEECH.PARA: There was a general breakdown of Project Control procedures with the following deficiencies being identified:
financial reports since December 1986 were not examined or an examination attempted.
other than audit reports, most periodical reports submitted by organisations were deficient in some aspect.
Release of funds reports (C4's) were poorly prepared-some evidence of falsification of information existed.
Releases of capital funds in most cases were not properly conducted.
Letters of Offer for the Supply Period 1987-88 didn't show evidence that they were signed by the delegated officer.
File copy was unsigned.

Releases were made without the prerequisite offer/acceptance letters in some cases, and many releases were made in August/September 87 without cover of offer/acceptance-advice was that a separate cover was to hand from State Office.
Audited financial statements relating to the 1986-87 financial year were not examined in most cases and consequently surpluses were not and still have not been adjusted.
Releases of funds were made in March 1988 without reference to the need to examine audit reports-this requirement was overlooked.
Later on I will raise the matter of the audit reports of a number of Aboriginal communities in Western Australia which impinge directly on that finding. The report continues:
Many releases of funds that should have been made under delegation were not.
There was very little evidence on files that follow up action had been taken by officers to obtain outstanding information-financial returns, certificates, etc.
Financial Reporting

The quality of financial reporting to the Region by most of the funded organisations is poor. Financial reports are not received on time and are usually deficient in some regard. Audit Reports as a consequence are heavily qualified.
For almost two years deficient financial reports have been tacitly accepted by the Regional Office. These reports were not examined and organisations not advised of shortcomings.
The deficiencies identified were as follows:-
Many organisations presented consolidated Income and Expenditure or Receipts and Payments Statements that contained a variety of items not connected with DAA grants.

The most substantial item included in most cases was funds contributed by members. `Chuck in Money' which was expended on various items including many consumables-taxi fares, beverages, travel and the like.
Due to the existence of these items the identification of expenditure against funds was extremely difficult if not impossible.
The purpose of financial reports, i.e. to identify the cash situation of organisations and to monitor grants could not be achieved.
All periodical reporting requirements were rarely received and those deficiencies were not pointed out to the organisation concerned.
A letter has been prepared for dispatch to organisations . . . outlining accounting requirements, however, it is likely that in many cases this will not be understood by the recipients.
In respect of block grants--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, when Senator Crichton-Browne commenced reading the report, I missed who was the author or the authors.

—Forgive me. I understand that the report was prepared by the Department in Western Australia and related generally to the status of grants, their management, disbursement and accountability in Aboriginal communities in Western Australia. Let us look at block grants. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the poor reporting record of most funded organisations they continue to be placed on block grants and/or six monthly reporting requirements.
It should be noted that block funding and the relaxation of financial reporting is generally reserved for organisations with good records of accountability and demonstrated sound managerial ability.
I would have thought that that was reasonable. In terms of the release of funds forms-that is the C4 forms-the report states:
As outlined above, these forms were poorly addressed by Regional staff. In many cases the information presented was incorrect or false.
I do not know where the word `false' comes from. One can understand the word `incompetent' but the word `false' surely leads us in another direction. It goes on:
Checks made reveal several instances of forms conveying information that was not supported by evidence on files and in some cases evidence existed that forms were knowingly falsified.
The impression gained was that the release of funds was paramount and that control mechanisms were knowingly overridden in order to achieve this objective.
The major deficiencies noted were as follows:

* Widespread statements in the form C4s that reports were to hand had been examined and that deficiencies were noted and being followed up when the reports had not been received, or were received but not examined.
* Cases existed where reports for periods were said to have been received and examined when the reports in question were not required, sought, or indeed received, or ever likely to be received.
* Statements in the C4s that the necessary quotes/tender arrangements had been complied with when they had not. In some cases quotes/tenders were obtained after the release of the funds.
* Quotes sometimes beyond their usual validity periods (in other words, old quotes) were used for convenience to facilitate the release of capital funds.
This is what it says about grant acquittals:
Prior to the visit the total of unacquitted grants for the Region was 151 grants.
Everyone else seems to know the number of unacquitted grants except the officers who are here advising us tonight. The authors of the report went on to say:

Steps were taken while in Derby to accelerate the acquittance of grants where possible. This took the form of Mr Dunlevy acquainting the project officer concerned with unresolved issues that hindered the acquittance of the grant concerned.
With the assistance of the project officer concerned matters were resolved where possible or steps taken towards the resolution of outstanding matters . . .

And so the report goes on. I conclude this part of my argument by saying that the report alleges that likewise there are a number of other projects which did not come under the jurisdiction of any particular project officer at the time and headway with these was not possible. I ask the Minister to comment on this quote from the report. It says:

With regard to the deficiencies noted in the course of the file review, it is necessary to acknowledge that a major breakdown has occurred and that steps will be taken to ensure that grant administration will be normalised immediately.

There is very little value at this stage of the Department's life to attempt to rectify the lapses that have occurred, as such an attempt would deplete the resources available for the current, ongoing, day to day operations of the Department and the Region.

In the light of the inability of the Department to advise the Minister of what I would describe as very elementary questions, which should be contained within the files in an ongoing capacity, is the Minister satisfied with what he understands to be the performance of the Department so far? Does he accept that it should take two weeks for unacquitted grants to be provided to him? Does he think a department should have on its computer process, which cost millions of dollars, a simple mechanism where a button could be pressed to show the position of Ombulgurri or Kalumburu or Balgo or Marra Worra Worra or Junjuwa or any other Aboriginal community one likes to name? It is elementary that that information should be available, and I would have thought that most enterprises would know to whom they had given money, whether it had been accounted for, whether it had been repaid, whether it was still outstanding, who owed money, why it was owed and who was incompetent. Yet we have millions and millions of dollars of taxpayers' money somewhere rotating, floating and circulating out there which no one can quite get a handle on. The Department does not seem to know who has got what money, where it is going, what it is for and what it is supposed to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —And if they do they are not telling.

—That is right. If the Department does know it is not telling. If it does not know it is not telling us about the nervous breakdown it is having. We are being kept in total darkness. The shutters have been brought down. If the Department said to the Minister, `We have made a terrible mess, we are trying to retrieve the situation, thank you for bringing it to our attention. Yes, you are right, we have been incompetent, indolent, inefficient and our attempts have been futile but mea culpa, mea culpa, mea maxima culpa, we are on the way to recovery', I would buy it. But for the Minister to try to stonewall me and say that he does not know but is trying to work out the mess he has got himself into is far from satisfactory. Perhaps the Minister could give me his reflection, his enlightened views, on the information with which I have provided him, which no doubt is at the fingertips of his Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to the question of the administration of the portfolio and the various programs within it, honourable senators will be aware of the sorts of matters which gave rise to the various inquiries instituted by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) which are now under way. I expect that the sort of review of these programs being undertaken by the Public Service Commission, the Auditor-General and the Department of Finance, and in an overall way by Mr Andrew Menzies, will enable us to form a more considered view as to the general level of administrative skills possessed within the Department, and as to the competence and probity of the officers concerned in the administration of these programs. The Government, without making any assumptions, awaits those reports. We will then have an overall picture which will enable any steps that are required to be taken on the basis of most expert advice.

SPEECH.PARA: As for the particular document, which Senator Crichton-Browne says is a document provided from within the departmental office in Western Australia, obviously I am not conversant with it. None of the officers present in the chamber assisting is conversant with that document. Therefore, I am unable to comment on the assertions of fact and the allegations as to maladministration which are made in it. Nevertheless, it is a matter for concern, and if it is a departmental report for the benefit of the administrators of the programs in Western Australia, then I imagine that the matter, having been so carefully defined and assessed, was handled by way of preliminary to concerted action being taken to remedy the situation. One imagines that a report is not made in order to vent some sort of spleen, but to base a more stringent approach to the problems which are revealed. I hope that that is the purpose of the report. It is not one which the central office has in its possession.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had no answers at all tonight. If the honourable senators look at the Hansard proceedings they will find that there has not been a single answer to any of the questions. Therefore, I suppose it is with some futility that I turn to a particular application which was for a literature writing project at Marra Worra Worra granted for the period from 1986. An application was granted to Stephen Hawke for the purpose of writing a book on the events of Noonkanbah for the period 1979-80, involving an amount of $22,255.20. Would the Department know whether all the funds have been consumed? Would it know whether the book has been written? If it has not been written, would the Department know the status of the writing of the book?

—Obviously it is a matter administered by the Department in Western Australia. Officers in the central office would not know about every grant of that size and nature. It is quite unlikely that they would know, and they do not know. We have to be clear as to the function of the Committee of the Whole in relation to Senate Estimates committees. As I understand it, it is the subject of a report which is suggesting a more streamlined approach to the way in which the Committee of the Whole receives Estimates committee reports. The information sought in the kind of detailed question which the honourable senator just posed is obviously within the knowledge of regional officers of the Department and the question could well be raised at Estimates committee hearings or, through the Estimates committee secretariat, put to officers in the Department or the Aboriginal Development Commission. I am sure that they would have been able to have provided an answer for the honourable senator tonight. But it is quite impossible, and I do not think it advances any thesis to make it apparent, for officers here tonight to answer that sort of question. It is just too detailed, as they do not have available to them matters which are clearly on the files of regional directors.

—I have to say that I find that statement absolutely outstanding. I have never heard a more impertinent answer in my life. At the beginning of the evening I asked the Minister a simple question. I thought I would start with a broader canvass and work my way down. I asked the Minister how many unacquitted grants there were nationally and he did not know. I asked him how many unacquitted grants there were State by State and he did not know. I asked the Minister why they had not been acquitted and he did not know. I asked him whether his departmental officers were competent to acquit them and he did not know. I asked him why they were not competent and he did not know. I asked him whether they were competent and he did not know. I have been here since 8.30 and I have not had one answer. For the Minister to criticise me and to suggest that my questions are too trivial I find remarkable and, as I have said, impertinent.

—I did not make the statement that the honourable senator's questions were trivial. As far as I know they could be quite serious. I did not say they were trivial; I said they were detailed, and there is a big difference. As the honourable senator would know, it is quite absurd to expect officers to give details off the cuff of a grant made by the Western Australian office. They obviously do not have that information and cannot help the honourable senator. If Senator Crichton-Browne wants to be helped, which I understand is the purpose of asking such questions, I suggest that it would have been helpful to give some notice of his questions. Then the answers would have been provided.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me talk in a more global sense in terms of principles to see whether we can reach some sort of resolution. Let me deal with some general areas of principal; that is, the accountability, the control and the management of funds in respect of various organisations and the role the Minister sees the Department having in the assistance it provides to Aboriginal communities to ensure that they have competent, capable and dedicated officers with certain levels of integrity. Let me ask the Minister about Oombulgurri, which the Minister discussed with me at the same stage last year, where $200,000 was lost to the community when the bookkeeper disappeared with the books and the money. The Minister's answer to me last year was that he thought that the Australian Federal Police were investigating the matter and his Department was examining the books to see what could be done about it. My understanding is that, since then, the officer has been found and, in some obscure way-I ask the Minister to forgive me for not knowing any more than that, but it seems to be a big leap forward in terms of what the Department knows-has now been paid $35,000 in compensation. Yet my fleeting examination of the auditor's report of Oombulgurri shows me that the accountability has not improved and the standard of bookkeeping have not improved. Perhaps the Minister can explain to me why, concerning the period to 30 June 1987, the auditor states:

SPEECH.PARA: During the first few months of the year ended June 30 1987 the internal controls over cash payments were not sufficient to ensure that all payments were made for bona fide community purposes.
A list of payments made for which we could find no supporting documentation whatsoever . . .
The internal controls surrounding the cash float system were not adequate to ensure that all outgoings could be accounted for or that transactions were correctly recorded.

I will not go through that report in detail, or the Balgo report, or the Kalumburu report-which I have personally asked Senator Tate about before-or the rest. I simply ask him to explain to me why that man received $30,000, $35,000 or $40,000-I am not certain about the total-in compensation. Last year Senator Tate told me that the Department was looking for him to retrieve the money. Having had this matter brought to his Department's attention, and his being advised of it, his Department was well aware of the deficiencies in bookkeeping in that organisation. Why have we had an audit report since then which shows that these defects have not been rectified?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure. I think the audit report refers to 1986-87. As to the person concerned, I do not have any information which I could make available to Senator Crichton-Browne tonight.

—Would the Minister tell me at a later time what steps the Department is taking-I have no doubt it has got audit reports from all these organisations-to ensure that there is some sensible and proper regime in the bookkeeping and accounting procedures. Or does he think that self-determination means that once money is paid out, it is no longer the Department's responsibility?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I do not believe that and I do not believe it is the attitude of the Department. There is a real necessity to ensure that moneys which are provided for Aboriginal communities, for the advancement of Aboriginal people, or paid to some Aboriginal organisation, are used for their intended purposes. Accounting is required for that. The sort of reporting and the sort of acquittal that we have been speaking about for the last hour is a means by which the Department checks that the moneys which it pays out are paid out with no thought as to their devotion to the purposes for which they were provided. There are mechanisms in place to try to ensure that those purposes are indeed fulfilled by the expenditure of those moneys.

SPEECH.PARA: I think I have also pointed out that there are programs intended to build up management expertise and skills in bookkeeping within Aboriginal organisations. Indeed, there is quite a large program. We have discussed the Aboriginal organisation training program, which is directed to trying to provide Aboriginal organisations with those sorts of skills. Obviously it is not straightforward or easy to achieve, in a short space of time. But it is one of the programs being undertaken in order to ensure that within Aboriginal organisations there is proper accounting of the moneys provided. It is quite clear from this Government's attitude that money should be acquitted and properly accounted for. One would hope that the review by the Department of Finance, by the Public Service Commissioner and by the Auditor-General will perhaps better focus on such matters as need to be undertaken in order to ensure that the management of those funds is as stringent as possible. I have just received a note that the training under the Aboriginal organisation training program involves an expenditure of some $3.5m per year. In so far as that expenditure provides for the training of persons within Aboriginal organisations, it may be seen to be a very good investment if, indeed, it leads to a situation where persons can undertake the bookkeeping and the acquittal which is of such concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —If my memory serves me correctly, I understand that the present Chairman of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC), Mr Cedric Wyatt, when asked what was his particular skill that was deserving of his appointment, said that he had managerial competence and administrative skills. I think that was approximately his response to the question.
—I think he said he was good at managing people; something like that.

—Good at managing people; does the Minister think that having 800 unacquitted grants for the State of Western Australia and allowing some organisations to continue to receive grants which already have outstanding unacquitted grants shows good, competent and capable managerial skills of the type the Minister thinks are desirable? Does he think that that level of competence deserves a promotion to the Aboriginal Development Commission? Is that the sort of person that he thinks is satisfactory to have in such a position? I ask not a rhetorical question but a serious question: does the Minister think that a person with such a record is the sort of person who could walk into the ADC as acting manager and solve those enormous human resource problems and financial and political problems?

—An answer to that, of course, would depend on knowing what Mr Wyatt's attitude had been to those unacquitted grants. There are obviously any number of reasons for the failure of those particular grants to be acquitted over a period of time. It is a responsibility, obviously, of the organisation concerned to provide the report and material which enables the grant to be properly acquitted. I do not know offhand whether the skills of management which Mr Wyatt possesses were brought to bear in a way which enabled that situation to linger and fester. I do not believe that would be the case. So it is improper to deduce from the fact that there were 800 unacquitted grants-and I do not know exactly what period that refers to--
—It is a cumulative number.
—A cumulative number; I do not know whether that reflects his managerial skills which have been evidence in various appointments that he has held.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I move on I must say that I find the Minister's answer quite remarkable. I understand that this is not his Department and that he is carrying a load of lead for somebody else-Mr Hand. I find it absolutely stunningly remarkable that he would proffer to this chamber the opinion on whether Mr Wyatt is the appropriate person to administer the Aboriginal Development Commission on the basis of saying, when I asked him about the unacquitted grants, that it depends upon his attitude to these unacquitted grants. What is his role? What is his responsibility? I do not want to drag this out tonight, but what is the function of the head of a region, of a State, of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA)? Is he required to have some knowledge of the outstanding grants? Is he expected to know what grants have been acquitted and what grants have been unacquitted? Is that part of his functions? Is that part of his responsibility? Is that part of his duty, or is it, as the Minister says, a matter for the organisation concerned? Is it a matter of concern for the organisations of Oombulgurri or Kalumburu that they have unacquitted grants of a couple of million dollars of taxpayers' funds, and that it is only their problem-that is not the Minister's problem, it is not the taxpayers' problem, it is not the departmental head's problem? Whose problem is it? I find it remarkable that the Minister would say to me that it is not Mr Wyatt's problem.
—I did not say that.

—The Minister said that it depends on Mr Wyatt's attitude towards it. If there are 800 unacquitted grants in Western Australia, hypothetically, surely that is his responsibility. Tens of millions worth of dollars are involved in those unacquitted grants. At the end of the day, the responsibility for the approval of those grants-in some respects the administration and in all respects the acquittal-rests with him. It is not good enough to say that the Aboriginal community at Noonkanbah is exclusively responsible. The Minister knows that most of the leaders of those Aboriginal communities are unable to read or write, least of all count. In many cases they barely speak English. Yet the Minister puts it to me-to use his expression-that it is the responsibility of the organisation concerned. That is why I asked Senator Tate what he sees is the responsibility of the Department in respect of the various officers appointed. I understand what self-determination means in the minds of some and I do not know what it means in the minds of others. I certainly do not know what it means in the mind of the Department. Does it mean that it has the exclusive right to hire and fire who it likes and, at the end of the day, if millions of dollars goes astray, so be it? Is that what self-determination means?

SPEECH.PARA: Let me refer the Minister to the Wangkatjungka auditor's report. I have raised this man's name before and I regret that it could give the impression that I am concerned about him. I am concerned about a principle. I refer to a Mr Peter Ross, who was still on the payroll of one of the organisations. The auditor's report referred to the fact that Mr Ross was `booking up personal motor expenses to the association when he visited Derby. The association paid for two charter flights to and from Derby on 2 May 1985 and 18 February 1986 carrying Mr Ross'. There is no indication that that was on behalf of the organisation. The expense items, stores purchased, included various expenditures which did not relate to stores purchased. They included food items used by Mr Ross in entertaining visiting officials and personal items for Mr Ross, which Mr Ross maintained should have been deducted from his wages by the Marra Worra Worra Association but were not deducted. The only problem is that there was never any authorisation given to Marra Worra Worra. There were items for supplies for home maintenance and items of equipment for the projects officer's house-that is, Mr Ross's house-and 34 cartons of beer which Mr Ross informed the auditor were used to entertain visiting officials.

There are those who would complain that Mr Ross has an unfortunate but long history of misplacing organisations' and taxpayers' funds. There have been complaints that he has misappropriated pension cheques. It is a well known fact that in the Fitzroy Crossing area Mr Ross used to go to the local pub in anticipation of the pension cheques coming in and getting $8,000 or $10,000 of hot cash in his hot little hand. Then he would dole it out like a benevolent Father Christmas. When the cheques came in, he would cash them and pay back the pub. Nobody ever knew whether Mr Ross stashed half the money in his pocket, down his pants, in his boots, or what happened. There was no accountability. By way of example, Mr Ross went to Christmas Creek. In 1985 Christmas Creek brought a brand new Toyota Hi-Lux. It arrived at Derby for pick up. The Wangkatjungka community authorised two senior members of the community to take custody of the vehicle. One was Jimmy Angie and the other was Sandowner Elliot. But Mr Ross interfered and two young men of doubtful reputation went across to pick the vehicle up. One, Marty Stevens was well known in the area. Instead of picking it up in Derby and taking it back to Wangkatjangka they decided they would go to the rodeo in Broome. They got 170 kilometres south in this brand spanking new vehicle and rolled it over. It was written off and sold to the wreckers for $3,500. That was the Wangkatjangka's one and only source of transport. That was Mr Ross's contribution.

At about the same time a Mr Joe Tramata was appointed to the local school. There had been a resolution by the local community that the community school would be kept quite separate and autonomous from the affairs of the community. Mr Ross got there and in five minutes rounded up the Aboriginal community, passed his own resolutions and caused havoc in the school.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that fellow a white?

—This man is a white, yes. There have been complaints about him. Time is against me. I have letters here written to the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Clyde Holding, from the Chairman of the Marra Worra Worra Association of Fitzroy Crossing. I have a letter here to Clyde Holding, from Johnny Watson, Chairman of the Kimberley Land Council. Both letters complain about this man in clear and precise detail. They even say that when he was lobbying for the job he bribed the Aboriginal community with motor cars and rifles. The Department first of all ignored the allegations, then, if my memory serves me correctly, wrote back and said that it was none of their business. That is why I bring these matters before the Minister. I do not raise them for the sake of airing bad linen.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Ross worked for the Junjuwah Association. He is a justice of the peace. He threatened several Aboriginal people with physical violence. On one occasion the Junjuwah people called a meeting for his dismissal. He walked in and offered one of the senior elders, Mr Adam Andrews, a motor car. He gave him the key and said, `That's what I can do for you as long as I am running your organisation'. He gave a DAA car away-a taxpayers' car-to keep his job. I do not want to go on and on and on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, of course you do.

—Senator Ray ought not provoke me. Mr Ross got involved in Marra Worra Worra recently. He called a meeting. He rounded up all the members of the Aboriginal community he could lay his hands on, threatened, intimidated and stood over them, and got them to sack the bookkeepers. I will give the Department credit: it at least went to examine the books and found them not wanting and the bookkeeper to be a person of good repute, I understand. But by then Mr Ross had caused all the trouble he wanted to cause. The auditors observed:

SPEECH.PARA: We are of the opinion that Mr Ross should not have become directly involved in the affairs of Marra Worra Worra. He is not of Aboriginal descent. He is not a member of Marra Worra Worra staff and his actions concerning Marra Worra Worra could be attributable in part to personal motives.

That same Mr Ross is presently employed by Junjuwah in the same town. I ask the question: What responsibility does the Minister see the Department having to deal with these problems which he must know are beyond the competence, capacity and ability of these Aboriginal communities to deal with personally? It seems that the Department continues to wash its hands of matters on every occasion. One on occasion the Marra Worra Worra community complained about the local regional officer, a Mr Hunter if my memory serves me correctly. The community complained first that he interfered and insisted that it employ people. One such person stole $5,000 and disappeared to the eastern States. He also chose to drive the community's vehicle from Perth to Marra Worra Worra without the community's authority. He rolled the vehicle over on the way and the community never saw it.

I ask: What does the Department judge on balance to be its responsibility in ensuring the preservation of the integrity of these organisations and their funds and their functions? Or does it wash its hands and say, `It has nothing to do with us. They are autonomous organisations. We concern ourselves not with the employees; we concern ourselves not with the funds; we concern ourselves not with the audit reports; we concern ourselves not with whether they are achieving the objectives, the goals, the ambitions and perhaps the desires and aspirations that they have for themselves?' Does it just write them off? Does it just keep feeding money into them or does it think it has some intrinsic responsibility towards them? Does it try to manifest that responsibility in some way through the white advisers, the white community employees, the white officers of the Department who presumably are there to help and assist; not hinder, not manipulate, not in any way seek for their own agenda to cause the problems that are flowing right through Australia now, causing the divisions and divisiveness that the Government claims is the responsibility of this side of politics?

There seems to be no care, no regard, no passion by the Department, nor its officers and, least of all, the Ministers for the plight of these people and it gets worse. Every year when I look at the audit reports of these communities I find more money lost, misappropriated, stolen or just plain disappeared, and the response I get on every occasion is, `We do not know the answer; we will look at it; it is a matter of regional consequence that we cannot concern ourselves about'. Surely at the end of the day, it makes up the broader canvass and fulfils the larger picture. Surely the department has a responsibility. Surely it sees itself as having to ensure, in the balance of self-determination, in the balance of responsibilities resting with the local community, some counterbalance so that these people, at the end of the day, do not suffer as a result of the lack of endeavour or concern or contribution by the Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise as an ordinary backbencher whose main function in this place is to maintain a quorum, it seems, but at the same time I also rise as the Chairman of the Estimates Committee that dealt with these issues relating to Aboriginal affairs for about two weeks. From my memory there were 2,000 questions or more on notice. There was a significant period of questioning, probably more than on any other committee I have been associated with, in relation to Aboriginal affairs. A number of Liberal, National Party and Democrat senators turned up to those Estimates hearings, as did the press, as did pretty well everyone in Australia by the time the press had finished with reporting those Estimates hearings.

SPEECH.PARA: I did not see Senator Crichton-Browne at any of those hearings. I did not see written questions on notice that could have been handed in to the Committee. I did not see the sort of detail that the honourable senator is raising tonight raised during those hearings. I did hear, for example, accusations about black mafia corruption and so on in Aboriginal affairs being brought forward by Senator Tambling, who at least had the courage to sit through all the hearings, who at least had the courage to put his name to a report, and who at least had the time to stand up and be counted in that particular issue, similarly with Senator Short. Tonight I have heard that process taken a step further. Senator Crichton-Browne stood up in this place and established himself as judge, jury and executioner of people's reputations. I do not know Mr Ross from Adam, nor Adam Smith, which was another name raised by Senator Crichton-Browne, but I have a personal view about what we ought to be doing in this chamber about people's reputations. It is my view that there are other jurisdictions to accuse, try and sentence people for crimes or misdemeanours which are not accepted by the community, which are considered to be criminal offences.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I take a point of order. I am not intimidated by the pathetic drivel I hear from the other side.
—Order! What is the honourable senator's point of order?

—We are addressing ourselves to particular appropriations. While they have no doubt escaped the attention of the honourable senator on the other side, they relate to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. I ask you, Mr Temporary Chairman, whether he is addressing himself to the funding of that Department.
—On that point of order: Senator Aulich is attempting to show whether Senator Crichton-Browne was relevant.
—Why don't you talk to Walsh?
—Shut up, Shirley.

—The real question Senator Aulich is asking is whether fresh material-some of it is fresh, some of it is not-is appropriate at this stage. I think he is entitled to make that point in the committee stage. It is relevant. I am sure that he will move on to some other material shortly. I think he is allowed to put the landscape, especially as he has not detained the Committee for very long in these proceedings.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, I take a point of order. I ask the honourable senator to withdraw his unparliamentary remark to me.
—I am sorry; I did not hear it.
—What remark? It was not me.
—Aulich said it first; McKiernan said it second. I will get an apology from Aulich first.
—There is no point of order before the Chair at the moment.

—I will not detain the Committee much longer. As I have said, I have listened to the discussions that have occurred in this chamber. I have listened very carefully to people in the Committee discussing this issue. I am as concerned as anyone else in this chamber about the possible misappropriation of money. I am as concerned as anyone else in this chamber about accountability. I believe that there is value in the Opposition digging deeply into what goes on in various departments right throughout the government. That is what this is all about. But if it is a question of abusing this chamber, in order, for example-

—Mr Temporary Chairman, on a point of order: Senator Ray sought to give some friendly advice to his colleague but his colleague has obviously missed the point. Mr Temporary Chairman, is the honourable senator addressing the estimates for this Department and, if he is, what aspect of the estimates is he addressing?
—Speaking to the point of order --
—Well, do it politely.

—I will do it quietly, as normal. We have heard 15 minutes of vilification of an individual who did not have an opportunity to defend himself. It is atrocious that Senator Crichton-Browne has the audacity to call a point of order on Senator Aulich at this stage.
—Senator McKiernan, you have no point of order.

—Three points of order have been called on me in less than four minutes. I assumed that I would have been able to speak in this chamber on a serious issue that concerns people's reputations and the right of the Senate to make departments accountable without having three interruptions in something like four minutes. If Senator Crichton-Browne is not able to take the sort of issue I am raising, he ought not to be here. I have heard tonight, as we have talked about accountability, a great deal of new evidence being brought into this chamber, many new questions which were not raised during the Estimates hearings. As I have said, Senator Crichton-Browne had the opportunity, in the two weeks that our Committee sat, to raise these issues, either in writing--
—I take a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. I ask you to rule on whether Senator Aulich is addressing the estimates presently before the Chair.
—I think that, if Senator Aulich drew his argument to a close, the Committee would benefit.

—I was about to finish within a minute or so. The most recent point of order is now the fourth attempt in something like five minutes to silence me. I will finish by quoting some of the points Senator Crichton-Browne made. I will quote him directly. Firstly, he says, `It is a well known fact that Mr Ross did something or other'. I cannot recall Senator Crichton-Browne putting those questions on notice in our Committee. He says, `Two young men of doubtful reputation', then goes on to state who they were. He says that Mr Ross--
—Mr Temporary Chairman, I take a point of order. We are debating the estimates for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.
—What is your point of order, Senator?

—My point of order is that the honourable senator is not addressing his remarks to the estimates. He is attacking Senator Crichton-Browne. There is an appropriate place to do that, but it certainly is not in this Committee. Senator Aulich is wasting the time of the Committee. I ask you to bring him to order.

—I rise on the point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. I support my colleague Senator Boswell, who is correct. Senator Aulich is not in order-the same as Senator Crichton-Browne was not in order. Let us get on with it.
—Precisely, and if there are any more frivolous points of order taken, I will deal with them. Have you finished, Senator Aulich?

—I will finish on this point, Mr Temporary Chairman. There have been a significant number of questions. I have sat here listening to those questions. I believe that as a senator I have a right to expect that the chamber will behave in a particular way with regard to people's reputations. I must say-and I think I have the right to say this in this chamber-that quotations such as, `He offered Mr Andrews a taxpayers' car to keep his job', `He threatened several people with violence', and so on, are quotations which, if they needed to be checked for their veracity, should have been raised during the Estimates committees. Either we address this issue tonight or next year we go through the same process where we have more then 2,500 questions asked in the Estimates committees and then we go through the whole issue all over again, punishing people's reputations in this place. I believe that there are many people on the other side of this chamber who take exception to that particular process.

SPEECH.PARA: I have raised my protest at this stage. I will not say any more about this issue. I indicate that next year, presumably as Chairman of Estimates Committee E again, I will be asking questions, during the process of our discussions and our analysis as an Estimates committee, and I will be raising this matter again if it gets before the Committee of the Whole House.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Short's) be agreed to.
A division having been called and the bells having been rung-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I take a point of order. I see in the circulated typed amendment to be moved by Senator Tambling-in fact it was moved by Senator Short-that there is no mention of a date on which it is to be laid on the table of the Senate. I understood that there was an amendment stating that it be laid on the table of the Senate on or before 5 December. Is that part of the motion that you have before you?
—Senator Short moved that as part of his motion. The second paragraph should read: `To be laid on the table of the Senate on or before 5 December 1988'.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditure agreed to.

Department of Primary Industries and Energy
