Proposed expenditure, $1,294,590,000

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a number of questions in regard to the Department of Community Services and Health. I understand that, because of staff reductions within the Department, tests of the effectiveness of some drugs have for some time been operating at reduced levels. As a result, serious backlogs have developed in the area. I understand that the supply of some fertility hormone used to treat infertile women was not tested for nine months after it had been used in the program. On testing, that hormone was found to be inactive. Is that correct?
—In general there are backlogs, as I understand. However, I have no information on the particular hormonal drug which Senator Walters mentioned and the delay in its testing.

—I did not have this information at the time of the Estimates. This information came to me a result of the answers I received from the Department. I did not have the opportunity, therefore, of asking these questions during the course of the Estimates Committee. These questions have arisen as a direct result of the answers I received from the Department-from Mr Roche, in particular. I would like to ask this question again because I am quite sure that if such a serious occurrence happened in the Department surely the Department would know about it and we would be able to get the information tonight. I ask again: Was it a fact that the supply of a fertility hormone used to treat infertile women was not tested for nine months after it had been used in the program and, on testing, was found to be inactive?

—I apologise to Senator Walters. We were switching over Ministers to deal with these estimates and my attention was diverted. However, in regard to the particular drug that Senator Walters referred to, I am sorry that I am not in a position to give an answer on the specifics of it. There are some delays in the testing of drugs and there are a number of reasons for the delays. I am not sure whether there are appropriate reasons in the particular case the honourable senator referred to but, since she has raised that matter, I will seek specific details for her from the Department of Community Services and Health.

—I am sorry, but I am not quite clear what that means. Did the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) say that does occur sometimes, or did he say that he has no knowledge of it occurring? It is a very serious matter. I can imagine that the infertile women who were tested with the hormone that was found to be inactive would be rather upset by it. Is the delay due to staff cuts or because of the backlog in the testing? They are pretty basic questions. As I say, I was unable to ask them during the Estimates Committee hearing. I asked Mr Roche particularly about the staff cuts and the effects of the staff cuts. I want to find out if this backlog has caused the problems we see.

—As I said, there are some delays in particular cases. I cannot answer on the spot whether the drug that the honourable senator mentioned has been affected by those delays. She asked as well whether the delay is caused by staff cuts. I can say categorically no, it is not. There are some delays due to testing procedures that have been embarked on, and there are delays for other reasons. If the honourable senator will allow me, I will take her question on notice because it is about a specific drug. I can see from her demeanour that she is concerned about it and she therefore wants a specific answer, and I will undertake to get that.

—Could the Minister also find out what drug was used? He tells me that the delay is not the result of staff cuts. He tells me there are backlogs. Could he tell me the size of the backlogs in this area?

(10.13)-I am advised that there is a backlog in testing of approximately 15 months. I cannot indicate the precise number of drugs as I am not aware of that. As I said, the backlog is occasioned for a number of reasons and I think those reasons have been fairly well canvassed in the past, but they do not relate to staff cuts.
—The Minister says very categorically that the delay was not as a result of staff cuts. Could he tell me how many cuts in staff there have been in that area?
—Senator Walters has again asked for some precise data. My advice is that in this particular area of the Department there have been only minor staff cuts.
—I am not asking for rough figures. I am asking for the detail of how many staff cuts there have been in that area.
—If the honourable senator will allow me to answer=m-
—Order! Senator Cook has the call.

—There are only minor staff cuts. The backlog to which I have referred to is a backlog that applied separate from and before those staff cuts were instituted. So I say categorically that my advice is that the staff cuts themselves have not contributed to the delay in the valuation procedures. The delay in the valuation procedures has been caused by other reasons. Since the honourable senator has asked for precise information, might I say with due respect that this is a question she could have pursued at the Committee. We did, I think, provide ample scope for pursuit of specific questions when the officers were all in attendance. I cannot now pluck figures out of the air to answer the question. I will see if I can get some further advice on it now, but if I am unable to get further advice I will have to take the honourable senator's question on notice again, I am sorry.
—I did ask these questions in the Estimates Committee. There is nothing I am asking the Minister tonight that I could have asked then.
—I do not think there is any question you did not ask.

—If we are going to have smart interjections, we are going to be here all night and the Minister is not going to have this through before the adjournment. So let us calm down. If the Minister wants the appropriations in a quarter of an hour then he had better tell people that there will be no smart interjections.
—We will go and have a cup of coffee.

—I think it would be a jolly good idea. Senator Cook has told me that there is a backlog of 15 months, that that has nothing to do with staff cuts, that it was there before the additional staff cuts were made. He says the staff cuts have been only minor. I asked Mr Roche whether in the therapeutic division there had been any staff cuts and he said, `I do not think there have been reductions in staff'. He then gave us a table and in that period said that there were reductions in staff. Senator Cook told me that there was a 15 months backlog prior to the staff cuts. He then cut staff, but he says that the backlog had nothing to do with staff cuts. I would have thought it was pretty obvious that if one wanted to lessen the period of the backlog then one certainly would not have made any cuts but would have increased the number of staff.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that, while that is an observation, it is also a question. Can I say to the first part of the honourable senator's statement that if my colleagues were interjecting it is not my responsibility to maintain decorum in this chamber. I do not think it is reasonable to say, nor do I accept any challenge from the honourable senator, with due respect, that things will be held up if I do not maintain decorum in this chamber. That is the responsibility of the Chairman, who is doing an excellent job, might I say.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the staff question which the honourable senator has raised, I advised her a moment ago that I was not able to specify the particular figures but I thought that the staff cuts were minor. Let me now correct that advice because I have in front of me a table which is in the Hansard of Estimates Committee F, page F70. This is the hearing on 13 October and the table is one submitted by the Department of Community Services and Health and is headed `Staffing by Function'. In the function column against No. 5, Therapeutics, the 1987-88 usage's figure, that is, the staff deployed by the department under that heading, was 325.7. I feel sorry for the 0.7 of a person! The estimated target for 1988-89 is in fact an increase, it is not a decrease, and I correct that general comment that I made earlier. It is 328 staff, and that is also true for 1989-90. The estimate for 1989-90 is also 328 staff.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the Minister point that out? Under `Therapeutics' I have 319 and 317.

—I am looking at page F70 of Senate Hansard for 13 October 1988. At the bottom of that page there is a table that goes right across the two columns. On the left-hand column there is a heading `Function'. If the honourable senator travels down to No. 5 she will be able to see it.
—Could the Minister turn to page F72 and have a look under the heading `Therapeutics'? Could the Minister tell me whether there is an intention of staff cuts?

—I am advised that the table I have directed the honourable senator to at page F70 is the table to consult. The table on page F72 refers to therapeutics. The numbers 319 and 317 refer to the allocation for the Australian Capital Territory. The honourable senator will see as well, below that list of functions, a division by States. There are people working under the therapeutics heading allocated to the States. That takes me to the number that I referred to on page F70.
—Can the Minister tell me whether a review of therapeutic clearance processes was undertaken in 1987?

—Is the honourable senator referring to the Public Service Commission report that was discussed by the Joint Standing Committee of Public Accounts referred to at the hearing of the Senate Estimates Committee?
—If it was a review, I probably am. I am asking: Was there a review of the therapeutic clearance process?
—To the extent that that document could be styled a review, the answer is yes.
—Can the Minister tell me what the result of that review was?

—My advice is that there were questions at the Senate Estimates Committee on this matter but this question was answered in some detail in the material supplied by the Department to the Committee subsequent to the Committee hearing. I have documentation being obtained for me now which, when I receive it, I will be able to table, and it will perhaps answer those questions for the honourable senator if her copy of the document has gone astray.
—Could the Minister tell me whether over the past year the therapeutics area was running at some 30 per cent below establishment?

—The question is accurately answered by reference to the generality rather than, in this case, the particular. If I were to give the honourable senator the particular answer it would be yes. But it is explained by reference to the general practice that the staff establishment levels are usually above what are the practical levels, and the Department reserves the right, of course, to recruit for diversity of particular staff for particular jobs. That does not always mean to say that the staff levels are at the cited establishment level. My understanding is that it is common for them to be below that level.
—I presume the Minister will be getting that information in a few minutes.
—I am sorry, which information is that?
—The information that you are waiting for. I am asking the Minister questions while he is waiting.
—So I might be clear on this point, the information that is being looked up is the answer to your previous question.
—The Minister answered that it was running at 30 per cent below establishment.
—I did not say 30 per cent. I said it was below establishment. I did not put a figure on it.
—My question was whether it was running at below 30 per cent, and the Minister said specifically yes, and then he went on. Maybe he wants to change that.

—I do not think this is a correction; I think Hansard will bear this out: what I said was that it is normal for the actual staffing levels to be below the establishment figure. I do not believe I confirmed a percentage. I was just indicating in general terms that that is not unusual practice. There may be a communications confusion between us.
—Would the Minister now establish whether it was 30 per cent below?
—As best as I can advise Senator Walters, it is approximately of that order of magnitude.

—We seem to be wasting time with me having to ask these questions. Can the Minister tell me whether the additional 2.3 staff that that area was given was based on that 30 per cent below or on the actual establishment figure?
—It is based on the actual approved staffing levels, which is not related to the establishment figure at all. Might I say that if there is some particular point to this question, rather than--
—I thought it was pretty clear.
—What I am trying to do is help the honourable senator.
—You are from the Government. You are here to help us.

—That is exactly right, I am glad that Senator Stone recognises that quality in us. That is the quality we have, and that is the reason why we occupy this treasury bench. Now is not the time for me to make a political speech; it is appropriate for me to answer the question of Senator Walters. Rather than conduct what is an inquisitorial dialogue across the chamber, if the honourable senator went to the general point that she wanted to make we could make all that information available. There is no inclination or intention on our behalf to withhold information that it is appropriate to disclose in this chamber. So rather than one or two questions leading to a particular point, if she gives me the general gist we will oblige.
—I am trying to be brief; maybe that is my problem. Perhaps I am not being clear enough. We have two minutes left before the adjournment. I am attempting to get some answers.
—We have got hours yet.

—If we keep having interjections we are going to slow things up. It is pretty obvious what I am getting at. I have asked whether in this particular area there was a cut. The Minister told me that there was a staff increase of 2.3 people. I asked whether that was based on the 30 per cent below establishment that that area was presently running at when the increase was made. That is what I am asking: were those 2.3 people an increase on the lower 30 per cent below establishment level and, therefore, not an increase at all?
—Let me first table the answers to the earlier questions.
—I want to hear what they are.

—I am doing this because I said I would, in answer to the second part of Senator Walters's question. As I tried to say earlier, the issue is that normally the staffing is less than the notated establishment figure. I have listened carefully to what Senator Walters has asked. It seems to me that we keep coming back to that same point and it is not possible for me to enlarge on it. I have said that in this particular case it is of the magnitude of about 30 per cent.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: THE CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman do now leave the Chair and report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have questions on two matters. My first set of questions concerns the administration of section 19 (5) of the Health Insurance Act and the Health Insurance Commission's interpretation of it. I would like to discuss briefly whether there is any discernible movement from the Government away from the rather rigid, narrow interpretation of health screening or, as it is otherwise referred to, ortho-molecular medicine. I understand that this is defined in a bulletin MB234 which currently prevails and which spells out the interpretation because this is fairly significant to appropriations and the dollars that are available to address new challenges in social medicine. The Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) is obviously aware of my interest in this from questions I have posed over a period of 15 months. It is apparent that with the thrust into preventative medicine, which is now being enunciated in medical schools and spelled out in medical policy, there is an inherent contradiction between the requirements in the community and the interpretation and specifications in legislation. I am simply citing the fact that quite divergent and contradictory positions are being adopted by the Government towards the needs of the profession and the community. This is affecting doctors dramatically; in other words, those doctors who are attempting to practise preventative medicine, which is defined in the documents I have referred to as ortho-molecular medicine, are being frustrated in those attempts and the patients whom they are servicing are being denied their entitlements under the promises of the Health Insurance Act. We are simply requesting the Government to address this contradiction. Has the Government addressed it in the appropriations?

SPEECH.PARA: I particularly draw the Minister's attention once again, but only briefly on this occasion, to the evidence of this contradiction that is apparent in my own community of the central coast and which is being substantiated by findings in the United States suggesting that we are on the forward edge of a major social medical problem which will simply be frustrated by this apparent contradiction of position.

I know that a number of very sincere and genuine medical practitioners have attempted to test this legal position. A number of patients have even been advised that they will have to test it in the High Court of Australia to get their Medicare claim substantiated. I will put a sharper edge on it by saying that of the 96 people whose blood samples have been tested in the United States-I have passed the findings from those tests to Senator Cook and to Minister Blewett in the last 48 hours; I think they were known to the Ministers from other sources anyway-not one has had a Medicare claim honoured. I simply suggest that it is unacceptable, and it should be unacceptable to the Government, that people who walk through the door of a bona fide medical practitioner's office in this country, and incur a medical cost-in some cases in the order of $700 or $800-should find themselves later being served with a summons. I have gone with them to seek legal advice at the Public Interest Advocacy Centre where they have been told to take their Medicare claims to the High Court of Australia. Yet the same 96 people are ill. The evidence of their blood samples is that there could be toxicity levels in their blood 20 times those which are found in the United States. Yet as a result of the present interpretation of that section of the Act, as it is being rigidly adhered to and not moved from as medical teaching and philosophy and social requirements would suggest, they are being told to go to the High Court of Australia to have their Medicare claims honoured.

I have put this matter to the Minister previously in questions. I also put it to him exactly a year ago in the last appropriations debate. I raised precisely the same issue. I know the history of this philosophical issue; it has been spelt out to me that it has evolved over a period of six years. I am simply saying that the time has arrived for a shift to occur. Medical skills are telling the Government that; genuine practitioners are trying to put into effect the philosophy that is inherent in the Government's own policies. I urge the Minister to advise the bureaucrats who are administering and interpreting the legislation on his behalf that the time has come to shift and to honour the Medicare claims of these 96 people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take that as a general question from Senator McLean. Two questions on this subject have been raised-one by him and one by Senator Haines-in Question Time over the last nine months. I cannot actually recall when Senator McLean raised this matter, but I recall that in my formal answer, given after the question was originally raised on notice, I put to him that, if there was particular evidence that the Department of Community Services and Health should consider when dealing with this matter, he should bring this forward. I have not been advised that this has been done. I know that Senator McLean has referred to tests in the United States and so on, but I do not have a reference for that.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps the best way to deal with this is for me to extend to Senator McLean an invitation to meet officials from the Department and go through the particular evidence that he has to see whether we disagree on the basis of an interpretation which can be resolved by discussion, or whether we disagree over a major matter of principle. It could be that we disagree over a matter of principle in terms of what is entitled to be claimed on the Medicare schedule and whether the types of services being rendered are services of a paramedical nature which are not claimable under that schedule. I do not want to judge this matter, however, and I extend to Senator McLean the invitation to meet departmental officials, go through the particular cases and clean them up. That may be a much more expeditious way of dealing with the matter. I certainly do not think that bald advice to people to go to the High Court is a satisfactory way of dealing with it. The course I have suggested might prove to be the avenue to settle this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Invariably, if people approach, ask and seek they get the bureaucratic answer that the Health Insurance Act does not allow this. We are saying that the Act should be changed, that the interpretation of it should be changed. The time has come, professionally, in terms of government policy and in terms of honouring claims to change the Act or its interpretation. I have sent this evidence to the offices of the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) and the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) in the last 48 hours. Dr Donahue, who is the doctor in question, has virtually had his practice closed down. Some of the pathologists he used have had their practices closed down. Some have gone bankrupt because for the last two years they have been pursuing the need for shift. There is a need for shift away, but as soon as they ask the question again they are given the same answers.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Minister for Resources to read the Hansard report of the last appropriations debate when I addressed precisely the same questions and was told that the Minister would take the questions on notice. She did, she eventually responded and I received the classic answer-namely, that it is interpreted as health screening and that there has been no shift from the position of ortho-molecular medicine. I am saying that the time has come to shift. The time has come to see that pathology is at the centre of social medicine. Patients of doctors who were trying to apply the new medicine which they had been taught in progressive medical schools-and I refer to my son who is a graduate of a progressive medical school at Newcastle-are being told not to go to those people because their claims will not be honoured. They are told that if they contest it, they will have to go to the High Court.

The Minister tells me to give him the evidence. I have already given it to him. He also asks me to sit and talk with him. I have tried to do that as a senator by asking questions on notice, questions without notice, by making representations to the Minister for Community Services and Health, by standing in this chamber a year ago and entering into an appropriations debate on the issue. I have stood up on every possible occasion and said, `The time has come to change'. Yet the Minister tells me yet again to enter into further discussion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am now advised that within the last 48 hours Senator McLean provided information to my office. The honourable senator's question was several months ago, when we invited him to provide the information. I do not think it is reasonable now for the honourable senator to come into the chamber and say, `You have had it in the last two days, and why have I not had an answer?'. This is a matter requiring more detail and a more complicated response to the types of material Senator McLean has produced than is reasonable to expect in these circumstances. However, I am grateful for the honourable senator's reply to my answer and to my invitation. It has now identified clearly that the purpose of Senator McLean's question is to change the Act. Perhaps we would have saved ourselves a lot of time had the point been made specifically from the outset that it was desired to change the very Act under which Medicare operates. The Government needs to keep a clear check on what types of medical procedures are to be met under the Medicare table. Doctors may go to what Senator McLean has called a progressive medical school to practise medicine that is not recognised under the Medicare table--
—There are thousands of doctors going there.

—I am not sure that there are thousands, but I accept the number put forward in the honourable senator's interjection. It is another matter to get these procedures accepted on the Medicare table. In terms of the Medicare table, services provided by medical practitioners, consultations by optometrists and certain dental procedures are accepted on the Medicare table. The Government has said that it has no intention of extending fee for service Medicare benefits to the services of any other health practitioners. The question whether Medicare arrangements should be expanded to provide benefits for certain paramedical and alternative medicine services was addressed in June 1986 in the second report of the Medicare Benefits Review Committee, the Layton Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: That Committee was established by the Government specifically to consider, amongst other things, whether benefits should be provided for certain of the types of services to which the honourable senator has referred. The Committee was not prepared to recommend an extension of the Medicare arrangements to cover, on a fee for service basis, the service of any modality of health occupation which is not already included in the arrangements. A major factor in that Committee's decision at the time was its finding that no modality could control service levels. Although the Layton Committee considered that certain paramedical services should attract additional public funding on other than a fee for service basis, these did not include the services of naturopaths. Natural therapy was not proposed for public funding because the Layton Committee was not satisfied that it was an effective modality, nor that it had established standards of training and practice. That is the finding of the Layton Committee. I am sure that that finding is known to the honourable senator and that this is not the first time the explanation I have given him has been visited on him.

However, I renew the offer. If the honourable senator wants to change the Act, the definition and the way in which these things are designed as being acceptable medical services for the purposes of the Medicare table, that is a matter of substance. It is not a matter of the administration of the Act; thus it is not a matter that goes to the proper regulation and control of the Department and whether applications for Medicare payments are being properly met. It goes to the very basis of what constitutes an entitlement and what does not. I suggest that that is a matter of policy. I should widen my invitation and take the name in vain of the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, whom I represent in this chamber, and suggest that he and I would both be prepared to meet with the honourable senator to discuss whether it is appropriate to change the Act, as he has put it. But one would have to see that invitation, as I freely give, it, against the background and in the context of how we have dealt with these things in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make several points before I move on briefly to my second area of interest in relation to these appropriations. I attempted one year ago to make it very clear that the intention was to change the Act and that the time had arrived to accommodate a shift in philosophy, practice and policy. I made that perfectly clear at the beginning of my entry into this debate 15 months ago. I think it is important to distinguish between two sets of questions that I have asked over those 15 months. The first set of questions related to a series of doctors in practice and the frustrations that they were experiencing. Those doctors had been visited by officers of the Health Insurance Commission; the profiles of their practices had been investigated; their records had been removed from their offices; and the circumstances and the manner in which they were administering and practising their medicine had been thoroughly investigated. There has been no lack of evidence there. My recent questions have related quite specifically to a study being undertaken of the toxicity in the blood taken from people in eastern seaboard communities. So two sets of questions have been pursued over the last 15 months by me and those who have supported me.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank the Minister for the offer of discussions with him and Minister Blewett. I would like to take that up. I would like now to move on to a second area of concern which is entirely different.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I do not want to intervene but, since we are changing gear and moving to the next set of questions, Senator Tate has some documents that he wishes to table. This might be the correct juncture at which to deal with that so we can go on with the rest of the estimates for Estimates Committee F.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in the evening the Senate passed a resolution to the effect that certain documents should be tabled. I wish to table certain of those documents at this moment. I will be tabling the answer given by Mr Hand in the other place on 8 November 1988 in which he made it clear that he had met with representatives of the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation and had discussed funding arrangements for the future and said that he was yet to make a decision. The documents I will table will make it clear that that is indeed still the case. The documents are as follows: a letter dated 15 February 1988 from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) to Mr Shane Houston, the National Coordinator of the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation; a document requested in the Senate resolution, being a note for file of 1 September 1988, signed by Mr D. MacDonald, Acting Assistant Secretary, Community Development; a minute of the senior officers' meeting held on 5 September 1988 entitled a Record of Proceedings; a document being a ministerial submission with several dates on it, but perhaps the end of August would be the best way to put it.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, this matter is not associated with the amounts that we are now considering for the Department of Community Services and Health. Is it in order for the Minister to be--
—Yes, it is in order, Senator Harradine. I gave Senator Tate the call after an explanation by Senator Cook. It relates to a motion passed in the Committee about an hour ago. He is in order.
—I understand.

—I am simply trying to respond at the earliest opportunity. The remainder of the tabled documents are as follows: a document being a ministerial submission dated the end of August with a note attached dated 15 September; a note from Mr MacDonald dated 22 September; a note from Mr MacDonald dated 13 October; a note from-I cannot read the name but I believe it is Ms Humes-dated 18 October; an internal minute or note for file; and a typewritten note dated 1 December 1988, being today, recalling a conversation and discussion which took place on 8 November and signed by the officers who were present at that meeting with the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: I therefore table those documents which relate to the decision making, deliberation and consideration of funding for the National Aboriginal Islander Health Organisation. When those documents are perused it will become abundantly clear that the minutes of the senior officers' meeting were not correct in so far as they indicated that the Minister had approved funding for the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation. Indeed, he has still to make that decision. That becomes clear as the documents are read. The Minister is still considering the auditor's report which was asked to be tabled. Obviously that falls into a different category to these internal documents. I table these documents in accordance with the resolution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I rise on a procedural point. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to be brief although I think that I am once again raising a very substantive question. I have been approached by a number of nursing homes which have raised with me what I am told is called the care aggregate module (CAM) which is the formula under which it is determined how much money nursing homes will now get and what they can deliver to the community. I am advised that CAM is dependent upon what is called the resident classification formula and that this has changed. This change in the formula means that the application of the care aggregate module has, to put it bluntly, disseminated the finances of nursing homes and that they are having to readjust their services dramatically.

SPEECH.PARA: The Scone District Nursing Home, which I visited fairly recently, is having to close down the only district day care centre within the northern Hunter region. I am told by Peninsula Homes for the Aged Ltd in the Woy Woy-Umina peninsula area that it is having to revise the funding of its service dramatically. I am told that it is typical of what is happening to the financing of nursing homes across the country. I have received fairly strong representations, long explanations and cogent arguments from the staff of the Scone District Nursing Home. They suggest that we plead with the Department to analyse the effect of the revision to the resident classification formula as it is being administered through the care aggregate module and the impact that it is having on the funds that are available to those attempting to service nursing homes needs.

To put a political edge on it, the Government has become sensitive to the dimensions of grey power. It has been suggested to me that those who came out in their thousands from places such as the Sydney Town Hall about six weeks ago and demonstrated the extraordinary potential impact of grey power were the healthy aged. The people I am referring to are the frail aged, the ones who can barely move in bed.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a superficial argument.

—It is not a superficial argument at all; it is a very potent and humane argument. The third component, if you like, of grey power comprises people such as the veterans whose point of view I put in this chamber yesterday. I suggest that the formulas being applied by the Government in relation to the aged in our community, whether they be frail and in bed, whether they be healthy and on their feet and able to attend public meetings at the Sydney Town Hall or whether they be veterans of the Returned Services League, are in fact pretty crude these days, and they are being interpreted that way. I put a political edge on the argument which, in terms of the submissions from nursing homes that I have in front of me, is very real; they are having grave difficulty in sustaining the services that they are delivering to communities across the country.

—Senator McLean is completely right. He is talking about the resident classification instrument that is being used by the Government today to reduce the number of people who qualify for the top health benefits when they are long term sick in nursing homes. It goes so far as to make people, who have had bilateral strokes and are blind, ineligible for the top rate of nursing home cover in nursing homes. In fact, it is such a severe restriction on the number of people who qualify for top rebate care in nursing homes that it will cause many nursing homes and hostels in Australia to restrict their services-I do not whether to say that they will go broke-until such time as the Government comes to its senses and rectifies that dreadful and restrictive anomaly in Medicare. The resident classification instrument is the problem: it is too severe.
—Can the Minister give me the answers that he was looking for?
—I tabled them. I do not know what has happened to them since then.
—I know that the Minister tabled them, but I do not want them tabled. I want to know what they are.
—Do you want me to hand them to you or read them into Hansard?
—What I asked for was the result of the review. If it is a lengthy answer, perhaps the Minister can tell me what it was. I just want to know what the substance of the result was.

—I have the full documentation here. It answers comprehensively and completely all the points that Senator Walters may wish to raise. I put it down-it was regarded as tabled-on the Clerk's desk. I resubmit it to Senator Walters.

—I will have to look at it later. Can the Minister tell me whether industry made a complaint about the backlog and, as a result of those complaints, were two science positions created to undertake fast track clearance of minor pharmaceutical formulation changes? Was that a suggestion of the Department?
—The honourable senator asked whether industry complained about the backlog.
—Yes, of the clearance of minor pharmaceutical formulation changes.

—I was just articulating the first part of the honourable senator's question. Might I say, by way of preface before I come to an answer, that there was a long session on all of these things in the Estimates Committee. These questions are not questions that have sprung up since the Estimates Committee met. They were questions able to be pursued in the Estimates Committee. At the conclusion of the hearing of that Committee, there were expressions from the Committee that the Department had conducted itself as openly, as fully and as frankly as it could possibly be expected to do. I mention for the record that there is no question that these issues could not have been pursued in the Estimates Committee. Given that the opportunity was extended for them to be pursued there, it is in my view inappropriate now to delay the proceedings in the Committee of the Whole on matters that properly ought to have been proceeded with elsewhere.
—It will be a very long night.

—In that case we might as well dispense with the process of having Estimates committees and deal with it all in the Committee of the Whole. The only purpose of having Estimates committees is to enable these things to be dealt with exhaustively in the Estimates committees. Might I say that that view was expressed-it is a matter of record as it is in the Hansard-at the end of the Estimates Committee hearing. Senator Walters asked whether industry complained. The industry is constantly complaining about how things are administered and carried out in the Department. Doubtless it made a complaint on that score as well.
—I inform the Minister that honourable senators do have a right to ask these questions, even if they have missed them in the Estimates committees.

—The Minister has not answered the questions. I asked whether, as a result of industry complaints, two science positions were created to undertake fast track clearance of minor pharmaceutical formulation changes.
—I will put that question on notice and get back to the honourable senator in due course.

—I want the Department to answer that now. It must know the answer to that. It appears that the officers who should be here are not here. I am sure that the officers present would know the answer to that question. If the Minister refuses to answer it, we will have a very long night.

—If it comes to making expressions of intimidation, Senator Walters can be my guest. I have never fallen for that ploy in the past and I do not intend to do so now. If Senator Walters says that it will be a long night, it will be a long night. It will take as long as it needs to take. That will not worry me one little bit. That will be her choice, not mine. Let me consult with the officers to see whether I am in a position to answer that question. Otherwise, it will go on notice. We do not have specifics with us to answer the question; that is one of the reasons why it needs to go on notice. But given the views that Senator Walters has expressed, the Department has indicated to me just now that the advisers will send someone to ring the officer who may know the answer to that question, and I hope we can get an answer to it.
—Why could you not have said that before?

—I did not say it before because I object to being intimidated by honourable senators rising and threatening to keep me here all night. If honourable senators want to threaten me they can be my guest, but it never works.

—I return to the point that Senator Sheil and I were developing a few moments ago; that is, the impact of the resident classification instrument upon the flow of funds to those who are rendering nursing care in Australian communities. They argue that the instrument is inappropriate and illogical. Let me cite one specific example: the case of elderly, frail, demented people who are bedridden. They receive a high classification and therefore attract dollars to the nursing home. Those who are mobile and therefore substantially disrupt the service that can be rendered to others within the nursing home attract, under this instrument, a low level of funding. Those administering the hospitals and nursing homes argue that it is an irrational formula. That is only one area in which they cite its irrationality. They say the end effect of this-fewer dollars-will be to cut back on staff and to cut back on services, not to reduce the number of people in the nursing home. Eventually this will substantially negate the very process that they so vitally represent in the community. The long and short of it is that I ask the Minister to guide the Department towards a review of the resident classification instrument as it is being administered through the care aggregate module and to take into account the impact it is having on the level of funding.

—That is the second time I have heard that main point being put by Senator McLean. I intended to acknowledge it but intervening questions prevented my doing so. Let me now acknowledge the point that Senator McLean made and, I think, the point that Senator Sheil has made as well. The Department has estimated that with a change away from a submissions-based assessment to an assessment based on the needs of the residents, the increase would have been about 0.9 of an hour per patient on average. Therefore, claims that some or all are suffering great hardship do not seem to us to be true. The Department advises me that it is monitoring the situation. Senator McLean has asked us to look harder and closer. That is a fair request. We will certainly do that. In conformity with my earlier openness, if Senator McLean wants to discuss that matter in great detail with us we will be happy to oblige.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —That may be Senator McLean's request but it is certainly not my request. For nearly two months I have been involved with nursing homes and hostels to a considerable degree, discussing this classification of patients which is reducing the income of nursing homes and hostels. They will be in dire straits and will have to reduce the amount of nursing to the patients. This is the problem. It is all very well for the Minister to say that the Department will monitor the problem that the Government has caused. The problem is real, it is on the ground, and it affects people in nursing homes and hostels now. It is inappropriate for the Minister to say that he will look at the problem. The problem exists out in the field now and people are suffering.

SPEECH.PARA: It is nursing care that is required; not more money for the nurses or doctors or staff looking after these people. The Government has made these people dependent-and I do not blame just this Government. Over many years governments have made these people uninsurable We have been complaining in the Senate for some time about the reduction in pharmaceutical benefits, pathology benefits and nursing home benefits. It is part of the whole attack on the health system, but this time the Government is attacking the old, the disabled and the people who need care and are incapable of looking after themselves. Those people cannot earn any more money and are dependent on the Government, and the Government has cut down by a severe classification of what it will pay for in these institutions. It is no good monitoring the situation. The problem is there now and I would like the Minister to say something about solving that problem. These people are in extreme difficulties right now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think most of Senator Sheil's speech was political.
—No, it was not. It was real.

—At least it was a series of assertions and it concluded by asking me to reply immediately about what we are doing. I will have to refer to my reply to Senator McLean. We are looking at the situation from the point of view of monitoring it. If Senator Sheil has any evidence that would help us monitor it more effectively, he should bring it forward.

SPEECH.PARA: The view of the Department, which is in touch with what is happening in this field, is that most people ought to be better off. There might be at the margin some who will be immediately affected but this is a substantial change which moves away from the people who can best make a submission to the needs of the patient, and that is an emphasis that we regard as vital and fundamental.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to hear the Minister say that I am making a political speech on this matter and that he is looking after the needs of the patients. That is far from the facts. I have been out with the patients and I know that they are extremely disadvantaged at present by the change that the Government has made. I do not know what to say to the Minister now. He is obviously not inclined to listen to a real plea from people who are suffering because of this Government's action. Apparently, the Government intends to refuse to deal with the problem which exists now. It is real and it is out there in the community.

—I do not accept that we are refusing to answer the question in the terms in which Senator Sheil put it. I have said that we, through the Department, are in touch with what is happening in the field, that we are keeping a weather eye cocked to those developments, and that we will make whatever adjustments are found to be appropriate. We believe the emphasis away from submission based to needs based is correct. However, if there is found to be an injustice, we will no doubt deal with it. I do not accept the allegation that the Government in this respect is not properly addressing the needs of people.

—I have three issues that I would like to raise briefly. One is that, when the arrangements were made for nursing home funding and to introduce the five categories, I referred in my speech-I do not believe I have had any answer to the issue I raised-to the document which outlined the research into the development of those categories which suggested the percentage of residents who would fall into categories 1 to 5. In that document or in the explanatory memorandum there was a statement that there would be an attempt to reduce the number of patients in category 5 by attempting to ensure that those residents went into hostels. I said in my speech that if that happened the nature of the population in nursing homes would shift and across the nation we would have fewer patients in category 5 than we have now. I think there are about 10 per cent of patients now in category 5. The Department might be able to remind me of the figure. As we are moving towards a policy of decreasing the number of patients in category 5, will the Government increase the number of categories 1, 2, 3 and 4 patients that it will fund and reduce the number of category 5 patients?

—I have before me a copy of the November 1988 edition of Residential Care News. Senator Patterson was right when she said that 10 per cent of patients were in category 5. On page 4 of the November edition of Residential Care News there is a table which shows that Australia-wide the percentage of patients in category 5 is 10.4 per cent. The Government anticipated that the figure would be about 20 per cent. If one looks at the State by State breakdown of the figures one sees that the population of a category depends on what State the patients come from. The percentage of Western Australian and New South Wales patients in this category is quite a bit higher, two or three percentage points higher, than the percentage of patients from other States in this category. But in Queensland and South Australia the percentage is much lower. The answer to the honourable senator's question as to whether the Government is prepared to adjust the percentage of patients in categories 1 and 2 is yes.

—Obviously the Minister will be aware of the concern that rural Victoria has shown about patients in Bush Nursing hospitals. The issue will be debated, I guess, in a Bill that is coming up. Is the Department considering unusual cases, especially cases in rural areas where people do not have access to approved nursing homes, in regard to what sorts of measures can be put in place to address some of these issues?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —To step back from the particular question, answer it with a generality and come to the honourable senator's point, the threat by the Victorian health funds to cease paying benefits for nursing home-type patients in Bush Nursing hospitals is, in our view, and, I think, in anyone's view unacceptable action. Health funds have a moral and legal obligation to pay benefits to the patients involved. In many cases patients have contributed to their health funds for many years in the belief over the last decade that benefits would be payable in these circumstances. Since 1979 it has been the practice for nursing home-type patients to be accommodated in both public and private hospitals and for health funds to pay benefits at the lower, nursing home-type patient rate for them.

SPEECH.PARA: The health funds recently sought to exploit what they believed to be a loophole in the 1979 legislation allowing them to abrogate a responsibility which they had accepted for almost a decade. In order to reinforce the obligation of the health funds, the Government introduced legislation on 10 November this year to clarify that requirement and confirm the 1979 arrangements. In the longer term the Government is prepared to work with the funds and the State governments on particular problems involving aged and long stay patients. Considerable advances have already been made in this area under this Government. Earlier this week senior officials of the Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health had preliminary discussions with Victorian officials and visited a range of service facilities in rural Victoria to examine the cost and feasibility of various approaches to providing good care for frail aged people in small population centres.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his answer because this particular problem occurs in Victoria with those sorts of hospitals. The other question I would like to ask the Minister is one I have asked the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) but as yet have not had an answer. I asked that question not all that long ago. With the resident classification it has been pointed out to me that there have been some genuine errors where, for example, one proprietor filled in a classification medical record incorrectly. The nursing home receives $8.32 per day less because a genuine error was made as the director of nursing had the flu. Because of the number of appeals that are being made genuine ones are being missed out. I know that the Department is trying to address this problem. In the interim, people who have made genuine errors are being penalised because of some vexatious appellants. Could the Minister advise me as to what could be done to tease out the genuine appellants from those who are making appeals which are not warranted?

—Officers from the Department cannot advise me at present in terms of Senator Patterson's general question. As I understand her question, it is that there are frivolous appeals and genuine appeals and how do we sort the wheat from the chaff and expeditiously deal with the genuine ones and reply promptly to disallow the frivolous ones. In any large system such as this, that is a constant problem. I noted in the beginning of her question that she indicated that she had asked it directly of the Minister, Dr Blewett. I am not able to be advised here now as to what the answer to the question is. But I take the raising of it by Senator Patterson in this procedure as being an indication that we should hotfoot it back to the Department and give the honourable senator an answer pronto, which we will do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter at this late stage which would not have needed to be raised had I obtained an answer from the Department of Community Services and Health prior to this. I have not had an answer from the Department. A number of senators spent hours on the Estimates Committee. I asked a question in relation to Australia giving a special grant to the specific World Health Organisation program called the special program of research development, research training and human reproduction. In 1985 this special program decided that its priority research area would be the development of the abortion drug RU486 and the development of an abortifacient anti-HCG vaccine.

SPEECH.PARA: For the benefit of the Committee, it is important to note that the drug RU486 functions by blocking the foetus's use of a vital nutritive hormone, progesterone. Without this the unborn human being starves to death and drops off the uterus wall. Bleeding and severe cramps then take place and in most cases the woman has an abortion. I wish to ask a question in respect of that program which relates to the drug RU486 and the abortifacient anti-HCG vaccine. I shall quote from page F123 of the Estimates Committee F transcript:

If Australia gives a specific grant to this specific WHO program and has agreed to trial it in Australia, and is a member of the Policy and Coordinating Advisory Committee of the program, surely it is relevant for one to ask what policy was expressed by the representative of Australia, and whether that policy reflected the view of the Department.

I think the Committee would be interested in the response. The Department slightly changed my question, nominating RU486 after the word `it'. `It' referred to the program and the program has two elements: one is the development of RU486 and the other is the development of the anti-HCG vaccine. The answer was:

Australia is a member of the Policy Coordinating Advisory Committee of the program. The last meeting of this Committee, now termed the PCC, was held in Geneva from 4 to 6 July 1988 and was attended by representatives from the Permanent Mission of Australia to the UN office in General and from ADAB Canberra. The representatives did not put a view to the meeting.

That was not my question. That is not an answer to my question. In fact, I regard that as an insult. If the officers of the Department had read my question, as they should have-they were present at the Estimates Committee hearing-they would have known that I was referring to the decision of the Committee, of which Australia is a member, to adopt this program as a priority. I want an answer to that question. I now ask that question again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters would like to ask a couple of questions, if possible. She had to leave for a moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that Senator Walters does want to ask a couple of questions. I might even have an answer for one of the earlier questions she asked. She may have more as a consequence.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me turn to Senator Harradine's question. First, I thank him for the courtesy of indicating to me today that he would pursue this matter in the Committee of the Whole this evening. I thank him also for drawing my attention to page F123 of the Senate Estimates Committee Hansard of 20 October, on which the honourable senator asked this question and remarked on what he perceived to be the inadequacy of the answer by the Department.

The World Health Organisation's research training in human reproduction program, commonly known as the HRP, or the human reproduction program, is a program which supports, among a number of other initiatives-this is not the only initiative, there is a whole range of initiatives-the research into RU486. Australia supports the program. It is to be seen as supporting the whole program in a holistic way, rather than supporting particular issues within it. We in Australia recognise that this drug had other properties than the the ones the honourable senator had described. For example, it is a drug that properly can be used where the foetus has died in the womb so as to expel that foetus so that the health of the mother is maintained. From an Australian point of view, that is a proper medical use of the drug. While it could-as the honourable senator has described and as I am informed-have other uses, we see it as fulfilling that particular use.

With respect to what the Australian representative to the Policy Coordinating Advisory Committee said on behalf of Australia when this matter was before the Committee, I am advised that Australia's representative on that Committee has since left our employ and joined the World Health Organisation. I am not able to give the honourable member the verbatim reply for two reasons. The first reason is that I understand that the proceedings of the Committee are not necessarily recorded. It is not the sort of proceeding for which one is able to obtain the record and look matters up. It is more a discussion type format. Although interpretation is involved it does not involve verbatim transcripts or electronic recordings. The second reason is that we have some difficulty in reaching the individual concerned to find out exactly what he may have said. To answer Senator Harradine's question in precise terms, I think that we would need to have done that. I undertake that we will attempt to do that. Having said both those things, I should say that the attitude of the Government is well known. We would expect that a representative of the Australian Government, serving on a body such as that, would represent our views appropriately.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the World Health Organisation (WHO) Policy and Co-ordinating Advisory Committee decided that the human reproduction program (HRP) is a priority? The Minister has said to me that there are a number of elements in the program. However, the HRP program is the priority. That is the word of WHO. Does the Minister not understand that WHO HRP has stated that the development of RU486 and the anti-HCG is the priority? Does the Minister not understand that that is the priority?

—I am advised that probably it is the priority of the Policy and Co-ordinating Advisory Committee. I cannot confirm exactly whether it is the first and overwhelming priority, but I understand it is a high priority.

—Given the fact that in 1985 the special program decided that its research priority would be in this area-I asked this question back on 20 October 1988-what was the policy expressed by Australia's representative on that Committee, on behalf of Australia? Did he support the development of RU486 and the anti-HCG? If he did, did he do so on behalf of the Government? The Minister has had since 20 October to ask that question of that person. The Minister has not responded. It is a very serious matter. Australia is actually funding the program.
—In part.

—It is funding it. The money is going to the program. An amount of $225,000 is possibly going to this particular program, bringing the total amount that Australia has paid to $1.9m. That is not an insignificant sum. Therefore, it is important that the Minister answer the question so that we know whether the Government is supporting the program. Is the Government supporting the development of the abortion drug RU486 and the anti-HCG vaccine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

The understanding of procedures that I want to clarify now relating to these ethical considerations is first, the role and the function of the World Health Organisation (WHO) in making ethical considerations. The World Health Organisation, as an international body, consists of countries with all sorts of different religious, moral and cultural codes. Those countries are affiliated with WHO for the services it provides. It is thus not a body which, of itself, decides on a universal or world ethical code; it identifies particular developments in medicine. Component countries of WHO then decide what they may do ethically in terms of testing or evaluating those things.

In the morning, when Opposition senators think about what they have done to somebody for whom they have had a great deal of respect over the years, about the attack they have made on a man whose reputation is amongst the highest in the country, and about what they have done for their own immediate political gain, they will regret the action they have taken.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other hand, I think we can rely on the people who are going to decide this issue-the Australian Democrats. Senator McLean and Senator Coulter said that all they want to do is look at the evidence and see how they will make the decision. That is a proper approach and I hope they have been satisfied with the evidence that was given promptly and without equivocation by Senator Tate. We cannot expect to convert the very decent people on the other side who live under the name of the Opposition. I am sure that they are all convinced that they ought to vote against Senator Tate. That is not their collective view but each individual one has said that Senator Tate is a man who deserves to be censured, that this person with whom they have sat on committees over the years and with whom they have been very impressed has not spoken the truth-and that is the consequence of their voting against Senator Tate. They are saying that in the answer he has given he has twisted the truth. When the morning comes the Opposition will realise that that view of Senator Tate is not the attitude they should have taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good try.
—I hope it is a good try. I hope what has been said will influence the minds of the Democrats, who are the jury in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition Senators-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Members of the Opposition are the prosecutors with very flimsy evidence, or in fact no evidence at all. They have followed the usual process of raising allegations, asking questions and regarding those allegations and questions as evidence. Questions can be asked. They are not evidence. Allegations are not evidence. The evidence is all one way-that is, that the Minister, Senator Tate, has acted with the highest of honour and the highest of motives. Having answered the questions that the Democrats have so properly asked, this motion will be lost, as it ought to be lost. It has absolutely no merit at all, and the Opposition knows it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I have the privilege of closing the debate because we are in committee, but I do think it would be useful to get back to the actual charge which is brought in this amendment motion, rather than to deal with the quite different points dealt with by Senator Cooney with such skill. It is an old lawyer's technique that if you have a bad case, talk about another case. Senator Cooney showed great skills in setting up straw men which he then demolished. Let us get back to what this amendment says. What we are complaining about and what we seek to censure the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Tate, for doing is for tabling an incomplete document. That is a matter which has been clearly acknowledged by Senator Tate. He tabled an incomplete document, a document which was not in accord with the order of the Committee which had been made.

SPEECH.PARA: The one thing I am grateful to Senator Cooney for is that he reminded us of the skills of Senator Tate. I think it would be fair to say that were Senator Cooney on the front bench, with his more knock-about approach, one might be less inclined to be critical. Were other members of the back bench on the front bench and they made this error, one might be less inclined to be critical also. But as Senator Cooney has said, we are dealing with a man who has one of the highest reputations in the country. We are dealing with a man who was Dean of the Faculty of Law at the University of Tasmania. We are not dealing with some goat. We are dealing with a person of high legal competence. He has just told us that, in an excess of enthusiasm to serve the will of the Committee, he has brought a document into this place which is, on the face of it, incomplete. He has, at the very minimum, been grossly careless in attention to his duties.
1-2 December 1988 SENATE

1-2 December 1988 SENATE

The context in which this has occurred is a context in which the President of the Senate has said on two occasions that the Opposition had made out a prima facie case that in presenting evidence to the Senate Estimates Committee in this same portfolio area there is a case to be considered for the privilege of the Parliament having been breached. This is a situation where the Committee has made it absolutely clear that we regard access to accurate and clear information as an area of great difficulty and an area where the Government is clearly maladministering a department. The Minister has, in that context, behaved in a way which is inexcusably careless. That is not the standard which is expected of a Minister of the Crown.

Ministers of the Crown are judged by exacting standards. I can remember a very popular, well-regarded deputy leader of the Australian Labor Party who signed a letter that he did not read. He lost his job, not because anyone said that he was guilty of moral turpitude; he just did not live up to the standards that the Prime Minister of the day said were required of Ministers of the Crown. We have a skilled lawyer, a man of the highest reputation, who has brought documents into the Committee and has not bothered to check an error which was apparent on the face of the documents.

The Minister has come in and said, `I have now checked it. I table the document which contains all these paragraphs. Yes, they are there'. I heard Labor Party senators jeering at Senator Short when he said that the clear presumption one makes from these documents is that there are preceding paragraphs. He described the document quite precisely while the Government jeered from the Labor benches. The Minister came in and indicated that the document was precisely in the form that Senator Short had indicated in the debate that it would be. The fact is that the Minister did not bother to check, and he comes in and says, `But it does not matter'. In substance it does not matter because the Senate has not been misled. That is a matter of pure good fortune for this Minister. Those minutes could have contained any amount of material on any subject. This Minister carelessly ignored that possibility. Senator Tate cannot claim as a matter of virtue that the Senate was not misled. It is a lucky accident as far as Senator Tate is concerned. He simply took this document, which clearly had been doctored, and put it down before us. That is scarcely the act of a responsible Minister, a Minister of the skills that everybody keeps talking about Senator Tate having. If it was one of the dogs that were referred to in this debate-we had to withdraw that expression, as I recall-one might be less inclined to be critical.

The truth is that this Government's record of misleading the Parliament in this area is as bad as its record of misleading the Aboriginal community. When Senator Robert Ray was filibustering to give Senator Tate time to get the complete document and to get back here to mount his own defence, he said, `What is the relevance of these other matters to Aboriginal affairs?' The relevance is that I do not think there are any senators on the front bench-except for Senator Cook, and I remember some of our clashes over difficult issues-who profess an interest in Aboriginal affairs. I ask Labor senators on the back bench who have taken an interest in Aboriginal affairs whether any of them can honestly say that this Government has not behaved shamefully in terms of the promises it has broken to the Aboriginal people. Not one of them could claim that. I remind those who campaigned in the 1983 election of what their campaign literature said they should say to the Aboriginal people. They were to promise them national land rights, and the Australian Democrats guaranteed them the capacity to deliver on that promise. And they broke it because they knew it was not the thing to do and that the Australian people were not going to tolerate it. They backed off. They bought the votes and then refused to pay the price.

That is the Government's record in Aboriginal affairs. It is a record of perfidy. I believe that for a Minister who has gone through the heat and fire of the recent months in relation to Aboriginal affairs, and who has seen the reasons why we have sent matters to the Privileges Committee, not to exercise the highest standards of care in tabling documents in this place is pathetic. It is a pathetic indictment of this Minister that he did not take the trouble to run a lawyer's eye over that document. It took a second's perusal of that document to see. For the Minister to come in here and say, `I did not check that; I simply relied on the fact that this document was delivered to me' is pathetic. If that is the best defence that the Government can put up, I say that this motion of censure certainly should be carried.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 12 April 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did Anne Summers in the Australian Financial Review on 27 March 1987 (p. 12) refer to an offer by the President of Sikorsky, Mr Robert Zincone, to convene a meeting of the chief executive officers of major United States defence contractors so that Australia could brief these companies on Australia's balance-of-payments difficulties.
(2) Did a meeting with some 20 defence contractors take place at Australia's Washington Embassy in early April, 1987; and if so, on what date and time; if not, why not.
(3) Which American companies attended the meeting, what were the names of the company representatives and what were the names of the Australian personnel who met with them.
(4) What was the purpose of the meeting and what arguments and information were conveyed to these company representatives.

(5) Is the Government aware of whether Sikorsky, in fact, later turned one of its regular congressional breakfast meetings into a briefing session on Australia's trading problems; if so, what was the date of the meeting, who were the Congressmen and what effect did the briefing have.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes. The meeting was held at 4.14 on the afternoon of 21 April 1987.

(3) Boeing, Mr H.V. Geison; Todd Shipyards, Mr E.D. Foreman, Jnr; Rockwell, Mr R. Garcia; Lockheed, Mr W. C. Moller; General Dynamics, Mr K. Lauenstein; Sikorsky, Mr G. Rast; General Electric, Mr N. Labash; McDonnell-Douglas, Mr D. McDonald; FMC Corporation, Mr H. S. Russell; Hughes Aircraft, Mr E. D. Majors; Gould, Mr K. Wu; Litton, Mr W. Lukens; Honeywell, Mr J. Hager; Westinghouse, Mr R. Seidel; Northrop, Mr E. Brewster; Singer, Mr A. Watson; United Technologies, Mr J. Nelson. Some representatives also brought along additional personnel.

Australian personnel attending were: Mr A. Woods, Secretary, Department of Defence; Air Vice-Marshal Gration, Head of Australian Defence Staff; Mr G. S. R. Wood, Minister, Commercial; Mr J. McCarthy, Minister, Congressional Liaison.

(4) The main purpose was to outline difficulties with current and possibly future U.S. trade legislation. The main argument was that U.S. action on trade could have a long-term impact on Australia's capacity to purchase defence equipment from the United States.
(5) No. Sikorsky did, however, in writing to the Embassy refer to contacts it had made with a number of members of the Senate and House of Representatives.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 12 April 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister or his representatives met with any U.S. defence contractors since March 1983 in order to impress on these companies that Australia's capacity to purchase weapons from them is being compromised by the United States trading policies.

(2) If so, what was the date of each of these meetings, where were they held, what were the names of the defence contractors and company representatives, and if representatives of the Minister met the contractors, what were their names.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (2). Apart from the meetings with defence contractors on 27 March 1987, which was the subject of the honourable senator's Question on Notice No. 288 of 12 April, there is no record of other meetings with American defence contractors by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade or his representatives for the purpose of drawing attention to the effects of United States' trading policies on Australia's capacity to purchase weapons. At the Australia-United States Ministerial Talks in June 1987, however, the then Minister for Foreign Affairs made the point very clearly that United States actions have a bearing on our ability to carry out our security commitments and that to the extent that protectionism and agricultural subsidisation impose economic strains on Australia they impair Australia's ability to work effectively with its allies and friends. The Government has, in addition, made a particular effort to have these views registered on the United States Congress.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 18 April 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What speeches did Australian Ministers or Australian representatives in the United States (U.S.) make in the U.S. which raised the issue of the Export Enhancement Program (contained in the US Food Security Act 1985) and which were delivered prior to this Bill's enactment?
(2) Who delivered the speeches, and when and to whom were the speeches made?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The following speeches made in the United States raised the issue of the Export Enhancement Program prior to the enactment of the 1985 Food Security Act.
A speech on 2 October 1985 by the Australian Ambassador to the U.S.A., Mr Rawdon Dalrymple, on ``Trade: Is It Divisive or Civilising?'' to the World Affairs Council of Boston.
A speech on 10 December 1985 by Counsellor (Agriculture) Frances Cassidy to Friends of the Industry of Agriculture, Richmond, Virginia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 18 April 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What press statement did Government Ministers or Australian officials at the Washington Embassy issue to the American media on the Export Enhancement Program (which was contained in the United States Food Security Act 1985) prior to this Bill's enactment?
(2) Who made the statements, what did the statements contain and when were they released?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) & (2) Australia's concern about the EEP, particularly its use in Egypt and Yemen, was raised by the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, during his visit in October 1985 when he met Ambassador Yeutter, U.S. Trade Representative. This issue was discussed by Mr Hayden at his press briefing on 9 October 1985.

Australia's concerns about agricultural trade, including the EEP, are made known to the American media primarily through ``Australia News'', the Embassy's regular news sheet. ``Australia News'' reports on ministerial visits and provides details of Australian Government statements.
Our concerns about the EEP prior to the passing of the US Food Security Act were referred to in ``Australia News'' items reporting on the following:
the visit to the U.S. of the then Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) in May 1985

the joint statement by the then Ministers for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) and Trade (Mr Dawkins) released in June 1985, following a meeting between the Ministers and senior representatives of the Commission of the European Communities in Brussels.
the Prime Minister's statement on the EEP in Canberra on 17 June 1985
the Australia/US Ministerial talks in Canberra on 15 July 1985, led by the then Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) and U.S. Secretary of State (Mr Shultz).

In addition, Mr Kerin issued an international press release in June 1985, at the World Food Council Ministerial Meeting in Paris. The press release, which was available to the American media, contained details of US assurances to Australia about the EEP.
