QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Since 11 July 1987, how many Senior Executive Service (SES) officers have become unattached within the Minister's area of portfolio responsibility, including statutory authorities, and of these: (a) how many were placed in substantive positions at their own level; (b) how many were placed in substantive positions below their substantive level; (c) how many were offered early retirement packages; (d) what was the mean value of the packages; (e) what was the age structure of these officers.

(2) Since July 1987 how many administrative support other than scientific and technical officers became unattached, and of these: (a) how many were placed in substantive positions at their own level; (b) how many were placed in substantive positions below their substantive level; (c) how many were offered early retirement packages; (d) what was the mean value of the packages; (e) what was the age structure of these officers.
(3) What programs of retraining and redeployment are in place to usefully employ those permanent officers still on the unattached, supernumerary and redundancy list.
(4) What has been the net saving in SES and other positions in each portfolio/statutory authority since 11 July 1987.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Officers may become unattached while on maternity leave, while on leave without pay, including for periods of employment in other Commonwealth organisations not staffed under the Public Service Act, or while on long term training and development programs and as a result of organisational change and re-structuring. Since July 1987, 29 Senior Executive Service staff have become unattached as a result of organisational change and re-structuring, and the answers in parts (a) to (e) below relate to these staff.
(b) none

(d) $55,089 in addition to any entitlements for payments in lieu of recreation and long service leave. As they were deemed to have retired involuntarily, they also received superannuation entitlements in accordance with the provisions of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme.

Of the 7 SES officers who remain unattached, 1 is on leave without pay, 2 are on sick leave, 2 occupy positions at a higher level pending their permanent filling and 2 are engaged on special project work.

(a) and (b) As mentioned in answer to question 1 there is a number of circumstances where an officer might become unattached. Information on all of these unattachments over the period since July 87 was not collected however it is believed that all officers on being re-attached have been placed at their substantive level or promoted.
(d) $23,044, in addition to any entitlements for payments in lieu of recreation and long service leave and any superannuation entitlements.
(e) This information is not readily available, and I am not willing to devote the considerable resources required to provide an answer.

(3) Retraining and redeployment of staff who are excess to departmental requirements is administered in accordance with the APS Redeployment and Retirement (Redundancy) Award 1987 or the Guidelines on Redundancy in Australian Government Employment, and administrative instructions issued by the Public Service Commission and Department of Industrial Relations. These provisions provide for excess staff to be considered for vacancies at their substantive level prior to and in isolation from other applicants and on the basis of their ability to perform the duties of the position in question immediately or after a reasonable period of training. This generally takes the form of on the job training which continues until the officer is sufficiently skilled in the duties.
(4) There has been a net saving of 1034 positions, including 16 SES positions. These are a result of the abolition of positions or the transfer of functions to other organisations.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade: Staff

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 1 June 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Were 2 Senior Executive Service (SES) positions in the Peace, Arms Control and Disarmament Section of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade abolished in 1987.
(2) Was the key expert (Clerical Administrative, Class 11) in the Section transferred in 1988.
(3) Were the Branch Heads, 2 of 3 Section Heads and both Class 9s in the Section replaced by people who had no operational background in the field.
(4) Did this result in a six months time lag for the new officers to become proficient, with diminished institutional memory and critical mass of expertise taking longer to remedy.
(5) Did these changes mean a curtailed performance in the section with priority going to reconstruction of Branch expertise rather than operational task.

(6) If the changes in parts (1), (2), (3), (4) and (5), above, did take place, does the Minister admit that the answers given by Senator Evans to Senator Wood on 13 April 1988 (Hansard p. 1459) and Senator Vallentine on 19 April 1988 (Hansard p. 1689) were misleading.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. In November 1986 the present Peace, Arms Control and Disarmament Branch was formed by combining two other branches which had previously been headed by SFS Level 1 officers. The new branch was, and still is, headed by a SES Level 2 officer. In September 1987 the SES Level 3 position of Special Disarmament Adviser was transferred to another area of the Department as part of the process of restructuring which was required following the amalgamation of the former Departments of Trade anf Foreign Affairs and Promotion Australia and also to give greater priority to assisting Australia's external economic performance by devoting more resources to economic and trade issues.

(2) There are three ASO8 (formerly Clerical Administrative, Class 11) officers in Peace, Arms Control and Disarmament Branch. One of them, who was particularly experienced in disarmament work was transferred to another branch in August 1987 in order to gain broader Departmental experience and transferred back into the branch in June 1988. During this period he was replaced by an officer who also had experience in the area. Another vacancy caused by the resignation of an ASO8 officer in December 1987 was filled by an officer with little experience in disarmament work but substantial experience in many aspects of the Department's responsibilities, some of which was directly relevant to the work of the branch.

(3) The branch head position was filled in February 1988 by an officer who had no direct experience in the field of disarmament but had wide experience in other areas of the Department's responsibilities. The two section heads who left the branch in 1987 were the two ASO8 officers referred to in (2) above. A third section head was replaced in February 1988 by an officer with substantial experience in disarmament work. Both ASO7 (formerly Clerical Administrative, Class 9) officers have been replaced in the past 12 months; one by an officer who had just completed a UN Disarmament Fellowship and the other by an officer who had no direct experience in disarmament issues. However, another ASO7 officer who has considerable expertise in disarmament work commenced work in the branch in July 1988. It should be noted that since September 1986, the Division in which this Branch is located has been headed by a senior officer with extensive disarmament experience. Changes in staffing of this kind are common in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade which is responsible for staffing 88 diplomatic missions overseas as well as central office in Canberra.

(4) No. As indicated above several of those who left the Branch were replaced by offices with disarmament experience. In addition, the other officers in the branch had all been there for some time and provided the necessary institutional memory.

(6) No. As was stated in reply to those questions, there has been no downgrading of the Government's priorities or activities on disarmament. The changes described above have all been the result of either normal staff rotations which are an inevitable feature of any foreign service or reductions in resources which have been made to all areas of Government activity.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) To which countries have Barra Sonobuoys been sold.
(2) What quantity of Barra Sonobuoys has been sold to each country.
(3) In which maritime regions does each country deploy Barra Sonobuoys.
(4) What means does each country use to deploy Barra Sonobuoys.
(5) Which nationalities and classes of submarine does each country use Barra Sonobuoys to detect.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Barra Sonobuoys have been sold to the UK and are also used by the Royal Australian Air Force (R.A.A.F). Evaluation quantities have been provided to the United States Navy.
(2) (3) & (5) The answers to these questions involve classified information on stocks and operational issues which is not made publicly available either in this country or the UK.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has Australian Automatic Arms Pty Ltd based in Kempton, Tasmania, exported firearms between 1985 and the present; if so, what was the nature, quantity and destination of each shipment of the firearms exported.
(2) What steps were taken to ensure that these exports were not diverted to military use.
(3) What steps were taken to ensure that these exports were not diverted for sale on the arms black market.

(4) Has Australian Automatic Arms received any financial, technical or other assistance from the Department of Defence or any other Federal Government department; if so, what was the nature and cost of that assistance, in each case.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australian Automatic Arms Pty Ltd has been granted approvals to export firearms between 1985 and the present. The firearms included sporting rifles, semi-automatic sporting rifles and pistols. In 1986, 56 firearms were approved for export to the USA. In 1987, 104 firearms were approved for export to the USA and NZ. In 1988, 60 pistols were approved for export to the USA.
(2) None. The approvals given were for the sporting version only.

(3) None. The Government is unaware of any diversion. Control would be a matter for the importing country. The nature and volume of the sporting firearms sold by Australian Automatic Arms is not indicative of any significant potential problem.

(4) Australian Automatic Arms has not received any financial, technical or other assistance from the Department of Defence. I am advised that in 1985/86 the company received $3,624 under AUSTRADE'S Export Market Development Scheme. I am also advised that in 1986/87 it received a further $2,330 under that scheme and $17,870 under the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentive Scheme administered by the Department of Industry Technology and Commerce.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice on 2 November 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was an agreement made between the US and Australia in 1953 on the Establishment and Procedures for the Handling of Classified Information; if so, where may a copy of this agreement be found.
(2) Why is the 1953 Agreement not in the Australian Treaty Series.
(3) Who signed the Agreement for (a) Australia and (b) the US.
(4) Where and when was the agreement signed.
(5) Have any amendments been made to this agreement; if so, (a) on what date or dates and (b) what was the substantive effect in each case.
(6) Will the Minister make available a copy of this agreement and any amendments thereto; if not, why not.

(7) If an agreement between the US and Australia on the establishment of procedures for the handling of classified information has not been made, what procedures have been established for the handling of such information and (a) when were they established, (b) under what authority or agreement were they established, (c) have any variations been entered into since they were established and what are the details of the variations and (d) will the Minister make available a (i) current copy or (ii) description of the procedures established; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2)-(6) Not applicable.

(7) Although no agreement was made in 1953, the United States and Australia have executed instruments in other years dealing with the procedures for the handling of classified information. Those procedures are set out in the following documents:

(a) The Security Agreement between the United States and the Australian Department of Defence which came into effect on 29 August 1950. The agreement was amended in 1952 (to enable US classified information to be passed to the Department of Defence Production), in 1956 (to enable Australia to pass US classified information to private contractors for military purposes, subject to conditions) and in 1968 to reflect the transfer of munitions production from the Department of Defence Production to the Department of Supply and to enable transfer of US classified information to the Department of External Affairs and Australian Government authorities having a need to know). Arrangements under that Agreement are in place.
(b) The Arrangements between the United States and Australia known as the General Security of Information Agreement came into effect on 2 May 1962 and was amended in 1981.

I am not in a position to make available a copy of either the 1950 Security Agreement (as amended) and the arrangements under it or the 1962 General Security of Information Agreement (as amended) nor the procedures set out in them as both documents are classified.
